text:
SWEET CHEEZEUS. 

This was really good!! My guinea pig tasters said it was better than commercially sold ones! -beams- But I must admit, all the credit goes to the recipe! It is really easy to make and turned out so beautifully. 

The only changes I made were: (1) Using 2c digestive biscuits in place of graham crackers; (2) Cutting down 1/4c on sugar; (3) Handmixing after creaming the cream cheese and sugar; (4) Using a water bath. MY CHEESECAKE DID NOT CRACK! -beamsbeams- 

In future, I might take out the cheesecake after 2 hours, 5 hours browned the top too much :\ Also, for those who like a thick layer of biscuit under your cheesecake, the proportions of this one are woefully inadequate! 

Overall, a wonderful recipe, thank you Chantal (:

text:
Great texture and great flavor. I did change a few things but nothing major. I didn't have graham crackers to crush up but I did have a box of graham cracker crumbs. I used 1 cup crumbs, half a stick of butter and 1 T. white sugar for the crust and it was perfect. Instead of vanilla extract in the filling I used vanilla bean paste which tastes better and is prettier (you can see the bean flecks in the cheesecake). Mine did not crack and I took extra precautions to make sure that it didn't - I took care not to overbeat and I used a water bath. I took the advice of one reviewer and didn't check the cheesecake after 1 hr. of baking. I just baked for 1 hr. and then shut the oven off. It was baked perfectly. I did let it cool in the oven for about an hour, then I took it out to loosen the edges and put it back in to finish cooling for about another 2 hours. It did have a slightly eggy flavor and I think I will use a little lemon emulsion next time to take care of that. I will also maybe try dialing down the temp a little bit as the top got a little darker than I wanted. But overall it's an outstanding cheesecake and I will make it again.

Display Name:

city:

country:

text:
My grandkids say this is their favorite food!Only ingredient change I made is to crust. (Use 1 & 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs precrushed bought in baking aisle, 1/4 cup sugar, 1/3 cup melted butter).Mix well in bowl and press on bottom & 1/3 up sides of buttered 9 inch springform pan. (Another reviewer wrote that a 9 inch pan isn't large enough. I've made this 10 times, and it is the perfect size). For cheesecake, bring all ingredients to room temperature then beat as follows with electric mixer: 1st beat cream cheese until smooth, then beat in sour cream, beat in sugar mixed with 1/4 cup flour. Add milk and vanilla and beat again. (Don't overbeat, just beat everything until mixed).  THEN, hand STIR in eggs one at a time until well blended. You don't want too much air, because that causes cracks. Book I read by pastry chef uses different method to prevent cracks without the dreaded water bath: Preheat oven to 350. Bake for 20 minutes. Lower to 300 and bake another 20 minutes. Lower to 250 degrees and bake for 20 minutes. Lower to 225 and bake for 20 minutes.  DO NOT open the door at all during all of this. Now turn the oven off, keep door closed and let it sit around an hour until the oven is cool.Cracks occur when there's a sudden temperature change. This seems complicated, but usually helps to prevent cracks without using water bath.(I tried it the way it is written in recipe, and it did crack).Tastes best when made the day before. Great w/ choc. ganache from this site.

text:
Excellent cheesecake. I followed the advice of some other reviewers and made some minor modifications. 
For the crust I did 1 1/2 c crushed graham crackers, 1/4 cup butter, dash of sugar and almond meal. The almond meal added a nice touch. I also baked the crust for about 15 minutes before adding in the cheese cake.
The only modification I made for the cheesecake itself was I decreased the flour to 2 tbsp and baked at 325 for 1 hr 15 min (in a water bath) then turned the oven off and left the cheesecake in the oven cooling for about 1 hour. After that I put the cheesecake in the refrigerator and served a few hours later.
Great taste, great texture, no cracking! Excellent recipe!

text:
This is the first cheesecake I ever made. I was quite apprehensive, because I though cheesecakes were really hard to make. Plus, I didn't even have a hand mixer at the time, so I was mixing up four blocks of cream cheese with a fork, hah. Well, if you're worried that this will be too difficult, don't be. This cheesecake was SO simple, and so delicious. I gave it to a family friend for his birthday, and he's crazy about it! 

The only thing I did differently was the crust. I followed the recipe for the cheesecake exactly, but I followed the crust recipe of one of the reviewers. The crust got pretty soggy though, so the next time I make it, I think I'll stick the crust in the oven for about 15 minutes, then pour in the cream cheese mixture. Also, bake this in a water bath! I had no problems of sinking or cracking. Also, if you're planning on making these into cupcakes (which are also delicious, by the way), bake in a water bath for 30 minutes.

Thank you to the reviewer who suggested using a crock pot liner bag instead of aluminum foil (which can leak). city:

country:

text:
This scored a 4 on taste, a 4 on directions, and 5 for a good base of a recipe.  CRUST:  I had no clue if I should use full-size crackers or not.  I think 15 full-size ones were too big, so I would use 11 or 12 next time. I would also increase the butter from 2 Tbl to 6 and would add a little more sweetness by adding 2 Tbl sugar to it.  FILLING:  Perfect - - just make sure to not overmix it to prevent cracking later.  DIRECTION ALTERATIONS:  1)  Make sure to grease the side of the pan too.   2)  I wrapped the pan with two layers of aluminum foil to prevent the water bath from getting in.   3)  Use a roasting pan to put a 1" very hot water bath around the cheesecake pan.  I didn't have one, so I used a jellyroll pan with 1/4" water and it still worked out fine.   4)  I baked at 325 degrees for 1 hour, then turned off the oven and left it in there for another hour.  Then I opened the oven door for an hour.  Then I took it out and let it sit out for about 2-3 hours.  You want to gradually cool it over time to prevent cracking.  Put it in the refrigerator, covered, overnight or for at least 8 hours.  Take out 30 minutes before you want to serve and you can remove the pan.   5)  Dip a knife in warm water before slicing each piece.  (I ran mine under water each time to get rid of the cheesecake residue.)  It looks great and was delicious with a can of cherry pie filling on top.

text:
AMAZING!!!  I read through a ton of reviews for tips and tricks, and have made this twice now, and this is what I'd suggest:

Really truly make sure your cream cheese is softened.  If you don't let it soften enough, it will be lumpy and uneven. 
DO NOT OVERBEAT.  I used beaters for step 2 and part of three through the milk stage.  I then used a rubber spatula from the eggs on out.
Really grease the pan and crust prior to adding filling.  This will keep it from cracking.

Finally, the crust really takes away from the heavenly filling.  It did not have nearly enough butter.  I followed the recipe exactly the first go around and although everyone loved the cheesecake, they agreed that the crust was essentially nothing more than crushed grahams.  Use a traditional graham cracker crust recipe with more butter and some sugar, and bake it ahead of time.  You don't want to have the perfect filling but have the crust fall short.

Doing everything as suggested above will give you the most delicious cheesecake you will ever have in your entire life.  I made it for my boss's bday and people who swore up and down that they hated cheesecake became converts. WOW!!!

text:
My three-star rating includes the four-star taste and the two-star tips from reviewers I chose to listen to. With every recipe I read the reviews first to pick up tips from others who had more success adding ingredients/steps/etc. I decided to use the following tips all to hopefully stop the dreaded cracking of the cake: "lower the oven temp to 325," "grease around the sides of the pan to the top to help prevent the cake from adhering to the walls," "mix everything by hand until just incorporated," and "use a water bath or a pan full of water underneath the cake." Well, after taking these precautions, a half hour into the bake and I had a HUGE crack down the middle. Very disappointing. I liked the taste of this uber-traditional cheesecake, but I think next time I make this; I'll forego the safeguards from other reviewers and follow the recipe without worrying about cracks. A crack does not affect the taste, but the useless tips wasted my time and dirtied more dishes. By the way, I made a vanilla mango sauce for the top and it was fantastic.

text:
This cheesecake is amazing. I've made it several times, changing things here and there to make it better. Thanks to other reviewers for suggestions. I use a mixer for the cream cheese and sugar, after that mix by hand. Only use 2 tablespoons of flour for creamier cake. And finally, the WATER BATH! Very important for not cracking! The first time I did it I tried foil and water got in my springform pan. If you use a Turkey Roasting Bag, and just place the pan down in the bag, cutting off extra bag, no water gets in, and it's perfect!! Best Cheesecake Ever!

text:
This is a NEW YORK STYLE cheesecake. The addition of flour in the recipe (the full 1/4 cup) gives it the proper New York Style cheesecake texture. I've been using this exact recipe for years. I use room-temperature ingredients and I wrap foil around bottom and sides of pan (careful not to slide it too much when putting it in the oven). When I first turn the oven on, I put a large, rectangular metal cake pan filled half-way with water on the bottom shelf and leave it there. I bake on middle shelf, 325 degrees for 80 minutes - perfect temp and time for my gas oven. I used to sprinkle the flour in the batter but now I gradually mix it, along with the vanilla, into the sour cream first. Sometimes I remember to grease sides of pan, sometimes not. Rarely does the cheesecake crack, unless I over-beat it! Once the cheese and sugar are mixed, use the electric beater only in moderation. I let it sit in the cooling oven for 5 - 6 hours (I bake it at night and set the alarm clock to get up and put it in the fridge) and in the fridge all day. I consider the time in the oven "fermenting" time :)  It tastes good all by itself. (one can get carried away!) I've made this cheesecake for bridal/baby showers, wedding receptions, with cranberry/holly sprig decorations at christmas, with homemade fruit toppings, with apple and caramel, with lemon curd topping... It doesn't taste bland; it tastes like class. The crust does not overpower the taste of the cake. It's just wonderful!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-12-26T01:48:51.943
helpfulCount:

userID:
2512485
Display Name:
Carmen
isPro:
False
followersCount:

madeRecipesCount:
56
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just be sure that all of your cold ingredients are left at room temperature for a few hours. I only use an electric mixer to cream together the cream cheese and sugar. Everything else is folded together by hand. No need to worry about lumps, because they'll bake out. Don't forget to bake it in a water bath, so it'll stay at a consistent temperature. For the crust, I put six honey-flavored graham crackers (the whole crackers, not the sections of crackers) into a ziploc bag and smash them with a cup or a rolling pin. I then combine the crumbs with 1/4 cup unsalted butter, 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon, and 1/4 cup white sugar. I usually cut a circular piece of parchment paper for the bottom of my pan, so that I don't have to use additional fat. I bake the crust for 10 minutes before adding the mix, just so it can harden up a bit. The filling can be halfed and put into a regular 9-inch pie pan. The recipe can be easily altered to make different cheesecake flavors (I added melted some of the cream cheese and milk in a double broiler with 2 cups of white chocolate to add to the filling, covered the cake in raspberry topping, and used chocolate flavored graham crackers for the crust for Christmas). Of course, it's also just fine on its own with all of the bells and whistles.

text:
I made this recipe again on Sun for the holidays in a 9in pan & a 10in pan (just increased all ingredients by 25%). Both came out perfect, no cracks! Of course I'm giving this a 5 based on the tweaks I've made to the filling and the crust. For the crust: 1.5cups of cinnamon graham crackers/7T butter/dash of nutmeg. For the filling: didn't use milk, only 1T flour, & juice of 1 lemon; also switched to wooden spoon aften beating the cream cheese. In a seperate bowl, I mixed my sugar/flour together & gradually added the combo to the cream cheese. After making filling, let it rest for ~30 min;also used the steam bath method. Cooked on 325 for 1hr, left it in oven w/ cracked stove door for 2hrs, cooled completely on counter for 3hrs & then in the frige!

text:
My first cheesecake - delish and beautiful! I read a ton of other reviews, consulted with friend, and here's my technique, FWIW: used crust recipe from Philadelphia cream cheese website (1-1/2C crushed graham crackers, 1/2C chopped walnuts, 4T melted butter - it makes a little too much for a 9-in pan, FYI). I pre-baked the crust for 15 minutes as I was making the filling. I cut the temp to 325 since I was using a dark colored/glass bottom springform pan. Greased both bottom and sides of springform pan to avoid sticking. I made the filling recipe exactly as suggested here, except added a vanilla bean per cashoda's suggestion on this website, and cut the vanilla to 2t - a nice vanilla-y flavor! Make sure your cream cheese is at room temp, even if you have to zap it in the microwave for a few seconds. Mine was a little too cool, and so I had to overmix to get the lumps out. Then, to get rid of resulting air bubbles, after pouring into the springform pan, I let it sit for 15 min and dropped it on the table a few times so air bubbles would rise to the top, and then popped them. I did not do a water bath b/c I was afraid of leaks, but put a 9x13 pan on a lower shelf with boiling water to get the steam effect.  Once I put it in the oven, did not open the oven at all during 1 hr of baking! I removed it after baking to run a knife along the sides and put back in for 5 hours (again, no peeking!) before removing it to the fridge overnight. Topped with chocolate shavings before serving.

text:
If I could give this recipie AND review's below a hundred stars, I would do that.  Cooking the cheesecake at 200 degrees for 3 hours and then letting it cool in the oven after its turned off for an hour has saved ALL of my cheesecakes that I made for an event. (I made 14 cheesecakes, 2 at a time) None of the cheesecakes that I made cracked, and all were creamy and not sunken in!  Thanks so much!  I have now had offers from people to buy them @ $35 each.  Oh another thing I changed is, I used heavy whipping cream instead of milk.  I used the baking method on all of the different cheesecakes I made, and all of them turned out wonderful!  UPDATE:  I was having trouble with my water bath going through the foil and into my cheesecake, so I fould that if i used oven bags just around the pan NOT closed around the cheesecake that I have no more water in my cheesecakes.  Also I stopped using butter in my crust, I found that the crust stays nice and dry and not so moist due to the butter.  Holds well.  Thanks again!  I just got done with another cheesecake party for a client and it turned out WONDERFUL!

text:
WOW!  What an incredible cheesecake!  I've only made two cheesecakes in my LIFE, and this was the best I've ever tasted.  The only thing I will do differently next time is let it bake for another maybe 5 minutes; the middle was still a bit on the runny side with only 60 minutes.  I wrapped the well-greased springform pan twice in tin foil, and then placed it in 1 inch of HOT water before putting it in the oven.  Then, after it was finished baking, I took a greased knife and ran it between the pan and the edge of the cake.  Lastly, I closed the oven door and turned it off, and let the cheesecake sit in the oven in the water bath for about 3 or 4 hours, cooling.  I can't believe how great those tips were!  The texture was perfect, there were absolutely NO cracks, and it was a beautiful golden brown.  Oh, I also made sure that I didn't overmix the batter.  I only mixed it just enough to incorporate the ingredients.  I think it's easier not to overmix if you mix by hand, not with a mixer.  This is definitely something I'll be making again!  Thank you for posting!

text:
First, let me say I am a newbie at baking anything. Actually, this is the first cake I've ever baked. I went out and bought a spring form pan just for this!

I followed the recipe exactly to make the filling. The only changes I made were to use the graham cracker/butter/cinnamon/sugar crust (good call!) and I set the oven at 325 using a water bath. I did bake the crust alone for 10 minutes while mixing the batter.

Let me just say wow! There was no browning at all, no cracking at all and it came out creamy and delicious! The taste was truly great. I can honestly say this is restaurant quality (better than most restaurants) cheesecake!

The only problems I had were 1. I made a pretty big mess - I am a newbie to this! and 2. it was difficult to get the crust to peacefully separate from the bottom of the pan - I think this was exacerbated by the little lip around the pan. Therefore I couldn't transfer it to a serving plate as planned. I had to cut it in the pan bottom and then I could get a nice piece, crust and all. I think next time I'll try using a 9" parchment round paper in the bottom to help with this.

Edit: Last time I flipped the bottom of the pan to get rid of the lip (like I said, I'm learning) and did use parchment paper. It was a piece of cake (pun intended) to remove from the pan this time!

text:
I LOVE his recipe. I doubled it and it filled the 9 inch springform to the top, it doesn't run over. It made a super thick cake, I posted a couple of pictures of the result. I also increased the cook time by 20 minutes to make sure the center was done to make up for the extra volume. The only extra thing I added was lemon and orange zest, and used heavy cream instead of regular milk. I didn't have any cracks at all, I used a water bath and let it sit for 5 hours without touching it. When you double the recipe this looks like a real NY cheesecake, being from there, I know my stuff. Great recipe, this is my new favorite!

text:
This is an excellent cheesecake recipe. I made a few changes to the baking method and my cheesecakes come out beautifully. When mixing, I use the paddle instead of the whisk on my kitchenaid mixer and I mix it on the lowest speed.  Don't over.  The more you mix, the more air you incorporate in the batter, which tends to make the cheesecakes crack.  I line the bottom of my springform pan with parchment paper.  I butter the sides and bottom of the pan before I put in the crust.  This helps with removing the cheesecake from the pan.  Instead of putting the cheesecake in a water bath, I place a casserole dish of hot water underneath the cheesecake while it bakes.

This is now the ONLY cheesecake recipe I will use!  It is fantastic.  I made the crust that one reviewer suggested, with more graham crackers, sugar, cinnamon, and butter, and it was good. I did not use the flour in the filling, since I wanted a creamier cheesecake, but I do want to try it with the flour to see how it is.  It came out nice and creamy.  I also put a pan of water on the rack below the cheesecake since I didn't have a large enough pan to do the water bath.  I left it in the oven for close to six hours.  There wasn't even a HINT of a crack, it was beautiful!

text:
I have been searching for the "perfect" cheesecake recipe for several years.  I feel like I have tried them all.  Finally, this recipe delivered.  I wouldn't change a thing about the ingredients.  The only thing to remember about this cheesecake is that it is not a recipe that can be planned and implemented on a last moment's notice.  I usually bake this cheesecake a day before, leave it in the oven all night after turning the oven off, and refrigerate for at least four hours until I serve.  This is not something that can be made in a hurry.  However, the extra time is worth it.  This cheesecake is "to die for".

text:
This is a very well written recipe.  For tips on how to end up with a beautiful result sort the reviews by most helpful and read the comments by reviewer Chung_Brenda.  You will end up with a perfect cheesecake if you follow these tips.  I had to add a little more butter (3 Tbsp.) to the graham crackers to moisten them enough.  One note, check on the water bath throughout the cooking time.  Mine all cooked off and I had to add more.  I don't think the cheesecake needs to stay in the oven after baking for more than 2 hours.  At that point it can be refrigerated.  The result was both beautiful and great tasting! I served with fresh strawberries but the possibilities are endless.  Thanks for this one!

text:
This was excellent!  FYI, if your cheesecake cracks from baking, I have a little tip/suggestion...  What I do is make a quick "Sour Cream Topping" for it.  Use 1 pint of sour cream, 6 TB sugar, 1 tsp vanilla and a tsp of Grand Marnier (optional.  Whisk everything together until well blended.  Spread on top of the cheesecake during the last 5 min. or so of baking, then cool and chill the cake.  That usually covers the cracks pretty well.

I have made a lot of cheesecakes in my life and this has been the best one yet. It was a hit with all of my family. I did change the crust to add a little more flavor to it by doing what others recommended  1 1/2 C Grahm Cracker 1/4 C melted butter 1/2 tsp cinnamon 1/4 cup sugar. I cooked the crust for 15 minutes before adding the cheesecake mixture. Unfortunately it did have a huge crack in it because I forgot to grease the pan so please make sure and grease the pan. I also highly recommend the water bath. I think it added to the lightness of the cheesecake

text:
This cheesecake is to die for! I used Splenda instead of sugar to accommodate a diabetic family member and it turned out great. Instead of placing in a water bath,I set a pan of water on the rack below. The cheesecake ended up with a few cracks but they were too tiny to matter. The texture was firm but creamy. I'll be making this one again and again.

Update: Made this cheesecake several times using real sugar, heavy cream instead of milk, and a teaspoon of lemon extract. This is without a doubt the creamiest, best tasting cheesecake I've ever tasted. I bake it for exactly one hour, no more and no less. When done, I shut off the oven and run a knife between the cheesecake and the side of the springform to loosen it then I leave in the oven for an additional hour to cool. I've found that leaving it the oven for 5-6 hours causes my cheesecake to crack so I take it out of the oven and leave it on a cooling rack until it reaches room temperature then I put it in the fridge to chill completely. Try this recipe, you won't regret it and if your cheesecake cracks, don't sweat it. That's what toppings are for. Just spread it on and eat happily.

Display Name:
JESSICA

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first ever attempt at Cheesecake and it turned out perfect! I read quite a few reviews, so I took a  few tips of advice. I had to purchase a springfoam pan for this recipe. I followed the recipe almost. I used 1 1/4 cups of graham cracker crumbs and doubled the amount of butter (and used real butter) I also added about 1/4 tsp of cinnamon to the crust and about a teaspoon-tablespoon of white sugar to the crust. I added about one tablespoon of lemon juice to the cream cheese mixture. I used regular cream cheese and whole milk (though tempted to buy the reduced fat cream cheese and lower fat milk, I didn't want to chance it and compromise the taste) I greased my pan very well and did use a version of this crazy water bath I had read about. I  put about 1" of hot water in a 9X13 pyrex and put it in the oven on the rack directly under the rack the cheesecake was on. I baked for one hour on 350 degrees and never even opened the oven door! I wanted to so badly, but was afraid it would mess the cheesecake up. I let it cool for the full amount of time, and when I took it out, It was golden brown on top and not one crack and It did not sink either! the taste was excellent, will definitely make this one again! This will be my cheesecake recipe-it tastes store bought.

text:
This is a keeper! I have made it countless times. I've tried others and wasn't impressed. I have never changed anything on this recipe before, but yesterday I decided to do a little tweaking and they (I made two) turned out great. First I did about 2/3 graham crackers and 1/3 vanilla wafers, because that's what I had on hand. I also added a few more tablespoons of butter to the crust. Then the only other change was I baked it for 10 minutes at 425 degrees, then dropped it down to 350 for the rest of the time. I also baked them in a hot water bath this time. This is necessary though, I just wanted to try it. Make sure to tin-foil your springform pan on the outside if you do decide to try it. It turns out beautifully no matter how you bake it. Trust me, I have tried many and this one is THE BEST!

text:
It was my first time making cheesecake and I feel like the queen of cheesecakes now thanks to you Chantal!  I took suggestions from others:  Double the butter in the crust.  Use a reynolds oven bag over the bottom of the pan and use a water bath 1/2 way up the pan in another pan.  Cook for a little over an hour so the center isn't mushy.  Cool in the oven for only about 1 1/2 hours then directly to the fridge.  Outrageous...boyfriend says the best he ever had - the taste, the consistency...I'm sooo happy!!!

text:
This is a fabulous recipe, and one I'm requested to bring almost everywhere I go. With this, I HAVE FINALLY SOLVED MY WATERBATH PROBLEM! Wrapping tin-foil around my pan always allows water to leak in anyway, so I went looking for a better solution - and I've got it! I went to Bed Bath and Beyond and bought one of those red SiliconeZone Flexi Bakeware 9 1/2 in. cake pans. (It costs $14.99 without one of those coupons they send out all the time that never expire.) Anyway, I got home prepared my cheesecake as usual, and then pryed the cake pan around my glass-bottomed springform pan. (I recommend the glass bottom pan because the glass doesn't have any lip on it, and if you want to transfer your cheesecake to a serving platter, it's easy to get underneath it.) It's very tight, but the silicone bends easily and you want to keep the water out. After I had the springform pan resting inside the red cake pan, I put it in the water bath and baked as usual. MY CHEESECAKE WAS PERFECT! Usually my crust gets soggy because the water bath leaks in, but the crust was crunchy and tasty and the whole thing looked great. Best of luck to you with your cheesecake baking. Thanks for this FABULOUS RECIPE, CHANTAL!

None
text:
Came out perfect!  I used a water bath and also reduced baking temp to 335.  The cheesecake should have a wobbly 2-3 inch center when it's done...it will firm up in the 1-2 hours it sits in the cooling-off oven.  It doesn't need to sit 5-6 as the recipe calls for...you should get it in the fridge after 1-2 hours.  Mine did not crack at all.  A crust variation-- add 4 Tbs sugar, 2 Tbs brown sugar, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, and use 4 Tbs melted butter per package of cinnamon graham crackers...really good crust.  Pre-bake for a few minutes before pouring in cheesecake batter.  Delicious cheesecake recipe!

country:
None
text:
The best cheesecake I have made yet, and I keep trying. The secret I am finding to all good cheesecakes is to just barely mix after the eggs go in and to use all room-temperature ingredients (or warm them in the microwave). That helps to keep things smooth. Also, cooling completely in the oven (without once opening the oven during cooking) keeps the cake from cracking.

And I am so glad I chose this recipe! Even having never made cheesecake before, this wasn't difficult at all - just long. It was torture waiting the 6+ hours for it to cool! None
text:
This is a great cheesecake recipe. For those of you that had unsuccessful results, I would like to share some of my tips for making a great cheesecake.... I always make sure all of my ingredients are room temperature because it eliminates any lumps in my batter... I also always mix my ingredients with a wooden spoon by hand, never a mixer. If there is too much air in your batter, it will taste gritty. Also, don't forget to spray the sides of your pan with a baking spray to prevent the cake from sticking- this step, combined with the water bath will eliminate any cracks. Also, it never hurts to use an oven thermometer to check the accuracy of your oven temp.

I made this cheesecake for my wife for Valentine's Day and she absolutely LOVED it.  She always orders cheesecake if we order dessert when we're dining out, and she said this was better than any she's had anywhere.  

I followed the recipe completely, and it didn't crack and was perfect. 

I made a raspberry sauce out of a small container of frozen raspberries.  Added a bit of orange juice and a tablespoon of sugar.  Heated it to boiling after I added 2 tsp. of cornstarch that had been mixed into 2 TBLSP. of water.  Perfect.

Every time we cut a piece and drizzled the sauce on it one of us said that it looked just like in a magazine.  Thanks for this recipe.

text:
I rarely write a review but this recipe is absolutely devine so it was a must! This recipe was my first attempt at cheesecake EVER. I've made it twice in the same month so far.  I made it just as it is listed ingredient wise (maybe adding a little more sugar the second time.) I did however use a water bath. Which in my opinion changes NOTHING as far as the actual recipe is concerned, the method of cooking with a waterbath just enhanced this recipes texture (moisture) and apperance (little to no cracking). In my first attempt the cake did have a very small crack (I think it was because I opened the oven a few time too many times). I baked it in a 8 in cake pan since I didn't own a spring form pan at the time. The cake did rise and fall but was still perfect in the end. To cover the small crack I used a sour cream topping. The second time I used a springform pan. I tried to cheat and only wrapped foil halfway up the pan once, water did leak in a little. The crust did get soggy but wasn't a huge issue. The second attempt using the springform pan didn't look as nice as the cake pan edge wise, but was still a success with no cracks at all. I also covered it with a sour cream topping. Lastly, I also baked the crust for a few mins. before for each cake.  My water bath pan was a 1 1/2 inch cookie sheet with hot water added about 1 inch up. In my next attempt I will adjusted the temp a little lower to see of it helps lighten the edges. All in all this recipe is a Slam Dunk!

text:
Simply deelish! I did change the crust from graham crackers to 50 Nilla wafers. I'm not a fan of graham and I found the vanilla wafers lighter. Something else not mentioned is the water bath, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT! Next to NOT over beating the batter, I believe that a water bath aids in the cheesecake NOT cracking! I took the advice of something I read on this site and used one of those cooking bags instead of tin foil for the bath. I thought, "what a great idea! That way there is no chance of the water seeping into the cheesecake!" Worked like a charm and I'll use that again!!!! This was the most beautiful,  perfect, deliciously simple cheesecake I have ever made! I brought it to a Christmas party and people actually thought it came from a bakery! (No one touched the store bought cheesecake another guest brought!)

text:
It's not fair for me to say its terrible or awesome because I didn't follow the directions to a tee. However, I thought the recipe was very good. I didn't use milk or flour because I have never seen that before. I did add 1/2 c of sugar to my crust to give it more flavor. I also did 1/4 of melted butter. I accidentally used a whole stick and it didn't work so I had to scrap the crust. I let my cream cheese set out for over an hour to bring it to room temperature. I used my stand mixer to mix the ingredients. I was very careful not to go past 1 and to not let over beat. I forgot to put in the vanilla. I baked at 325 for 10 minutes and changed my mind and lowered it to 225 for 3 hours. I let it cool for another 2 in the oven then placed in the fridge over night. My cheesecake didn't not burn, fall or crack! I was so excited. It is very creamy and moist. I used a crock pot liner to put under my springform pan and placed in a water bath also. This took a while to make  and I grounded my husband from the kitchen and told him he had to tiptoe around the house.

text:
The cheesecake itself was delicious and there were certainly no complaints! I made it exactly as the recipes states, but where I got stumped was the "15 Graham Crackers". I didn't know what constitutes 1 Graham Cracker so I watched the video and to me it looked like one whole cracker sheet, so I used 15 of those.... well I was wrong because my crust was really dry! Now I've determined it was 15 half cracker sheets (7 1/2 whole cracker sheets). No one whose eatin it has seed to mind and I will definitely make it again but this time I'll use what I've determined to be the proper amount of graham crackers. I left a pic too if anyone wants to see it! :)

text:
My very first homemade cheesecake and all I can say is wow! This recipe is almost perfect. I only made a few slight alterations. I used the crust recipe from the other reviews and I baked it at 335 degrees for 1hr 10 mins, then shut off oven and left it in there for only 3 hrs, cracking the oven door the last hr. Then put it in the fridge.  It came out flawless, no cracks and the taste was absolutely divine. Firm but still very creamy.  Better than I have had in a lot of restaurants. I used my stand mixer the whole way through, made sure the ingredients were at room temperature, sprayed the spring form pan with Pam, and put it in a water bath in a pizza pan. Don't forget these steps and you should be golden.

city:

country:
None
text:
This will give you a rich but light, almost fluffy cheesecake. Wonderful! If you want a more dense cake, omit the flour. Here are some other tips. 
1. Use a water bath, as with any cheesecake or custard.  2. Preheat oven to 350, then reset to 300 once the cake is in. Bake 60 min, the leave for 3-3.5 hours in unopened oven. Cake will be set with no browning or cracks.  3. Don't overfill the pan. 4. The recipe makes a bit too much. I use a couple ramekins for mini cakes. 5. I use buttermilk or milk soured with lemon juice in place of milk and love the extra tang. 6. Half Splenda, half sugar works beautifully.

text:
I think this cheesecake would had been perfect if I had read the comments before baking it at 350. I followed the recipe perfectly, and did not over beat. Only after 20 mins of being in the over, my cake had risen quite a bit. I then read comments saying that cheesecakes need to be cooked at 325 or 300. I dropped the temp to 325 but still after the hour, the whole top and sides were over cooked and hard. On the plus side, the flavor was great, so I only suggest to cook at a lower temp

text:
Just wanted to give those of you who are about to attempt to make this (or any cheesecake) if you wish to avoid cracking in your cheesecake, if you have a pan large enough to place your springform pan inside it, and place water about 1/4 the way up the side of the springform. If you do not have a pan big enough to place it in, then just below the cake, place a baking dish with water the moisture will prevent the cheesecake from cracking. Happy Baking!!

text:
By the time I finished reading many reviews and alterations people had made to this recipe, my head was spinning, and I wondered what changes I should or should not make. So, I did what I usually do…stick to the original recipe first! I think it is only fair to try it as written first, then come back and change it, if necessary. With a few common-sense exceptions, of course, for example if you don’t like an ingredient (and omitting it doesn’t affect the recipe too much) omit it. 


On to the review: I did use the suggested water bath (with a pan of water underneath the cheesecake, NOT sitting directly inside…didn’t want to fuss with wrapping in foil or potential “leakage” issues). I also spiced up the crust to our families liking (adding cinnamon, sugar, a dash of nutmeg and crushed pecans). I do not consider the crust to be the real recipe here, and it is easily adjustable to tastes. The filling, conversely is the real “meat” of the recipe: For it, I followed the recipe exactly as written, including all mixing, oven temperature, baking time, instructions...added all the flour, sour cream, milk…everything just as the recipe states. How was it? Perfect! Smooth, creamy, not too custard-like or too heavy/firm…perfect texture, smooth, well-balanced flavor. We loved it! I did, however, get one small crack in the top of my cheesecake, but it didn’t affect the taste at all. I plan to try again using a newer springform pan (this might be my problem with cracking). Happy Baking!

This is an excellent recipe!!! Whether you make it exactly or make substitutions, this one is sure to be a crowd pleaser.  I usually swap half (or sometimes all) of the cream cheese for ricotta and or neuchâtel, and the flour for half as much corn starch (gluten allergy). I also swap the graham crakers for gluten free cookies (or puffins gf cereal, believe it or not) and pop them in the food processor to crush them easily.  Happy eating!

Display Name:
Cheryl Jones

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1167743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple & delicious.  I only had 3 (8oz) pkgs of cream cheese instead of 4, so I cut the sugar down to 1 cup & used only 3 eggs.  I also cut the milk down to 1/2 cup.  I used a 9" round cake pan instead of a springform pan & pressed the graham cracker crust along the bottom & up the sides of the cake pan.  I set a 9"x13" baking pan filled w/ 2" of water on a lower oven rack w/ the cheesecake baking on the rack just above it.  I baked it in a preheated 350 degree oven for an hour.  At the end of an hour, I shut my oven off & forgot about the cheesecake for 5 hours.  I then transferred it to my fridge & served it the next day.  It turned out beautiful, tasted delicious, & there were no cracks!

Cheesecake shrinks as it cools & pulls away from the sides of the pan.  Cracks form because the cheesecake sticks to the sides of the pan during the cooling/shrinking process.  Either grease the inside of your pan EXTREMELY well or just press a crust up the sides of the pan as well as along the bottom.  Serve each slice straight from the cake pan like you're serving a slice of pie.  Yum!

I followed the recipe exactly...But I halved it and put it into a pre-made crust. (Thank goodness I halved it! Barely fit in the crust!) I followed another person's review and used a hand mixer for the first step and a wooden spoon for the rest. I tried really hard to just stir until incorporated, but last time I made cheesecake (was not with this recipe) I hadn't stirred enough...So this time I tried to stir it just enough...Baked for an hour (wasn't sure if I should bake it for less since it was smaller...) and it turned out a bit brown. Left it in the oven overnight and then put in the fridge all day. Lots of condensation on top of cake :( I wonder how to minimize that. Served it with fresh strawberries and it was quite good! The bites I had without strawberries were a little lacking in flavor, but my family didn't seem to agree with me--my sister raved about it and my mother said it was better than the cheesecake she had just had on a cruise. I would make this recipe again but I'm just wondering how I could add a little more flavor to it...

country:
None
text:
I have been making this a couple times a year for a few years and it is a no-fail recipe.  I am not a pastry chef, and this recipe comes out perfect for me every time.  Personally, my trick to keep it from cracking is to REALLY butter the sides of the pan.  When buttered, the cheesecake can pull away from the edges as it contracts and cools and not crack.  I have made it with and without a water bath and have never found that it made a difference.  After I pour the filling into the pan I always giggle the pan and tap it for a few minutes to get the air bubbles to rise.  It always comes out dense and perfect for us.  People are amazed.  Apparently, cheesecakes are supposed to be hard to make!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I live in France and have learned to re-create a New York cheesecake with this recipe. I have, however, modified this somewhat (but not much). I freeze the cookie crumb crust once in the springform to make sure that when pouring in the cheese filling it doesn't break up. I reduce the sugar to 1 cup, removed the milk and most of the sour cream, adding 1 can of non sweetened condensed milk instead as well as about 3 Tb of sour cream. I prefer lemon cheesecakes, so I put in 1 tsp of lemon extract instead of the vanilla. And lastly, I replace the flour with cornstarch. Baking time is usually more than one hour and I leave it in the oven until cooled. Mine rarely crack. Thanks for the recipe, the base was a perfect. I've used it to create a chocolate version as well as a raspberry version.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have never made a cheesecake before so I am thankful this was the first one I tried!  My husband needed one for work so I thought I would give it a shot and it turned out perfect!  I followed the following tips: 1) line springform pan w/ parchment paper, 2) boil water for water bath, 3) use the large heavy duty foil to wrap outside of springform pan to prevent water from entering the springform pan and 4) I let it cool in the oven with the door shut for 6 hours.  There was not one crack in it nor did it sink in the middle and it cooked evenly without browning.  I also let all ingredients warm to room temperature before mixing and I had a very smooth batter.  Since I was sending this to my husband's office I also needed to transfer the cheesecake from my springform pan to a disposable cardboard round (covered in foil) and into a box.  So, I also followed the recommendations of others to make sure the bottom of the springform pan was the raised side and not the other side.  Since I lined the bottom of the pan with parchment paper it was easy to transfer to the round.  I simply removed the ring, ran a long flat cake frosting spatula between the parchment and the bottom of the pan and when this raised the cake slightly, I slid the covered cardboard round underneath the cake and it transferred without problem.  Thank you to all the previous reviewers for your comments as I would not have had the success I had without your tips!!!

text:
This cheesecake is GREAT! I made this cake in a water bath and the water had seeped into the crust making it soggy. I made it a second time and not a drop of water went inside. This is what I did: 1) covered the entire bottom & up sides of springform pan w/ foil, baked the crust for 8 mins. 2) after cooled and before filling it, I placed the springform pan into an oven bag and rolled the bag down to the rim of the springform pan making the bag even with the pan. 3) Put springform pan in a roasting pan and placed in oven, filling the roasting pan with water only a 1/4 high up the side of springform pan.. OMG! when it was ready to eat the crust was awesome! I hope tis helps!

Display Name:
Angela

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is spot on, with the only omission that all ingredients MUST be at room temp.  Take them out of the fridge at least 2 hrs before you start, or warm them up in the microwave (milk, sour cream, cream cheese).  They have to be room temp when you blend them.  I mix ingredients in the following order to avoid over mixing the eggs: beat cream cheese with sugar and sour cream on low with mixer, then use spatula to mix in milk, eggs one at a time, then add flour and vanilla as you mix the last egg. The less you air up the eggs, the better. I bake for 45 min at 350 without any water bath. I sometimes open to oven in the last 5 min or so to gently shake the pan. If the mix does not jiggle very much, I turn off the oven; otherwise I bake it for a few more min. Cooling it in the oven, with door closed is a must and will help it set and further cook if the middle is still jiggly. Over baking will cause it to crack, very simple. This is an awesome recipe!

If I could give this 20 more stars I would!  This was the very first real cheesecake I ever made and it was a thing of beauty!  I used the water bath as several suggested, and I baked for one hour, turned off the oven and let it sit in the cooling oven for 5 hours.  I also let the cream cheese get to room temp before mixing.  There wasn't one crack and not one single lump!  Cheesecake, it would seem, is not as horribly difficult as it seems to be.  I now have friends and family begging me to make "MY" cheesecake for the next occasion or no occasion at all!  Thank you Chantal!  AND New York!  I have to add some new comments here as I have been using this recipe to make my special cheesecakes that EVERYONE loves and begs for! I've added Raspberry extract, strawberry extract or pumpkin to make great variations.  This week I made an Oreo Cheesecake using an Oreo crust. The next one will be a turtle cheesecake by adding chocolate, caramel and pecans or a Neopolitan making layers of Chantals vanilla, a chocolate layer and a strawberry layer!  This is STILL the best cheesecake recipe ANYWHERE!!!

text:
This cheesecake came out beautiful.  I made 3 of them and had no cracks or sinkage.  I baked as directed, turned off the oven, and left my cheesecakes in the oven over night.  The next morning I refrigerated. They were perfect.  NO WATER BATH, YEAH!!! For those having problems, make sure cream cheese and eggs are room temperature before beginning.  DON'T OVER BEAT.  I just used a plastic mixing spoon to blend all the ingredients together (which is easy to do when your cream cheese is at room temperature).  As a heads up if you are using a dark nonstick pan you'll need to lower the oven temp. I only rated it 4 stars just out of flavor preference.  I like my cheese cakes a little sweeter.  Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

text:
Absolutely perfect cheesecake as is!  Wonderful smooth taste!  However, we cannot eat such a large dessert, so I wanted to try different sizes.  From one recipe I made 24 bite-sized (1 inch), 24 mini’s (2 inch) and 2 small (4 inch)!!  I did make a second batch of crust. To bake smaller sizes, lower the oven temperature to 300 degrees.  I used paper liners for the 1.5 inch size, ½ teaspoon crust, and baked for 10-12 minutes.  I have a pan (Chicago Metallic) with removable bottoms (2 inch) that I greased and used 1 teaspoon crust and baked for 12-14 minutes.  Lastly I have several 4 inch springform pans that took 2 tablespoons crust and baked for 14-16 minutes. If you have a wooden "tapper," it is very useful to press down the crumb crust, but you could use your fingers or anything the right size.  I placed two pans of water in the oven for increased humidity. I did not have a cracking problem. These freeze well.  Now I can use a few from the freezer in the weeks ahead.   I have topped them with fruits or whipped cream.  Handy and fantastic!  MUCH better in taste and texture than any of the “mini” recipes on this site.

text:
Folks, I am by no means a beginner baker... but I'll be honest, I was INTIMIDATED by this cake! Mainly because of ALL the reviews. But on the contrary- this was SO easy to make! NO cracks, presentation was phenomenal, and taste was unquestionably 5 stars. I chose to top mine with canned strawberries. Little bakers secret: 1 cup crisco (not butter flavored) 1 cup flour, 1/2 cup veg. oil, mix it all together and you've got yourself a NO FAIL baking pan spread(keep it in a sealed container in your pantry). Brush it on your pan and your cakes will NEVER stick. I don't have a pan large enough to put my springform pan in a 'water bath', so I took another delightful reviewers tip of filling a pan of water and placing it on the rack below the cake, the steam rises and works just as good. YUM-MY, it was devoured at my New Years party, next time I'll have to make two : )

city:

country:
None
text:
Perfect cheesecake!! Okay so I agree with another user, if you mess this recipe up its your fault, not the recipe. I live in Colorado so here are directions for anyone at high elevation: 1. Use extra large eggs, and grease well with shortening. 2. Bake in preheated 350 deg oven middle rack in a water bath for 1hr 30 min. 3. DO NOT use foil to wrap your spring form pan, the water will leak through, use an oven bag and leave it open on the top. 4. Cover the top of the cheesecake with foil (tent form); because of our elevation the top will brown before the center is anywhere near done, remove foil after 45min, bake for an additional 45min uncovered. 5. Once the cheesecake is done baking run a butter knife around edge to help the cake pull away from the side so it does not stick and crack. 6. turn off oven and leave in the oven  as recomemned, then cool in refrigerator. Now onto the crust: I used 1 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/3 cup white sugar, 1 1/2 tbs cinnamon, and 5tbs melted butter. Toppings: I made a raspberry sauce. I used 2 tbs butter, 1 1/2 tbs raspberry extract and 1 1/2 tbs vanilla ectract, 2/3 cup water, 1 tbs honey, 4 tbs sugar, 1 package fresh raspberries. Combine ingredients in a medium sauce pan over medium heat. Mash raspberries with a potato masher, bring to boil, reduce heat to low and simmer until sauce is thick, cool and enjoy!!!! ( I pipe some into my cheesecake batter while it is in the pan so it cooks with some raspberry saue in the cheesecake.)

text:
This is a pretty good recipe.  I've been making Chantel's cheesecake for several years.  My suggestion for using a water bath (and i very much recommend it) is to put the water bath into the oven while the oven is preheating.  Once you are ready to put your cheesecake into the oven, put it on the rack ABOVE and directly over the bath instead of inside the pan.  You can still wrap aluminum around the pan.  Putting the water bath into the oven while it is preheating creates a moist invironment for the cheesecake which in turn will produce one with less cracks or hopefully none at all.

text:
I bake a lot of cheesecakes and I have to say this recipe is simply the best! I'm going to use it as a base now for all my cheesecake recipes. To try a variation -- split the recipe in half (make two smaller batches) and add 4 squares of melted baker's chocolate to one of the batches. Pour the chocolate batch in first and then the vanilla one on top and swirl gently with a knife. I make this with an oreo crust. It's fabulous! Make sure all your ingredients are at room temperature to prevent lumps. Next time I will follow other's advice and bake at 325* (mine burned ever so slightly). I love this recipe and so does everyone who eats it!

text:
Wow, this is an amazing recipe. The cheesecake is smooth, creamy and delicious! I made some modifications per other user's suggestions-- wrapped the springform pan in aluminimum, baked in a roasting pan water bath with 1 inch of hot boiling water, reduced the sugar to 1 1/4 cup, and added to the crust ingredients (used 1 1/2 cup of graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 tsp of cinnamon powder, 3 tbsp more of butter, and a splash of vanilla.). All the ingredients were at room temperature.  After baking for 1 hour at 350 degrees, I left it in there for another 2 hours, then transferred to the fridge for overnight. The cheesecake came out perfect! I made some strawberry compote to put on top, but just plain, it was to die for. Thank you so much for a wonderful recipe!

text:
I had such high hopes for this recipe based on all of the reviews, but I think it was my own fault that it did not turn out *perfectly*. First off, I left the cream cheese to soften on the counter for about 2 hours, which was not enough time. I should have either left it out longer before using it, or tried to soften it in the microwave, as my beater would not cut through the cheese, leaving it somewhat chunky. I was afraid of over-beating it so I left it with some chunks. Also, when adding the flour, sour cream and vanilla, I should have added each one individually, because when I added them together the vanilla stuck to the flour and ended up making small chunks in the batter. Otherwise, the recipe was really delicious.

text:
This is a very outstanding basic cheesecake recipe. I have added cocoa powder to make it chocolate. I like to put mine is a water bath to prevent cracking. For all of you who watch Food Network, Alton Brown's Good Eats has an excellent episode with some great cheesecake tips, so try to watch it!** UPDATE** Here are some of the tips from the episode: 1. put cheesecake in pan (same shape but bigger) filled with 2 quarts of WARMED water 2. after cooking, turn off oven, open for one minute, then close and leave cheesecake in for one hour 3. Add one tablespoon of cornstarch to mix before adding sugar- it helps keep it from cracking.

text:
FANTASTIC!! Im from NY and this is how it should be. Important tip: Make sure the cream cheese is a room temp, and DO NOT OVER MIX! I wrapped foil around the spring form and put a pie pan filled with water on the lower shelf of the oven. DO NOT, DO NOT open the oven to peek at all. This will put cracks in the cake. And make sure to leave in the oven for at least five hours after cooking. Again do not open the door I know its hard, but will be worth it. Make the night ahead so it can chill. One of the best recipes yet. Thank you!

text:
This is a great recipe! I made the cheesecake mix as directed but put them in cupcake tins instead of a pie tin. I pressed the graham cracker crust into the cupcake tins using a cup and then filled them up with the cheesecake. Baked at 350 for about 25 minutes or until the cheesecake is set in the middle. When they cooled I topped them with frosting. It's fun to watch people take a bite expecting a regular cupcake and get so much more! I followed the instructions in the recipe and also used the tips from the cheesecake articles from all recipes. If you've never made cheesecake before or if yours doesn't turn out I'd consult the recipes. Cheesecake is very delicate!

Followed the recipe *exactly*. The crust did not stay together. The cheesecake itself was not very sweet, in fact it didn't really have much of a flavor at all. The texture was really nice and smooth but this is not a NEW YORK cheesecake. Where's the tang? You can't even taste the cream cheese -- isn't that the point of "cheesecake"? text:
Well to start, the crust doesn't have enough butter to hold it together.  Also it wasn't very tasty.  The cheesecake's texture was all wrong.  I prefer cheesecake to be rich, dense, creamy and smooth.  I knew as soon as I added the milk and it went all runny that it was wrong and adding the flour just makes it worse, because that is the texture you feel as you eat it.  Fluff and flour.  Flavor wise, it was just ok.  The first couple bites are alright, but then the blandness and bad texture completely kills it.  Not even topping helps at that point.  Thanks for the effort and I'm glad many people seem to enjoy it.  To each their own.  I will never use this recipe again however.

text:
This recipe ROCKS. This was my first time to make a cheesecake; made it for our poker night to celebrate two birthdays, and guests loved it. I read all the reviews and the secret to the cake not cracking really is to run the knife around the edge when it finishes baking. I served with cherry pie filling and it was creamy and delicious. Because of a time challenge, I chilled it straight from the oven and it was great. Next time I'll chill it overnight. I baked it in a round Pampered Chef stoneware dish with a pan of boiling water on the rack beneath, and it was great. This is a keeper! Thanks for the post! **Update 8/31/08** Made for a Labor Day party and again it was a hit. I didn't let it chill overnight yet, but hubby went back for seconds. Note: use white all-purpose flour in the cheesecake, not wheat. I used wheat flour and it left little specks in the cheesecake, but fortunately this didn't affect the taste. Only one small crack but maybe because I let it cool for 20 mins then put in fridge on the coldest setting. Once it cooled enough I put it in the freezer for about 30 mins. This time, there was almost 2 cups of batter left over.

text:
I wish I had read more of the reviews before I made this cheesecake.   While it was tasty it does have a grand cayon of a crack and is a bit brown on the top.

What I've learned:   DON'T OVERWHIP.   Make sure you blend the cream cheese smooth BEFORE you add the eggs and then mix as little as possible.  Cook at 325...350 is too hot and results in a brown cake.

Good taste though.

text:
WOW. Just WOW. 

I made this cheesecake to celebrate an early Easter dinner with my parents & everyone was floored at how incredibly delicious it was. My MOM couldn't get over how perfectly even the top of the cake was & when I released the spring part from the base of the pan, I couldn't help but smile at how beautiful it looked! Like something I might have bought at a bakery but BETTER!

That doesn't even begin to describe the flavor, the perfect texture, the creaminess, etc. This is my new cheesecake recipe & I will NEVER use another. I think I even made my little sister (the world's best baker) jealous -  up until now her cheesecake was hands down best. We're having a "cake-off" in May.

One thing I may change in the future, a tblsp more butter to the crust as it seemed it could have used a tad more. Also, I will grate some fresh lemon rind into the batter. That's how my mom always does it, and despite it tasting fantastic, that was the one thing missing that I am used to.

The only other thing I did different from the recipe was I only had time to leave it in the oven for 2 hours post baking. Then I refrigerated for a full 24 hours prior to serving.

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!!! GREAT recipe!!!

YUMMY!  I can't believe how creamy, yet firm this cheesecake is.  I started mixing my ingredients and realized I didn't have any eggs so I had to leave the cream cheese and sugar mixture sit at room tempature for about a hour.  The finished product still tasted amazing!  I think it would be very hard to mess this one up.  Word of caution - make darn sure ALL of your ingredients are at room temp.  I put the vanilla extract directly from fridge to mixing bowl and it formed some small pods in the filling.  It didn't hurt the taste at all and actually made for a neat inner appearance.  Lucky, I guess!  I'm very thankful I chose this recipe.  Delicious!

text:
first time i tried it out, i got no cracks, even w/o a water bath. the next 3 times, all have had cracks. i think it's in part that i was using 2 different ovens, so i'll attempt the water bath for when i use the oven at my house. also, i find that the crust needs about 1 Tb more butter. what i've done in the past is take 1/3 of the batter, add 1/2 cup of melted chocolate chips and mix it, then pour it into the white batter in the springform pan and use a knife to cut into it and make swirls. and the result- a great looking chocolate marbled cheesecake!

Very good. I used a little less sour cream as suggested on other reviews and added half a cup of milk chocolate chips after putting the batter into the pan too. text:
I can't say enough how much I LOVE this cheesecake. I've made it at least a dozen times, and here's what I do different:  I use the Graham Cracker Crust I recipe from this site for the crust. Make sure all my ingredients are at room temp, it really does help keep your batter from being lumpy. Beat my sugar and cream cheese until smooth and then use a wooden spoon for the rest of the mixing. I don't have a 9" spring form, so I bake in a 10". When using a 10", decrease baking time by about 10 minutes. Be sure to grease the sides of the pan! My pan won't fit in a water bath so I place a 9x13 pan filled with water on the bottom rack. Leave it in the oven for the full 5-6 hours to cool and voila, perfection!!!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Delicious! The crust needed to be sweetened a little. A friend suggested the following crust: 15 graham crackers, crushed; 1/4 cup butter, melted; 2 tablespoons sugar; 1 teaspoon all-purpose flour; pat into a springform and bake for 5 minutes. Let cool completely before pouring cheesecake filling over. I opted to bake in a water bath, and it turned out better than I expected. I left everything else the way it was; the cheesecake was phenomenal! Everyone who has tried it loved it! I've baked 3 so far; my fourth one will come soon.

text:
WOW this is goood cheesecake!!!  I catered my mom-in-law's 60th birthday party and wanted to make something special and this fit the bill.  There were 30+ people there and they all raved about how good this cheesecake was.  There was a fantastic chocolate cake there also and the cheescake went first (very quickly!) and half the cake was left.  Many people asked for the recipe, they commented on how moist and the sweetness was just right.  My oven cooks hot so I lowered the temp 25 degrees, and I put a baking pan on the shelf below the cheesecake and half filled it with hot water before putting in the cheesecake (waterbath), and left it in for the time recommended.  After I turned the oven off and left the cake in the closed oven for several hours as recoomended I forget and left it an extra hour, no problems it was picture perfect like out of a bakery and delicious as well.  WELL DONE and thanks for the excellent recipe!

text:
Wow! First time making any cheesecake in general and very surprised! This recipe is defineatly an esteem booster. It's very easy to make and the result is great. It's very important to make sure that the springform pan that you bake the cake in, is leak-proof. Even though i wrapped mine in aluminum foil before baking in the water bath, some water still got in. It didn't ruin the cake, but i got scared it would. Other than that, just follow the tips found on this web-site about how to bake a cheesecake and you're set! Great recipe! Thank you!

text:
This was okay but not the best cheesecake I've ever had.  Could have been richer I think - to make it more indulgent.  But it was so easy to make!  I actually halved the filling recipe and baked mine in a pie pan.  I 'freestyled' the crust because I wanted mine nice and thick.  To the crust I added finely chopped walnuts, 2 Tbsp sugar, and a dash of cinnamon.  I used a water bath and left mine in the oven for about 3 hours - no cracks!  It was beautiful!  I think I will keep this recipe but maybe look out for another cheesecake recipe to try next time.

text:
I made this for Easter dinner and served it with strawberry sauce.  It was absolutely wonderful!  It was also my first time making a cheesecake.  The crust came out a little thick for a 9" springform pan.  I did use 15 "whole" graham crackers (meaning two squares = 1 cracker), so I'm thinking that may have been the reason why mine came out so thick.  I also had a little of the cheese mixture left over that didn't fit into the pan.  So next time I make this, I will probably put it in a larger springform pan (maybe 10-11").  The top did crack slightly in one spot - but not that big of a deal.  I will try using a water bath next time, as others suggested.  I will definately make this again! UPDATE: Made this for Christmas Eve 2014 - Used 15 graham cracker squares and a 9" pan and did exactly as Morena suggested, and it turned out PERFECT. No waterbath, no cracks, perfect amount of crust & filling!

None
country:
None
text:
Great cheesecake, easy to prepare!  When I make cheesecakes, or minature cheesecakes in muffin papers, I usually have problems with cracking or the middle will sink a little.  I always mix up an 8 oz. container of sour cream to 2 heaping tablespoons of granulated sugar.  Pour or spoon that over the cheesecake, while the cheesecake is warm.  It will fill in any cracks, and leave a smooth shiny topping that sets like a gelatin.  Works everytime!  You can then even put your berry toppings or cinnamon.

KTE74

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe! I've made it a few times now and I've had to make some adjustments in order for it to look the way I want it to. I used a stick of butter for my crust because it didn't seem to hold together as well for me. Use room temperature ingredients from the fridge and do not over mix! Drop the spring form pan a couple of times on the counter to let any air bubbles rise to the top. I also used a water bath. Very important step! Get a big roasting pan, put that spring form pan in an oven bag and give it a bath. I don't trust the foil route! I barely trusted the oven bag. That made all the difference in the world in how the finished product looked for me. The taste has never changed, it's been delicious from the first time I made this! Thank you for sharing the recipe! I looked everywhere and with all the reviews and ratings, I chose this one and it's the only one you'll ever need! KUDOS!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-04-07T19:06:06.2
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
6000739
Display Name:
Dallyoop
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
143
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the best cheesecake I've ever had.  It was perfect in every way... Creamy and rich with a great vanilla taste and not too sweet either.  Even Cheesecake Factory has nothing on this one.  I read some of the other reviewer's suggestions and made just a few changes.  I added half a teaspoon of almond extract to the batter which gave the flavor just a little bit of something extra but no one could tell what it was.  I made sure to use regular cream cheese instead of lower fat as well as light cream instead of milk.  I lowered the oven temp by 10 degrees as a reviewer suggested as I didn't want the top to brown too much and it baked for the required time.  My oven temp might be a little warmer than it reads on the display anyway.  I put the cheesecake into a hot water bath while cooking which really helped bake it perfectly.  Be sure to wrap the pan in two layers of foil so the water doesn't get into the cheesecake while baking.  Lastly, I left the cheesecake in the oven, with it turned off and the door cracked open, so it would cool slowly for about an hour.  Then I let it cool on the counter a few hours before refrigerating it.  The result was a perfect looking and tasting dessert with no cracks at all.  This cheesecake needed no topping because it was wonderful without anything added.  I am throwing away any other cheesecake recipes I have and just make this one.

region:

country:

text:
Love!
12 
 1.My 1st cheesecake EVER. I knew nothing! Cracks? Water baths? Huh? I was certain I would ruin this and not know why.
2. EASY PREP. I used a mixer for cream cheese and sugar only, wooden spoon for the rest, as suggested by someone else. (Ok so far, plenty of time to mess it up)
3. I added almond extract (I like it)
4. Used a hot water bath because I saw it in other recipes and got confused...I think this is ok
5. After an hour, oven off, I peeked and saw that cc was caramel colored and sunken in the middle. (was that ok? Who knows...  optimism dropping)
6. 30 min later worried about water bath, Googled, found out that not using foil around the pan, like me, in the bath, makes crust soggy. :/  whoops -- not very optimistic 
7. Immediately pulled it out of the oven, out of the water, then back in the oven.  (was that bad? Maybe. Probably ruined)
8. Left it in oven overnight. 7ish hrs. (was that too long? Definitely ruined)
9. In the morning CC was flat, pulled away from sides of pan and"crackless" (apparently all good things--maybe its ok)
10. Didn't know when to take it out of the pan, waited till last minute (did I mess up the crust? The easiest part?) carefully used icing spatula to get it off the bottom of pan. NP.
11. Crust edges a little soggy, but dried up after an hour. (not bad)
12. Best cheesecake my family had ever eaten! (shucks :) ) creamy on the inside, not too sweet, delicious alone or with the blueberry glaze prepared by my daughter! I am so exited.

text:
Turned out perfect! Cheesecake came out beautiful and no cracks. I cooked in a water bath and changed the crust a little. I crushed the 15 graham crackers and it seemed like a lot. I looked up a recipe for a basic cheesecake crust. Mix 1 1/2 graham cracker crumbs with 1/3 butter and 1/3 c sugar. Bake crust at 350 for 8 min and then fill with cheesecake batter and bake another hour. Perfect.

text:
I just made this recipe. And it is probably the best cheesecake I have ever tried. Tastes professional. I wasn't sure how many cups of graham cracker crumbs 15 cookies would be so I added melted butter to the crumbs and kept adding till the crust was As thick as I like it. I also added a splash of lemon juice though I can't taste it. I used 1% milk and low fat sour cream as that's all I had. For the vanilla I used vanilla bean paste. I followed the baking instructions but did not do a water bath. Cheesecake turned out amazing although there was a Crack which didn't matter as I cut up slices anyway. The cake tasted the best the next day. I have distributed this recipe to everyone who tried It. Thanks for an amazing recipe.

text:
11/27/15 I had to update my review.  I just made this cheese cake again and it was wonderful.  I made it exactly as the recipe called for and it was perfect yet again.  Don't be afraid of the reviews that bash the taste, the work, or how easy it is to crack.  Dive in, fear not and use a pan of water under your cheese cake.

This is the best cheesecake recipe I have tried.  I've made it about half a dozen times and it comes out perfect each and every time.  The trick is to stick a pan of water on a rack under the cheesecake to keep it from cracking.  Then just let it sit; don't move it, don't put it in the fridge just let it finishing cooling in the oven.  You won't be disappointed.  This has made me a hero in my house.   Thank you.

text:
Delicious! I followed he recipe exactly except two small exceptions. (1) I used the crust recipe on the back of the crushed graham cracker box (1-1/4 c. Crushed graham crackers, 1/4 c. Sugar, 5 T. Butter). (2) The whole reason I was making a cheesecake was to use some guava butter I made earlier that turned out a little runny. I poured half the batter into the pan, added a few spoonfuls of guava butter, poured the rest of the batter in the pan, drizzled a few more spoonfuls of guava butter, and then swirled with a knife. I followed the baking directions as they are printed and it turned out perfectly! Impressive presentation!

Display Name:
sarah245

city:

country:
None
text:
I think this is basically a great recipe for New York style Cheesecake. I made it the first time as instructed with the exception of adding sugar, cinnamon, and a dash of nutmeg to my crust mixture. I also let the ingredients come to room temperature, wrapped the bottom up the sides of my pan in aluminum foil, and baked in a water bath. I ended up with an overly brown top, no cracks, and too wet in the middle for my taste. I like a creamy, yet fairly firm texture. This is a recipe for those who like their NY Cheesecake's VERY creamy.

I made it again and changed a little more up. The first time, after adding the flour last I had noticed more lumps. This time I whisked about 2/3 cup of milk (instead of the 3/4)and the 1/4 cup of flour in a bowl before adding to the cream cheese/ sugar mixture. I added the eggs last after the rest of the ingredients, then detached the bowl and stirred a bit by hand. I baked the cake in the oven at 325 for 1 hour and let it cool inside for 3 hours. I opened the door and left it for another hour before storing in the fridge.
I ended up with a beautiful top, a creamy but firm texture,and enjoyed it more to my liking. I added these alterations to my comment, because several people tweak recipes to their liking and even though it changes some, it is so other people can read this and try it to appease a preferred taste or texture similar to mine. This recipe is great for tweaking or leaving as is.

OMG...this recipe is rediculously delicious!  I made the filling exactly as written, and filled 2 premade graham crusts.  I put both cheesecakes on large cookie sheet, poured approximately 4 cups water on bottom of pan to create a "water bath," baked 350 for 45 minutes, turned oven off and let sit for roughly 2 1/2 with door closed. userID:
13841865
Display Name:
Justin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making cheesecake, and it turned out amazing! No cracks, no sinking in the middle, etc. The consistency is perfect after you refrigerate it overnight. I was paranoid that I would mess up somewhere along the way because this was my first cheesecake, but thanks to the pointers that other people gave in their reviews on here, I had no issues. 
I did change a few things, however, based on other reviews. I used a water bath, which I assume is the reason mine didn't crack. I also completely left out the flour and milk, and it turned out amazing. It's like restaurant quality, seriously. I'm not sure what the point of the milk and flour is, because this cheesecake is incredible without them, and no other recipes I looked at called for either of those things. 
For the crust, again per other reviews, I used 1 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs (the kind in a can you can buy already crushed), 1/4 cup sugar, 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon, and 1/4 cup butter...turned out great, you can actually taste the flavor in it, unlike a lot of cheesecakes where the crust is pretty bland. I also changed the oven temperature to 325º and baked it for 1 hour and 25 minutes. 

PS: it's not necessary to cool it in the oven. I've always taken it out right away and cooled it on a wire rack and it's never cracked.

text:
I have been making this cheesecake recipe for more than a couple of years - and am just now submitting my 2 cents.  :)  This is an easy recipe with an end result that is sure to impress anyone you serve this to.  It is a dense yet creamy cheesecake that is delicious without any topping. If using a topping with this cake I would suggest using something simple and as close to fresh as possible - as opposed to a canned pie filling.  This recipe has never failed me following the recipe as is.  Ensure you leave this in the fridge for at least 6+ hours after taking out of the oven to allow it to settle & give you the best texture.  Bake it an hour before bedtime and leave it in the oven until you get up in the morning, then refrigerate.  It's ready to serve for dinner dessert. Nice....

city:

country:
None
text:
This was my first time making a cheesecake, and this recipe came out perfectly.  Based on others' reviews, I placed my baking dish in a larger pan and filled the large pan with hot water before baking.  I baked until the edges were just slightly brown and beginning to dull (the center was still shiny and wobbled when I hit the pan), and then I let the cheesecake cool for an hour before removing it to the counter for another half hour.  I didn't have any trouble with it falling or cracking.  

Make sure to bring the ingredients to room temperature before mixing.  One thing I would do differently is that I would combine the flour, sour cream, and vanilla before mixing into the other ingredients because I had trouble with the flour clumping but was concerned about overmixing.

text:
I used this recipe to make my first cheesecake ever.  There are so many recipes to choose from but I went with this one because of the great reviews.  I was not disappointed.  This recipe makes a nice and light cheesecake which is my preference for cheesecake.  This will be my go-to recipe for cheesecake from now on.

I had to bake my cheesecake for about 70 minutes.  I let it cool in the oven for only 30 minutes because I wanted to cool it down slowly but I didn't have the time to leave it in the oven for 5 hours because I needed my oven for other things.  I set the cheesecake on my counter and cooled it completely before putting it in the refrigerator.  I'm not sure leaving the cheesecake in the oven for such an extended period of time is necessary as my cheesecake never cracked.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent base recipe for a novice to even tweak if they wanted to, easy to make, good flavor, so here is the deal I made this last night it came out flawless baked in a water bath at 350 for 1 hour and I know its not in the instructions but making ANY cheese cake a water bath is an option for the baker especially if your oven has hot spots or is just crappy in general also you want to bake with no convection or air that will dry any top, that being said I am only writing this review because I went over some negative ones and I cracked up , one said I followed everything to the T and I don't know what happened it came out burned and cracked..lol well I don't know maybe you burned it? just saying ..lol.. you can almost not mess up the prep so any mistakes will fall on baking temps and time or oven, the water bath helps minimize that, get a larger tray put the 9" in it and use something to add HOT water in the open space between the trays as it sits on the rack mid oven , this will help you not getting any water in your cheese cake, fill up to about 1" from the top of the 9" tray so you can lift it out from the water without getting your hands wet with hot water, Don't attempt to pull the whole thing out water in and cake that's how you get water in your cake or serve the floor the whole thing, the water tray will be easy to handle when the 9" tray is out. Good Luck!!
