text:
Made this cheesecake yesterday.  I must have done several things incorrecly because it turned out to be a flub.  First, I've never made graham cracker crust without sugar but I did as the recipe said.  I never greased the springform pan for a cheescake before but I did as the recipe instructed.  Followed instructions and put in oven @ 350 for 1 hour.  The cheesecake had risen well past the top of the pan. DID NOT open oven at all.  After 1 hr turned oven off and left it in for the 5 hours stated.  Turned oven light on several times to "peek" and saw the cake had "deflated".  At the end of 5 hours i took it out.  The entire center had sunk in and top had a burned look to it.  I just had to taste it as it really didn't look great.  Had more of a custard texture than a cheesecake texture.  I'm hoping that being refrigerated will help the texture, but nothing will help the appearance.  Taste was so-so. With all the rave reviews I'm assuming I must have done several things wrong. This was not my first cheesecake but it was the first one I had problems with.  Have a can of cherry pie filling that I hope will help with looks at least.

text:
Great recipe! I love to bake but have never tried making a cheesecake before. I decided to make this recipe for a Valentine's Day family dinner. Everyone loved it....my brother-in-law's sister makes cheesecakes and other desserts for catered events and he said my cheesecake rivaled even her best cheesecakes. I followed the advice of other reviewers and made sure all of the ingredients were room temperature. I also baked the cake for about fifty minutes (with a water bath) and then turned off the oven and let it sit for about three hours. I also recommend sifting the flour because it was a pain to get all of the lumps out when mixing. Amazing recipe that I know I will make again soon!

text:
This was my first time ever making a cheesecake.  After reading the review I was tempted to change the recipe, but I decided to make it as is, and I am happy I did. I did however change the crust recipe by adding cinnamon and sugar to the graham cracker crumbs.  I don't own a spring form pan so I used a 9x9 glass dish. I also halved the recipe becasue I only had 2 packages of cream cheese.  I baked it in the oven on 325 with a dish full of water on the shelf below.  I only allowed it to cool in the oven for about 1 1/2 hours then put it in the fridge.  I was plesantly surprised at the flavor and texture.  I will definately be making this again!

text:
This was an absolute hit. Everyone was raving about it - even days later! I made it exactly as directed, only to make it gluten-free, I substituted gluten-free cookies for the crust and used sweet rice flour in place of the all-purpose flour. I also used skim milk and it still turned out delicious. I did not use a water bath, and it still turned out perfect, so don't go through the trouble! A word of warning though, this cake rises like crazy! It was almost touching the top of my oven by the time I went to turn the oven off. Don't worry though, it sinks back down to normal as it cools. It comes out very thick and creamy. Don't look any further - this is it!!! Thanks for the great recipe, Taliesen!

text:
So this was my first attempt EVER at a cheesecake. It was INCREDIBLE! No cracks, no flops....just great tasting cheesecake.  

I followed the direct pretty darn close. I was really worried I would mess it up. Especially after reading all the comments about cracking. There was a lot of conflicting advice. Mixing: I used a hand mixer. At every step I mixed until just smooth. Baking: This recipe said nothing about a water bath. My Mom and the "Cheesecake basics" both mentioned this. This is my only deviation from the instructions, turns out I did it wrong anyway. I placed the cheesecake pan in a shallow water bath and used cold water. It is supposed to be deep and hot water. But I guess it didn't make a difference. 

I will say in the future, I may modify the crust as I found it a little plain. The cheesecake did brown a little on top, but not burned.

text:
After two rounds of making this, I finally got the recipe to work... however there should be a specified time to chill in the refrigerator.  That time being at least 12 hours.

I got up early and made the first batch yesterday morning.  Did the recipe as directed.  After it set in the oven for about 6 hours, the cheesecake had cracked.  So I went ahead and placed it in the refrigerator.  After about 3 1/2 - 4 hours of chilling in the refrigerator, I served it.  It was the most disgusting cheesecake I'd ever had.  It was fluffy.  :(

So, I put the left overs back in the fridge and started making a 2nd batch.  I baked it an hour but inserted it directly into the fridge after baking.  I checked on it after 5 hours and it seemed fluffy, so I waited until this morning. 

After a total of 12 hours in the refrigerator, this cheesecake is absolutely delicious!   And it didn't crack!

Now, regarding the first cheesecake... since I'd let the leftovers set over night, it seems to have set well too.  Not as good as the 2nd batch, but it isn't as fluffy anymore!  

So I say whether you keep it in the oven or not is your call.  Should you make this recipe, do it the day before, that way it will have the right amount of time to set while chilling in the fridge.

Thank you Taliesen for the great recipe!  :)

If you follow this recipe exactly, your cheesecake will be perfect! I have made this 5 times in the past few weeks and they have all been flawless. I used a water bath with all of them, and none cracked. I recommend leaving the cheesecake in the oven for the full 6 hours after cooking, then place it in the freezer for an hour or 2; it really helps when it's time to remove it from the pan. I have received so many compliments on how tasty the cake is, and I have never attempted a cheesecake before :)

text:
I make this cheescake frequently and for the longest I always over mixed. To avoid this I have modified the recipe. I mix the sugar, cream cheese and flour with the mixer and add the milk, sour cream, and vanilla with a spoon and incorporate the eggs one at a time last. Also I am kinda lazy so I poor about a cup or 2 of water in the bottom of the oven in lieu of the watter bath because I don't have a pan large enough to do the water bath and only have one rack in my oven. I also add strawberry syrup and swirl it into the batter as you would a marble cake. This is kinda sweet so I modify by only using 1 cup of sugar for balance. Also I use vanilla wafers instead of graham crackers. De-lish!

Display Name:
foodiefoodie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The cheesecake comes out creamy, fluffy and light. If you use a 9 inch springform baking pan for this recipe, the cheesecake turns out really fancy looking, twice as thick and twice as yum. I didn’t have one handy, so I had to make two smaller ones (oreo and graham crackers).

The key to having it not crack is creating a water bath for your cheesecake. The steam from the water rises and keeps the bulk of your cheesecake from separating/cracking because of the moistness. Another key is to fold in the eggs. I used a mixer to mix all the ingredients first. Then, I folded in the four eggs. If you over beat the eggs, your mix becomes bubbly and will rise in your batter while baking and inevitably crack. But, if it turns out ugly—you put strawberries on and no one knows the difference!

country:
None
text:
I have never had a cheesecake turn out this perfectly! I followed the suggested tips (tinfoil wrap, waterbath, greasing the pan and gently mixing the batter) and its level, smooth, uncracked and absolultey beautiful.

-February 2012  

I made this again and AGAIN it turned out perfect. This time I placed a piece of parchment paper on the bottom for easy release (and because I was leaving the cake behind and taking the pan with me when I left a party), if you use bakers tape to seal the parchment to the sides of the pan it helps prevent water from leaking in. Also, a triple layer of foil, taped up the sides is an added layer of protection. Make sure you grease the sides well with butter! This helps prevent cracking as the cake cools and the water bath is essential. I let the cake cool for about 5 minutes longer than this recipe calls for because last time the center was a little soft. It turned out perfect! Don't open the door once the hour/ 5-10 minute baking time is up! Let it cool completely and then store in the fridge. This was divine. Add spices to the crust to give it a little oopmf. I tossed in brown sugar and cinnamon. It was a total hit

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best recipe for cheesecake EVER! If followed correctly, you will end up with restaurant quality tasting cheesecake. Many that have tried it said it was better than Cheesecake Factory cheesecake! I followed a review and made the graham cracker crust with 1.5c graham crackers, 1/4 cup both sugar and butter and 1/2 tsp cinnamon, this crust is amazing! After three tries, I finally figured out how to avoid the dreaded crack - definitely use a water bath (i used a large roasting pan and filled it with hot water 1/3 way up the springform, and wrapped the springform with foil to avoid water seeping in) and bake it for a longer time at a lower temperature (i did about 1.5 hours at 330 degrees, but adjust time to avoid the browning of the top, i'd keep watch after an hour and ten minutes) - finally, a picture perfect cheesecake!

text:
This was my first attempt at cheesecake making and I must say that I am very pleased with the results.  My cheesecake came out beautifully, with no cracks.  I baked it at 325 for 55 minutes then shut off the oven and let it sit for 4 hours before refrigerating.  I tried to mix all the ingredients by hand but found out that it was almost impossible to cream the sugar and cream cheese to a smooth consistancy, even with room temperature ingredients.  Next time I will use an electric mixer to cream the sugar and cream cheese and hand mix the remaining ingredients.  This recipe is a keeper for me!!

text:
I've made this cheesecake twice. The first time, I added the vanilla & flour at the end as the directions say & the vanilla stuck to the flour & it all clumped up in little balls. The texture of the cake was grainy. The second time, I added the vanilla to the milk then I added the flour last, but slowly and I made sure to sift it first. The texture was perfect!!! I also changed the crust to be 2 cups of Nilla wafers (measured before crushing) and 4 tbsp butter. It was SO delish! Everyone who tried it loved it and one person even asked me to make one for his mom. Amazing recipe, rivals Juniors!!!

userID:
6185066
Display Name:
jenny
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am so excited!  This cheesecake turned out PERFECTLY.  I have NEVER been able to make a cheesecake without it cracking AND sinking -- this one was beautiful enough to sell, and it tasted superb!    I did read all of the tips, and they really helped.   I made the crust on the back of the graham cracker crumbs box, only because I didn't want to deal with crushing graham crackers.  This was very easy.  I pressed it into the springform pan and baked it for 10 minutes for 350.  I prepared the cheesecake.  I mixed the cream cheese and sugar, but was so afraid of over-mixing, that I may not have made it creamy enough, because when I added the milk, at which point I switched to hand-mixing, there were some lumps.  I couldn't get them out, and I wasn't sure which was worse -- some small lumps (would they even out during baking??), or overmixing.  Well, I took a risk, dumped the whole thing into my vitamix blender and set it on high for about 30 seconds.  I poured it back into my mixing bowl and it was smooth as can be.  I hand-mixed the rest.  To be cautious, I let the batter sit for about 10 minutes, and I raised the bowl and dropped it a few times to release any air bubbles.  I didn't notice any, so who knows if this helped?  I placed the springform pan into an oven bag (turkey bag), rolled down the sides of the bag, then placed the whole thing in a larger roasting pan, which I filled with 2 inches of water.  I baked it for one hour at 350, then turned the oven off and waited.

userID:
3012817
Display Name:
Jen914

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first cheesecake and I decided to change nothing at all (at least not anything that would make a significant outcome in the taste of the overall cheesecake recipe). Although the cheesecake wasn't AS light as I like my cheesecake, (just my personal preference) it was  delish! I just had my first slice and loved it. The only things I did differently from the recipe is that I used a pre-made graham cracker crust pie shell instead of a spring-form pan. If you are planning to do this like I did, then HALF the recipe. I'm glad I decided to do that (due to height difference) because even when I halved it to 6 servings and filled up the graham cracker pie crust, there was still some filling left over! Using the graham cracker shell I baked mine for 50 minutes to be safe not to overbake it and left it in the oven for about 4 hours before placing in the fridge and mine did not crack at all (although since I made the cake for myself I wouldn't give a rats behind if it did anyways as long as it tasted good!) But anyways next time I think I will just buy graham crackers instead so I will be able to make about 3-4 mini cheesecakes with the left over filling. Also I substituted 1/4th a teaspoon of the vanilla ext. for almond extract AND for a little variety I swirled 2 tablespoons of red raspberry preserves into half of the cake. The pie crust thing is genius for those on a budget and/or diet. Half of the ingredients used, about half the calories, same 1 slice of cheesecake.

text:
I have made this cheesecake at least 50 times, every time comes out perfect, it is the best cheesecake you can eat including restaurants. Everyone who tasted always asked me to do again over and over. Follow the instructions and there shouldn't be any problem.  Make sure your ingredients are at room temperature. Definitely add the eggs one at a time otherwise your cheesecake won't be white. When done with mixing hit the bowl to the table a few times in order to get rid of the lumps. When ready to put into the oven, place the springform into another bigger pan full of water to avoid cracks. I genereally use sweetener instead of sugar and add one teaspoon of cinnamon and 2 tablespoons of sugar (sweetener) to the base, in order to sweeten the digestive biscuits I use. I use creme fraische instead and Philadelphia lights.

userID:

Display Name:
cookin fool

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't made a lot of cheesecakes in general, but this is by far the best recipe i have run across. The consistency is heavenly; creamy, thick, and the perfect balance of cream cheese and sugar. The graham cracker crust is what makes it for me in almost any cheesecake. I varied the crust a little bit by adding some striped chocolate shortbread cookies. I also made my crust thicker by doubling the amounts suggested in the recipe.  When i mixed up the cheesecake batter I ended up with an excess amount of batter which i used to make mini cheesecake cupcakes. They were perfect! I simply pulled out a cupcake pan, filled it with cupcake wrappers, put a layer of crust, then filled it 3/4 full with the batter. Baked it for 15 min or until they were firm, but still a little jiggly in the middle.  When making the cheesecake I aslo used a water bath as some others suggested. I would definitely reccomend this. It seemed to even out the baking of the cheesecake. Also, letting the cheesecake cool in the oven after baking allowed it to cool evenly and prevented any cracking. All in all, this was a PERFECT cheesecake! I will definitely use this recipe again!

text:
I used more butter to get the crust to stick together a bit better.  I used a bit more crackers than they said and a larger pan.  Next time I will be more careful to add the flour separately from the vanilla and sour cream because some of the vanilla got with flour and made clumps - would be easier to make smooth that way.  as other reviewers said that to stop it from cracking, don't overbeat, grease the sides of the springform very thoroughly, put a dish with water in the oven with it, and leave it in the oven for a long time, then out on the counter for a long time, before putting in fridge, so the cooling is very slow.  - did all these things and it didn't crack at all, looked and tasted very nice :)

text:
I saved this recipe a few years ago and decided to finally make it over the weekend for my husband's birthday. All I can say is this was the easiest, most delicious cheesecake I've ever made. My husband, who isn't very big on sweets, thought it was absolutely delicious. No cracking, just perfect!!!! I highly recommend this cheesecake recipe. If I could give it 10 stars I would!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/392799.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake came out close to perfection. For some, it just might be the perfect cheesecake since the texture was light, fluffy, and creamy. The taste however wasn't as rich as I would like it. The sour cream left a slight aftertaste. The cake took 1 1/2 hr to bake which the cheesecake article on this site said was correct. The cake came out crackless because I used a waterbath and really smooth with a nice slightly browned top. Crust was a little soggy but I didn't care too much for it. Instead of leaving the cake in the oven for 5 hours, I just turned off the heat after baking, left the oven door slightly ajarred, and let the cake rest for half an hour. This allowed enough time for the cheesecake to adjust to room temperature without cracking. After the half hour in the oven, cool the cheesecake completely to room temperature, about 2 hours, and then chill overnight.

Update* After a few days the cheesecake's vanilla taste was more apparent and the sour cream aftertaste disappeared. It's possible that the flavors in the cake was more evenly distributed after being left in the fridge for a few days. I personally liked the results.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this cheesecake as a dessert side for a fondue dinner party, and it was a big hit.  It was my very first cheesecake, so I was extremely nervous about my abilities to properly make one, but everyone raved about it and ate their full slices (even after completely gorging ourselves on meat fondue.)  I did wind up with one small crack, though that was no fault of the recipe, but a fault of my own.  Since I was completely new to making cheesecake, I didn't let the cream cheese soften enough, and therefore had to overbeat the batter in order to get rid of the lumps.  I'd therefore advise any one making this recipe to spend the time to allow the cream cheese to reach room temperature.  Even despite my overbeating, however, I still only had one tiny crack, which was a better result than I expected.  I added a small basin of water in a pyrex dish underneath the cheesecake to also help eliminate cracking.  In the future, I'd maybe eliminate the four from the recipe, in order to make the cheesecake a bit creamier.  Oh, FYI, my boyfriend made a wonderful strawberry topping by mixing strawberries with 1/3 cup sugar in a saucepan and whisking it.  Perfect!

text:
With all the glorious reviews, I was expecting something much more incredible. I really wasn't impressed with this cheesecake...I don't know why, but it came out with a sort of light, fluffy texture that I didn't care for. On the other hand, my brother, who doesn't care for cheesecake, really loved this one. I also had a problem with the recipe...the 15 graham crackers made no sense. I crushed up 15 whole sheets, and it was way too much...I think it means 15 half sheets. And there isn't enough butter either...2 tbs. isn't enough to hold it together. I did make one change to the recipe...I used one package of Neufchatel cheese (1/3 less fat, but tastes/works the same) instead of one of the packages of full fat cream cheese. I do this all the time with other cheesecakes, and it has never affected them. Also, I was in a hurry and had to bake a cake after the cheesecake, so I had to move the baked cheesecake to the top oven (I have a double oven) to cool for 6 hours. The cheesecake cracked, of course, which is what I expected to happen. But what else could I do? Thanks for sharing the recipe, but I won't be making this again. Unless my brother requests it, of course :)

text:
I made this cheesecake for Thanksgiving this year. I follow the recipe to a T and I did bake in a water bath. My ingredients were at room temp when I started. I wrapped the springform pan w/ two layers of heavy duty foil and set it down in my roasting pan and added water 1/2 way up the pan. I had to bake a little longer than the the hour the recipe indicated because after one hour the cheesecake was a little bit wobbly in the center. I baked for abour 10-15 minutes longer and turned the oven off and let it cool overnight in the oven. I then wrapped in celophane and put it in the refrigerator in the morning. It was delicious. I let guests choose a homemade strawberry topping I made from this site or a caramel topping that I purchased from the store w/ toasted pecans. Either of toppings went well with this. I will definitely make this again.

text:
This is a really awsome recipe! I did have to solve a few common problems with cheesecake baking . I had all of the usual problems like cracking and and lumpy cheesecakes so here is how i made a PERFECT cheese cake. I started with preheating the oven AND the waterbath. For a waterbath i just used a turkey roaster half fill with water on the center shelf of the oven. Despite having a really nice springform pan mine is not watertight so i used a turkey roasting bag. I just placed the pan in the bottom of the turkey bag and tied 100%cotton twine around the lip of the pan to hold the bag in place and keep it from sliping. I just sniped off the extra bag about 1 1/2 inches above the lip of the pan.I brought all of my ingredients to room temp.I put cream chese in the microwave for about 15 sec a block and put the eggs in a bowl of warm water for a few min till they were room temp.I also only used a mixer to mix the creamcheese and sugar after that i used a wisk and mixed everything else by hand so that i didnt incorporate air in the mixing(that is really importaint!)I baked as directed and then without opening the door i just turned off the oven and let it cool about 5 hours. I removed the cake from the oven and cut the twine to remove the bag. I placed the cake in the fridge over night and it came out like a professional cheesecake.I also used a thin fishing line to cut the slices so it came out perfect like you see at a fancy restruant!!! It was so nice i have made dozens of them

text:
I followed this recipe exactly. When I mean exactly I mean I followed this recipe to a T. The recipe was very vague in describing both the ingredients and the direction for making this cheesecake. 15 graham crackers??? (does that mean one whole graham cracker with 4 sections counted as one or does that mean the one graham cracker with 4 sections counted as 4 graham crackers.) Also they should emphasis how we should mix all the ingredients. Whether in an electric mixer or by hand. Also when I poured my mixture on to the crust, some of the graham cracker pieces ended up floating to the top of the mixture which ended up to be a huge disaster, but I still kept going. After about 50 minutes, I ended up turning off the oven because the cheesecake was almost burnt. I went to go check up on it after 2 hours and I end up seeing so many cracks and the crust caved in.I hate to rate this recipe so low, but I had huge expectations for this recipe because of such great ratings, but I was not satisfied at all. Word of advice, if this is your first time making cheesecake I would try finding a different recipe that provides more information than this recipe.

text:
Awesome cheesecake recipes.  It was my first time making one and I followed the ratings of others.  If followed the recipe to the T, but only cooled it in the fridge for about 3 hours.  It was not totally settled in the middle, but the taste was incredible.    I've made an adjustment to the water bath method that I found at another website...  You can use a Reynolds Oven Bag (used for baking turkeys) instead of foil and a 'oven proof' rubber band (Architec SCBMP 2-Inch Stretch Cooking Band, Multicolor, 25-Package) found at Bed Bath and Beyond.  I rolled the bag up enough to just cover the springfoam pan and put the rubberband around the bag and place it in the pan of water.  No leakage and the bag and rubberband is reusable.  I will certainly make this again.  Thanks Chantal!

text:
I have never made cheesecake before until this recipe came along. It didn't crack! The only problem I had was I found the crust wasnt very solid.  Also, the top came out a little brown. I used a water bath and did not overmix the batter. 1/30/11 update: I have made this cheesecake over half a dozen times now and it never fails to impress. However, I have given up on the crust. This last time I made it I used an Oreo cookie crust: 2.5 cups of finely crushed Oreo cookies (centers removed), 1/3 cup white sugar, 5 tbsp melted butter, 1/8 tsp salt.  Mixed well and pressed into springform pan making sure to cover about 1-2 inches along the sides as well. I baked it at 325 instead of 350 and it was just perfect. Everybody ooh'd and ah'd telling me I had taken this cheesecake to a whole new level!

text:
Thank You!  I would be considered a "beginner" in the cheesecake world, and this turned out wonderfully for me!  Creamy, no cracks, not dry.  I used a waterbath, and baked it for 60 minutes and shut the oven off, didn't even check it, and it was perfect.  The only thing that happened (which was my fault, so don't do this!) was I let it sit in the oven for 3 hours, not 4-6, and I put it in the refrigerator, uncovered right then.  I think it was still too warm, and it caused condensation to form inside the mold and made the crust soggy.  So make sure to wait until it is COMPLETELY cool before refrigerating.  Then wait 12-24 hours to cut it.  I know it's hard to have that much patience, but it's worth it!  Thank you so much for all the helpful hints everyone!

This cheescake turned out to be a huge hit, everyone loved it. When I made the cheesecake I did cheat a little bit. I used a pre-made ready graham cracker crust, and thus had to change the serving size to 8. I also added some carmel topping into the cream cheese mixture, making it yummy! I also only baked it for 45 minutes and followed the other reviews doing the water bath and shutting oven off so it didn't crack. When I was ready to serve it I put a little carmel topping making it even better! I will be making this again!

SteveH

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe. The hints to avoid to avoid cracking, which is a problem I've had in the past, were exceptionally helpful. Wanting to remove as much air as I could I used a strong wooden spoon to hand mix the room-temperature ingredients in a large heavy ceramic bowl. (It required patience and determination, with occasional rest periods.)  After blending it all, I bounced the bowl on a thick cutting board and watched numerous bubbles pop as they rose to the surface. Following the rest of the instructions produced a professionally looking cheesecake.  I had extra batter left over because I'd proportionally upped the ingredients, which I’d planned to use to make enough for fifteen servings, instead of the 12 noted in the recipe. As it turned out, my springform pan wouldn't hold it. So I poured the rest in a paper lined cupcake tin. Being smaller they cooked much faster. When they browned on top I knew I had to pull them out even knowing they would collapse. I figured they'd make OK failures for me to eat as snacks. Sure enough, they did collapse but, being fresh fruit season, I realized that those depressions would make great places to stuff some crushed or halved fruit. Using strawberries for some and mashed papaya for the others, they made super bite sized finger desserts.  All goes to show that good things can even come from an ill-designed experiment by a novice baker!

text:
We love this cheesecake.We did let everything get to room temp before we began combining the ingredients. We also added some more butter to the crust so it would press nicely. We also used a water bath on the rack below the cake. We sprayed the inside of the pan with cooking spray. It came out great! We baked it at night and left it in the oven over night after baking it for one hour (we did not touch the oven door)! We are very pleased with this cheesecake. We will make it again.

text:
OMG! I'm 15 and i like to cook. I tried this recipe aqa couple times brfore and the cake cracked and it browned on the edges. That was because my dad was being too cheap to buy a springform pan. We used ghram cracker pie crusts- eww! this time i got my mom to buy a springform pan and it came out perfectly.  Helpful tips: Make sure the cream cheese and sugar is completly mixed. Not grainy., It does not matter how long you cream these two. Add the other stuff and mix that with a spoon. When adding the eggs, do not use electric beater, the eggs hold air which is bad for cheesecake. And lastly, after everything is mixed i add a tablespoon of lemon juice to make it a little tangy! This recipe is great and i will make this again!!!

The cheesecake this recipe produces is simply amazing. It is creamy, rich and flavorful. My husband who normally turns his nose up to this dessert raved about how delicious this cheesecake is. The recipe is so easy to follow.  I gave my sister and her husband some of the cheesecake (in an attempt to get it out of the house; I would eat all of it! It is just that good!) and he claimed it is "the cheesecake that will change your life."  The first two I made didn't crack, but every one after those have been getting large "Y" cracks in the center.  I greased the sides, put a pan of water underneath the cake, and added a teaspoon of cornstarch.  I'm guessing that maybe I over mixed the batter.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe last weekend to make my first ever real cheesecake.  It turned out fabulous- very dense, creamy and smooth texture.  I was nervous about over mixing as I used my stand mixer- but it turned out perfectly.  Tips I used-  1.  reduced flour to 2 tbs and mixed it with the sugar before adding to the cream cheese mixture (to avoid clumps) 2.  Put pan of water on the rack below the cheesecake when cooking (modified water bath) 3.  Baked for one hour as instructed and cooled in over for 5 more- didn't open the door at all!    Result- no crackes, perfectly cooked cheesecake.  I am trying a lemon version today- addint 2 tbs lemon juice and 1.5tbs grated lemon peal.  Using Kraft animal crackers for crust and blind baking crust first so it is crispier.

Display Name:
chickennoodles

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake is to die for!  As I was mixing my ingredients, I realized I made a huge mistake.  I did not know it was a baked cheesecake and I wasn't planning on using a 9" pan.  I freaked out about the oven temp and the amount of time to bake the cheesecakes. However, it turned out far better than EXCELLENT!  I cut the ingredients into halves. and I made 18 cupcake cheesecakes!!  I used 2 pkgs LIGHT philly cream cheese and used more butter than it called for the crust. I turned the oven down to 320 F and baked it for 25-30 MINUTES.  I also added the WATER BATH  and lightly greased the sides of the muffin cups and my cheesecakes did not crack at all.  Greasing is important because bits of cheesecake will stick to the side when you peel the paper muffin cups off. Also, I didn't wait to cool it down in the oven for an hour and however many hours out of the oven because I really wanted to eat it so I took it out and straight into the fridge.   To finish, I used "Supreme Strawberry Topping" from Allrecipes to top it off.  It was SOOOOOO good.  I will be making this again and again and again. Thank you for this WONDERFUL recipe.

text:
USE THE WATER BATH!  I had never made a cheesecake before so I made this one based on the high rating.  Made the first one following the recipe to the letter, not using a water bath.  Amazing taste, but it had a huge crack, and the edge was browned all around.  Rave reviews from those that tried some!  Made a second today, modified the crust a bit, using a few more crackers, 5 TBSP butter, some cinnamon, and a hint of ginger.  I used the water bath method, and this one looks beautiful!  Can't wait to try it out tomorrow!  Next, I'm going to be looking for some toppings to make, and maybe some things to swirl into the next one I make...

None
text:
This is an awesome recipe.  I baked it 3 times during the holiday season.  From my experience baking Cheesecakes here are the most needed tips for a perfect cheesecake.
1.  Place the springform pan in a water bath while baking to prevent cracking.
2.  After placing the cheesecake mixture in the pan, before baking, let it sit on the kitchen counter for 15 minutes.  Any air bubbles caused by overmixing will rise to the top of the mixture.  Prick them with a fork to remove them.
3.  DO NOT OPEN THE OVEN WHILE BAKING.  Put the cheesecake in the oven and don't even think of opening the oven door for several more hours.
Bake and cool as directed and the cheesecake will be ready to devour in about 24 hours!

text:
Wow!  The taste of this cake is unreal!  In all fairness mine cracked.  I did use a water bath but I didn't properly grease the sides of the springform pan.  I think to get a crack-free cake takes practice, because it totally depends on what oven you're using and room temperature.  That said I followed the recipe exactly and got a massive 10' cake!!!  Everybody said it was the best cake ever.  It's thick, dense and the taste is the perfect combination of creamy semi-sweet cheese.  One sliver will fill you up if you're hungry, because it's that dense (at least it did for me).  I will be definitely experimenting with this recipe in the future to get crack-free cake, but in the mean time slapping some topping on works great!!!!  I wish I could rate it more then 5 stars.

text:
100% the best! I made this as a surprise wedding cake for my cheesecake-loving brother and sister in law. They raved more about this cheesecake than any other desert I have ever seen them eat. This turned out PERFECT, not a single crack, no bubbles, it cut, came out and held together perfectly. I made a couple slight changes based on other reviews. I baked the crust for about 15 min. and also added some sugar and increased the butter to 1/2 cup, which made a perfect crust. Also reduced the flour to 2 heaping Tblsp. I baked at 325 for 50 minutes, then reduced to 250 for another 20-30 min, cooled in the oven for over an hour, removed to cooling rack, covered for bit, then uncovered, then finally to the fridge about 2 hours after it was done baking. This made a perfect cheesecake- no browning on top, perfectly set, no cracks, and did not fall apart once cut and served.

text:
This wasn't the first cheesecake I made, but what a perfect cheesecake! My family doesn't like to eat things that are too sweet, so I halved the sugar and it's still sweet. It's best if you use the cream cheese when it's at room temperature to prevent over-beating and creating air bubbles in the batter. I bake this in a 9 inch springfoam pan with a water bath to evenly distribute the heat, let it cool with the oven closed, and it has no ugly cracks on the top of the cheesecake. The center will be a little jiggly when you take it out, but that's normal. The worst thing about this recipe is the WAIT - like every cheesecake, it has to firm up, which is torture when it looks so good. Let it set in the fridge overnight and it will be dense, rich and delicious!

text:
This is a fantastic recipe! I have made it twice now for special occasions and everyone loves it! Plus it impresses even the experienced cooks in the family that you can make a homemade cheesecake. This is an easy recipe and turns out so delicious! For the crust, I use 1 1/2 cups crushed graham crackers, 1/4 cup melted butter, 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon & 1/4 cup sugar. The cinnamon just adds a little extra flavor that I like. Make sure your ingredients are at room temperature. I use a hand mixer for the cream cheese and sugar, but then switch to a wooden spoon for the rest of the mixing. After baking for 1 hour, I run a greased knife around the edges of the pan so it won't stick, turn off the oven and leave it in the oven overnight to cool. Then just keep in the fridge until ready to serve. We love this one. Thank you for the recipe!

text:
This was my first attempt at cheesecake -was way easier than I expected.  I didn't do a water bath as I wanted to give the original recipe a chance - although I did use a different graham cracker crumb crust (with the cinnamon and sugar) as recommended in the most helpful tips.  I sprayed the sides with butter flavored Pam - I did get a few cracks but it didn't sink.  My sides were not stuck to the pan so I don't think running the knife around would have prevented the crack.  I know I didn't overbeat either.  I'm pretty sure if I would have done the water bath I wouldn't have had the cracks.  As for taste, I am so not a cheesecake person and even I enjoyed it (topped with cherry pie filling).  I used all light ingredients and you never would have known.  Will definitely use this recipe again when I need a cheescake. (BTW - I almost chickened out and bought one instead...they were a quarter the size that this one was - for the ease of making this recipe, it would not have been worth it to purchase a store bought one!)  Update:  This is even better the next day.  I for sure would make this a day ahead - especially since you have to let it sit in the oven so long, it takes a long time to cool off and even more time to chill in the fridge.  If you're using cherry pie filling as a topping, one can isn't quite enough as the the cheesecake is thick.  I'm still getting rave reviews the next day.  An impressive recipe (that I would keep as your little secret! ;)

PERFECT, PERFECT, PERFECT! After reading other reviews, this is what I did. All ingredients were at room temp. I used 1 1/2 cups of cinnamon graham crackers with 1/4 butter for the crust. Greased the pan all the way up sides. I decreased the flour to 2 tbsp, and used a hot water bath. Baked for 1 hour at 325* then let it sit in the oven for 5 hours. Then moved to the fridge. Not one crack, and no browning. I am at high altitude and it turned out beautiful! My other recipe... gone to the trash!

text:
This is by far the best cheesecake I've tried from this site. It was perfect, smooth, no cracks,..... mmmmmmm, delicious!! As others said, place the pan in a water bath, and do not open the oven during the process, this way you avoid all those annoying cracks. Also don't overcook it, 60 min is just right, and leave the cake in the oven. I think it's not a problem if your ingredients are not at room temperature (at least it wasn't for me: the cheese, sour cream, eggs, milk...were very cold), and overbeating the batter only causes little air bubbles, not cracks! As a result of overbeating the batter, my cheesecake ended up with little tiny insignificant bubbles I could barely see.
Thanx for this recipe, it's a keeper!

text:
When ever I decide to make a recipe from this website I always read reviews first. Reviews add helpful tips. So, the night before I made this cheesecake I read alot of the reviews. I got up in the morning and pulled everything I needed out of the fridge so that it would all be at room temp. I went about my morning cleaning and then came back to make the cheesecake. Excited by all of the reviews I really wanted to like this cheesecake. These are the problems I had 1.) Not enough butter for the graham crackers, had to add alot more. 2.)Way to much batter. I had to reread the recipe to make sure it called for a 9in. pan and not a 10in. pan. I filled mine to the top and still had about a 1/4 or more of the batter left in my mixing bowl. 3.) Started cooking wonderfully, then about 40 minutes into cooking it rised about 2in. over the pan and began to crack everywhere. Then the sides all fell off onto the bottom of my oven. Maybe this is my fault for not using a water bath?
After cooking 1 hour I turned the oven off and left it in the oven for 2 hours. There is something about leaving a milk based product in the oven for 5-6 hours that doesn't sit right with me. I then placed it in the fridge for 3 hours. After dinner my cheesecake loving husband couldn't wait to try this cheesecake. The whole thing was mushy, it did not have the texture of a cheesecake. It was no where near done, but yet very brown all over. After trashing this cheesecake I came to the conclusion that this is more
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-03-14T15:42:24.937

2525863
Display Name:
Kevin

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can assure you, this recipe will yield a tasty result. I followed the recipe to a "T" -- alright, I've already lied! I used "Half and half" rather than milk. For the crust, I used 1 to 2 cups graham cracker crumbs, combined with 4 tablespoons of melted butter and 1/4 cup sugar. It made a lot of crust, so I threw some away... then I realized I had too little of a crust! Anyway, I didn't, but I would suggest baking the crust for about 5 or 10 minutes first. As for the cheesecake, I beat it by hand with a wooden spoon after the initial cream cheese/sugar beating. This was rather exhausting and my texture still ended up rather funny (Maybe it's the flour?), but it is definitely acceptable. This made A LOT of filling for my 9" Springform Pan... it was nearly overflowing, definitely maximized space. I don't have a deep baking dish, so I place a casserole dish full of boiling water into the oven for my "mock" waterbath, I baked it at 325 (Lower temp than what it calls for) for 1 hour, then shut the oven off and left it in there for about 4 hours before putting it in the fridge. It did not crack at all, and the top only had the slightest lightest brown color-- quite pretty. Eat it plain, or with some cherry topping to mix it up! I think the tangy flavor would go well with some citrus-- I'm going to try combining lemons and/or limes with it next time.

city:

country:

text:
Excellent flavor and texture!!  Wouldn't be able to tell the difference between this or a bakery bought cheesecake.  I halved the cream cheese mixture, just because I didn't have enough cream cheese for the full recipe.  Still delicious, just a shorter cake.  I also used(room temp.): 1/3 less fat cream cheese, fat free sour cream, 1% milk, the cinnamon crust recipe(per another review).  I only used my mixer for the cream cheese and sugar and then used a wooden spoon to mix the rest of the ingredients. I baked at 325 for an hour with a pan of water on the rack underneath.  Took sharp knife around edge of cheesecake after the hour (I had sprayed my pan with cooking spray), then left in closed oven for about 2 1/2 hours, then refrigerated. After the hour, there were a few very small cracks along the edge of the cake, but after leaving it in the oven the 2 1/2 hours, they had disappeared.  I had sprinkled some chocolate chips over the top of half of the cheesecake and there were a few small cracks by the chips, but not bad.  I will definitely make again and my husband(the real cheesecake lover) wants me to try the full recipe for the taller cake.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

Very good cheesecake and very simple. I cut the recipe in half and made it in a premade graham cracker crusts from the grocery store. I don't have a springform pan so I had to improvise. It turned out excellent. I did not do the water bath as some suggested. I just put it in the oven at 350 for 40 mins then turned the oven off and left it for 2 hours. Then I stuck it in the fridge overnight and I didn't get any cracks. We had some for breakfast this morning with our coffee and it was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake was fantastic!  I did make a few modifications to the recipe after reading the reviews. I baked it in a water bath as suggested by other reviewers and it worked perfectly. I also sprayed the bottom and sides of my springform pan with Pam before adding the crust and cheesecake batter. It pulled apart from the sides super easy and didn't crack even a little bit.  I decreased the flour to 2 tbsp and hand mixed the ingredients after I blended the cream cheese and sugar together. I also added about a 1/4 cup of sugar to the crust and about 2 more tbsp of butter to the crust mixture. It was sooo good!  I do have a couple of things I would do differently next time. I would recommend mixing each ingredient into the mixture individually. I put my flour and vanilla in at the same time and the vanilla clumped with the flour, so there were little spots of vanilla in the mixture. I am also going to use less vanilla next time, like only about 1 teaspoon instead of a tablespoon.  The texture of this cheesecake was fabulous! I let it sit in the oven overnight because I baked it in the evening. I then refrigerated it all day before we finally cut into it.  It really turned out GREAT. And the flavors seem to get better each day as the cheesecake ages.  Thank you so much for the recipe!!!

text:
wow. wow. wow. wow. WOW.

this was my first attempt in making cheesecake and i was totally blown away at the end result! i was really afraid of overbeating the cream cheese, so i beat the cream cheese with a beater and then mixed in everything else by hand. however, i was still a bit paranoid, and might have underbeat the filling (there were small little lumps).

however, this recipe turned out to be AMAZING. it was creamy and had a great texture!!

on top, i made a raspberry sauce (10oz frozen raspberries, sugar, cornstarch, little bit of water to boil; drain seeds). so i drizzled the raspberry sauce and garnished with fresh blueberries make a killer combo! :D

i will be most definitely making this again!!

text:
This is really good...mine cracked a little, despite a water bath, but who cares. It was my first. I dont think it's a true NY cheesecake, but it's yummy. For my sauce I made this: 1/4 cup sugar (heated in a pan), a cup of pureed raspberries and a cup of pureed strawberries. Strain both and add to the sugar. Put in almost a whole bottle of a mini bottle (airplane bottle) of Amaretto, drink whats left of the amaretto, and juice of half a lemon. Heat just under a boil then refridgerate. A perfect berry sauce.

text:
This is a spectacular cheesecake recipe!  Although I have spent years baking, I have never attempted a cheesecake before.  I decided that I had to try this one after I read all of the great reviews.  I made sure all of my ingredients were room temperature and I also made sure not to overmix the filling.  I did as other reviewers suggested and placed a pan of hot water in the oven on the bottom rack for 20 minutes prior to baking the cheesecake.  I left it in there the entire time and my cheesecake did not have one single crack in it.  I also made sure not to ever open the oven door.  The suspense was killing me, but it was so worth it.  I used cherry pie filling as a topping.  This is just a really great recipe and I can't wait to make it again!

text:
I made this cheesecake with my mother for a family reunion. We used a 10 inch springform pan because she didn't have an 8 inch. It raised very high while baking, almost spilling over the pan. We thought it wasn't done so we left it in about 20 minutes longer and the whole top turned brown. While it was sitting overnight it shrunk down in height, and cracked in a circle. I think if we'd just let it be after the first hour it would have turned out better. None the less it tastes great! and I'm topping it with "Praline Sundae Topping" from thsi site - Heaven!

text:
Wow!  Amazing recipe, great flavor and texture.  I followed the recipe exactly except I did take others' advice and I reduced the amount of graham crackers to about 12 and I still had too much.  The secret to a NO-CRACK top is to spray the sides of the springform with Pam.  As the cheesecake cools it won't stick to the side of the pan which causes the crack in the middle.  I tried it and I had a picture perfect result.  Everyone kept asking me if I bought it!! A winner, I will make this again and again!

text:
Great Recipe!!  I also altered the crust as other users did.  I actually used a 9.5" glass pie pan, because I don't have a springform pan(this was my first cheesecake).  I had quite a bit of batter left so this gave me two cheesecakes :-).  Worked great... tasted delicious and no cracks!  I set my oven to  325, filled a broiler pan with water and set the dish in that.  Once the cake was set, but still moved in the center I shut off the oven and let set for 5 hours.  My family loved it!!  We drizzled the top of the cheesecake with sliced frozen strawberries.  Yum!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe. This was my first time making a cheesecake. I got a springform pan for easter, so I thought why not. My family and boss are already putting in orders. I loved the recipe, it was so easy. I did everything in the reviews, greasing the whole pan super well, ingredients all at room teperature, tried not to overmix, wraped it in double foil, and bathed it. I got out a old roast pan and filled it half way with water. I only checked it about 45 minutes later so the water did not all evaporate. I didnt want to open the door a bunch and ruin it or let all the warm air out. I let mine cook a hour, rest in the oven for almost seven hours and cool in the refrig. untill we ate. Actually, we fell asleep.  At the end, NOT ONE CRACK!!!!! I was so excited. The only thing I made different was I made mine oreo, with oreo crust, I used 16 oreos but should of used probably 25- 28. I cooked the crust for ten minutes while i mix the other stuff, and folded in six crushed oreos. I would give ten more stars!!!!!

I am writing this review only for people who want to try mini cheesecakes like me. I just couldn't have baked a whole cheesecake for 2 people, yet I wanted the dessert to be special. So, made 1/4th the recipe and baked in muffin tins with muffin paper. Baked for 30 mins. My minis cracked like none of my cheesecakes ever have inspite of the water bath. So, worth the effort but  baking the whole thing would have been better.

text:
Superb.  I got a little crack even though I used a water bath, but I admit I opened the oven door to sneak a peek after my 60 minutes was up.  Actually, I think 55 min would have been long enough for my oven which runs very hot.  When I checked it at 59 minutes it was definitely done (nearly set in the center) and starting to brown around the edges.  Next time I'll just peek through the oven door at 55 min and see if it looks done.  Having said that though, this is definitely EXCELLENT both in flavor and texture.  You don't need me to tell you that 900 reviews later though!  Definitely a keeper for "plain" (in the nicest sense of the word) cheesecake.  Delicious.  Thank you.

text:
I made this recipe for Longest Night (cheesecake for Longest Night being a tradition in our family) and it was absolutely delicious. I was terrified I'd overbaked it because of the springy feel it had by the time I turned the oven off, but it turned out to be slightly *less* done than I like! The middle was done, but creamy and soft, whereas I prefer a dryer, almost crumbly texture, which the edges did have. Next time I'll bake it longer and with more confidence, and believe me, there will be a next time.

userID:
1492005
Display Name:
Ambersand

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a gem! I've made this cheesecake a few times and I always get the most compliments from it. For those of you that know The Cheesecake Factory, this recipe rivals their NY Cheesecake recipe. 

I also added a sour cream "Topping". I don't let the cake sit in the oven for hours - I find that mine cracks regardless, so I let it sit for 30-45 min in the oven then take 1 8oz container of REAL (not low or no fat)sour cream, mix in confectioners sugar to taste, then spread on top. I place the cake back in the oven for another 30 min or so, take it out, and  let it cool on the counter...then into the fridge overnight.  When I take it from the springform, voila! A beautiful NY Cheesecake. 

THANKS CHANTAL!!!

text:
I'd give this recipe more stars if I could!!! Simply put, it's the best! Tastes like it's from the bakery and has restaurant quality---it was my very first successful cheesecake (others I've tried before turned out to be a gooey mess, even after I've baked it). This tastes best after a couple of days, so like others said, you should make it 2-3 days ahead of time. Didn't change a thing about it! I did have a teeny tiny crack, but didn't care because it tasted so good. This is the only traditional cheesecake recipe I'll use from now on!!! (I made it for Thanksgiving, and the family and I fought over who gets the 'left over' or 'extra' pieces of cheesecake after everone already got a piece!!!)

text:
The cheesecake itself is wonderful.  I actually took some advice from other members by adding more butter, sugar, and cinnamon to the crust, and a sour cream topping to the top after baking.  Well, I should have followed the original recipe word for word.  My crust was too sweet and the topping sub par.  I cooked the cake in a water bath and springform pan, with no cracks or sinking whatsoever.  The cake came out beautiful (and HUGE!).  For classic cheesecake, this is the best recipe ever!

text:
This cheesecake is amazing! After I combined the graham crackers with the butter and tuck into the base of springform pan, I put it in the freezer for 15 min, or you can put it in the fridge for an hour to make sure it doesn't get messy and stays firm after baking. Baked for an hour with a bigger pan filled with water (au bain marie), and make sure cover the bottom of the springform pan with aluminium foil. I never once opened the oven door, went to the mall and when we came back, it stayed there for around 2 hours and it looked beautiful. No cracks or whatsoever and taste delicious. Dip the knive in hot water before cutting. Thanks a lot for the recipe. Hubby says it's one of the best cheesecake out there!

text:
This is one of the few cheesecakes that I've made that turned out picture perfect!  It sliced perfectly (with the help of a heated knife) and looked store bought. I did make a few changes though...I added more graham crumbs and butter to work up the sides of the pan (I just think it looks nicer) I also didn't add the flour or milk and used 500ml (2 cups)of sour cream instead of one. This made the cake firm yet rich in taste...I also used a water bath.  I'm not a fan of creamy or runny cheesecakes so to me this is one of the best yet!  I will definitely make this time and time again!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is the first cheesecake I have ever made and it is without a doubt the richest and creamiest cheesecake I have ever eaten. Not because I made it, but because the recipe is sensational. 

This recipe was really not as daunting as I expected it to be.
     I left the cream cheese, sour cream, butter and the eggs out for 3 hours to get to room temperature. I preheated the oven  whilst I was mixing the ingredients and then made the base. (I blended it on med-low until smooth and it came out with no lumps at all. 
I put the cheesecake in the waterbath of HOT water and placed it in the oven for and 1 hour at 175c. (I also have a non-stick spring pan that seals well so i didn't have any water leakage.) I let it cool for 3 hours in the oven and then took it out and placed it on the counter for another 30 min. Then I refrigerated it for 3 hours and it was ready. I had no cracking or bubbling whatsoever.

Overall this recipe is wonderful and I strongly suggest that you give it a go.

For the base you absolutely have to try Dutch spiced windmill cookies. They already have a rich blend of flavours in them and really seem to bring out this cheesecake well. I used 1 and 1/2 cups of them and about 60g of butter. It worked a treat for me. I do hope some of you give them a go.

text:
How many times can I say YUM?! This was only my second cheesecake I've ever baked...it was perfect! No cracks, no sinking...I was SO excited when I woke up 6 hours later and removed it from the oven! I did, however, as a safety precaution, put a little metal bowl of water in the oven next to it while it baked because I heard that prevented cracking. This was delicious! I did, however, have some trouble with the crust...2 tbls butter was just not enough. I ended up refering to this site's White Chocolate Blueberry Cheesecake (my first cheesecake) recipe to make the crust, using 1/4 cup butter and 2 tsp caramel but omitting the almonds. Delicious! I used 1 block of reduced fat cream cheese with 3 regulars, still tasted awesome! I baked it for my friends and they loved it...one even announced to everyone that I bake the best cheesecake in the world *grin* Thanks so much for this fantastic recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe.  Everytime I make it, someone asks me where I found the recipe.   I have changed a few things.  For the crust I double the butter, otherwise the crust turns out really crumbly.  This cheesecake also HAS TO be baked in a water bath, or it will definitely crack.  Instead of wrapping tin foil around the base of your spring form pan,  use an oven bag to put around the pan, because with tinfoil water leaks in no matter what.  I don't keep the cake in the oven for 5 to 6 hours.  I immediately put it in the fridge.  This also helps to prevent cracking.  Don't be discouraged if the first time you make it, it cracks.  It takes a little practice.  Even if it does crack, the flavor is generally just as delicious.

text:
I made this cheesecake last night, and as I do with any new recipe I doubled it. I made one cheesecake for myself to test before serving the other one to friends and family.  As stated in the blip this does taste just like real New York deli cheesecake.  Its wonderful, and didn’t crack at all!  However, I did feel the recipe needed a couple of alterations.

1.)For the crust 15 gram crackers just didn’t quite seem like enough (I like to push the gram crackers to the sides of the pan as well as the bottom).  I used about 1/12 cups of crushed CINNAMON gram crackers and 6 tablespoons of melted butter.  The crust was soooo yummy!  I baked the crust for 5 min in the 350 degree oven before adding the batter
2.) Also, I’m not sure if it’s my oven or what, but the cheesecake required LONGER than 60 min to bake…the center was still too gooey.  I baked it an hour and 20 min (using a water bath as other readers suggested it didn’t crack at all.
3.)I only left the cheesecake in the oven for an hour (rather than 6 like stated) before placing in the fridge….I didn’t receive any cracking.

This was a wonderful cheesecake and I will definitely use it again!  Thanks!

Chantal! My, my, my, my, umm, umm, good!  Guess what! this was my very firt time baking a cheesecake and I got very good raves on it. I am a homebaker in the Raleigh area (Unique Cakes) and I've had request on doing a cheesecake wedding cake. This will be the recipe I will use. I wish I could give it more stars other than 5 because this deserves it. I made a few moderations to this for my taste and it worked out well for me. I was reading over some of the many reviews you got from this and I've added 1/2 cup of sugar and increased the butter to 1/2 cup for the crust. I didn't count the graham crackers but I put 1 1/2 cups (I guess it depends on how thick you wnat it. I also added 1/2 t. pure almond extract to the filling and it was great.  As for the crust I bake it at 400 degrees for 3 min. and bake the whole ch.cake for 15 min. and turned the oven down to 200 and continue baking for 3 hours. I let this cool in the oven for about 5 hours then refrigeated it, It turned out beautifully.  Thanks again.

text:
There's a reason for the high rating on this one!  It is superb!  My husband LOVES cheesecake but I have never tried it before because I always thought they were so fickle.  After reading through all of the reviews and tips here, I decided to try it.  I did the graham cracker crust with the seasonings and avoided overmixing.  I placed a 9x13 pan full of boiling water on the rack below the springform pan, baked for 1 hr at 325 degrees (I had a dark pan) and let it sit for 4 hours in the oven before refrigerating uncovered overnight.  No cracks!  I served with some blueberry topping I made with fresh blueberries.  Even I, who doesn't care much for cheesecake, can hardly keep out of it!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
mmmm!! it is deeelicciousss. i made a different crust using the recipe other reviewers suggested: 1 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 cup chopped pecans, 1/4 cup melted butter, except i only used 1/2 tsp cinnamon and 1/8 tsp nutmeg. the crust had a nice taste although maybe i'll try a walnuts next time. i baked the crust for 3 minutes before filling it but i think it was too little time because it is still a little soggy and i didn't even use a waterbath. so next time i will bake for 5-10 minutes. i had this huuuuge crack in my cheesecake, but i think it was because i overmixed it. good tip i read on here .. add the vanilla and mix that in before adding the flour! i baked it for an hour at 325 F because i have a dark pan. when it was done, i was about to take it out and take my knife and run it around the edges to prevent cracking but as soon as i opened the door i started panicking because it looked sooo weird! so don't get freaked out when you open the oven door and the middle is sunken in and take a knife and dip it in warm water and run it around the edges to prevent cracking and stick it back in the oven for cooling. and don't cover the cheesecake when you put it in the refrigerator to cool or else it'll get all.....wet. this was my first time making cheesecake and even though there were a few minor problems it still turned out delicious in the end!! i will definitely be making more cheesecakes now :)

Very easy to make.  I chose to use a pan of boiling water on the rack below the cheesecake instead of the water bath.  Didn't want to take a chance of water seeping in. Mine did crack, but leaving it in the oven for 5  hours and refridgerate till the next day, it settled and couldn't see a trace of the cracks. This was very creamy & delicious.

text:
Having been from NYC originally, I was looking for a recipe that really popped. La Bella Ferrara or Junior's type cheesecake. That's not what I got. I only left the heat on for 45 minutes vs. an hour and it was still a little too brown on the edges. I had two very small cracks, even with a water bath, but if the cake wasn't so brown it would have still looked nice. The texture was right on, but the flavor wasn't. Any good cheesecake I've ever had has had a slight twinge of some sort of citrus-like flavor and this lacked it. I'll probably try it again, but the recipe and cooking time will be tweaked a bit.

text:
I improvised this recipe somewhat and it turned out perfect.  I used 11/4 cups graham cracker crumbs with 1/4 cup sugar and 1/3 cup melted butter for the crust.  I only used 1/2 cup milk and three eggs to make it less runny and a bit more dense. Baked it at 325 degrees for one hour.  The secret to not having cracks is letting cheese come to room temp. and making sure you don't overmix batter.  Also careful not to overbake.  Thanks for the great recipe Chantal.

text:
This is my usual recipe for New York style cheesecake. It's practically foolproof if you have the correct temp in your oven and follow the directions.  The number of people who have negative ratings on this lead me to believe that they have never had the real New York style. It's dense and not overly sweet. I usually put slices in the freezer and only partially defrost so it's still very cold and firm and pieces flake off with a fork.  Once it gets to the correct time, I turn the oven off and leave. I don't look, peek, or check for 6-8 hours. Never, ever had a problem in over 20 years of using this recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-11-04T01:28:42.48
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
13876214
Display Name:
PearlT
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
25
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This (with a few tiny adjustments) is the best cheesecake in the world. Here are my recommendations - First, use 1 and 1/2 tablespoons of vanilla instead of 1. Second, add a tablespoon of lemon juice to the cheesecake mixture. Third, use 2 tablespoons of flour instead of 1/4 cup. Fourth, bake it at 325 for one hour exactly, then turn the oven off and let it sit for at least one more hour before putting it into the fridge uncovered overnight. I did not bake it in a water bath, instead I put a large pan of boiling water on the shelf below it as it was cooking. It did not crack at all.

That's it! I made my own custom graham cracker crust but unfortunately I eyeballed everything for the crust instead of using measurements. I used a medium stack of graham crackers, finely crushed. Add no more than 1/2 cup finely ground raw unsalted almonds. Dash of cinnamon, tiny pinch salt, nice little pile of sugar. mix together, then slowly blend in melted unsalted butter until it it at a consistency that can *almost* be formed into a ball without falling apart. Press into pan and voila.

text:
Yes! This! It's amazing. Although I used a different crust (Graham Cracker Crust I from this site, which was delicious), I followed the recipe otherwise. I baked it at 325 for an hour with some pans of water on the bottom rack of the oven, left it in the oven for 2 hours to cool, then put it in the fridge overnight. It was the perfect texture and flavour and it didn't have any cracks. This is the best cheesecake I've ever made (and I've made a lot). One tip (which someone else has probably written somewhere in the thousands of reviews of this cake) for bringing your cream cheese to room temperature more quickly without a microwave is to put the little foil packages of cream cheese in a Ziploc bag and submerge them in a bowl of warm water. I left mine in there for about 30 minutes I think. Having room temperature cream cheese (and other ingredients, but cream cheese especially) is really important and this is a good way to expedite the process if you are in a hurry.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this cheesecake many times and it always gets rave reviews. However, I don't care for the crust so I use my own Oreo crust recipe - 2.5 cups ground Oreo cookies (centers removed), 5 tbsp melted butter, 1/3 c sugar, 1/8 tsp salt. 
I usually follow the directions and leave the cheesecake in the oven for 5 hours after baking but this last time I didn't because I was pressed for time. After it was done baking I cracked the oven door open and used a wooden spoon to keep it from closing. I let it sit for about 20 minutes then pulled it out and let it cool on the counter for about an hour before putting it in the fridge to chill. No cracks. I believe it's because I baked it in a water bath. I wrapped my 9" springform cheesecake batter filled pan with 2 layers of aluminum foil and set it inside a 12" round pan. I poured about 1" of boiling water into the larger pan. Then put it in the oven to bake. The steam from the water helps keeps the cheesecake moist and prevents cracks. In fact, once I didn't use a water bath and the cheesecake cracked even after letting it cool in the oven for 5 hours.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
14066509
Display Name:
Karen E. Duffy
isPro:

city:

country:
None
text:
This is only my second cheesecake, and I made a few changes based on other recipes I've found.  

For the crust, I used 2 cups cinnamon graham crackers, pulsed in food processor with 1/2 cup walnuts, 1/2 cup melted, unsalted butter, 1 egg white, 1/2 cup organic sugar, 1 tsp. cinnamon and 1/2 tsp. nutmeg.  I greased a springform pan and pressed the crust mixture into the bottom and up around the sides (my husband prefers it that way); then I pre-baked the crust in a 325 degree oven for 17 min.

For the batter, I omitted the flour and milk altogether. The rest of the ingredients are the same.  I found that Cabot Neufchatel Cheese and Cabot Sour Cream work well, and they are GMO-free.

Rather than wrapping the pan in foil to set in the bain marie, I simply filled a large roasting pan with about 1 inch of hot water and set it on the rack below the cheesecake.  I baked it at 325 for one hour and let it set for only 2-3 hours in the oven (no opening the door).  Removed from oven, I let it cool to room temp. (no cracking! Yay!), then popped it into the fridge overnight to chill.  

This made an AWESOME cheesecake!  The crust was the best I've ever tasted, probably thanks to the added walnuts, sugar & cinnamon.  I am new to cheesecake-baking, but I found this combination of ingredients to be a total winner.  This cake got RAVE reviews from family & friends, and is so easy to make.  Will be making this for years to come!

TexasHotMama

text:
This is a delicious, delicious cheesecake! And this was my first attempt at cheesecake too. I watch my carbs, and gluten is not my friend, so I replaced the sugar with 1 1/2 cups of regular Splenda, and I replaced the flour with about a tablespoon of coconut flour (coconut flour is much more absorbent than regular flour, so it is not a cup-for-cup exchange). I also used 15 gluten-free graham crackers for the crust. Success! I probably over-mixed it a bit, because while it was baking, the top puffed up like a souffle - but it sank evenly while it cooled, and the end result was still delicious, thick, rich, creamy, and the texture and flavor were perfect.  The top did crack but I made a quick sour cream topping and covered them up. No one knew the difference, and it was so good, no one would have cared anyway. No one would have guessed it was sugar free, either! Other than the sugar/flour substitutions, I made the recipe as written. If you follow the directions exactly, start off with room temp ingredients, and don't overmix - this comes out perfect! A great sugar-free, gluten free dessert!

text:
This was my first ever attempt at making a cheesecake and it turned out perfect! I followed the recipe as is, with only two slight changes (per other reviewers):
1) the crust: Be careful here. it calls for "15 Graham crackers" which I interpreted as 15 whole crackers or 1.5 packages! I realized this was way too much after crushing them all. Use the previously mentioned recipe for the crust ( 1.5 C crushed graham crackers etc).
2) I did follow others recommendation and baked in the water bath. I used 3 layers of foil someone suggested and had no problem with water getting into the pan. 
I baked it for 60 min at 325 degrees and then just shut the oven off and let it sit in the oven for 8 hours (over night, since I baked it in the evening)Then, in the morning, refrigerated until serving it that night.
Perfect, perfect. perfect. So yummy. Thanks so much. This is a keeper!

Let me just say I have never made a cheesecake a day in my life. This receipt is rich, creamy, and absolutely delicious. I followed the instructions to the letter. I also baked it in a water bath as some have suggested. I sprayed my pan with a bakers spray that contains flour before I added my filling. I mixed the floor in with a wisk by hand for about 30 seconds. I didn't want to over mix the cake. This receipt is perfect.

text:
This is the best and easiest cheesecake I have ever made. I live in Germany and made this for my Osteopath and when I saw him on the next visit he had to pause and take a deep breath and say, 'This is the best cheesecake I have ever tasted.' Mind you, I live 20 minutes from France and they are know for their cheesecakes. I have tried this cake with cream cheese and with creme fresh, depending on what I had on hand, and had great success with both. The creme fresh tends to be lighter in texture, but not on flavor. I make my own Grahame crackers from organic Spelt instead of wheat. I use the recipe from here for the crackers. They are wonderful as well.  I do add my eggs last and it seems to make it even creamier in texture.  I have also made half the recipe and used a small spring form pan and it worked out great.  This is definitely a keeper. I try to make one a month, if not for my wonderful husband and I, then to family or neighbors. What a great gift to give, yummy cheesecake! I have added several pictures so you can see just how wonderful this cake is. MashaAllah!  Enjoy!

Half-wit Baker

None
text:
It was my very first time making a cheesecake from scratch and naturally, it was more than a little intimidating. Secondly, my oven won't be nominated for any prizes -- unless you count "Museum Centerpiece" or "Not-quite-antique-but-just-old", so, needless to say, the odds were stacked against me from the get-go. But, the amazing thing is, having read all the reviews, and, intent on applying the cross-cutting modifications, then reading a review that said to ignore all the modifications, I went ahead and ignored them, and then some. I did, in the short of it, follow this recipe to the exact T, nearly, with the exception of substituting regular milk for low-fat evaporated milk and very religiously, ensuring that I did not get too carried away with the mixing. Taking another reviewer's suggestion, I only mixed the cream cheese and the sugar with the handmixer. I did, however, pulverize the white sugar into a castor-sugar like particle in order to cut down the mixing time. And thereafter, I used a spoon to do the incorporating. I don't know if this helped - but I had not a crack on my cheesecake - absolutely flawless. My oven time did run to about 1 hour 30 minutes, but I fear that's because my oven will soon be retiring (or so, I hope!). All in all, this is an absolutely (almost) fail-safe, and comfortingly decadent and soothing cheesecake recipe. Bake away and enjoy to your heart's (but not waistline!) content.

text:
This was great!  My only criticism is that the crust was too dry, so it was still in cracker crumb condition even after baking, so I'm going to stick to my tried-and-true crust recipe in the future.  I used blanched almond flour instead of all-purpose, since I don't keep all-purpose at home.  I used one of my mom's cheesecake tricks, which is making everything in the food processor, and it turned out perfectly, aside from the crumbly crust.  I didn't open the oven from the time it went in until 7 hours later when I took it out.  The taste and texture are fantastic, just what I was looking for.  New staple for the holidays!

I made this to recipe, it turned out perfect! I have never had cracking happen from not greasing the pan,(I never remember to grease the pan) but I do know if you over stir, it will crack for sure. I use my kitchenaid mixer on the lowest speed and let it stir until it is smooth. When I pour it into the pan I tap to make sure any bubbles are out. city:

country:

text:
This turned out so beautiful!!  The third cheesecake recipe I've tried and this one I will keep as a staple.  Perfect texture, very creamy, very cheesy, with just the right amount of cakey.  My batter did come out lumpy because I used fresh-out-of-the-yogurt-maker homemade sour cream, but after it's baked you can't really tell.  I used a smaller pan so I scaled all the ingredients to 2/3 of the original, used 1/2 cup truvia (2 diabetics in the family), and used seeds of a vanilla bean instead of the extract.  Those are the only changes I made.  Oh, and I also used a waterbath.  I blind baked my crust first, cooled, wrapped plastic wrap tightly around the bottom, then added 2 extra layers of aluminum foil.  No soggy crust.  My cheesecake did have a brown skin forming on top though, not sure why, but probably because the top was burning.  Next time I'll try baking with a loosely covered foil on top.  Great recipe, but probably wont turn out as well if you don't know tips & tricks or have experience.

text:
This is the best NY cheesecake I have seem, and Joan says the best tasting. I followed directions with one change. I cooked the cheesecake in a Freling glass bottomed springform placed in a Cheesecake Moat pan the moat is a pan in the middle of a pan allowing you to surround your creation with water that can never get in your springform. The only two changes made were to cook in a water bath, using the cheesecake most to protect the cake from any leakage.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2014-07-12T14:58:29.34
helpfulCount:

userID:
13904188
Display Name:
Zulema
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
