0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to recipe for cheesecake. I love that the texture can be modified to be creamier by leaving out the flour or made drier and more cake-like by adding a little more flour. I change my crust recipe to a shortbread one (found on "New York cheesecake III" recipe which i also use but prefer this one with less ingredients)  its 1 1/2 Cups flour, 1/3 Cup white sugar, 1/2 unsalted butter,  and one egg. Mix the flour, sugar and butter together until butter is small crumbs then add egg and flatten into a greased springform pan. Bake for 15 mins at  400. Let cool, re-grease the pan sides and place extra long foil around the pan. Make sure the foil is covering the sides completely and then make the cheesecake. While you make the cheesecake place a large saucepan on the stove and fill with water. Bring to a boil. I place my springform pan into a large cake pan and fill the cheesecake. I put this in the oven and carefully pour the water into the surrounding cakepan. The water should come up to about 1/2 way. Then I let bake 1 to 1 1/2 hours until cheesecake is fairly firm. This is called a bain-marie (water bath). It ensures even baking and keeps the cheesecake moist. Ive never had a cheesecake crack when I do this. I take mine out of the oven, wait a few mins and pour the leftover water out. Remove the foil and pop into the fridge or freezer. This all sounds like a lot of work but its really not lol. My family, friends and co-workers beg for this cheesecake and this makes it

text:
I use this recipe a lot. It is a lot fluffier than an average cheesecake but it tastes exactly the same. I have to make an oatmeal crust since I have a vegetable oil intolerance (probably a chemical since I can eat pressed oils) and graham crackers always have some sort of vegetable oil. It still turns out really excellent. It always cracks but I don't worry too much, its easier to top the cheesecake with fruit sauce and pretend its not there than worry about water baths and cooling times. The hardest part is keeping the boys away from it for a day to truly set.

Only a few changes to the recipe.  My family doesn't like a thick crust so I brush the sides with melted butter and dust the pan with crushed graham crackers ( about 2-3 is all you need).  Also the flavor of the cheesecake doesn't truly come out till you let it sit for atleast 24 hours (refrigerated).  Plan ahead and you won't be disappointed.

text:
Very good recipe. I've made it already a few times and always get good reviews on it. 
I do recommend, if you're short on time, to replace the milk, sugar, and sour cream with a 14 oz can of sweetened condensed milk. It still comes out with a great taste and texture but you don't have to give yourself the trouble of measuring all the ingredients. 
Oh and for extra taste you can add cinnamon powder to the cracker mix.

text:
Baked my first cheesecake with this recipe & it received rave reviews! I did read some reviews first & made the following changes. 1.) The crust 11/2C. Graham cracker crumbs, 1/4C.melted butter, 1/2tsp cinnamon & 1/4C. sugar. 2.) Kept the filling the same with the addition of 1TBS. Almond extract. 3.) Reduced the oven temperature to 325* still baked for 1 hour & placed a 9x13 glass baking dish of water on the rack under the cheesecake. Did not open the oven until 3 hours later & stored in the fridge until the next day. No cracks & a light golden edge. Now lets see if I can do that again!

text:
I made a gluten free version of this recipe using Udis Gingerbread cookies, crumbed - rather than the graham crackers.  I also used a GF all purpouse flour.  I pressed the cookie crumbles and butter mixture into cupcake tins and poured the mixture right on top.  There weren't enough cookie crumbles for all the tins, so i poured some cheesecakes without a crust.  I baked each batch for about 17 minutes at 350 degrees, just until i saw the first signs of cracking - then i removed them from the oven and allowed them to cool.  They turned out perfect - these are amazing! Great recipe! Both the ones with the crust and no crust turned out great.  I topped them each differently with pie filling, melted chocolate, carmel, peanut butter and chocolate, and cherries. Definitley a keeper!

text:
This cheesecake was awesome!  I made 4 mini cheesecakes using 1/2 this recipe. I baked cheesecakes in 4.5" springform pans in water bath at 300* for 42 minutes.  After turning off the oven I left the cheesecakes in the oven for an hour with the door cracked then refrigerated for about 4 hours.

This recipe is perfect as is, only explaining what I did because I looked for instructions on making mini cheesecakes in waterbath and couldn't find the info so thought I'd share what worked for me.

text:
2019 Update: I’ve made this cheesecake numerous times and it’s truly a never-fail, often requested recipe.  Going to try a chocolate version of this. Fingers crossed.

2013 Review:  I followed the directions and it came out perfect.  Mine stayed in the oven about 3 1/2 hours after I turned it off.  And I used the water bath to keep it from cracking, double wrapped the springform pan in tinfoil as suggested.  The only two changes I would make is perhaps a tad more sugar, though my family didn't agree.  Plus I would place a piece of tin foil loosely on top of the pan about an hour after the oven was shut off to prevent further browning.  It looked great just a bit golden on the outer edges that I would have preferred not to have but that's just me being picky.  I made a strawberry sauce and served that along with hot fudge sauce and caramel sauce for topping options.  The purists ate it with nothing on top and raved!  A perfect go-to cheesecake recipe and very simple.

text:
I made this recipe for Thanksgiving because my little sister doesn't like pie, and it was a huge hit!! We had some friends over for dessert and I think more people ate this cheesecake than any of the pies I made! It was absolutely delicious!! We always have leftover pie and cheesecake for breakfast the few days after Thanksgiving, and there was hardly any leftover cheesecake! Needless to say, my sister was not very happy about it. I substituted the graham cracker crust for an Oreo crust (I'm a chocoholic!) and everybody loved it! My only complaint was that it still cracked even though I left it in the oven for 6 hours; however I live at a high altitude so a cracking cheesecake is hard to avoid.

text:
After reading several of the bad reviews this morning, I have to chime in. This is my only cheesecake recipe. I have tried others, but I adore this one. To circumvent the "burned top" issue, I simply LIGHTLY COVERED just the top of the cheesecake for most of the baking time. I used my food processor to mix the ingredients, and it always comes out very smooth and creamy. This recipe does not crack, or sink, if you follow the directions. It's a great recipe for "dressing up" if you have a theme event to go to, like today, I'm making one for a holiday event, so I'm adding a bit of pumpkin spice to it. I did this last week, and it came out so wonderfully good!

text:
I LOVED THIS CHEESECAKE!  This was my second time making cheesecake ever, first being a Red Velvet Cheesecake several years ago(it too was awesome).  I am not so concerned with the top cracking a little as I always top mine.  I put two bread pans of broiling water on the second rack, one on each side of the oven, instead of doing the whole foil water mess.  Maybe some day I will try it.  I did add some pecans to my crust as I like that a lot!  I would not change another things... except maybe a wonderful Fresh Strawberry Topping that I made to put over it.  I made a water/sugar/cornstarch mixture and cooked until boiling, then added about a cup of chopped/mashed strawberries and cooked it a while longer. I then poured this over 2 cups of sliced strawberries - mixed it together.  I put this in a bowl next to the cake so those that wanted topping could have it!  The strawberries remain very fresh tasting and have perfect sweetness!

I have made around 12 pies with this recipe now and have made some adjustments. 1st my bf who is a cheesecake fanatic, (I make the cakes for him) complains theres too much vanilla. I cut the vanilla in half and the masterpiece was separating the egg yolks and white. Beating the whiites till they have stiff peaks and folding it into the batter. The result was a delicious and lighter version. Best I have made yet. Oh and after adjustments it cracked like crazy, but the taste was sensational.

Stop looking for the perfect cheesecake recipe! This is the one! I followed the recipe to a t. No substitutions or altercations. I have searched for years and now I finally found my go to cheesecake recipe. As long as you follow directions you will be fine. Make sure the cream cheese is room temp. I am looking forward to making this again with different flavors swirled in! Wow what a cheesecake!! It received rave reviews!

text:
I made this for the first time. I don't usually adjust recipes the first time I try them, but after reading the reviews, I decided to change a few things. I cut back slightly on the flour, adding about 2/3 cup instead of 3/4. I also replaced about 1/4 cup of the milk with fresh Meyer lemon juice. Finally, I made a sour cream topping, using about 1/2 cup sour cream, 1/8 cup sugar and a tsp. vanilla. I mixed this thoroughly. When the cheesecake was done, I gently spread the sour cream topping, put it back in the oven and let it sit for several hours as the recipe indicates. I served it with a fresh strawberry sauce (strawberries, water, sugar and a little cornstarch cooked on the stovetop). The result -- a delicate, creamy, perfect cheesecake.

text:
Every time I bring this somewhere people say it's the best cheesecake they've ever had and they want the recipe.  I make it exactly as stated other than i push the crust crumbs into the bottom and sides of the springform pan.  The only time I have had this crack on me is once I tried using the mixer on it's LOWEST speed to incorporate the eggs (thinking it would be as gentle as hand mixing). I was wrong and it cracked.  If you follow the recipe directions exactly and ALL ingredients are at room temperature before starting and you mix very gently by hand from the point you start adding eggs until the end of the directions then it shouldn't crack.

text:
I love this recipe! It's never failed me! I use this cheesecake recipe as the base for my turtle cheesecake and it's the best! I just substitute oreo crumbs for the graham crackers and swirl melted chocolate through the cheesecake batter and top with caramel, melted chocolate, and pecans. The water bath is super important to prevent cracking, as is keeping the door completely closed for the full time. We found that the flavor actually tastes better if we allow it to sit in the fridge for a minimum of 2 days. It helps coease everything together flavorwise. You can really take some broad liberations with the recipe to achieve anything from chocolate cheesecake, raspberry swirl or whatever. It holds up well!

text:
First of all i love traditional new york style cheesecake, this is the best recipe i have tried and i dont think i will go away from it.  That being said, ive made this recipe several times...is it just me or is this alot of batter? I can make 2 cheesecakes with the amouts given (ill admit i cheat a little and use premaid crusts).  Second, everytime i make cheesecake it ALWAYS cracks....fustrated ive done a little research...no you dont have to the water baking method.  It seems the temperature is just too high in the oven! Simple fix..adjust the oven temperature to 325 and bake for one hr...aaand voila! No crack cheesecake..hope this helps for those of you who have the cracking problem :)
p.s - just ket it bake and DONT OPEN THE OVEN DOOR! I know its tempting but dont do it! Also once its done baking let it sit in the over for a bit...and hr or so...more if you have the time...Good luck!

text:
This is a great cheesecake ...... I baked mine using the "waterbath" as I do all my cheesecakes which prevents cracking.Stuck to the original recipe.I also do not leave it in the oven for all those hours which I believe would cause some moisture loss(residual heat). I simply remove it from the oven and waterbath and place the springform pan on a wire cookie grate to bring down to room temperature.After it's cooled it goes into the fridge overnight ....done ! No offense but if your cheesecake "cracks" you either did not use a waterbath or you wayyyy over beat it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely amazing!!! I did the fat-free version: using fat-free cream cheese, fat-free yogurt instead of sour cream, and fat-free milk, and the result was a rich and dense cake! I don't think it is a huge compromise, and it does reduce the calories.
TO AVOID CRACKING: Apply butter LIBERALLY on the sides of the pan! This way it will separate easily as it bakes. I bake in a water-bath, and start checking for doneness at 45-50 min, and then every 15 min (until it jiggles like jello in the center, but the outside is firm). I left 1 hour in the oven, then with a warm knife separate the cake from the sides, leave outside 2-3 hours, then refrigerate. My cakes never cracked so far!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have become famous for my cheesecakes because of this recipe! :)
My tips: 
1. Understand what a New York style cheesecake is: it's denser, and less super sweet than the "no bake" styles of cheesecakes. This cake is made to be topped with whatever you like, and so it is an unparalleled blank canvas!
2. Use a water bath to prevent cracking/falling of the cake. Also, DO NOT open the oven door! Even regular cakes will fall if you open the oven door.
3. Grease the sides of the springform pan to prevent cracking
4. Do not overmix the cake. It is not meant to be light and airy (it's not frosting). I agree with Morena: only use an electric mixer to cream the cheese and sugar; after that, use a wooden spoon. Introducing too much air into the mixture will cause the cake to crack.
Try a crushed pecan crust instead of graham crackers!

text:
Awesome recipe!  I have made many cheesecakes and this is our new favorite recipe!  I followed the cheesecake recipe exactly as written with the exception of the addition of sugar and cinnamon to the crust and I reduced the cooking temperature to 325.  The cake cooked for one hour, I then turned off the oven and let the cake sit over night. It was perfect.  No browning, cracking etc.  I did cook the cake in a water bath, used room temp ingredients and a well greased pan.  My guests raved about it!  I even had one woman pull me aside on her way out and ask me if I really made it!  Obviously it was a success!  I definitely recommend this recipe!

text:
Wonderful recipe! It tasted delicious. This was my first time making cheesecake, and I messed a few things up. First, I didn't realize that a graham cracker was one SQUARE, not one rectangle- I crushed double the amount of crackers and didn't realize it until it was already in the pan, so I just removed half and added more butter to try to make up for the lost. Then, the cream cheese wasn't room temperature yet- it was still a little cold. This made my batter a bit lumpy. Lastly, when baking, I accidentally turned the oven off for a few minutes without realizing it, but I'm not sure this changed anything. I would reccommend avoiding these mistakes, and not even checking to see if the cake looks finished after an hour, since it doesn't get golden or look done. You can serve this with chocolate syrup on top, cherry pie filling, strawberry sauce or whatever filling you want. A delicious, moist cheesecake.

text:
I made this cheesecake yesterday after reading many reviews from other members who raved about this recipe. I did not bother with a water bath and there was no crack when I turned off the oven. However when I was letting the cake cool in the oven, cracks started to form. I guess it was because I baked it in a black springform pan and I should've lowered the temperature slightly. I should have turned off the oven when the middle part of the cheesecake is jiggly but the sides are firm.

I did exactly what the recipe called for but because  I could not get graham crackers from where I live (Malaysia), I substituted it with Digestive biscuits. 

The recipe is really good, my family and friends loved it however I did find it a little bit eggy tasting. I'll be making this again but I will add some lemon juice to give it a little tangy taste. The texture of the cheesecake is really creamy and dense. Even with the cracks, my friends and family claimed it's really good. Looks like this recipe is a keeper.

text:
If you're looking for a cheesecake recipe that will produce a dense cake, then this is the recipe for you! I made this yesterday with some variations: 1). Instead of the graham crust, I opted for an Oreo crust. 2). I topped it off with some chocolate ganache once it was cooled.

Some tips: 1). You can't make this on the day you plan to serve it. It has to be refrigerated overnight to get the best consistency and texture. 2). If you're wondering how to tell whether a cheesecake is ready to be removed from the oven-- the center should be quite jiggly in the center. Cool the cheesecake to room temp before refrigerating. 3). Have fun! If you don't enjoy what you are doing, it will show in your product. 4). Making cheesecakes need lots of patience! 

This is a definite keeper, and I wish everyone the best of luck in their cheesecake making. Cheers!

text:
Caveat: sour cream is expensive and difficult to find overseas where I am staying now so I omitted the sour cream; likewise, graham crackers practically don't exist so I substituted digestive biscuits. That being said, this recipe blew the socks off every single person I served it to... and these are picky people who usually moan and groan about the slightest shortcoming in a food! The taste and texture of this cheesecake is pretty much perfect: smooth with a bit of a cheesy bite. Honestly, I probably won't ever bother with sour cream in a cheesecake from now on. This is a tough cheesecake not to crack though, so be super careful not to over mix and make sure you have the oven temperature perfect. If you still have cracking trouble, CHEAT: use cupcake trays for mini cheesecakes, or throw a topping onto the cheesecake (although this cheesecake frankly doesn't need a topping so less is more if you go that route).

text:
This recipe turned out fantastic! I used half and half instead of milk, and I added some sweetened ground cocoa to my graham crackers to make a chocolate crust. I baked it for an hour and 15 minutes and then I used a silicone spoon in the oven door so it was only cracked a little. I left it in there for 7 hours. It had a small superficial crack on top,  very minor. It didn't fall at all. It was very thick and had perfect texture. My sister and brother-in law said it was the best cheesecake they had ever had. This will be the only cheesecake recipe I use from now on.

text:
What a fabulous recipe.  This was my first cheesecake and it’s defiantly a keeper.  For the crust, I used:  1 1 /2 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1/4 c. finely chopped Unsalted nuts (walnuts, pecans), 1/4 c. melted butter, 1 tsp. cinnamon and a 1/4 tsp. nutmeg. Mix together and press into 9" spring form pan and baked for 5 minutes.  I didn't have a pan big enough to put my 9-inch spring form pan in for a water bath, so I just put it on a rack and put a pan of water underneath it. It was steamy enough to produce a perfect uncracked cake.  Highly recommend!!

country:
None
text:
Just made my 1st cheesecake(s) & they turned out perfect! This recipe, along with the tips on this site, worked as well as everyone else says! Tastes great, looks perfect, no cracks! 

FYI- I did change a few things b/c I was intending to experiment. 

1) I used 2 store bought graham cracker piecrusts. I still had about half of the mixture left, so I quickly made the crust on this recipe, & pressed it into paper lined muffin pan. After filling 12 individual cups, there was still more left over. 

2) I used the 'alternate' water bath mentioned on reviews. I put the muffins in a casserole dish of water, but only put another dish w/ water under the 2 pies. 

3) Used a diff baking method, also found on the other reviews. I preheated the oven to 350 for about 30 mins. As soon as I put them in the oven, I lowered the temp to 250. After 1 hr, I turned the oven off. I let them stay in the oven for 6 hrs to cool. I also did not open the oven during baking or cooling, not even 1x. 

I hope this helps! I felt like I did everything wrong, but w/ room temp ingredents & not over-mixing, I was so suprised to see and taste perfect cheesecakes!

text:
This is the easiest, most versatile cheesecake recipe I have ever used.  I've made the plain one dozens of times.  I've also made it mint chocolate chip and pumpkin spice.  Takes some trial and error with those adjustments but the results are always edible and sometimes they are amazing!  LOL  The only tip I want to add is, when you're baking it in a water bath, instead of wrapping the pan in tin foil, which never completely works, use a crock pot liner.  Set the pan inside the liner, folding down the edges so it doesn't touch the batter.  You'll have a perfectly dry crust every time.

text:
This recipe probably doesn't need ANOTHER endorsement, but the other reviews were so helpful in selecting this gem that I wanted to add my voice to the chorus. My 9 yr old daughter and I, made this cheesecake as a surprise for my wife's birthday, and it was a hit. My wife begs us to make it again and again. Three cheesecakes in, and we're still turning out excellent cheesecakes. Follow the directions to a T, and USE THE HINTS IN THE "CHEESECAKE TIPS!" We bake it in a water bath, and it cooks up perfectly every time--no cracks, no sagging middle. We also crush up our own graham crackers rather than buying pre-crushed graham crackers, but that's really just because it's fun to do. :-) This is truly an excellent, restaurant-grade recipe that even a husband and a 9-year-old who barely know a TBSP from a TSP can make. Thank you, Chantal. Happy eating!

userID:
7619236
Display Name:
purply_8
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me start by saying, this is the best cheesecake mix out there. I make cheesecakes regularly and this year's Thanksgiving I decided to make this recipe just because I wanted try something different than my usual recipe...I felt like taking on some risk. Anyway, everyone was raaaving about this cheesecake (I added my personal touches of course). The taste is pretty basic if you don't spice it up a little and if you love NY cheesecake you will not put the spoon down on this one. 
I basically followed the recipe. For the crust I used: 3 tbspoons butter, graham crackers (crumbled), about 1/3 of a teaspoon ground cinnamon and about 2 tablespoons of granulated sugar (NOT confectioners). 
Melt the butter and add the cinnamon then the graham crackers and the sugar *in that order would be optimal cause you don't want the sugar melting to caramel* mix them well over low heat; when the mix looks wet enough press it down on the pan and throw it in the oven for a couple of minutes to 'dry'. 
Now, for the cake I basically added an extra tbspoon of vanilla extract and about 1/2 teaspoon lemon zest for fragrance and flavor. (you can add zest to your taste just don't over do it and your guests think you are serving them lemon custard cake. 
I served mine with homemade strawberry topping and fresh strawberries. I baked it at 360F for 1h and let in the oven 1 hour. It sets nicely and NO cracks :) Creamy perfection! HIT recipe, you won't regret making it.

text:
I never made a baked cheesecake before, and then I tried this recipe...Oh my gosh, am I glad I did!

This is the BEST and easiest cheesecake you can make. I have made this 4 times all with great results. 

Today's cake is for my husband, 10 year anniversary! 

How I make mine: make my crust and bake it for 5 min., let cool for a few minutes, then spray the sides of the springform pan, use a hand  mixer and slowly beat creamcheese and sugar. Everything after that is really slow (not to overbeat) and the last few items, I stir in by hand. 

Bake in a water bath (springform wrapped in heavyduty foil) 1 hour at 350, turn oven off and leave in for 4-5 hours.

I'm so happy I found this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The perfect New York Style Cheesecake. Echoing others sentiments...make sure the cream cheese is at room temp and do not overbeat. I made this in a half size (4" springform) and mini muffin tins for a gathering and it turned out excellent. If you are concerned about cracking or dryness you could bake it in a water bath (roasting pan with a little water in it). I added a pinch of salt and a little 2 tsp of lemon juice to the batter for the taste I like. Will be topping it with a layer of sweetened sour cream. Enjoy! Easy and a good recipe!

text:
This is the bomb! This is the most fantastic cheesecake! I've made many, but I struggled to find the perfect texture. This is it. I'll never go back to the sub-par recipes. I took the advice to reduce the flour to 2 tbs because I prefer an ultra creamy texture. I avoided over beating, used a water bath, and allowed it to cool in the oven. And guess what? No cracking! For the first time ever! It's also delicious, way better than any cheesecake I've ever eaten. I like this with a gingersnap crust. My only issue was the very outer edge browned slightly. It didn't overset or become tough, just slightly golden in a couple of spots. Next time I will take the advice to lower the heat considerably and cook longer. I chalk this up to user error or a wonky oven. It's certainly not the recipe's fault. I absolutely love this!

text:
Fanatastic.  Made this gluten free by substituting 1/4 cup flour with 1/4 cornstarch.  Substituted graham cracker crust....with 2 cups gf ginger snaps from Trader Joe's...6 Tbsp melted butter. Also, decreased fat by using low fat cream cheese/sour cream.  

Took many reviewers suggestions:  Did not overbeat; baked in hot water bath; used Bailey's Irish Cream instead of milk.. This recipe is a winner.

text:
I can't remember if I rated/commented before. I made this for the third time this weekend. Last time I changed pans, overmixed and overcooked it.  It still tasted good but texture was wrong and it cracked. THIS time I used a hotwater bath due to uneven heating in my oven, used parchment paper for the bottom and sides, had all ingredients at room temp., and only used a mixer for creaming the sugar and cream cheese and gently mixed the rest by hand.  This was THE MOST PERFECT cheesecake I have ever had! If there is such a thing, it was too perfect.  No one believed I had made it.  Oh well. I knew and that was all that counted. Served with two toppings, a sour cherry topping and a peach topping.  Both had a hint of Amaretto and they were so good.  This is definitely my go-to recipe for cheesecake!

4154498
Display Name:
Blaire Chandler Wilcox
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1881345.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was terrified to make my first cheesecake, but I needn't have been!  This turned out PERFECT!  I can't believe I made something so pretty and so delicious!  And I didn't even have the springform pan!  I used a 2 inch tall, 9 inch cake pan instead.

I assembled the ingredients in the exact order, used the handmixer only for combining the cream cheese and sugar (about 30 seconds on the low setting), after which I gently stirred everything with a wooden spoon.  I baked it at 350 for 60 minutes as directed.  (I did place the cake pan in a deep cookie sheet and poured hot water in the cookie sheet to keep the top from cracking while cooking.)  After turning off the oven, I let sit for 6 hours without cracking the door.  

The springform pan would have made the slicing easier, but because I buttered the sides of the cake pan really well before pouring the batter in, when it cooled and pulled away from the sides, there was just exactly the right amount of space to slide a flexible cake cutter inside.  The first piece wasn't perfect in terms of its look, but all the others were!

I am so excited to know how to make such a wonderful cheesecake.  Thank you so much!

I followed this recipe as listed.  
1. It rose out of the pan-made too much batter for a 9 inch springform
2. It was completely burnt around the outside, even the bottom of the crust was burnt.
3. After turning the oven off, I let it sit for two hours and then checked it and it not only fell, but all the sides cracked off and fell into the center of the cake.  
4. Once I pulled it out and peeled away a bit of the burnt pieces, it looked like a cheesecake and definitely smelled like one so I thought, Hey! Maybe it's just not so pretty.  Took a few bites in different places, all you can taste is egg.  

All in all, a horrible recipe.

text:
This recipe is wonderful as is, except I used oven temp. of 325 degrees and cooked it 15 min. longer, and I used a casserole dish of water under the cheese as water bath. The cheesecake turned out beautiful (no cracks), and tasted wonderful. Had compliments from all who ate it, and they wanted the recipe.  Actually, this was my second one in one day because on the first one, I turned the oven on broil instead of bake (by mistake of course). When I started smelling it right away I knew something was wrong, so I checked it and sure enough the selector knob was on broil instead of bake.Duh....I immediately turned it to bake and finished baking it for the remainder of 1 hour, and left it in the oven for an hour to cool(while I went to the store and bought new ingrediends). Believe it or not, it tasted pretty good after I peeled off the burned part.All in all, it is a great recipe and I will definately make it again (and cook on bake instead of broil!).

This always turns out perfectly for me. It tastes delicious and is my go-to New York  cheesecake recipe. I follow the recipe exactly (ingredient and prep wise). The only change I make is the actual cooking instructions. I always bake my cheesecakes in a water bath and have only had one to crack (to the point I refused to present it to people outside my family) one time, and even then the taste was still perfect. I usually top it with fresh strawberries and the “Supreme Strawberry Topping” recipe I found on here as well and some sweetened whipped cream (the real stuff, not whipped topping).

text:
I make this cheesecake all the time, tweaking it depending on the flavor that is requested. I have discovered that baking it at 325 degrees and using a bain marie (water bath) results in a cake that doesn't crack as much as when baked at 350 degrees. I also place a wooden spoon in the door during the time it cools in order to slowly circulate air in the oven.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is an amazing cheesecake recipe. I used a 9 inch springform pan and I needed more graham crackers than the recipe calls for. It's soo important that the ingredients are at ROOM TEMPERATURE so that you end up with a smooth and creamy cheesecake and not a lumpy one. I used an oven bag to keep the water from getting into the pan as I cooked in a bain de marie. LEAVE IT IN THE OVEN! I cannot stress this enough. After one hour just turn the oven off and leave it in there for a few hours. I made an amazing ganache that I poured on top when the cheesecake was cold.

Nutella Ganache: 1 cup of heavy cream, 1 cup of nutella, 1/3 cup of semisweet chocolate chips, 1 tablespoon of dark rum. Heat in a saucepan and then cool.

This is excellet! ...Though I must admit I changed the dickens out of this receipe, just to make it as low cal / carb as possible ^____^ Okay: didn't use the crust, I used Tnuva fat free soft cheese instead of cream cheese, left out the milk, splenda instead of sugar, egg substitute, low fat sour cream and 2 tbs corn starch instead of flour. userID:
6360141
Display Name:
Nikki Stutzman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
130
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4541910.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Totally worth the time!  I was searching for a New York Cheesecake recipe to surprise my Valentine and stumbled upon this recipe.  I started by greasing the sides and bottom of my springform pan and made the crust with 1 1/2 c of graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 c of crushed almonds, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 cup butter, and 1 egg white (as recommended by another review.)  I mixed only the cream cheese and sugar with the mixer, and the rest of the ingredients by hand, and cut back on the flour to 2 Tablespoons for a more dense cake. I double wrapped the pan in aluminum foil before filling the water bath with boiling water from the teapot.  We could not wait the 5-6 hours until removing from the oven, but did give it a good 2 1/2 to cool and from there into the fridge.  It was picture perfect without cracks or lumps. Absolutely decadent.  I made us an optional topping on the stove with raspberry preserves, lemon juice, and a small amount of balsalmic vinegar to intensify the flavors, and thickened with a small amount of cornstarch...was good, but I preferred it plain.  You won't be disappointed!
Review:

5

text:
I know squat about making cheescakes, but had the hankering for one so I followed this recipe to the letter and it almost turned out perfect. Some cracking occurred. I decided to make more for xmas gifts and hand mixed the eggs and the next few cheesecakes turned out perfect. My neighbor said it was the best cheesecake he had in his life. I agree.  Three things are important! ...hand mixing the eggs at the end, bake on a small rack above a pan of water and letting it cool in the oven are key!!  Cooking above a pan of water keeps humidity and prevents cracking. Thank you.

Very good recipe.  I used 2 regular and 2 low fat packages cream cheese and Whey Low as a substitute for the sugar.  I also just followed the recipe on the Graham Cracker Crumbs box for the crust again using Whey Low instead of sugar.  I cooked down some frozen strawberries with a little sugar and vanilla for the topping which really set this off.  I took the advice of others and hand beat the cheesecake filling, but I think next time I will use my Kitchen Aid mixer set to 'stir' as the hand beating didn't seem to get this smooth enough.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
Great recipe ! i have never baked a cheesecake or even watched some1 do it ,and it turned out great .  here is summary of important advices : 1-all you ingredients must be at room temp.(V.Imp) 2-A water bath is the best approach so it wont be dry. 3-if white lumps are stil visible after mixing  just use a filter to remove them  4-grease the pan especially the edges. 5-when it is done cooking after one hour pass a 6-knife between the edges of the cake and pan. 7-instead of 1/4 cup of flour use 2tbs gives it a very creamy texture. 8-Add cinnamon ,and nutmeg 1/2 small spoon to the crust. dnt check on while it is baking,and hopfully it will turn out great !

text:
I've made this cheesecake twice and it is amazing!  The only changes I made were of a personal preference...i added about a 1/4 C of sugar to the graham cracker crumbs.  Also, the second time around I made a chocolate marble cheesecake.  My family of 4 polished them off w/i 24 hours...lol.    Also, let me say that if you follow the recipe and use the water bath, let the cheesecake cool the full 5-6 hours and then refridgerate...there should be no cracks.  If you follow the recipe, you'll end up with a perfect cheesecake.  If you don't end up with a perfect result....YOU DID SOMETHING WRONG!!!  Don't blame the recipe and give it a poor rating, if you don't use the water bath or altar the recipe drastically.  It's unfair to blame the recipe writer because you can't follow simple directions.    Thanks Chantal for a truly amazing cheesecake recipe.

text:
I want to start off by saying that when I made this recipe I was living in the United Kingdom so had to use Digestive biscuits instead of the crackers. I have now emigrated to California and will definately be making this again - hopefully this weekend.  Anyhow - The first time I made it  I decided to substitute half of the cheese for a low fat option and followed the directly to the t but I just don't know what went wrong, maybe combination of the cheese and overbeating..? But it just didn't seem to be cooking  for some time and once it was done it tasted a bit like feet, had a hint of cheesecake flavour but it just was not good. But it didn't put me off and I attempted a second one - only I used all full fat Philadelphia. That one came out perfect! No cracking and really did taste amazing. I put half of it in an air tight container and froze it (it keeps very well) and kept the other half in the fridge and it seemed to taste even better the following day! I put it down to the flavours coming through. This really is a great recipe and one I will use again and again.

This was my first attempt at making cheesecake - and it turned out amazing!! I am so excited! I followed a few tips by other reviewers (placed a pan of water on the rack underneath the cheesecake as the water bath, used a graham/butter/sugar crust and hand mixed all ingredients after the cream cheese and sugar).  This turned out great - no cracking.  It got a little brown on top so next time I might cut the time down just a touch, but it didn't change the taste so it probably doesn't matter.  Very easy recipe - I'm not a cook by all means so if I can make this then anyone can.

text:
Tried this recipe this week and loved it.  My husband said it was the best one I have ever made.  It turned out creamy and did NOT crack!  I was so happy since I was making it for a baby shower.  I did follow the advice of several other reviews.  I reduced the flour to 3 T, did a different crust (1 1/2 c graham crack crumbs, 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 sugar) and reduced cooking temp to 325.  I probably could of cooked it an additional 5 minutes and still been good.  I left it in the oven for 2 hours after baking.  I am not sure what caused it not to crack but from now on when I make my cheesecakes I will mix by hand all ingredients after beating the cream cheese and sugar together and grease my springform pan.  Seriously have to agree with others on this recipe.  FABULOUS and will def make it again@

Its for sure a labor of love, but I followed this pretty much exactly and it turned out great.. once the hour is up just turn the over off.. no peeking and also if you have greased your spring form pan, you shouldn't have to run a knife along the sides... I greased well but then opened the oven after the time was up to run the knife and realized fast that all i was doing was messing things up, it was already pulling away from the sides fine.. So just leave it alone.. So good. I also followed what others suggested with the berry sauce.

text:
Wow, thank you for helping me make an awesome cheesecake!  This was the first one I have ever made, and it set perfectly without cracks.  I doubled the crust so I would lots for the sides as well (used 1 1 1/2 cups crumbs, 1/4 cup butter, and 1/4 cup sugar for each batch of crust, as suggested by other reviewers).  I greased the whole pan really well, used room temperature ingredients, tried to minimize mixing time, and used a water bath.  I didn't have time to let it sit in the oven for 6 hours, but 1 1/2 hours worked well, and after sitting in the fridge overnight, this is the best cheesecake ever!!

city:

country:
None
text:
An excellent recipe that delivers what it promises:  professional-level dense New York cheesecake.  I was concerned about the crust--it seemed so simple--but it also worked well, adding a bit of a counter-balance to the sweetness of the filling.  One quibble:  I threw in the sour cream, vanilla and flour all together and the flour clumped a little with vanilla, marring an otherwise perfect cake (I covered it with blueberry sauce).  To avoid cracking, bring up the ingredients to room temperature, use an oven thermometer to ensure exact heat, put the cooking cake in a water bath and run a knife around the edge of the cake after it has baked.  Presto, perfect.  With all that said, I personally prefer a less dense and fluffy cheesecake and I was wondering if readers here can point me to a reliable recipe?  Thanks!

text:
I've been thinking about making this cheesecake for about a month, after reading all the reviews and tips I decided to try it.  This is the first time I have ever made a cheesecake in the oven, so I was gonna make sure I did it right.  I bought the full fat cream cheese, sour cream, let it set out overnight with the eggs to bring it to room temperature.  I get up in the morning to make the cheesecake, and my eggs are missing...My husband ate them for breakfast!  I was thinking, "Do u always make it a habit to eat stuff that is just sitting around on the counter?"  Anyways, after buying more eggs and warming them in the oven.  I made the cheesecake. Left my daughter in charge of the crust, she forgot to add the sugar. We added a 1/4c of pecans to the crust mixture(YUMMY). I used almond extract instead of vanilla (my preference)  After the cheesecake had been baking for about 30 min, I realized I forgot to add the flour.  Anyways, after letting it cool down for a bit in the fridge(I couldn't wait) I tried a piece.   It is great! So creamy, not too sugary, not too sweet, just perfect. I gave some to my co-workers, they said it was the best cheesecake they had ever had.  So, at the end of the day it was a perfect cheesecake for a not-so-perfect day.

Nice, classic cheesecake. Mine did crack, but I didn't not bother with the water bath-- I figured that it was going to be cut up anyways :) It was smooth and creamy and I thought it was plenty sweet enough.  I was a little confused about the amount of graham crackers, I wasn't sure if it was the whole sheets or individual crackers. Obviously it was NOT the whole sheets b/c that was way too much for the crust. Will use those crumbs for a different dessert. Also, next time I would use a 10 inch springform. There was so much batter that the whole thing rose out of the pan during baking and because of this, became a little to o brown around the edges.

text:
First time cheesecake here!! I was a bit nervous after reading all the reviews on cracking and overcooking etc.  I followed the recipe and the cake was PERFECT.  Mine did not crack but I had one or two almost invisible air bubbles on the top.  I followed the suggestions of previous reviewers and changed the recipe for the crust.  I used 1 and 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 cup melted butter, 1/2 tsp. ground cinnamon, and 1/4 cup sugar.   I also used a water bath and wrapped alumunium foil over to prevent water from seeping through. Since this was my first cheesecake Iwas patient enough to wait for the 6hr cooling time and it was worth the wait..simply delicious!! I can't wait to make this again.  Thanks for the recipe. AMAZING!!!!

first two times i made this it came out not so great. but i accept full responsibility for that! first time, i didn't get past prep, cause my ingredients weren't room temperature(big mistake, i got soup instead of cheesecake batter). the second time i didn't have the water bath, and i didn't grease the sides(also big mistake. it cracked BIG TIME). this last time though i had the water bath, and greased the sides(hooray!) and for good measure i put tin foil over the top just in case it decided to rise :P and it came out perfect! will be using this recipe for... um... ever?!

text:
I'm making this cheesecake for the 3rd time in a week.  I took one to work.  Our family just LOVES it.  I read the hints on making cheesecakes and found out the importance of the water bath.  I used my springform pan and also my 13"X9" cake pan.  When I used the springform pan it raised approximately 3½" without a crack.  In the cake pan it raised about 2".  Either way it was PERFECT~!  I used my 18qt. NESCO  oven to bake it in instead of my oven.  I placed a towel over the nesco to keep the heat in it better.  After the hour I turned it off and let it cool for about an hour before putting in the refrigerator.  I never had one crack and we enjoyed it without any toppings of any kind.  I just asked my 14 yo daughter what she'd rate the cake, I asked a 5, which is the best, she said, NO, Mom a 6.  LOL

country:

text:
this was my first cheesecake ever and it was a HUGE hit. the only thing i still wonder is whether or not to COVER the cake when baking..i didn't but as mentioned below i followed the cooking instructions to a T and mine had a light brown top layer.  i cooked the graham wafer crust for 7 min at 375 and cooled it as the receipe didn't mention what to do here and the wafer box had those instructions.    I used the boiling water bath for the cooking that other people suggested and then removed the bath when i turned off the oven at the 1 hour mark and ran a knife around outside of the cake and then immediately returned the cake into the cooling oven and left the oven door closed for 4 hours while it cooled.    i used only 2 tbsp of flour as others had suggested instead of 1/2c the receipe says.  i used a raspberry/ blackberry sauce made with about 2-3 cups of the berries heated and then strained from seeds and then put back on the oven top with about 1/2-3/4 c flour until deep colour and thickened. Cooled sauce before decorating.   i wasn't sure whether to knife away the top layer of the cake as mine was a light brown not white as in the photos, but the deep red sauce covered up the cake nicely. then to decorate, i used toasted coconut around the edges as well as the first inch of the crust's edge with some fresh kiwi fruit and it looked great.   i took it to a party and it was 100% worth the 5 stars!!!! everyone including myself thought it was DElicious!!!!

text:
This is the perfect cheesecake recipe and I have made it many many times!  My neighbor requests a cheesecake from me a couple times a year, and my daughter just called me for this recipe this morning as her husband requested it for Christmas Day! It is so good that a topping, although tasty, is unnecessary! I spray the bottom and sides of the pan, and I place a pan of water in the oven, but I do not put the cheesecake into the pan of water.  I also run a knife around the sides of the pan before removing it, as spraying helps, but it still may stick a little.  Otherwise, I follow the recipe as written, and it comes out perfectly every time!  I agree with another reviewer, if it doesn't work for you, it is definitely not the recipe, it is something you have done wrong!

text:
This is a very good cheesecake recipe. This was my first cheesecake and came out amazingly good. My family could not believe this cake wasn't store bought. Already there are requests for the next one. The only thing i change was the crust, I used the Graham Cracker Crust 1 recipe from this site. All of my ingredients that I use was room temperature e.g milk,eggs,cream cheese and sour cream.I didn't have a big pan to do an water bath, so I boil some water put the water in a pan directly under the cheesecake and bake it for one hour, turn the oven off and did not open the oven until six hours later. The best time for me to bake this cheescake was at night, there were no temptations for me to open the oven I was sleeping : ). If you are a fan of cheesecake this is a must have recipe.

text:
This recipe was so simple to make.  Some of the take-away points from other reviews that made this better for a novice cheesecake baker included: 1) room temperature ingredients, 2) grease the pan to allow proper cooling without cracks, 3) when preparing the water bath, use an oven bag to place the pan in to prevent any type of leaks to reach the cheesecake, 4) added some cinammon and nutmeg to the crust ingredients.  This cheesecake was just wonderful.  Fluffy, moist, and perfect consistency.  I am not a good cook, but I did it!!!  And, my family ate the whole cake with nothing to spare.  Way to go!!

text:
This was very tasty! It was my first cheesecake and for the most part turned out well. It didn't crack, yay! A few mistakes I made: I didn't let the creamcheese cool completely, I got impatient and the batter was a little clumpy, although I didn't really notice clumps of cream cheese in the finished product. And, the big one, I added sour cream, vanilla, and flour all together and then stirred. Anyone who is not a beginner like me would have foreseen the problem - the vanilla clumped up in the flour in little, dark and very strong tasting vanilla clumps. I tried my best to smoosh them all, but of course couldn't. The flavor turned out ok, but the appearance was ruined. When it came out I gave it some chocolate swirls and that covered it decently. I will know for next time.

text:
Awesome recipe.  I left out the flour as suggested and it was delicious, very moist.  My husband loves new york style cheesecake and said it was the best he ever had!  I used the bath, greased the sides of the pan with butter and the sides came away on it's own and there were no cracks.  Used really heavy duty tin foil and wrapped three times to make sure no water got in.  Used 10 inch pan as I didn't have my 9 inch pan.  Baked at 325 for 45 minutes and left in oven for 1 hour and 15 minutes more.  Then left out of oven for 1 hour, then refrigerated for two days.  Cannot rave enough about this cheesecake.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
My husband is a big fan of the deli style cheesecake, but I had never attempted to make one before because of how difficult I heard they were. For our sixth wedding anniversary I decided to give it a shot. Using 'Chantal's New York Cheesecake' recipe, along with following some tips from the reviewers, my first cheesecake turned out absolutely amazing!   The changes I made to the ingredients were to cut the flour in half and to use a different crust recipe ('Graham Cracker Crust I' from this site) that included more butter, plus sugar and cinnamon. Other than that, the tips I picked up were to be careful not to overmix the batter and make sure all the ingredients were at room temperature. I also set a pan of boiling water on the rack beneath the cheesecake in the oven. The result was heavenly and my husband can't wait for me to make this again!

text:
This review is based on Hubby's proclamation that it was better than Cheesecake Factory's.  I did make a few changes based on other's reviews:  added cinnamon and sugar to the crust, but next time I will add an egg white to bind it together a little better.  I only used 2T flour because I wanted a creamier cake rather and oh was it!  I used a water bath and baked at 350 for 1 hour and left in oven for about 2-3 hours before transferring to fridge.  I had a perfectly set cake by morning with no cracks.  The only other thing I will change next time is to use a cooking bag instead of double wrapped foil around my pan.  I ended up with soggy crust, but it didn't affect the taste of the cheesecake a bit.

userID:
1963939
Display Name:
Sugarboo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sugar Free Version: I used one cup of Sorbitol Powder instead of sugar. You can buy this for about $4  a pound.  I also used  one level teaspoon of : NuNaturals Brand, "White Stevia Powder".The cost varies for that product, based on the size,  but it is not expensive. If you don’t know what the natural sweetener “Stevia” is, please do a search on the internet. It is really good stuff!!! And no calories.  For the crust, I bought Vortman's brand sugarfree Shortbread cookies, put all of the cookies in a food processor, added 3 tablspoons unsalted melted butter, a dash of cinnamon, one half a teaspoon of sorbitol poweder, and 1/4 cup of unsweetned dessicated coconut, also available at Iherb.com.for about $3  a pound.  I pulsed this until it was all fine crumbs. I used that for the crust.. The cheesecake turned out  sweet, but not too sweet, and it does not have an aftertaste like a lot of artificial sweeteners have. I used a dallop of sugar free cool whip on the top of each slice. I have made many cheescakes and this one is simple and comes out perfect! The sweetener in the cookies is Maltitol,which is similar to Sorbitol and the Stevia powder is all natural, from a plant. So there is not Splenda(sucralose) and no Equal(Aspartame) sweeteners. If you like it more on the sweet side, add 1/2 cup more sorbitol powder to the cheescake batter.

None
text:
This was my very first time I had ever made this! And it turned out PERFECTLY! Thanks to all the reviews I read that helped me greatly.Before I do a recipe here I read the reviews first to get all the tips I can and thanks to that this was the most perfect cheese cake ever! My husband Just kept remarking how wonderful it was and so did I! I did use the water bath,the foil worked,no leaks I used the large size heavy duty foil.I only used the mixer for blending the cream cheese w/the sugar,then used a woooden spoon to mix the rest.Also made sure that eggs & cream cheese were at room temp. One thing I did do that I didn't see mentioned (since I seen that bubbles in the batter was one of the reasons that would make it crack)was after I poured the batter into the pan was to gently tap the pan on the counter several times to bring up air bubbles in the batter to the surface. I had o cracking.Baked for 1 hour turned oven off- then I left in the oven 'without peeking'lol for about 2 hours.Then let it set on the counter for about 4 hours.It was set firmly and was cooled and ready to slice,my husband(& me too) couldn/t wait any longer!It was perfect. Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe!And thanks to all that submitted their reviews,which were so very helpful.This is a Wickedly Good recipe!Can't wait to make it for a outing and of course the holidays!

I had never made a cheesecake like this before. After reading many helpful reviews by other cooks and cheesecake articles written by AR's staff, I was ready to attempt the unknown! Boy, was it worth the effort! Excellent dessert! It's important to know that your ingredients must be at room temperature so you won't have lumpy batter. Do not over beat the batter. text:
Excellent Recipe. I increased the recipe to 18 servings. Instead of using a 9 inch spring form pan I used a solid 10 inch by 3 inch deep cake pan. I lined the bottom of the pan with parchment paper befor puting in the crust. I followed the direction exactly for preparing the filling. Once I filled my cake pan I baked the cake at 300 deg for 3 hours in a water bath. Yes it may be a long baking time but with the size of the cake and thickness it is the best way to cook it. Once the cake was done I turned the oven off and left it in for the 6 hours. Once I removed it from the oven I put it in the fridge overnight and removed it from the pan in the morning and it came out perfect. The family loved it. I topped the cheese cake with the filling from the Strawberry Pie II. I will be using these recipes again.

text:
I was a nervous wreck making this cheesecake and all for no reason!  To date it is the best recipe I've chosen from this site!  I took the advice of another reviewer and cut the flour to 2TBSP for a smoother consistency!  It was easy to put together--I had no problems with cracking at all.  Mine did brown on top though and I baked in a water bath at 350 for one hour and turned off oven and let sit for approx. 5 hours.  Next time I think I'll take the tip of one reviewer and bake at 220 for nearly 4 hours; that may reduce the chance for browning on top.  Thanks for the recipe and all the great reviewer tips!!

This cheesecake tastes awesome and no cracks. My husband asked me where I bought it, he said it was the best cheesecake he has ever had. I made this in a 8 inch springform pan over a water bath (didn't have a pan big enough to put it inside) and sprayed the pan first with PAM, only used 1/2 a cup of milk and let the ingredients get to room temperature before mixing. Otherwise I made it exactly as stated. I made this around midnight and let it sit in the oven while I slept. Thank you for this recipe.

text:
I LOVE this cheesecake (as does everyone else that eats it). It is sooo thick and delicious. It's like a brick of cheesecakey goodness. My only complaints are that I would like it if the top of my cheesecake got more brown (the flavor is better then) and to use 5 T. of melted butter in the crust instead of 2 T. If I use 2 T., it's wayyy too crumbly and dry. Oh, and as always, I always top the cheesecake with canned cherry pie filling and piped whipped cream. Delicious and pretty!

text:
This was so delicious! I made one 6 in. pie and 2 dozen mini cheesecakes--yum! The mini ones took about 15 minutes to cook. I even melted some raspberry jam to swirl on top, but the plain ones were just as good.  I did have a problem with cracking for the pie, but I was in a hurry and I'm sure it was due to not cooling it slow enough.  My fault, not the recipe's.  Make sure the cream cheese isn't too cold or you'll have lumpy batter.  Next time, I'll sprinkle the flour in the batter a little by little b/c I got a few bumps.. maybe if I mix it into the sour cream first? Anyhow, I got a bunch of compliments, so I'll make this over and over (well, when I'm not counting calories =)

Display Name:
Terrie Flores Nguyen

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok! Let  me start by saying that this is the most delicious cheesecake I have ever tasted! And I am not just saying that because I made it, but everyone who ate it loved it! It is the first cheesecake I have ever made and to tell you the truth, I was so worried that it would be a disaster. I didn't know much prior to baking this cheese cake so I took advice from the other comments. I started by letting ALL my ingredients sit until they were room temperature.  Then I realized that I did not have an oven bag to wrap around the cake pan. So i used plastic wrap, making sure i placed it around the cake pan tightly and neat. After the plastic wrap, i wrapped it a few times with aluminum foil. I didn't use a mixer to mix my ingredients because I read that over mixing can create bubbles in the cake and cause it to crack. Since the ingredients were at room temp, it was easy to mix with a wooden spoon. I used one tablespoon less flour. I also whipped every egg separately before adding it to the batter. And i made sure to oil the sides of the cake pan. I cooked my cake in a water bath. I simply used a 9x13 baking dish and filled it half way with boiling water. Once my cake was baked, i waited 30 minutes, then took it out and removed it from the water bath, and place it back in the oven for 4 hrs. Then took it out, let it  cool completely to room temperature and placed it in the fridge. Next day, we enjoyed it!

text:
I was really a little freaked out about trying this recipe. The reviews were so good that I was a little intimidated. It turned out really good. My crust was a little soggy though. It certainly wasn't because I got water in it, I wrapped my pan with two layers of aluminum foil and used a crockpot bag to keep airtight. There was no evidence of water leaking in. I followed the recipe to a tee, except I only used 2 tablespoons of flour. I was a tad bit nervous about adding the flour, it didn't mix in well and seemed to be lumpy but it turned out beautiful. No cracks at all and there was no browning. I cooked for exactly 1 hour, then turned off the oven and left it in the oven without opening for 2 hours. The texture was smooth and creamy like a true New York cheesecake. I made a strawberry sauce by cutting up a pint of fresh strawberries and 1/3 cup sugar. I cooked on medium heat until thickened, about 5 minutes. It was yummy.

text:
This was great. I topped it with the Supreme Strawberry Topping from this site (VERY good). I did modify the crust to include sugar and cinnamon, and left out half of the flour, as per some other reviews. And put a pan of water on the rack below it in the oven. Otherwise, I just tried not to overmix and followed the instructions. Now I don't know if I peeked into the oven one too many times or what, but it couldn't have been cooling for more than a couple hours when it cracked like the Grand Canyon. Maybe I should've greased the sides or ran a knife around it. Oh well, I've never understood the anti-crack mania, since I'm just serving it to family here at home and it tastes just as good! The one issue I did have: the middle of the cheesecake tasted better than the outer part! It was all good, but the middle was just noticeably better -- more moist and sweet. Don't know how I could've overbaked it or anything, since I followed the instructions .... Oh well, I'll probably make it again, next time I get the cheesecake urge.

text:
BLUE RIBBON RECIPE!!!!!  This was my first cheesecake ever, Wow, it is delicious, and so easy to make. As some reviews say, YOU CAN NOT MESS THIS UP IF YOU FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS STEP BY STEP, trust me!  After reading some other reviews, I used "cinnamon-graham crackers" instead of plain graham crackers, and added some white sugar, about 1/4 cup, I also thought the crust  needed a little more butter, so I added an extra tbspn for a total of three. I sprayed the pan with "bakers joy" spray making sure I sprayed the sides, as I read some people had trouble with the cake sticking to the pan sides.  I always heard about the water bath and cheesecakes, and I had no clue as to how to "do the water bath" - nothing to it, I covered the bottom of my spring-form pan with two layers of aluminum foil and added boiling water to lasagna pan, and placed the spring-form pan right in the middle.  As the instructions say, I had it baking for exactly 60 minutes at 350 degrees. I then turned the oven off and left it in there overnigt, about 8 hours, although it says 6 hrs is enough, I went to sleep and took it out in the morning, placed it in the fridge for about 3 hours; and..... Wow!!!!  What an amzing cheesecake, no cracks, sinking, or nothing.. Thanks Chantal, and thanks to all of the reviewers for your tips!!!

text:
This is my first ever baked cheesecake.  I noted the following:    1.  For me, it took WAY MORE than         2 tbsp. melted butter for the         crust.  I used 1 1/2 sticks.        The crust turned out perfect.        I advise everyone to be aware and        be prepared when making the crust,        in case you find you need lots         butter like I did, you'll have it         out and ready.    2.  I baked the cake an hour and         20 minutes.  Next time, I'll go        an hour and 30 minutes minimum.    3.  I used everything straight out of         the fridge, added item by item to        my food processor.  Once it was         super creamy I poured it straight        into the springform, on the crust.        PERFECT!  No bubbles, no cracks.          (I'm not sure, therefore, what the         big deal is about overmixing.) The end result was a delicious, creamy smooth cheesecake that I will make again.

text:
This recipe was excellent. 1) Use a water bath and wrap foil around the pan to prevent water from seeping in 2) Hand mix to prevent air bubbles 3) Use a sieve if there are lumps 4) After pouring the batter into the pan, lightly drop the pan onto the countertop a few times and air bubbles inside the batter will rise to the top, then smooth the bubbles over with a spatula.

Wow.  This was spectacular! Served it to guests as part of a birthday celebration, and it got rave reviews from everyone.  I used Graham Cracker Crust II recipe from this site--didn't bake the crust, just poured the cheesecake in.  Added the flour in w/ the sugar and room temperature cream cheese, per another suggestion.  No other changes to the recipe.  I did NOT use a water bath, didn't have a pan big enough--and the cheesecake turned out PERFECTLY...no cracks at all.  This recipe makes a marvelous, better-than-store-bought cheesecake--thanks for sharing!!

this was a great base recipe.  I did bake for an hour in a water bath.  I didn't have any cracks.  I also used lowfat cream cheese and lowfat sour cream.  For the topping I did a mixed berry compote (that I usually use for pancake topping, etc.). 1.  Bag of frozen berries (abour 14oz) 2.  Place in saucepan w/ 1 tbsp. cornstarch, 2 tablespoons butter, 3/4 c. sugar, 1 lemon juiced 3.  Bring everything to a boil and then cool it in the fridge before topping cheesecake.    Delicious!

userID:
3522489
Display Name:
Cookin' Dude
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/176998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making cheesecakes for a long time, and this recipe is absolutely the gold standard. Success with it has a lot to do with mixing the batter properly and knowing when the cake is actually finished cooking. A few tips that make a difference for me -   1.BRING ALL COLD INGREDIENTS TO ROOM TEMPERATURE - if in a hurry, you can cut the creamcheese bars in half and *carefully* nuke them for 10-15 second intervals until room temp (use a digital thermometer to check), you can also soak the cold eggs in a bowl of tepid water for a few minutes  2. DON'T OVERBEAT THE BATTER. If you find that your cakes rise way up and then collapse in the oven, it's because there's too much air in the batter from overbeating. Instead gently mix by hand and thoroughly blend(especially the eggs) the ingreients.  3. USE A WATER BATH. You will never crack another cake if you do this. Make sure to use several layers of aluminum foil around the springform pan to prevent water leakage (I prefer a solid silicone pan instead, it takes some practice to flip the cake out afterwards, but result is worth it). 4. USE A DIGITAL THERMOMETER. Poke it into the center of the cake near the end of the cooking time, when it reads 160 deg  TURN OFF THE HEAT!  Happy Cheesecaking!

text:
I've cooked this a few times. It is really good plain or with your favorite toppings. I made it for my wife the first time for her birthday and she love it. Been making it every since. Has never cracked using the water bath. The 1/4 cup of almond, 1/4 cup of butter, 1/4 cup of sugar, and 1 1/2 cup of graham crackers that one review suggested gave the crust a really good flavor. You won't be disappointed with this recipe. To get a smooth clean cut when slicing the cheesecake, stick the knife in a glass of hot water for a few second to warm the knife. Dry off knife then slice.

text:
For the crust, I used the amounts suggested: 1.5 crumbs, .25 c sugar, .25 c butter, melted, 1 tsp cinnamon and dash of nutmeg.  However, I don't have graham crackers where I live, so I found a nice cookie to sub but also used IKEA gingersnaps for 1/3 of the amount.  Added a really nice quiet zing.  I used the bain marie (hot water bath) method as well as greased the sides of the pan and had a perfect cheesecake in form.  It was soft and creamy inside with a firm top without a crack in sight.  It was a thing of beauty although we didn't hesitate to cut to enjoy.

akoni

city:

None
country:
None
text:
As others would agree, this recipe is perfect. Why would I only give 4 stars? Well, aside from my personal preference of avoiding sour cream in cheesecake at all costs because I feel it ruins the smooth taste, I ran into a problem with the spring form pan. When using a spring form for this recipe, I learned that it was best to sit the spring form inside of a bowl-shaped sheet of aluminum foil before sitting it in a roasting pan of water. This ensures that no water finds its way into the spring form while it is resting/cooling after cooking. If water gets inside the cheesecake will get mushy. Also, using room temperature or warm water (not hot or boiling) in the roasting pan gave me the best results. I'm not a chef or food chemist so I can't tell you why, but that's how it was for me. After all of this, the end result is that my and my girlfriend's family loved it. My girlfriend's family swore it was store bought and refused to believe otherwise.

Like this recipe needs another review. Anyway this makes a lovely smooth creamy cheesecake. I think that it is very important to use room temp. cream cheese and eggs. I used my hand mixer for the cream cheese and sugar then mixed everything else by hand. Definetly use the water bath and leave in the oven for at least an hour after baking. I've made this twice so far and each time it came out without any cracks, did not sink in the middle and was very lightly brown on top.

text:
Delicious! Mine did crack because i forgot to run a knife in a 'S' shape before baking and I didn't do a waterbath but live and learn. I did do something slightly different that I saw on Throwdown with Bobby Flay, I separated the egg yolks from the whites, incorporated the yolks in the mixture and went on in the directions, I whipped the whites into soft peaks and at the end of all the original directions I folded them in, its supposed to give a light texture, I loved the texture of this cheesecake. I also used the topping Bobby used on his cheesecake that won him that throwdown. Caramel Apple topping. Delicious! Pretty easy too, but just to warn even if a little caramel sauce gets on your clothing let it sit or use a washrag because if it touches your skin you'll have a pretty painful blister on your hands, no pun intended...lol. Anyways definitely try this recipe and the topping...perfecto!

http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/bobby-flay/caramel-apple-cheesecake-recipe/index.html

text:
This is the PERFECT cheesecake! Sometimes cheesecake can be too rich and thick and  you really can't enjoy much of it. This is NOT the case with this one, it's so light and creamy and delicious at the same time! I kept the recipe exactly the same except I added a bit of sugar and more butter to the crust. I made sure my cream cheese was at room temp as well. I baked in a water bath at 325 degrees for an hour and 15 minutes then turned the oven off and left it in for 3 hours. I then took it out and let it get room temp on the counter, then put it in the fridge. It was absolutely perfect in color and texture with NO cracks. I made a strawberry sauce to serve with it, it was so delicious!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2008-08-31T15:33:52.967

text:
It has been at least 10 years since I've made a cheesecake, and I was worried about this, but I thought with so many reviews, I couldn't go wrong.

The flavor and consistency of the filling was absolutely perfect, perfect, perfect. I made a strawberry reduction with fresh strawberries and sugar to put on top.

There seemed to be something wrong with the crust---it was awfully dry. I'm not sure if the 15 graham crackers means 15 sections or 15 whole crackers. It seemed like I either needed to halve the graham crackers or double the butter.

That said, it was delicious, and I will keep it in my file and make the small change of doubling the butter in the crust.

text:
I LOVE THIS RECIPE!!! The first time I made it, it cracked big time but tasted fantastic.  So the second time I decided to try the water bath, which was a completely new concept to me.  But to all the skeptics - IT WORKS!  I did one and a half times the mixture and split between 2 cakes.  I also tried to have cream cheese very soft before beating and only beat until combined.  I'm going to cover with a chocolate ganache for a party.  But seeing how these are the most perfect cheesecakes I've ever made, it almost seems a shame to cover them up :-)

This is a very good NY Cheesecake recipe. Very easy to make and delivers in flavor. It really lacks nothing. I would have given it 5 stars but I feel it can be improved by putting your favorite topping on it. I did bake it wrapped in aluminum foil and submerged half way in water. This is a NY Cheesecake recipe that I will make again and again. Thanks for posting.

text:
So easy and yummy. 

I topped mine with blueberry pie filling ~ delicious! Could not resist eating on same day, but definitely recommend letting cheesecake cool overnight in fridge for better texture ~ allows it to set better. 

I read about the hot water bath, but also read about water leaking in, so i filled a tray with water and put it on a shelf underneath the cake ~ worked well, no cracks. 

Used the recipe for crust from other reviewers and not the one listed here. Got rave reviews for that too!

text:
I LOVED this recipe. I am blown away!!! I did use the suggested changes in the crust- cinnamon, graham crumbs, sugar and butter, and found it to be a wonderful surprise when you got to the crust. I used all items at room temp and put it in for exactly an hour. We did take it out after two hours, and the middle was still too soft. We put it in the fridge and waited till the next day and my goodness, the wait was well worth it, in fact, we tend to think on the 3rd day it was even better!!! We cooked it at 350 in the water bath and did the two layers of foil (though water still got in there, it didn't ruin it thankfully). My mother- who is NEVER impressed, went off her diet to have more than one piece EACH night we had it!!!

text:
This is the first cake I made in 30 years.  My cake's decoration was heavily inspired by The Italian Chef, another rater.  The cake itself was fantastic - better than expected.  It tasted great even though I am not a cheesecake fan (I made it for my husband's b-day.) No tears, no lumps, no grittiness.  I followed all the tips mentioned by other rater, e.g. no overmixing, double aluminum foil + waterbath, 6-hr+ cooling off time, hot knifeblade to loosen around the edges  and to cut in slices.  In order to get the cake onto a pretty plate I placed a flat plate on top of cake (after taking the springform off) and flipped.  Then I flipped it one more time onto a pretty plate.  This was my mom's idea and it worked.  I will make this cake again!

text:
To get a beautiful cheesecake that is golden brown on top and does not split/crack please take the time to read the reviews.  I used a water bath (for the water bath you can just use a deep cookie sheet filled w/hot water) and let my cake cool in the oven and my cheesecake was gorgeous and tasted amazing (I added two split vanilla beans and made a vanilla bean cheesecake).  **Tip for cutting**  Use a large butcher knife and run it through some really hot water, wipe dry w/a cloth and slice slowly into the cake.  Remove the knife and run under the water again, wipe off, and repeat...this will ensure clean even cuts each time.  Enjoy!  This is a keeper for sure!

userID:
2820745
Display Name:
Jeff
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an extremely good recipe. I made it for the first time yesterday, and although I didn't follow directions exactly, the cheesecake came out with absolutely no cracks, air bubbles, indentations, or sinking. It was perfectly cooked and set.Tips for people having difficulty:

1. Be sure that EVERYTHING (cheese, milk, eggs, sour cream) is at room temperature.

2. Mix sugar and cream cheese gently on low speed just until the ingredients are blended, then stop mixing.

3. Mix everything else in BY HAND, using a large wooden spoon.

4. Use a water bath!!!!!

What I did differently from the recipe is the following: 

1. I baked it for exactly 60 minutes but at 325 degrees instead of 350.

2. Because the top was already very brown and I guessed that leaving it in the over longer would result in more browning, after 60 minutes, I took the cheesecake out of the water bath (gently) and carefully ran a knife around the pan to insure no sticking. I let the cake cool on a rack, outside the oven, for 60 minutes.

3. After letting it cool for 60 minutes, I removed it from the springform pan, put it on a covered cake plate, and put it in the refrigerator overnight.

My only criticism of the cheesecake is that despite baking it at a lower temperature, the top browned. However, after it sat in the refrigerator overnight and had set well, I took a large, sharp 12" knife and carefully shaved off the thin layer of brown. The cheesecake looks perfect, just like from the bakers.

text:
This cheesecake is terrific! I halved the recipe and baked it for about 35 minutes at 325. I turned off the oven and left it in for about 2 hrs. I had a little bit of cracking, but no sinking which is what I was really worried about. I made a sour cream topping by using 1 cup sour cream, 1/2 sugar, and 2 tsp of vanilla. I added a little more sugar and vanilla to taste, and spread this on top of my cheesecake after I was finished baking it. As it sat in the oven, the topping harded and blended in with the cake. After I took it out of the oven, I let it cool in the fridge for several hours. It turned out great!

text:
Wow wow wow! This was PERFECT cheesecake! This was my first attempt at making a cheesecake, and it couldn't have been better!  I used the advice of others and modified the crust a bit by adding 1/2 cup of sugar to it.  Maybe next time I'll add the cinnamon and nutmeg too.  I made sure all ingredients were room temperature. I used my mixer to mix the sugar and cream cheese and stirred the rest of the time.  I also followed the recipe and kept the cheesecake in the oven 5 hours after it was done...lastly, I lightly greased the pan with spray and had NO problems with it sticking.  It was perfectly done after the hour baking. Before serving, I combined a 16 oz container of frozen strawberries with some corn starch and a little sugar. I brought it to a slow boil and boiled it, stirring constantly, for about 2 minutes. It made a delectable topping!  This was definitely impressive...perfection at its best! Thanks for the SUPER recipe!

None
text:
This was a perfect classic cheesecake!   The secret to no cracks is to run a knife around the edge of the pan to loosen the cake from the side of the pan.  Cheesecakes crack when it cools and shrinks but sticks to the side of the pan.  Mine didn't crack and I didn't use a water bath, used cold ingredients, and even opened the oven door several times to make sure the cake wasn't sticking to the pan as it cooled.  I served it with a blueberry/strawberry sauce and fruit on top and got lots of complements.  I'll definitely make again!!
