text:
The best Cheesecake I have ever made. I followed the tips and advice from the website and did not get any cracks at all. The cheesecake came out picture perfect. I followed the recipe exactly. With a few changes. 1>Used the halved version of this recipe, and made it in a pre made graham cracker crust. 2> Filled a cake pan with water and put it underneath on the bottom rack while baking. (I even peeked twice for a couple of seconds to check the doneness – still no cracks.) 3>  Then : Cool 3hrs in the oven, cool 3hrs on the counter, wrap and chill for 3hrs in the fridge. Came out perfect! Also making sure all ingredients are at room temp is a must.

text:
I think that I was expecting far too much from this recipe.  After reading all of the amazing reviews, I was a little disappointed with the end result.  It was an ok cheesecake - but I have definitely had far better.
I modified the crust - 1 cup of regular graham cracker crumbs, and 1/4 cup of chocolate crumbs for additional flavour(in the future I would probably increase the chocolate crumbs).  To prevent cracking, I did use a water bath, which was fairly successful - only one tiny crack that was easily covered.  The top browned a bit more than I would have liked (definitely will decrease the time on the next go).  Served it with chocolate sauce, which was very good!! I will try this recipe again, just with more modifications.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a friend's birthday and it was exactly what I was looking for - GREAT and truly "cheesecakey" but not TOO dense.  

I did have a tough time with the water bath (suggested by this site) though.  I read through people reporting that they had had difficulty (leaks etc.) and figured I should be safe - so I used 4 layers of alumininum foil (and figured that that wouldn't happen to ME!) and the first time around, it STILL leaked.  Aluminum foil is touch to make a water tight seal with, since it tears so easily.

Anyway - I threw that cake out, and the second time around - I put a pan of water on the tray beneath my cake when cooking.  I am not sure that it has the exact same effect, but did keep the oven moist, and relieved the worry of a ruined cake after all that effort.

The (successful) cake itself was phenomenal.  I did a middle layer of: partially cooked apples (4) with their water drained; 1/3 of a cup of sugar and a teaspoon of cinnamon mixed in. I also put pecans on top, and drizzled with carmel.  Yum!

city:

country:

text:
This is the first cheesecake I've ever made, and it was awesome! I was nervous because so many reviews mentioned that their's cracked, but MINE DIDNT! I was also unsure about the 15 graham crackers mentioned in the ingredients, maybe it was just me, but I didnt know if that meant 15 whole, or 15 halves or what since the crackers are broken up into 4 sections.  I kinda eyeballed it.  I ended up using 1.5 sleeves of crackers. Also, I added more butter to the crust, and i failed to measure it exactly, I just kept adding it until it stuck together, and was easy to mold.  Dont be alarmed if your cake starts to rise quite a bit above the pan, it will go back down on its own without overflowing.  I got nervous because it looked like it was about 1 inch above the rim, and was starting to turn dark brown, but it turned out perfect! I topped with Pecans, hot fudge and caramel! DELICIOUS! Everyone asked for the recipe!

text:
This is such an easy recipe to make - who knew I could bake cheesecake!  In fact, it's so good that I've stopped making it for family functions.  I made one for the family get-together for my boyfriend's birthday, and his mom's cake sat, uneaten.  Making this cake gets me in trouble!!  Only for non-family functions from now on :)  *UPDATED*  I have made this recipe numerous times now, and every time I get rave reviews.  One of the best ways I've prepared it, is to get caramel ice cream topping (a thick kind) and use it as 'glue' around the sides of the cheesecake.  Then press Oreo cookie crumbs into the caramel.  On the top, around the edge place Turtles chocolates, and then criss-cross caramel and chocolate sauce in the middle of the cheesecake.  Mmmmmmmmm!!!

"Absolutely deliciosly creamy!" its the second time i bake a cheesecake. Since my first attempt was a little bit disappointing (another cheesecake recipe), i gave it another try with this recipe and i am so happy it went very well. i followed one of the reviewers advice to wrap the pan with a double layer of aluminum foil and bake bath the cake with a very hot water. i also use a baking paper lining the inside part of the pan, as what is advice, i left the cake inside the oven -door close(after one hour of baking) for 6 to 7 hours. my husband is very particular with cakes and when had a sliced of it he says.."it's the best cheesecake he has ever had!" i'll definitely make this wonderful cake again!  thanks chantal! 5 stars for it...no doubt!!

Almost 800 people can't be wrong.  This cheesecake recipe is tops and it's so easy!  I've made it twice and both times it has been a success.  Took the suggestions for the crust (1.5 cups graham crackers, .25 cup butter, .25 cup sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon).  Did a water bath last time (using a roasting bag instead of foil).  This time I did just a pan of hot water in the oven with the cheesecake.  Great results both times.  And most importantly of all, it tastes delicious!

Wow!! My very first cheesecake turned out beautifully!  I did adjust the crust using the 1/4 cup sugar, 1/2 tsp cinnamon and I needed more graham crackers.  I think I used 1 1/2 packs of graham crackers.  I put a pan of boiling water on the rack under the cheesecake. I'm not sure but I think the springform pan I used was maybe a 10 or 11 inch because it didn't seem like enough crust.  Though I am a crust lover.  I took it out after 2 hours and loosened the sides of the pan and then returned it to the oven for 6 hours.  It was perfect!  The color was gorgeous and there wasn't a single crack! Yay!   And it was simply delicious.  Several family members that "don't care for cheesecake" said it was an exception to the rule! I loved it myself!

I am trying a new spin on this recipe.  I'm using brownie as the crust but keeping the cheesecake part the same.  I hope it turns out just as beautiful because I'm planning on giving this one as a gift!  

Thanks for the great recipe Chantal!

text:
OMG, this cake is delicous... Everyone loved it and it's so worth the wait... I do not use the crust on this recipe. I buy "Honey Maid" graham cracker crumbs. 1 1/2 graham cracker crumbs, 1 tablespoon sugar, 6 tablespoons of butter melted. To keep crust from getting soggy in water bath I wrap the bottom of the springform with aluminum foil.
Pat the crumbs on the bottom of springform pan, bake for 8 mins, let cool to room temp. Then, you can continue with the recipe instructions.

Don't throw out this recipe just yet! I've made it in two separate ovens and in the first one, the cheesecake came out burned, cracked, and eggy after only 30 minutes. I highly recommend getting a thermometer for your oven if this recipe didn't work out, because it is so worth it when it comes out right!

text:
Perfect cheesecake--dense, rich, creamy, but not runny. And no cracks!  I modified the recipe a bit (who doesn't?).  I used crushed gingersnaps for the crust; replacd 1/4 c. of  milk with Amarula (marula fruit creme, kind of like Bailey's Irish creme); added the zest of one lemon; baked it in a waterbath (using boiling water); let it sit in the oven for only two hours after baking, then on the counter (on a hot summer night) another 2 hours before putting it in the fridge.

text:
I've never been a huge fan of cheesecake. I made it for my brother's birthday, and I think it turned out pretty darn good for my first time making cheesecake. I will have to find a better recipe for the crust (maybe it depends on the type/brand of graham crackers that you buy). I will use less flour next time. I think it might be missing something though. I had high expectations for it after reading all the good reviews. I'll have to experiment a little more with this recipe. I used a water bath, and it ruined my aluminum pan. I wrapped the bottom in 2 sheets of foil, but water still seeped in. Use an oven bag! I didn't get any cracks. There's a page with advice about making cheesecakes on this site. Read it! I didn't open the oven at all until maybe 4 hours later. I used low-fat cream cheese, and it turned out just fine. I was very pleased with this recipe.

text:
Delicious, rich and creamy!  Not being one to like crusts, I omitted it and just buttered the pan.  I was careful  not to overmix the batter and actually put all the filling ingredients into my mixer bowl at once, then combined just until smooth.  It was a warm day and the cream cheese was very soft -- I had let it sit out for several hours to soften.  I used a water bath too.  When it came time to turn off the oven and let the cheesecake cool in the oven, I discovered it was almost time to start dinner and so the cheesecake had slightly over an hour of resting time, not the 5-6 hours recommended.  I removed it from the water bath and let it rest right on the oven rack for the cooling time.  At the end of an hour, the entire cake looked a little wiggly, but not liquid.  I refrigerated it overnight and the next day I had an uncracked, lovely, lightly browned, creamy, delicious cheesecake!  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Perfect as usual! I do have some tips to prevent the cracking. All ingredients should be room temp, Do not overbeat the ingredients, lightly butter the springform pan and when you take the cheesecake from the oven, gently loosen around the edges because it shrinks up a bit as it cools and if you don't loosen the edges it will pull from the middle and crack.

This recipe was the best! I made it for a family gathering and everyone enjoyed it. However, I did follow other reviews and baked it in a waterbath and it came out with no cracks.  I also double wrapped the pan in foil so no water would leak in. I also made a strawberry topping to go along with it (2 cups of strawberries, 1/2 cup of sugar, and 1 tbs. cornstarch; cook over low heat until desired consistency.)  I also found a sour cream topping that went great with the cake too (1 cup sour cream, 2 tbs. sugar, 1 tsp. vanilla extract, and 1/2 tsp. almond extract; mix all ingredients together).

text:
I have been making this recipe for years and ALWAYS get rave reviews.  I recently tried using a Reynold's oven bag for the water bath, as water always seeps in , even if I wrap the springform pan well with foil.  It worked!  Just place the springform pan in the oven bag, and roll the edges down to right below the top of the springform pan, and viola!  No leaks!  Thanks, Chantal for a really great recipe!

Great recipe- VERY easy- VERY delicious!  I used Baily's Irish creme instead of milk.  YUMMY!!  I made several attempts at this to make this into 4" springform pans.  I baked 4 at a time.  After several tries, here's what I found:  Bake at 325 degrees, 35-30 mins.   I placed a pan of water on the lowest rack in the oven, and it worked great.  No cracks.  Hope this helps someone else!

text:
I have tried many cheesecake recipes from this site, and this one is the BEST! I made only a couple of slight modifications: I made an Oreo crust and used only 1 1/2 teaspoons of vanilla, baked in a 10 3/4" springform pan, put a pan of warm water on the rack below the cheesecake in the oven, and did not cool it in the oven at all after it baked for an hour.  Cooled almost completely on the counter and refrigeratated.  We waited 24 hours to cut into it, and it was perfect: tangy, just the right amount of sweetnees, awesome creamy texture.  This will be my basic cheesecake recipe from now on!

None
text:
I've reviewed this many years ago, but I'll update it.

This recipe is very easy to play with.  

- I've added Balies Irish Cream in the batter as part of the liquid
- I've added powdered chocolate to half the batter to make swirls.  
-  I've topped it with tempered chocolate to make it like a cheesecake dove bar.  
- I always serve with a fruit topping.  Usually raspberry.  Just take a pack of fresh raspberries, mix it with some water, boil it, strain it, add in some sugar and corn starch, add in some brandy and you've got a nice creamy fruit topping.

You can do anything with it!

I wouldn't trust any other recipe at this point, even though this is the only one I've tried.

Some things I want to try:

- Oreo crumbles for crust.
- Make caramel and swirl it in with the batter.
- Pumpkin something.
- Using a non-springform pan to cook in (I can never seem to really seal up a springform pan so it is 100% water tight).
- Cooking on a lower temp for longer (another reviewer seems to cook it at 250 or so for a couple hours)
- Adding a tablespoon of corn starch with the sugar.  Alton Brown gives this as a tip to take out insurance against cracking.  
Remember you are basically making custard here.  The lower the temp and the longer the cooktime, the more "custard" it will become.  Watch Good Eats on this :-)

My advice for first-timers?  Make this recipe to the letter the first time.  Odds are very good in your favor it will work out.  Then just start to play with it the next time

text:
I made this dessert for a non-traditional Thanksgiving dinner my family had last night. I stayed up Wednesday evening to make 2 of these cheescakes. After the hour bake time (yes, I baked both in the oven together) I simply shut off the oven and went to bed. When I got up the next morning, I put them in the refrigerator to get cold, then took them to my party. My family absolutely LOVED them. Much better than any box mix. And on one cheesecake I nearly forgot a whole brick of cheese! I added it before the eggs and it still came out wonderful. For those willing to try this recipe, a few hints: first, have everything ready, all measurements of ingredients, etc. Mixing is the hardest part. Second, make sure the cream cheese is soft, nearly room temperature - it makes mixing that much easier. Third, think ahead. These should be baked a day before needed, to allow for rest time in oven and chill time in refrigerator. Fourth and last - DON'T BE TEMPTED TO TEST WITH A KNIFE! I wasn't thinking and tested for doneness with a knife and wound up with cracks. They still turned out wonderful and the cracks can be hidden by toppings, but who likes cheesecakes with cracks? All in all, an excellent recipe. Thank you Chantal!!!

text:
Creamy yet firm and delicious, this cheesecake is a winner! For the filling, we followed the instructions exactly and minded the recommendations for making cheesecake provided by AllRecipies.com, including making sure the ingredients are at room temperature when mixing, not overmixing, using the water bath, and letting the cake cool overnight. This produced a cheesecake a world of difference from what we had ever made before! Thanks for posting the recipie Chantal!

text:
SO GOOD. No more needs to be said, everyone else's comments have pretty much summed up what everyone who tasted this thought...
My boyfriend and I had just got back from NYC when we tried this recipe. We thought it was as good, if not better than what we bought in the delis. We did alter the crust by using one pack of graham crackers (10 graham crackers wrapped in plastic), nearly 1/2 cup of butter, 1/4 cup white sugar, and 1/2 tsp cinnamon. The crust turned out well, a bit sugary which I thought was wonderful. Thanks for the great recipe, it is DEFINITELY a keeper.

text:
I loved this recipe.  I used a water bath to prevent cracks and a different crust recipe using walnuts, pecans, cinnamon and nutmeg.  Left it in the oven over night and then refrigerated unwrapped for 4 hours. It is creamy and has a delicate flavor.  It was not as firm as a traditional NY Style cheesecake so I may have not baked it long enough (1 hour at 350 degrees).  It is a definite hit.

text:
This turned out really well. I made this for my family while I was on vacation, and every peice was eaten. If I could give one peice of advice for this recipe, it would be to have your cream cheese and sour cream at room temp. That's an important step in making the "perfect" cheesecake that many people ignore. I used a waterbath like other reviewers and wrapped the bottom of my springform pan with foil to prevent any leaking. I thought the crust was the best part, and I could have eaten it all by itself. I wonder if there is a way to make it into cookies??  I served this with Sue's Hot Fudge Sauce.  A terrific combination. Thanks Chantal

WONDERFUL!  I cut the recipe in half & added 8 drops of orange oil (could add orange zest as well) with the vanilla.  I used an 8 inch springform and baked at the same temperature for a half hour.  I turned off the oven & let it sit over night.  It did crack but I put a layer of bittersweet chocolate on top & then topped with Strawberries that had been dipped in chocolate.  Beautiful AND tasty.  You can't go wrong with a recipe that has been reviewed this many times and has a 5 star rating!

text:
The best. I have tried many different cheese cakes but this one wins hand down.  You can play with this recipe alittle.  I have made this with the low fat cream cheese, was good , but not as good as the regular recipe.  I add alittle lemon juice, and you can also sprinken some Cin. & Sugar on the bottom of the crust for extra kick. 

You do need to grease teh sides of the pan, and do use a water bath!! I have only had this cake crack once out of about 12 cakes.  So far .... so Good!


THE BEST CHEESECAKE!!!!!!!!!!!!!

text:
This is a very good cheesecake recipe.  I really like the flavor.  I had to reduce the heat some, because mine really started to brown on top.  My only real problem was the water bath.  For some reason, although I covered the pan in aluminum foil, the water still seeped into the pan leaving the crust really soggy.  :(  I think next time I will just try a pan of water on the rack under the cake.  I had no cracks, and only left it in the oven for 4 hours before transferring it to the fridge.  Great recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
This has been my go-to cheesecake recipe for a while now.  I have to admit, turning the oven off while cheesecake is still jiggly in the center always freaked me out a bit, so I'd always bake it for longer than recommended (another 30 minutes or so) until it was completely set.  The top would brown a bit and I always got cracks, but it tasted soooo good and was nice and dense but still creamy.

I just made this recipe again yesterday, determined that it was going to be a pretty cheesecake this time!  I followed the instructions exactly - baked at 350 for 1 hour, then I turned the oven off without opening the door and left it in there for about 4 hours.  I also wrapped the bottome of my springform pan in two layers of foil and put it in a hot water bath to bake.  It turned out gorgeous!  (See my posted photo for this recipe.)  Only very slightly browned on the edges, no cracks, and definitely pretty to look at.  However, the consistency was very creamy and soft.  Many people prefer their cheesecake this way, but I personally like mine more firm & dense, so I may go back to cooking it longer even if the end result isn't as pretty!

Either way, it's absolutely delicious!

I use 12 graham cracker squares (so 6 rectangles) and 3 Tbsp of melted butter for the crust.

text:
I've made this a few times and each time it's been amazing.  I have read a lot of reviews to see what the consensus is and used many of your tips.  This is what I did:
- since I like a dense cheesecake I reduced the flour to 2 tbsp and reduced the milk (in my case 1/2 &  1/2)
- added the zest of one Meyer lemon and about 2 tsp of the juice    
- let the ingredients, all in their original seal, sit out to get to room temp except for the 1/2 & 1/2
- beat everything only enough to incorporate
- put a 9x13 pan of water under the cake instead of the direct water bath which soaked my cake when I tried it
- 325F at 1 hr 15 min then left it in for several hours without ever opening the door, then into the fridge with saran wrap over it
Thanks to the original recipe poster and to everyone who has made this recipe and contributed to the comments...they're very helpful!
No cracks.   Delicious, dense, creamy NY style cheesecake that gets rave reviews from all who eat it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this cheesecake often following the recipe to the t, except for the cooking instructions. Here's what works best for me. I preheat the oven to 400 degrees. I then cook the cake on the middle rack for 10 minutes. Then, I turn the oven off and leave the cake in the closed oven (no peeking) for another full hour. I then open the oven door and leave the cake in the oven for another full hour. Next, I sit the cake on the counter for a couple of hours until it is completely cooled. And, lastly I cover the cake and sit in the fridge for another 24 to 48 hours. I always get rave reviews! Today, I tried something different. I wanted to make this cake for a dinner with friends tomorrow night, but the full cake would be really over doing it for 6 people. So, I bought myself a 7 inch springform pan and cut the recipe in half. I still preheated the oven to 400 degrees and cooked for 10 minutes, then I turned the oven off and kept in closed oven for 50 minutes, and then another 50 minutes with the door ajar. Another successful cheesecake! I can see myself making the half cake again often as we usually have so much leftover when I make the full cake. Cheers!

city:

country:
None
text:
Made this using the ingredients exactly called for in the recipe.  After reading many of the tips and reading the Allrecipes "How to make perfect cheesecakes", I decided to use the warm bath method and lower the temperature to 325 for one hour.  I didn't have a large enough pan to put the cheesecake directly in a warm bath, so I used the tip of putting a 13 x 9 dish filled with hot water below it in the oven.  I also left the cheesecake in the oven for 5 hours after the one hour of baking and then kept in in the refrigerator overnight. I was careful not to over mix the ingredients to minimize the amount of air in the mixture.  The cheesecake came out great with no cracking at all.  The taste and texture was just like a New York style cheesecake, as I like it.  The only difference I would make is set the oven for 350, as the recipe states, instead of the 325.  The center was very slightly softer and more of a custard like consistency and I believe the higher temp would have taken care of that.   Overall, for my first attempt at making a cheesecake,  I was extremely pleased.

text:
Wow! This cheesecake is absolutely perfect. I added some peppermint extract and instead of graham cracker crust used Oreos, and it still came out amazing. Plus, this cheesecake did not crack and fall in the center, like most others do. I only had time to leave it in the oven as directed for about 2 hours instead of 6, and it still came out gorgeous. I feared of it being a little mushy, because that's how it was when it came out of the oven, but it hardened into the perfect consistency overnight in the fridge. Cheesecake is my favorite dessert, and now I have the perfect starter recipe that I can modify into any type of cheesecake. You must start with room temperature ingredients - the batter will lump if not. Also, do not thoroughly mix the eggs, just enough to have them incorporated. If you follow these few "rules", you will have a gorgeous cheesecake waiting for you in the oven.

FABULOUS!!! My 16 year old found this recipe and made it. It was her first time baking a cake from scratch much less a cheese cake. It was Delicious and perfect. You have to be patient. It was so tempting to want to eat it warm. We even googled it to see it we could it looks so good.  Lolll. She listen too what the reviewer MORENA said and did not over mix and basically have we left it alone in the oven over night till the bottom of the pan was cool (she made it at night) then we chilled it in the fridge for the rest of the day and had it after dinner. I have never ever attempted to make a cheesecake. I followed the recipe to a T and took others advice to be sure not to over mix and bake it in a water bath.  I baked it exactly 1 hr and left it to cool in the oven for about 6 hrs ( got up at 3am to put it in the refrigerator quick lol) and it turned out PERFECT!  My boyfriend went back for seconds.  It's very creamy and light, not at all heavy. Success!!!!

city:

country:
None
text:
Made this for thanksgiving. So after looking at countless reviews and countless other recipes from Philadelphia cream cheese, Keebler, food network, and Nabisco, I basically followed this  recipe and did used some of the suggestions from other reviews. I will tell you NO WATERBATH NEEDED! CRUST: I crumbled up the vanilla flavored graham crackers ad added 1/4c butter,  1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4c sugar baked for about 10 minutes. FILLING: everything basically stayed the same but instead of using milk I used heavy whipping cream, and instead of using 1/4 c of flour I put 2tbsps of cornstarch. I baked on 300 instead of 325 for 1hr, left it in the oven for 3 hrs ad then let it sit in the refrigerator for another 3 hours . This was my first cheesecake and it did not crack and again I say I did not do a water bath. It was very rich and creamy. I did not pour all of the batter in but most of it I did and my daughter made cheesecake cupcakes out of the rest of the batter both tasted awesome. This was a big hit with my family and friends and my fiancé who loves Cheesecake and eats so much of it till he is sick

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made SO many cheesecakes and this is the first one I've ever made that didn't crack!! The whole "leaving it in the oven to cool" trick awesome! I even completely forgot to add the flour and it turned out great. IF yours DOES crack (like so many of mine through the years), I've learned to take about a cup of sour cream mixed with just enough sugar to take away the tang and a few drops of vanilla (or almond is great too!) and spread over the top when the cheesecake is done. Bake for about another 10 minutes, and you have a nice glazed, smooth top again.

text:
This is an awesome recipe.  I did make it twice so here are my tips.... I didn't grease the pan good enough the first time or do a water bath as recommend by other people. As a result it stuck to the sides and cracked bad along with not being very flat.  The second time I greased the pan really well and did the water bath.  It came out beautiful and perfectly flat.  I also made the Fresh Strawberry Sauce Recipe by Chef John that is on here and it was an amazing addition.   I will make this again soon I'm sure.

country:
None
text:
Like previous comments stated, be sure to butter the sides of the pan. Also, various graham crackers come in different sizes. Classic Nabisco graham crackers are 4 crackers per rectangle, so be wary of that whilst forming the crust! Don't be scared if the very center appears uncooked, the cooling in the oven makes short work of that. 

This recipe is fantastic! It's super easy and tasty! I made this dish for my family due to mild grief from having to share measly slices at restaurants. With this recipe,  you'll never be short on Cheesecake again! Be sure to follow the directions about letting it sit in the oven; the cooling process is critical to the flavor and feel of the Cheesecake.

text:
The best cheesecake recipe, secret is don't overbake. 1hr is perfect, it WILL set on cooling. Leave it in the oven (off) to cool for the full time, it does make a difference. When cooked properly it is smooth and creamy. Cooling it slowly makes all the difference. Made a lot of cheesecakes and this is THE best one!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is great every time! I've tried it several times, but this time I was able to get it to not crack! I greased the pan really well with coconut cooking spray. I baked it in a water bath, after having foiled the cake pan in several layers. Once the one hour of baking was up, I took out the cake for a minute to run a plastic knife around the inside edge of the pan to make sure the cake is not stuck to the pan. I then put the cake back into the oven and left it there for five hours. It's the best if you can leave the cake in the fridge for a long time before serving. The times where it sat in the fridge over night were best!

text:
This is a great recipe! It's so easy to make and very hard to mess up. I'm kind of a novice when it comes to making cheesecakes and even I couldn't mess this one up. My husband requested an Oreo cheesecake for his birthday so I made this cheesecake with an Oreo crust and I added some chopped Oreo's into the mix before baking it and then put some on top afterwards. You could easily add any type of topping or filling you desire and this will still be delicious. I will definitely be making this again. Also, I didn't have time to leave it in the oven for 5-6 hours. I left it in the oven for about 2 hours and it was still fine. I baked it with a pan of water underneath to help prevent cracking.

text:
I made this perfect cheesecake for Easter, without doing a test-run beforehand. Thank goodness it was absolutely delicious. It was dense, but still moist and fluffy. The only variation I made, which was completely accidental, was I used too many graham crackers. I used 15 sheets, when I think each small rectangle counted as 1 cracker - oops. But I just had an extra thick crust which went up the sides of  my spring-form pan. I also ended up adding a lot more butter to the crust, since I had quadruple the amount of crumbs. The addition of the flour and the lack of a water bath worried me, but I stuck with the exact instructions and I am glad I did. If you love cheesecake, make sure you try this recipe. You will love it!!

text:
I put strawberries on top and made the strawberry sauce from this site. Everybody asked me where I bought it. It was seriously amazing and looked fabulous -- this recipe obviously needs no further reviews but I couldn't help it. It deserves it. I used a water bath, left it in the oven for about 3-4 hours after baking and didn't overbeat the ingredients after the egg. I'm gluten free, so I just picked up a Midel GF graham crust, crumbled it and reformed it to my cheesecake pan. I also used GF flour.  Absolute perfection.

text:
I've made this cheesecake recipe twice now. The 1st time it cracked horribly. I thought I did something wrong, so I decided to give it another whirl. I followed the recipe exactly as written, and it still turned out super ugly and cracked. The cheesecake overflowed the spring form pan when I baked it. Either lessen the amount of ingredients listed or include something in the recipe about not pouring the entire bowl of batter in the pan. Also, 15 Graham crackers?! 2 Tbsp of butter?! What?! That makes no sense. Way too much Graham cracker and not nearly enough butter. The crust just falls apart if you follow the recipe, and 15 Graham crackers is too much anyway. I'm still giving this 3 stars because my family did thoroughly enjoyed the actual flavor and texture despite how ugly it was.

text:
WOW! Rich, creamy, outstanding cheesecake. I made this gluten free and lower-fat and got RAVE reviews from the family when I served this at Christmas dinner. My sister-in-law, a professional cook, even asked for the recipe! To accommodate my celiac husband, I substituted GF graham style crackers in the crust and used a GF all-purpose flour mix in the cake. Because I like a "darker" flavor profile, I also used brown sugar instead of white in the crust and about 3 tsp of cinnamon---this gave the crust a nice pop that my guests loved. I used neufchatel cheese, 1% milk, and fat-free sour cream, to reduce calories. Despite this, the cake came out amazingly creamy and rich, with a wonderfully decadent mouthfeel. I would never, ever have guessed that this cheesecake was either GF or lower-fat, if I hadn't made it myself!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was one of the best cheesecakes that I have ever made or tasted, so I want to thank you for this recipe.    It exceeded my expectations and I will be using it again.  The cheesecake was super smooth and creamy;  and neither too tart nor too sweet.    My family kept raving about it, asking if I made it, as though they were in disbelief that it didn’t come from a bakery.      I did cut down the entire recipe by 1/4th, using only 3 packages of cream cheese; because I was running short on ingredients.   It worked out fine in a 9-inch spring form pan, making the cheesecake about 2.75 inches tall.   The cheesecake was in a water bath while it was baking in the oven to prevent it from cracking or drying.  I also reduced the cooking time to 45 minutes.      When that time was reached, the oven was turned off and the cheesecake was left in it, gradually cooling down.   After a few hours of cooling in the oven, the cheesecake was wrapped in plastic and refrigerated overnight, while still in the spring form pan.   Please note that when the cheesecake was done baking for 45 minutes, the center of it had a slight jiggle, but the sides were firm a few inches deep all the way around it.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1695679.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is THE cheesecake recipe. And it's so versatile! I've used it to make pumpkin, strawberry, blueberry and blackberry cheesecakes.  It can be used with a graham cracker crust, an oreo crust, a nut-based crust, anything. I've used this recipe at least 10 times now. It's very difficult to do though. The recipe has to be followed very precisely, the mixing has to be PERFECT (make sure it's smooth as silk), and you absolutely have to leave it alone in the oven (don't check on it!). Also, if you don't have a springform pan, I really wouldn't recommend trying this recipe. It's very difficult without it. Use a water bath if you can manage it. It really helps prevent cracking from temperature variations. Grease the sides of the pan, it prevents cracking. And I personally like to put parchment paper on the base of the springform pan, then put the side on over it, close up the pan, then cut off the excess paper around the sides. This makes it very easy to move it around after you're done.

text:
I can't get graham crackers where I live, so I substituted it with 250g crushed digestive biscuits and 100g melted butter. I mixed it in a saucepan, pressed it onto the bottom of a cake tin and baked that for 10 minutes before pouring the cheesecake filling in. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly and it was outstanding. I served it at a family dinner and it was extremely well received! 

One small gripe I have about it is that despite switching off the oven and leaving the cake in for a few hours, my cake still cracked in the middle. Think that may have been due to insufficient buttering of the sides of the tin so I might try that in future. One of my aunts also felt that it was a little on the sweet side, so I might reduce the sugar to 1-1/3 cup in future. But if you follow the recipe exactly, the results will be fantastic, as good as if not better than any store-bought cheesecake!

text:
It's good but I wouldn't say it's the perfect cheesecake. I've made it twice now and both times, it has really cracked. Not that I care if it cracks, but if you follow the recipe perfectly, it will crack. Now to me the flavor is the more important part of these cheesecake and it is in this area that I find this recipe lacking. I wish it was a more creamy texture. The second time I made the cheesecake I did cut back on the flour (used about 1/8 cup), and decreased eggs. I also added sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg to the crust. These were good variations but still is just isn't quite as creamy of a cheesecake as I'd like. I'd say it almost reminds me more of a custard. I may try the recipe again and cut out an entire egg. Another note: it must cool all the way and be refrigerated for several hours! The first time I made it my S/O convinced me we should try it early (had been in over for about 5 hours but not in fridge for very long), the consistency was completely off! We were both disappointed. The next morning his son grabbed a piece and said how good it was, so we tried it again, it was a night and day difference! We vowed never to rush it again.

text:
A few years ago I tried this cheesecake as my first ever cheesecake attempt. I failed. I've been jinxed ever since and have FUBARed every cheesecake I try, but today I revisited this recipe and used a few tips I found throughout my cheesecake failures... And... It came out perfect!! I am so relieved and thrilled! Things I did differently this time: 
-let ingredients come to room temperature, not cold out of the fridge. 
-Water bath - if you don't know what it is you should google it! 
-Allow the cake to cool at least 1 hr in the oven, turned off, don't ever open the door! Allow to cool a few more hours on the counter before refrigerating, it won't crack! :) also don't take the spring form off until its cool.
Thanks so much for the great recipe I hope my tips can help the other cheesecake novices!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-08-25T00:51:06.953
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
14143379
Display Name:
Nicole lee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0

8
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1379159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake is possibly the best cheesecake ever! People that had issues with it's texture, or to dry, or to brown, or cracking, you are doing it wrong!

I want to first start off with saying, you HAVE to have  room temp ingredients. Don't over mix, actually I don't even use a mixer at all. I do everything by hand. I recommend not using the amount of flour it calls for (1/4 cup ?) I only used 1 tbs or you could not use any. Also I only add 2 tbs of milk. The sour cream gives it plenty of moisture all ready. 

Always use a water bath! Wrap the spring form pan in tin foil + a turkey bag. Some water still might seep in but it will evaporate if you stick it in a low temp oven for about 10 min after it's done. Don't RUSH it! I set my oven about 15 degrees below what it recommends ( My oven cooks hot) let it cook for the hour, shut off the oven, and let it do it's thing. 

Don't peak, look, or even stare at it! Let it sit for as long as humanly possible. Stick it in the fridge for min of 12 hours and I PROMISE you will have the best cheesecake you, your family, and friends have ever had!

This was my first time making a New York Cheesecake and it turned out great.  I didn't make any changes to the recipe.  I just made sure the ingredients were at room temperature and did not over mix.  I didn't have any foil to wrap the bottom of the springform pan so I just put a small pan of water on the rack below the cheesecake pan and it turned out wonderful with no cracks in it. I baked it for 1 hour and then left it in the oven for 4 hours. Once it cooled I then refrigerated it. The family said it was the best cheesecake they had ever ate.  This will be my go to recipe. text:
I had tried several slices of the famous New York - style cheesecake before trying to make it myself. I had even tried a couple of cheesecakes while in NYC. Since I'm from abroad, I was reluctant to try to make this at home, but after coming back from New York we decided there was no way we were going to get that same taste/creamyness/quality here in cafes/restaurants in Spain. Therefore, i decided to look for a recipe to make it myself at home, and we bumped into this one.
I decided to give it a try with light cream cheese and a lot more crust. The result? Heaven on Earth. 
The only downside to this recipe is that the baking temperature might be too high. I just made my second cheesecake, this time following the recipe to a tee and it's still too brown on the top for my taste. So i guess that baking with a lower oven temp could do the trick, or maybe even lowering the rack a bit.
Still...i give this a 5 star!!! We will never buy cheesecake here again!
This recipe is fool-proof if you:
-use good quality ingredients
- have all ingredients at room temp
-use a huge mixing bowl
-leave it in the oven to cool down (4-5hours) before chilling it in the fridge
the steps are better explained in Chef's john's version but this is the recipe I followed so this is the one I'm rating.
I have yet to try the water bath (bain Marie)
If you want an easy, heavenly cheese cake recipe, THIS IS IT!
Mine didn't crack!

text:
Although the taste is excellent but a bit creamy for our taste, I could not in good conscience give it five stars because the batter is way off ratio. As another reviewer said, there is enough for two 9-inch cake. The temperature is also too hot. At 150C, my cake still burnt a bit. It will probably be badly burnt if I went with the recommended temperature of 175C. For people who want a cheesecake not that moist, I suggest at least doubling the flour. Oh, and I cut the sugar to 120g instead of the 300g called for. It felt too excessive and may cover the cheese taste.

Made it for the first time for my friend's graduation. Came out pretty well, I didn't use a water bath or use the flour (because I ran out). Therefore, it cracked but it didn't matter b/c I improvised and used the leftover of my sour cream to cover it. I had 8 oz left and I added 2 tablespoons of sugar and 1 teaspoon of vanilla. Then I simmered it for 5 minutes and waited for it to cool. It was simple and my friends and family loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing. I've made it so many times, and it's time for me to leave a review with my 2 cents. 
Firstly, the ingredients should all be at room temperature, they're easier to mix if they are. I use only a tablespoon of flour, and I sieve so there are no lumps. A water bath should be used, I just stuck a pan of hot water underneath and it works the same way. 
Don't overbake, or it will crack and have this strange lumpy texture when eating. Leave it to cool in the oven when the centre is still a little jiggly, as residual heat in the cheesecake will cook it through.
I also used 1/3 of the recipe, which made 12 perfect mini cheesecakes (18 minutes in oven).
So delicious, thanks so much for sharing!! Will never use another baked cheesecake recipe ever again.

text:
The cheesecake itself is awesome. Great taste and perfect texture. I added a little bit of lemon zest and that was delicious. My only problem with this recipe is the crust. 15 graham crackers and 2 tablespoons of butter? Really? That doesn't make a crust, it makes crumbs. text:
Easy as pie...follow recipe, put in 350 oven for 1 hour, cut off oven and leave for 4 hours and DON'T OPEN DOOR. The cheese cake was wonderful, texture was great.I did wrap the cake in Saran wrap when I refrigerated it. When I made the cake again, I added 1/4 cup of sugar in crust. No cracks in cakes and tasted better than any cheesecake you could buy. Have no fear, this is a great recipe.

7492998
Display Name:
robinfla52

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a cheesecake fanatic and for years have been making Lindy's New York Cheesecake. Only problem I had was consistency in the results. I followed most of this recipe except I used heavy cream instead of milk and I also add orange zest from one orange. I like a nice smooth creamy texture and not too dense (dry as one review state LAURELC43 has a very good review except I was trying to get away  from the long cooking time.). When mine came out this way it was to die for according to many of my friends and family and church family. 
     The thing I find about this recipe is it is almost foolproof. I baked at 350 for 1 hour but let sit in oven without opening door for 3 hours. Also, I might cut the flour down to 2 TBLS like she did. you could see how it firmed up but did not get dense and was really creamy. I hesitate to even try 5-6 hours as stated in original recipe.
    A few things I have found are, make sure cream cheese is soft. I usually make mine in late afternoon after cream cheese has been sitting out all day. Then put in oven and take out when time for bed and put in fridge. I also found a lot of people who don't like the actual taste of cream cheese tasting cheesecake actually prefer the orange zest or maybe even lemon.

Rating:

dateLastModified:

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Like all other reviews, this is the best cheesecake, foolproof recipe, you'll ever find. I did not have enough time to let mine sit in an oven so I pulled it out about an hour after baking and put it in the refrigerator. It did crack as I did not do it the right way. But to me - who cares!!! Cover those cracks with some berries. I combined cut up strawberries, blueberries and raspberries in a bowl and tossed with about 2-3 tablespoons  strawberry glaze, just enough to coat the berries. Glaze can be found where the strawberries are in the supermarket. I also doubled the graham crackers and butter for a thicker crust.

text:
My cheesecake turned out completely awful. Okay, that's a half truth. The cheesecake itself tasted heavenly, but it wont be winning any beauty pageants anytime soon. I'll accent Morena's statement---the destruction of my cheesecake was my own doing. This was my very first attempt at making cheesecake that didn't come from a box (I hate those so very much, but it was what I had been accustomed to). That alone makes it special. I lacked the springform pan (again, all my fault), but all hope wasn't completely lost. There were cracks and at first it seemed mushy in the middle, but after placing it in the freezer for a few hours, it pulled together and tastes amazing. It was thicker than I imagined it would be, and my family loved it. This was only a prototype---one that will be made again and again. Five stars!

text:
I made this cheesecake one time before, first time was with a good processor. No air bubbles anywhere, it was the best darned cheesecake I've ever had in my life. (I don't like cheesecake so says a lot) exactly what a few offer people are saying, I used a sporting form pan, set the oven to 350, turned it off and left out to just do it's thing. It came out absolutely perfect. The second time I made it I was drunk. Really drunk. When I woke up and my hangover finally left me, I tried the creation yet again and it was just as delicious. (I followed the recipe to the T) it was just as perfect. THAT being said, this is the simplest, most delicious cheese you will ever make. Honestly though, follow the recipe, don't check it, leave all the hot air in, if you must, peek at it through the oven when you turn it off but DON'T TOUCH IT. Leave it there for 5 hours at least and you will be very happy.

text:
I have used this as a base cheesecake for lots of different things.  One that is never-fail with my friends is this: make the crust as usual. Mix the cheesecake mixture as directed. Pour part of mixture over crust. Flip out a frozen pecan pie over cheesecake mixture. Cover with remaining cheesecake mixture. Top with Chocolate Ganache (1 12 oz. dark chocolate chips, 1 tsp. vanilla, and 1 cup heavy cream; heat cream to near boiling, pour over chips, add vanilla, mix until smooth. Pour over cooled cheesecake; top with chopped pecans.

This is a good cheesecake! Easy too. I always do the crust with boxed breadcrumbs, butter, sugar and a little cinnamon. As for the "cheese" part-- omg! Yummy!!!! I was horrified I forgot the flour completely until it was in the oven. Made no difference at all. After the hour of cook time, I turned off the oven and let it sit in there for a few hours. Then put it in the fridge overnight. I got up to a chilled, beautiful cheesecake. My husband said it tastes like it's from an upscale bakery! Make this recipe!!!

text:
Made this cake for my friends birthday. I never liked the taste of cheesecake but decided to give it a try again and I really liked it. It helps if you put the cake pan in a larger cake pan with water it prevents it from cooing too fast and keeps the cake moist. If you are using a spring form like I did just cover the bottom weigh foil so water doesn't get in it. I also replaced the graham cracker with Oreos. I put the entire Oreo with the cream (regular not double stuffed) and put it in a food processor to crush it and continued with the rest of the recipe. (I used an entire pack of Oreos for the crust)

text:
Ok, so I've compiled a lot of the reviewers changes and loved the cheesecake from this recipe: 1) allow ingredients to come to room temp, 2) modified crust (1 1/2 cups crumbled gram cracker, 1/4 teasp ground nut meg, 1/2 teasp cinnamon, 3 teasp melted butter and 1/4 cup fine chopped walnuts), 3) grease the pan and bake in over and leave in there 5-6 hours or overnight to avoid cracking. SO DELICIOUS!!! I made little cheese cake cup cakes and bake ~40min

text:
Great recipe, very easy to follow. Everyone raved about it. One woman said it was the best cheesecake she has ever had (and she is in her 60's) My only question is what is meant by "15 Graham Crackers". They come in crackers about 2 1/2" x 5". Is that 2 crackers or 1? I used about 14 of these and it seemed like a LOT, so I only used about 2/3 of the mixture and the crust turned out just fine, not too thick, not too thin. So do these need to be broken in half before counting them? I couldn't even tell from the video what to do, so if I used twice as many crackers as I needed, then I only used half the needed butter for the amount of crackers I used. Other than this question the recipe was very clear and concise! 
Oh, and the top of the cake cracked (a big "X" shaped crack) despite leaving it in the oven to cool without opening the door. Next time I may put a pan of water on a lower rack to fix this, but the cracked surface didn't affect the quality or taste of the cake, so no biggy!

text:
I have been using this recipe for years.  I absolutely love it.  I also Have to agree.  If yours isn't coming out right you are doing do in something I make sure you don't just throw all the ingredients together and start blending.  Blend out the cream cheese till smoothe. If you follow correctly it will not crack.  Alternately you can bake it for about half way then drop the temp and adjust to bake longer at a lower temp.  I don't always let it sit for the 6 hours but I will at least a couple. Either way.  AMAZING recipe.

text:
I'm 65 years old and have been a cheesecake fanatic my whole life.  This is unequivocally the BEST Cheesecake recipe EVER...  It's easy, and quick (except waiting the 5-6 hours).  I will never make another cheesecake recipe again; this is my go-to.  That being said, I've just finished making one and used gingersnaps for the crust ( added a bit more butter than called for) and subbed a cup of ricotta for one of the cream cheese bars.  Did the same last time.  I was concerned about the overflow aspect and added a collar of foil.  Not needed - and nothing burned.  I must agreee with Morena - If it fails you it's not the recipe's fault.  The consistency was outstanding - nothing cracked.  I did appreciate the waterbath mention.  I think that goes a long way in preventing the cracking as well.  This one will be out Christmas Dinner dessert and I can't wait.  Thanks VERY MUCH Taliesen

country:
None
text:
This is absolutely the best cheesecake recipe.  The only thing that I do differently is wrapping my springform pan in extra large, heavy duty foil and place it in a bain marie (water bath) for even baking, which help prevent cracking.  You have to be careful when placing the springform pan in a bain marie or else you can end up with a soggy crust. Prepare the bain marie before you transfer any of the batter to ensure that your springform pan does not have any leaks.  MORENA's suggestions are also extremely helpful.  My cheesecakes have never failed.

I tried this recipe. omitted the flour as suggested by other user. also didnt use bain marie. I also halved the recipe since i was making for just the two of us. The cake was cooked thoroughly but was very very dense. The cake had initially sunk in the middle, but upon remaining in the oven for 4 hours it had settled nicely. I served with the raspberry puree as suggested by someone. the ONLY highlight of the preparation.

None
text:
I have been using this recipe for years! If I am having a get-together and my nephews don't want to come, I tell them aww too bad you can't make it, I am making cheesecake ... they cancel their other plans just to get a piece of this cheesecake! I bake it different than the instructions, if I bake it the entire hour it dries out, I shut the oven off after 40 minutes and let it sit in the oven for 8 hours and it comes out perfect every time. Using all ingredients at room temperature makes a big difference, and I fold ingredients by hand starting at the sour cream step. This recipe is also perfect for adding different ingredients lik eoreos, pecans, heath bars, just about anything to make a custom cheesecake!

country:
None
text:
Okay, so here's why things could have gone wrong:

I'm in a country that doesn't sell good cream cheese.

I was using disposable foil loaf tins.

I was using a tiny, cheap toaster oven.

And guess what, perfect, creamy, uncracked cheesecake. So delicious, really does taste like what you get in a cafe. And it looks such a lovely pale, even color... I was sure it woudln't work given the circumstances, but the recipe was too good :)

I didn't put my foil loaf pans in a water bath because there wasn't room, but I left the cookie tray that came with the toaster oven on the shelf below the rack the cheesecakes were on, and filled it with water. I don't know it it helped, but I didn't get a single crack. I did leave them to cool in the oven, and well-greased the pans with pam spray.

Now I can't help but cut myself a slice every few hours... mmm..

text:
This was the first cheesecake I have ever made and I have to say that I did fallow all instructions and left the cake in the oven for the full six hours to cool after baking and it did sink about a quarter of an inch... other then that I will add that if you are using a gas oven you will want to preheat oven at 350 and then lower the heat to 300 for the one hour bake time or it will burn. Gas cooks differently then electric ovens.  It's a beautiful recipe and very tasty, I might add my cake did not crack and I did substitute the cream cheese for plain white yogurt.  Thank you and I will try this recipe again. Rose

OK, so I made this last-minute - didn't let the ingredients come entirely up to room temp, and probably overbeat because of it.  The top cracked a little bit.  But who cares?  This cheesecake is the BOMB.  And it is super-easy, too.  The hardest thing about this (well two things) is remembering to take all the ingredients out of the fridge long enough to make it to room temperature, and not opening the oven while it's cooling.  Seriously, I turned on the oven light and peeked through the glass at one hour, and it looked slumped in the middle.  I kept the faith and turned off the oven.  When I looked through the glass at three hours, the cake had risen over the pan.  When I opened up the oven and pulled it out after eight hours, it was PERFECT.  Oh, and don't forget the water bath - I couldn't find my 12X18 cake pan, so I used a very large skillet, heated some water in my teapot, and poured it about halfway up the side of the pan (wrapped in foil, of course).  I also added a little bit of lemon and orange zest to the batter, and it tastes SO GOOD.  This will be my new go-to cheesecake recipe.  Thank you so much for sharing!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-03-31T01:55:38.78
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2460965
Display Name:
Lynesi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
100
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/61135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made many cheesecakes over the yrs and this one is by far the best one I have ever made. I slightly change part of the recipe to have a chocolate layer. Before starting your cheesecake batter, melt 3 oz of good dark chocolate 55%. Let it cool. After you make the cheesecake batter, pour half the batter into another bowl about 4 cups, set aside. Pour in the cooled melted cooled chocolate into the mixing bowl. Mix just until all the chocolate is incorporated. Pour the chocolate cheesecake batter into prepared pan, then the remaining cheesecake batter you set aside onto the chocolate batter. Bake as directed. The key to your cheesecake not cracking on top is not the amount of time left in the oven, but in greasing the sides of the spring form pan, this is a must! I use butter. You can leave the cheesecake in the oven for the amount of time after cooking as the recipe states though if you are not sure if its baked fully. I then made a chocolate ganache with 12oz dark chocolate 55% and 1 cup 35% cream. Bring the cream to just a boil and then stir into your chocolate. I use Valrhona chocolate disks and have no need to chop up the chocolate with these but you might need to do it if you use something else. When the ganache has cooled, it will thicken as it cools down, start in the middle of your cheesecake, pour the ganache and let it spread. Go slowly. Chill cheesecake and enjoy!

text:
I made this recipe today for the first time and my husband and I LOVED it!!  The only thing I improvised was the crust, as graham crackers and butter seemed a little bland to me.  For the crust I used: 1 1 /2 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1/4 c. finely chopped Unsalted nuts (walnuts, pecans), 6 tbsp. melted butter, 1 tsp. cinnamon and a 1/4 tsp. nutmeg...and it was amazing. We don't have a convection oven, so I had to bake the cheesecake for an hour and a half instead of an hour.  I put it in a water bath on the middle oven rack and after an hour and a half I turned the oven off and left the door open.  I let the cheesecake sit in the oven for one hour and then put it in the fridge uncovered (so it didn't condensate).  There was absolutely no cracking or browning at all! I'm really not sure how people got weird results with this recipe, ours was absolutely perfect.  Wow!! I will make this for every event from now on!

text:
First, this is the best recipe!! I have made this many times and I have never had a crack. The only difference to the recipe is that I use 3 tbsp. cornstarch instead of flour, and yes, having ingredients at room temp is important, also stirring in ingredients keeps it nice and dense. I put my pan on a cookie sheet, but not a hot water bath, bake it at 350 for 15 minutes then turn the oven to 200 for 2 hours. After the 2 hours, run a sharp knife around the  cake to loosen it from pan sides very carefully and then turn oven off for 2 hours. Remove cake from oven and let cool before putting in frig. Oh, and a little lemon extract or fresh grated lemon peel to the batter doesn't hurt either!! Yum!!

I have to rate the recipe with 5 stars because it came out perfect. If anything, I would change some of the ingredients. I usually like the taste that sweetened condensed milk gives a cheesecake so I was looking for a different taste/texture. I think the flour is what gave it a different texture. text:
My advanced foods class tried this recipe.  We LOVED it!  The flavor was just right and the recipe is very easy to follow and fits nicely into a 85-minute time slot.  I adjusted the recipe to half (6 servings) to save on lab costs.  We used muffin tins to make individual cakes rather than larger springform pans (don't forget to use paper liners if you use muffin tins!).  The cakes baked in about 28 minutes.  Students made fruit toppings while their cakes baked.

text:
Okay maybe this review is a little early but I will update it if I change my mind later. I have never made a cheesecake before that wasn't a "Jello" box made one, so I really have no experience on it and I haven't tried it yet as it is still cooling in the oven.  But I would like to say that I feel the directions for this cake is lacking.  Followed the directions exactly and the cake cracked really badly in the center and out to the sides.  My batter was also a bit lumpy when I made it.  I also felt that the crust need about another 2 or 3 tablespoons of melted butter in it to really shape nicely to the pan, but I just followed the directions still.  However, I apparently needed to read some of the reviews before making this because there were some helpful hints that could have prevented my problems.  The water bath suggestions, making sure that your ingredients are all at room temperature before mixing, and others who have also said to add more butter to the crust mix.  I feel that if these are the things that should be done when making this recipe then they should be in the directions.  But it was very easy to make.  So once this has been taste tested and I may try this recipe again using some of the hints found in the reviews, and if they work I will update my review.  But for now I am not ecstatic about it.

text:
I'm new to making cheesecake, this was my first. I ran to the store to pick up the ingredients, along with a springform pan! When I opened the pan, I pulled out the cardboard with the NordicWare logo, flipped it over to see if there was a recipe, and I kid you not, this EXACT recipe was on the back! Somebody swiped a recipe! Anyway, overall the flavor is pretty good. I didn't know anything about over beating the ingredients. I did it all with a hand mixer. I had a crack in the top, probably an inch deep and 3" long. Maybe from the fact that it rose high above the edge of the pan while baking? I don't know. It did settle back down though. I also didn't care for the crust. I used 15 sheets of graham cracker. Put in the 2T of melted butter. That didn't seem to do anything so I added another 2T & that helped it to hold its shape a little bit. It seemed like a lot of crust, but I used it. Pushed it up the sides of the pan about 2 finger widths high. When we pulled edge of the pan off, the crust had browned & changed flavor. It was ok-but Ill be looking for a new crust recipe. The top half of the cheesecake had also browned around the edges and was not very pretty. I let it set in the oven for a few hours. The crack was already there when it came out. I'm rating it 4 stars for the flavor. Given I didn't use a water bath or anything, I'm sure a lot of the mistakes are my fault, plus nearly 4,000 people can't be wrong. I will be making this again & trying the tips in the reviews.

I read the suggestions and varied the recipe.  I started with 1 and 1/2 c. graham crackers, 1/4 c. sugar, 1/4 c. butter and a dash of cinnamon for the crust.  I deleted the milk and flour from the recipe to make it creamier.  I baked it at 325 degrees for 1 hour and 15 mins. and turned off the oven and let it set for 2 hours. Mine didn't turn out like other bakers said theirs came out.  It was delicious but certainly could not be mistaken for a store bought cake.

text:
I am giving this recipie four stars because I used it as my base for my holiday cheesecake. I use the word base loosely because really the only things I changed were; I bought pre-crumbled graham crackers and I subsituted the milk for Eggnog. The cheesecake turned out great with a wonderful creamy texture and a bold but sweet cream cheese flavor. It did have a giant crack downt the middle but I think that was my fault not the recipe's. I definately overbeat it (I figured the more I beat it, the smoother it would be) and I put a pan of water on the rack underneath but didnt think to fill it with HOT water (oi). Also I preheated my oven the 350 but then turned it down to 325 after putting the cheesecake in, due to some other reviews suggesting the oven temp was to high. I will definately be using this recipe again.

The first time I made this cheesecake, I forgot the milk.  It turned out perfectly.  I read a few reviews that mentioned the milk created too much moisture.  I have since never added the milk.  This cheesecake gets rave reviews every single time I make it.  It bakes perfectly, and has a perfect "deli" consistency.  I've gotten rid of all my other cheesecake recipes... this one is foolproof.

This recipe was great! I've never made such a professional tasting and textured cheesecakes. Within in two hours of staying in the oven my cake had already developed a huge crack. Best tasting cheesecake I've ever had but by far the worst and biggest crack I've ever had.

text:
Very easy, basic recipe. 

Great flavour. Not too rich. Probably a little sweeter than I would normally prefer but no one else complained; I will very slightly reduce the sugar next time I make it. Nice texture, but that's an issue of technique so read up on your cheesecake making tips :). 

This was an impulse bake: I used low fat cream cheese instead of regular and Greek yoghurt instead of sour cream as it was what I had on hand - worked just fine and cut down on the fat content a little. 

I also had to halve the recipe because I didn't have enough cream cheese for the full recipe - used a smaller pan, adjusted the cooking time a little for a thicker cake, had no trouble really.

This is some of the best cheesecake I've ever had.  Great texture and just sweet enough (it doesn't even need fruit)! Just make DARN sure that if you're using a water bath (highly suggested) that it's water tight!  It wasn't particularly difficult to make.

text:
This is an almost perfect cheesecake. I say almost, because I have ran across more authentic methods and recipes (most "purists" cakes do not require flour, sour cream or "crusts" and many require water baths for maximum dense moisture). Since I am not a "purist" or cheesecake afficiondo, it's fine by me. This is a *perfect* cheesecake for an oops proof result, as long as you remember that it is AIR that is incorporated into the filling that is suspect number 1 if your cake splits or cracks. If you have made a sauce, jam or grown fruits you are particularly proud of, here is your perfect foil!

This recipe is off the chain! This recipe created 2 cakes for me with more than enough left over to create a third. However we just decided to lick the mix because it was so good! My hubby used it to dip strawberries for a snack. Anyhow I blew it a bit with the time set up because I really didn't realize how much mix I had so I put one pie in the oven first, then I added another maybe 30 minutes later.  Why am I sharing this well because I was a bit skeptical when I read all the negative reviews about the cracking and the blah blah blah so I was concerned.  Either way both pies (one was a bit browner than the other) came out as masterpieces! One was extra overcooked and the other a tiny bit under cooked (by 10 minutes) but you couldn't taste the difference at all by letting them cool. These pies didn't make it to the end of the week... I received so many compliments and wow did you make this? Yes I did, and I have Chantal to thank.... Amazing recipe, way better than the no bake Jello cheesecake that was my inspiration for finding this recipe in the first place!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect batter recipe!  (For the crust I followed a separate traditional graham cracker crust recipe.)  Followed the recipe exactly plus the tips given in reviews:  warm temp ingredients, don't overmix, double foil water bath, grease the pan well, leave in oven 60 mins then turn off and don't touch it for 5-6 hrs (not even to run a knife around the edge).  Absolutely gorgeous cheesecake, no cracks (a first for me), awesome taste.  Don't understand reviews that said it didn't taste like cream cheese, this came out so delicious and very much like a moist bakery's cheesecake.  To make sure there was no air in the batter before baking I lightly dropped the bowl on the countertop a couple of times, making the air bubbles rise to the top and burst (there weren't many, but just in case....).
Next time I will make sure to grease the bottom better as the crust stuck a bit, or bake the crust for 5 mins before filling.

If I would rate this on taste definitely 5 stars!!!!! But if I rated it on appearance, I would give it 3. I made this cheesecake a couple times, but each time it cracked terribley on top. I googled it and found that cheesecakes crack if the cool to fast, or if the inside reaches above 160 degrees F. I tried turning down the temperature for the last 30 minutesm but it didn't help. I think I'll search for a new cheesecake recipie.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to try making cheesecakes (because they are one of my favorite desserts) so I looked for something simple to put together and easy-to-shop ingredients.  This recipe is it.  I served it at my church and job potluck and everyone loved it!  Considering I've never made cheesecakes, this recipe was easy to follow and definitely easy to eat.  The only thing I would share is to put it in a water bath (make sure that water does NOT get into the cheesecake pan) and let it sit in the oven, after you turn it off, overnight (this really does help the cake not to crack).  Early the next morning put it in the fridge and its ready to go by noontime.  Great recipe, easy to make and wonderful taste.  One last note, just because I like to do stuff the easy way, I used canned cherry pie filling as the topping.  Still great and divinely tasting!

text:
Awesome recipe! I made this for my hubby's birthday surprise cake just this friday and he loved it!! Topped with his fave blueberry (sauce recipe by martha stewart) to sweeten the deal! First ever attempt at making cheesecake from scratch and it was a relative success. Used a water bath which guaranteed me no cracks whatsoever. The "don't overbeat" rule is a little tricky though. I might have overbeat mine just a tad bit coz it was definitely not as dense as i wanted it but the taste great! Hubby loved it ofcourse and said he liked my "lighter/airier" cake than the more denser ones at the store or resto. Overall a success and will definitely make this one again! Would add a little cinnamon sugar about 1/2 cup to the crust though for added sweetness and crunch to the crust. Would definitely recommend this one even cheeseake neophytes like myself! Cheesecake making is no longer an impossible dream! Wootwoot!

text:
You do not need to do an actual water bath, just put a pan of water in the oven, under the rack with the cake. If the pan is properlly greased, you should have no pro lens. I experimented with lemon shortbread and graham cracker crust, a perfect compliment to the vanilla here. No need for a blender! Use a rissotto spoon instead to break up the cheese and avoid over-beating. You want this cake a little soft. Enjoy! It's a lovely cake.

Display Name:
ChefJJ

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3118114.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic cheesecake! I halved the ingredients to make a small 6" cake. Baked at 160C for 25-30 min until the cake was wobbly in the center when tapped.

I baked it with a water bath and sprayed the sides of the tin with PAM. If u spray the sides, the cake will simply lift itself out of the tin. No need to scrape the sides with a knife. My cake turned out with PERFECT edges, no browning, sinking nor cracking.

For those of you the have trouble with water from the water bath seep into the foil, try lining the cake tin with a layer of parchment first.

Topped this with Blueberry Sauce by Isybel, also from this site.

text:
The recipe, as listed and baked, came out great. I gave it four stars only because I prefer a little more "bite" to my cheesecake flavor, and a 4-star rating may catch the attention of others who might feel the same. 

Excellent recipe, though! The texture was creamy but held up well, and the finished product had a fantastic "mouth feel." Not a bit of grit or dryness.

Again, the difference is in the final flavor. If you like a more tart cheesecake, I'd suggest a different recipe, or experiment on this one with some lemon zest and juice. Still -- well done, Chantal!

text:
My stepdaughter and I decided to make this for Thanksgiving. I was a little nervous since I had never made a baked cheesecake before. This recipe is truly simple, easy to make and will turn out perfectly. I turned off the oven after 1 hour and left it in the oven for approx. 2 hours; I then had to move it to the microwave to finish the cooling process as I needed my big oven for other things.  No cracks and we recieved raves about our "beautiful" cheesecake the next day!

THIS WAS DELICIOUS!!! NO cracks even w/o a water bath! 
I am not a big cheesecake fan, but I made this for my 14 year old son's birthday, he couldn't say enough wonderful things about it! My family loved it, friends loved it, I even loved it.

text:
I made this recipe and for the most part it was as wonderful as everyone said.  I made one change and that was to split the cream cheese so that I had 2 regular and 2 neufchatel.  It was very creamy and not as heavy as some cheesecakes.  The only thing I had a problem with and why I didn't give a full 5 stars (maybe I did something wrong) was the crust.  I did as told with the graham crackers but the crust was very dry and didn't compliment the cheesecake at all.  I welcome suggestions for what could have been done differently.  I am an avid baker and I would love to add this cheesecake to my list of favorites but have to fix the crust first.  Also, I baked for an hour and left it in the oven to cool for 5 hours and like many also had a big crack in the middle.  I am thinking it was do to over mixing but either way it didn't affect the taste at all.  Was proud to call this my first cheesecake!

country:
None
text:
I've used this recipe twice now and it bakes a perfect cheesecake. Definitely follow others peoples reviews and grease the sides of the pan and let the cheesecake cool in the oven for 1hr after cooking to ensure that it doesn't crack. Also for those wondering about the best way to crush the graham crackers to get an even consistency the best way I found was to put them into a ziploc bag and use a rolling pin to crush them. My go-to recipe for cheesecake!

text:
I've made this a number of times, all with great results.  The cheesecake always gets rave reviews.  I make the crust with some(1/3 cup) sugar and instead of doing everything full fat, I used skim milk, light sour cream and 1/2 of the cream cheese was low fat.  This thing is pretty high calorie and you don't lose the taste by making these substitutions.  Good luck everyone else :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! If you are looking for a classic new-york style cheesecake, this is the recipe for you! Like other reviewers, I made sure not to overmix the batter before pouring over the crust. I baked for one hour and let sit in the oven (after turning it off) for about 4-5 hours. It is really important to make sure the cream cheese is soft enough (room temperature) before making the filling. My crust was a tad dry - maybe I used too many graham crackers, but I think it could have done with a bit more butter. Overall, excellent cheesecake. Served with choice of whipped cream, cherry pie filling, and nutella glaze on the side and everyone loved it!

text:
This was beautiful. This was fantastic. This was delicious. 
I think I managed to fall in love with a cheesecake. 
It was literally that good. It even tasted better than anything I've had at a bakery. And that means stuff, folks. 
But anyway - I followed the recipe exactly, except I added a water bath. 
The only thing that needs to be edited is the crust - I believe some people recommended adding cinnamon and a few other spices, which I will definitely do next time(and there WILL be a next time). 
Otherwise, follow the recipe exactly. The oven instructions sound funky - listen anyway. It makes your life easier, anyway. 
Surprisingly, the most annoying part of this recipe was just making the crust. Everything else was completely easy and simple. And when a 17 year old says that, you know it's easy. 
My entire family loved the cheesecake too and could not get enough!

text:
Yum, this is 4.5 stars!  I made some minor changes.  I left out the flour.  I doubled the crust and added cinnamon and nutmeg to the mixture.  After beating the cream cheese and sugar, I did all the rest of the mixing by hand (wooden spoon). I cooked the cheesecake in a water bath.  I used a slow-cooker bag to put the cheesecake pan in so the water wouldnt seep into the cheesecake.  I cooked it for an hour then turned off the oven and let is sit inside for 2 hours.  NO CRACKING!  But the edges got a little brown which was disappointing.  It tasted delicious anyways!

Display Name:
ann

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ok.....I made this today, followed the recipe but in the cream cheese/sugar mixture, I added orange/lemon zest, I only used the hand mixer to mix the cream cheese and the sugar, the rest I mixed with the wooden spoons.  The suggestions by the other comments totally helped.  I baked mine 350 degrees for 1 hour/10 minutes.  Like the suggestion, I left it alone for almost 4 hours, and covered it with foil loosely, and refrigerated it.  Prior to all of these baking steps,  I made sure that bottom and sides of spring form pan was generously greased, in my opinion, you really have to do a water bath, that really helps the cooking process, making the heat even, also make sure that you wrap the bottom of the pan halfway to prevent seepage.  At long last, this is my first attempt at making the famous cheese cake and it was a complete, utter success.  It has no cracks, perfectly moist and creamy.  I made cherry sauce from one canned cherry filling.  I drained the cherries, put it aside, I added 2 tbsp of cornstarch and 1/4 cup sugar, let it boil and cooled, I then added the cherries...refrigerate it as well.  I know you're suppose to wait until cheese cake sets over night, but it was fine when I cut it after 5-6 hours.  My b/f was salivating the whole time, said a few expletives about how excellent and out of this world it was.  This success made my day, I will definitely make this cheese cake again......Thanks Chantal and all the wonderful suggestions from all the people here.....

country:
None
text:
Mine didn't turn out great.  Huge cracks on top, and an airy texture, not creamy.  I think I know what I did wrong!  Cream cheese wasn't room temp when I started, so I kept whipping, whipping, whipping to try and get everything to incorporate well.  But I think it added tons of air to the batter.  Resulting in a cheesecake that rose almost 4" above the top of the pan, only to fall and crack as it cooled.  I'll try this recipe again; this time with room temp ingredients and taking extra care to stir, only until combined.  Hopefully this will give me a dense, creamy, sweet, slice of deliciousness!  :)

Display Name:
Txmatey
