city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so well received by my friends that I felt like a celebrity chef. I think the only thing I did differently was just to make more crust. I like a thick graham cracker crust and so did my friends. I followed some other tips and buttered the sides and bottom of the springform pan to keep the cake from cracking as it cooked and pulled away from the sides. I also put a pan of water beneath the cake as it baked. Do not overbake this cake. The stated cooking time in a preheated oven is dead on. It will feel like you need to bake it longer, but don't! Leave the cake in the oven (along with the hot pan of water) and turn off the heat and let it cool completely in the oven. Then remove the springform sides. You will have a perfect cake with no cracks and it will be completely level and gorgeous. Not one thing about the recipe needed to be changed. This is the most perfect recipe I have ever used.

I didn't have a springform pan handy, but this cheesecake came out wonderful without one. I put wax paper in the bottom of a round cake pan and sprayed it with cooking spray. Because I used a pan that was more shallow, I had enough batter to make a second cake. I topped it with a can of cherry pie filling, and it was delicious. Not too rich.

text:
As someone who does not bake regularly and is generally just learning my way around a kitchen.. I was kicking myself when I agreed to make dessert for my (new) boyfriend's family Christmas dinner.  The cheesecake turned out so amazingly well that I've made it again and it has made me look like some kind of genius chef.  The only small modifications I recommend: use more crackers for the base than listed (I'm in England so I use digestives), about 22 makes for a thicker crust and also use more butter.  I also used a water bath and had no cracking whatsoever.  This recipe is idiot proof, trust me.  Make it and you will be very very popular at whatever party you attend.  Cheers.

text:
Awesome!  Great recipe, but I took advice from the reviews and made some changes:  All I had was a 9.5" spring form pan, so I increased the servings to 15 and prepared the filling accordingly and baked an extra 25 minutes.  I baked in a hot water bath, ran a knife around the edge after baking, and let cool in the oven for about 3-4 hours and refrigerated overnight.  It came out beautifully with no cracking!  For a little extra effect, I arranged fresh fruit attractively on the top and glazed.  For a perfect fruit glaze, heat orange marmalade on the stove and strain to remove orange pieces then brush over the top (spreads easily when heated).

country:

text:
Followed the advice in the comments: brought all ingredients to room temperature, added eggs last one at a time, reduced flour to 2 Tbsp, used a water bath, and left the cheesecake in the oven for several hours after baking. It turned out phenomenal! No cracks, and a beautifully smooth & creamy texture! I forgot to grease the sides of the pan before preparing the crust, but there was enough butter in the graham cracker crust to keep it from sticking. I also used 1/2 reduced fat cream cheese and light sour cream - still tasted great. My one slight complaint is that the crust was not crisp and crunchy. This is probably unavoidable, however, due to the long time between baking and eating. :) Wonderful recipe I will definitely be using again!

text:
This cake is awesome! I made some minor changes namely adding rum, more vanilla, using a little less milk (because i personally like my cheesecake nice and heavy) and using powdered sugar in place of white sugar in order to get the filling as smooth as possible, as well as covering the baking tin with aluminium foil to keep in the moisture. I also found it beneficial to run the filling through a strainer to get rid of all the lumps. When it came out it was perfect, not cracked, and it was so creamy and decadent. I used a store-bought strawberry pie filling as my topping and it was good to go!

text:
I've made a few cheesecakes in the past and none compare to this one! So easy to make and it turned out great. A couple of recommendations to definitely follow are to mix the eggs in last by hand and not to over mix! Then, I did bake mine in the water bath for 1 hour and turned the oven off. I left it in for 6 hours afterwards (my oven always takes forever) and it only had one crack (I think it was because I overmixed). I then let it chill in the fridge and covered the entire cheesecake in melted dark chocolate. It was amazing!

Great recipe! It was my first time making a cheesecake and I followed the recipe and came out with almost perfect results. The cheesecake was a little too brown on the top for my tastes and it did crack (no water bath but did put a pan of water underneath the middle rack that I baked the cheesecake at). The taste though! It was so yummy and everyone really loved it. Some claimed it was the best they had ever had because of its moistness. I added lemon juice to mine and it enhanced the flavor tremendously. This is a purist's cheesecake so keep that in mind when making this.

text:
OMG, this cake is delicous... Everyone loved it and it's so worth the wait... I do not use the crust on this recipe. I buy "Honey Maid" graham cracker crumbs. 1 1/2 graham cracker crumbs, 1 tablespoon sugar, 6 tablespoons of butter melted. To keep crust from getting soggy in water bath I wrap the bottom of the springform with aluminum foil. Pat the crumbs on the bottom of springform pan, bake for 8 mins, let cool to room temp. Then, you can continue with the recipe instructions.

text:
Fantastic recipe!! For a bit of a change I separated the filling into two halves. The plain half I poured into my springform pan as instructed, The other half I mixed with half a cup of Dulce de Leche caramel. I then poured the Carmel mix on top of the Plain half and mixed it in with a butter knife slicing it back and forth. When It was done cooking The cake had a nice marble look to it and had a sweet dulce de leche flavor.

country:

text:
i am not a novice to baking cheesecakes but in the past i've always used a bain marie when making them (they usually turn out picture perfect).  i decided to try chantal's recipe without the bain marie because it was so highly rated and honestly, if i can skip a step why not?  the batter looked great (NB> i am very careful not to overmix my cheesecakes) and all was well until *holy smokes* it cracked!  before cooling even.  i now have a cheesecake that looks likes the grand canyon is running through it.  in the future i will not cut out the bain marie step!  i may up the rating after i try it... but for now all i have to say is THANK GOODNESS i have a berry sauce to put on top otherwise i would be making something else to take to a dinner tonight!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
4920096
Display Name:
Leli
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/666827.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first cheesecake I have ever made and it was a great success. When I read the recipe and reviews I was intimidated by the amount of work involved. I did not want to go through the process and end up with a sunken, cracked cake. However, after reading numerous reviews and picking and choosing instructions from each one I made a great cake that my coworkers raved about. I used Laurelc43’s instructions for baking the cake @ 225 for 3hrs40min. I also used cut the flour to 2tbs. For the crust I used about 10-15 graham crackers, seven pecan sandies, 1/8 tsp cinnamon, 1/8 tbs nutmeg, ¼ cup of butter and ¼ cup of brown sugar. The crust was sweet so if you don’t want it too sweet cut the sugar. I used a reviewers suggestion to use an oven bag but found that condensation still got inside of the bag. I was not sure if I was supposed to seal the bag or simply sit the pan in the bag and fold the bag down on the side of the pan so next time I will wrap the pan in foil as well. The one problem I had was the crust sticking to the bottom of the pan (yes, I did grease the pan). Overall, this was the best cheesecake I have had in years and I will make it again.

Wow what a flalwless recipe! And like the other  reviewer said...if it doesn't turn out it's you or you oven. If you want true New York dense Cheesecake this is it! I made blackberry sauce for the top, 4 cups  blackberries and 1 1/2 cups sugar and 1 tbsp lemon juce. Cook down and run it through a sieve place back on stove add 2 tsp cornstartch disolved in water to the blackberries. Then add lemon juice. MMM MMM good...what a winner

The best cheesecake recipe!  I added a bit more butter to the crust mixture and think this may have made it a little soggy. I highly recommend this recipe if you like cheesecake factory results.

fantastic!!!!  I made 2 changes, since we live in the UK and don't have access to graham crackers....  so I substituted: 1 1/2 C. digestives and 1/4 C butter.   Followed others advice:  put a pan of water into the oven while cooking (rather than water bath) and ran a knife around the edge after 1hr cooking time. Then left it to cool in the oven over night. It turned out perfect!

text:
Ok, now i havent tasted it yet. Saving it for an Easter dinner tomorrow. BUT I did follow all the suggestions so it wouldnt crack. Mine STILL cracked. I used room temp ingrediants, I did bake it in a water bath, put 2 layers of foil around my springform, and let it bake for 60 minutes, used a buttered knife to seperate the cheesecake and the pan then let it sit in the oven for 5 hours. IT STILL CRACKED! What else could I have done!!!  Not only did it crack, but I also got WATER in the bottom of my crust. Now if my crust is mushy tomorrow....I will NOT be impressed...
So my crust was not only mushy, but completely inedible. I understand it was not the recipe's fault, as I followed reviews instead of sticking to the tried, tested and true recipe. I know better for next time, because there WILL be a next time. The cheesecake itself turned out fantastic. Very creamy, and rich and good. I do not reccomend putting it in a water bath. Mine cracked anyways, plus it leaked water in my crust, and made the crust horrible.

text:
I have not come across one person that has tasted this recipe that is not in love with the cheescake. I took others advice by dolling up the crust a bit. Add 1T cinniman, 1/4T nutmeg, and 1/2c chopped nuts (ie. walnuts or pecans), 1/2c white sugar, one graham cracker brick, mix all the ingredients with a food processor until finely choppped. Add 1/4c melted butter. As for the batter there was post about using a bath water and baking at 225 for 3hrs. and 40minutes. This is the key to a perfect cheesecake!!!!  Also, only use 2T of flour. Leave the cheesecake in the oven with the door cracked for 6 hours after baking. Then put in the fridge for at least 6 hours. Then tada you have heaven in your hands.

text:
This is a recipe that I have wanted to try for years after seeing all the beautiful photos and great reviews from others.  I did use a different graham cracker crust recipe, but followed the filling instructions exactly.  I thought this was good, but not very flavorful.  I ended up with a significant five-pointed crack that was about an inch deep...sort of a decoration across the entire top of the cheesecake even though I oiled the sides of the spring form pan all the way up and also let it cool for the full amount of time in the oven.  Next time I make a cheesecake I will probably try a different recipe, but if I do make this one again, I'll make sure to use a water bath and also add a little more vanilla.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Wow!!  I would recommend this rich, delicious cheesecake recipe to anyone.  I had never made a cheesecake before, and was very nervous.  I followed the directions and it came out beautifully.  There was some cracking on top, but who cares?  I gave slices to everyone at work, and people were raving.  Everyone said it was better than a restaurant.  While pressing the crust into the pan, it looked like it needed more butter...but in the end, more butter is unnecessary.  Just trust the recipe - it won't steer you wrong!  I will definitely make this one again and again!

EDIT - GLUTEN FREE: I made this again for my mother's birthday.  She is allergic to wheat, so I made the cake using a package of gluten-free gingersnaps in place of the graham crackers for the crust.  In place of flour in the cake, I used a special gluten-free flour blend that my father developed using various commercial non-wheat flours.  (You could also use a commercially available blend.)  Then I put fresh fruit on top.  The cake tasted exactly the same, except with a gingery crust.  Nobody could believe it was gluten-free!  My mom was so excited.  If someone in your family has celiac disease, this can be a great gluten-free special occasion cake.

Display Name:
CindyC
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably the best homemade cheesecake I've had and it's so easy to make.  As others have said, if it fails, it's because you're doing something wrong!  I use a water bath (wrap the pan twice in heavy duty foil - it never leaks), preheat my oven, make sure all ingredients are at room temperature and don't over-beat!  I don't know if this helps or not but I use a KitchenAid stand mixer on its slowest speed to mix.  I also rap the batter bowl on the counter after mixing in order to eliminate as many air bubbles as possible.  Additionally, right before I put the cake in the oven, I rap the pan gently on the counter - again, to eliminate any air bubbles.  Only thing I do different for the recipe itself is that I use a different graham crust as I like mine to have a little sugar and cinnamon.  I serve the cheesecake with a homemade raspberry or blueberry sauce and it gets RAVE reviews EVERY time!  Hope everyone else enjoys this one as much as I do!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was actually very easy and on my first try I made a delicious New York style cheesecake.  I used a bathwater and allowed all the ingredients to warm up to room temperature before combining them. While it was tempting to peek in the oven, I am glad that I didn't because I got a uniform, creamy and rich cake without any drying or cracking.  As it may have been suggested, wrap the bottom of your springform pan in aluminum foil before putting it in the bathwater to help eliminate a soggy crust. Keep in mind that this is a NEW YORK STYLE CHEESECAKE, and TRUE TO THAT STYLE, it is creamy, firm, and not extremely sweet, perfect for including sweet additions and/or toppings. This recipe is more Martha Stewart and less Paula Deen, if you know what I'm sayin'.

I used one person's idea of using Bailey's instead of milk, and I didn't really enjoy it. I'll have to try this recipe again just as is. text:
This cheesecake recipe is perfect and amazing. My family said it tasted just like a cheesecake from a deli or restaurant. I followed the instructions to a T, with a few hints from the comments section. I made sure my ingredients were warmed to room temperature, I was very careful not to overmix, and I ran a knife around the edge of the pan about an hour after turning off the oven. I only let it sit in the oven for about 4 hours before transferring to the fridge, then I let it cool in there for almost 3 hours before serving. The consistency was nothing short of perfect, and I only had one crack about a centimeter long. This cheesecake will not disappoint you if you follow the directions!

userID:
3784819
Display Name:
StacyJ
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Aaaah, the cheesecake.  So delicious. I brought it to a New Year Eve dinner part and it was a major hit.  People were all over me for the recipe.  And that never happens to me :)   BUT, I had to make the cake twice - the first one didn't turn out. It was lumpy and very cracked. Here's what I did different the second time around:  1.  Cooked at 325 degrees for 1 hour.  Immediately took cake out of oven and knifed around the edges of the cake pan and then quickly put back in oven to cool.  (my aunt the cheesecake expert told me to do this and it worked). After one hour the cake was still jiggly in the center and looked unbaked. But it set further as it was cooling.  2.  Seriously, the cream cheese has to be at room temperature.  And mix it well with the sugar. I was worried about overbeating.  I think its the later ingrediants that you have to go easy on the mixing.  3.  DO NOT mix in the flour and vanilla together. What a nightmare - my first cake had brown lumps in it. YUCK!  Good luck and be careful, these cakes are fiddly. But well worth it.  I froze my first cake and have been eating it too (not so bad tasting even though it is ugly)

Well, I was extremely skeptical of this recipe, having never before made one that called for flour, or that was completely liquid when I poured it in...I thought, "That's never going to set up!" But it did! Mine did crack down the center a bit, but I expected it to since I didn't use a water bath. I planned to top the pie with blackberry pie filling all along, and did so. It baked up tall, and fluffy, and almost the exact same consistency as cheesecakes from a well-known cheesecake making restaurant, which is what I was going for. I was very pleased! (P.S. I used 2 pkgs regular cream cheese and 2 pkgs 1/3rd less fat.)

text:
I followed this recipe to a T and incorporated the advice included in other reviews for a well-textured product.  I gave this one three stars:  zero for flavor and 5 for texture.  I LOVE cheesecakes, and it's not that the flavor was BAD (I've never met a cheesecake I DIDN'T like), but it certainly lacked the 'tang' associated with cream cheese that makes me sacrifice my hips for the cheesecake cause.  I don't know if it was masked by the flour or the sour cream or what, but it definitely wasn't there.  My sister, on the other hand, commented that it was the best cheesecake she's ever had, but her idea of cheesecake is thawing out a round brick from the freezer section and calling it good.  This was the first "from-scratch, homemade" cake she's had, and I'm accostumed to cheesecakes whose life didn't begin in a factory.  I didn't find the consistency to be too 'cakey', but pretty consistent other with New York Cheesecakes.  My overall conclusion was, "Meh".

userID:
4361220
Display Name:
Sophie's Mom
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
11
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fabulous recipe and the reviews were really helpful. I read a lot of the reviews and have listed the ones I used.  I brought this to a family gathering and got great reviews, an empty platter back and multiple requests for the recipe...  The tips I used from reading the reviews:  1. The person who thought to use an oven bag instead of tin foil for the water bath is a genius, it worked perfect, didn't leak and the top never cracked. (wish I would have thought of that)I didn't use a rubberband ... I just rolled the edges out so that it stayed up and fit...  2. I made sure to use my mixer only to beat the cream cheese and sugar and hand mixed everything else... this made for a nice dense cheesecake.  3. I listened and did not open the oven(eventhough I wanted to)... I'll be honest, I used the oven light and looked in at the hour mark and really questioned if I should turn off the oven.  I followed the directions and it was perfect. I made this the evening before and left it in the oven all night and first thing in the morning put in the fridge... by the time we left for our party it was well chilled and no cracks...  4.  Spraying the pan so the crust doesn't stick is essential (I have never had a cheesecake come out the pan that easily)  5.  I used Bailey's Irish Cream instead of Milk... (same amount of liquid) and it had a great taste.  6.  I did put sugar in the crust as many people suggested.  I usually do anyways so I would say this is a good tip.

text:
This is the Best Cheesecake Recipe! I followed other peoples reviews and used a water bath to bake the cheesecake in so it didn't dry out & covered the outside of the pan with foil so the water didn't leak in. I also used a foil tent while baking so the top did not brown.  I also added more crumbs than the recipe called for to the crust to make it thicker and more butter also. It turned out great, I just made it for thanksgiving and everyone loved it.

I made this exactly as stated, except that I topped it with blueberries (baked on).  I cooked  a 12 pkg of blueberries with 2tbsp flour and 4 tbsp cold water.  I cooked it until it was thickened, about 10 minutes.  It was wonderful...and perfectly cooked.  My only problem was I didn't have a springform pan, so I used a cake pan and the crust ended up being soft and sticking to the bottom (although i greased it.)

text:
This may replace the Bon Appetit cheesecake recipe that we've used for years!  Wonderful texture.  Easy to make!  I was hesitant to follow the directions and leave it cooling in the oven... but I did and it was even perfect.  (I actually wasn't even home.  I set the timed cook clock on the oven and left after I put it in the oven!)   Read the reviews about cooking with a water bath.  We'd never done that before... but it really helped prevent cracking!  Had to modify the crust a little bit: added more grahams and more butter, as there wasn't enough to cover the bottom of my pan.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe for true cheesecake although I did modify it a little on my second attempt. When I prepared it as directed I found it to be a little too sweet and a little too creamy (kind of like a box mix cheesecake) so, I dialed back the sugar to around 1.25 cups and I upped the flour to about .50 of a cup and it came out the consistency of a cheesecake you'd get at Cheesecake Factory or persoanlly it came out like the cake a friend of the family typically makes for the holidays.

text:
Incredible recipe if you do it right. My first try I couldn't get the water bath right. The cheesecake tasted good, but didn't have that good cheesecake texture to it and was more like a regular cake. Then I purchased extra-large aluminum foil and used that around the spring form pan so that I could use just one piece. This worked great! The cheesecake came out looking like what you would get from the Cheesecake Factory or from a nice restaurant. Now I'm totally into making these and will be making more at Christmas.

text:
This was great! I've never made cheesecake before, and decided to give it a shot for Thanksgiving...I know so daring :-)  I changed this recipe up a bit, for the crust I did a ginger snap crust (1.5 cups of crumbled gingersnaps, 1/4 cup of sugar, and 1/2 cup melted butter) and after I baked it and waited for it to cool I made pumpkin chiffon.  I took off about 1/2 of the top layer of the cheesecake and layered on the pumpkin chiffon.  This made it a double layered cake, half cheesecake and half pumpkin chiffon.  The pumpkin chiffon is very light and frothy so it was a nice compliment to the heaviness of the cheesecake.  It was so yummy, I'm making it for work tomorrow!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for Thanksgiving.  Used a stand mixer to mix all ingredients.  Everything was at room temperature.  I removed the cheesecake from the oven after letting it rest for about an hour and a half.  The top was slightly browned on the edges.  After being out of the oven for about 15 minutes it cracked.  Still tasted delicious!  It disappeared faster than the turkey.  I am going to make another one for Christmas.  Everyone told me it tasted like a restaurant quality cheesecake, and I agree. NOTE:  I wasn't sure if the 15 graham crackers meant 15 sheets, or 15 quarters, so I tried 15 quarters first, it wasn't nearly enough, so I went with 15 sheets.  This made a nice crust just under about 1/4 inch.  I packed it lightly with the bottom of a glass into a spring form pan. I baked the cheesecake without any water bath on the center rack for an hour, then left it for an hour and a half with the oven off.  In hindsight I think I should have baked it for about 45 minutes, then let it rest.

I haven't wrote a review in years, but this exceptional.  I made this one a couple of years ago, and it's still the best, but I just did things a little differently. text:
THis is the  second cheesecake I've made using this recipe. I baked it differently and it came out with no craccks.  Preheat oven to 350, put cheesecake in and immediately turn down to 250. BAke for 90 minutes, then shut off oven, but DO NOT OPEN DOOR at any time, and leave in for a few more hours. Also, put a pan of water directly under the cheesecake.  This works great. . no cracking, beautiful smoothe top like from the deli.

text:
I haven't eaten this yet, but will update when I do. I'm like a proud mama over this cheese cake. It is so beautiful! This was my first attempt at a cheese cake and I'm so happy with the out come. I mixed everything with a stand mixer on low, helping it along with a rubber spatula here and there. Make sure to ADD THE EGGS LAST! You do not want to mix very much after the eggs are added because it will make the cake crack. I was too scared to try a water bath so I just put a roasting pan full of water on the shelf below. I'm going to serve it with the chocolate  brandy sauce from the  White Chocolate Cheese Cake with Brandy Sauce recipe from this site. Can't wait to eat it!

text:
really amazing.  i used 2 tbs instead of 1/4 cup flour. i also use this recipe along with the double layer pumpkin cheesecake from this site.... basically take this recipe, pour half in the spring-form, then with the remaining half, add 1 3/4 or 2 cups of pumpkin puree, 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon, 2 pinches of clove, 2 pinches of nutmeg. then pour this pumpkin mixture on top of of the first layer.  bake as usual.  (you can also just use a can of pumpkin pie filling- already has the spices in there.  or if using the puree, you can vary the amount of puree and spices depending on your liking) soooo good!!

text:
Going to add my bit here- LOVE this.  I omit the flour, as I like the velvety smooth texture.  I made sure I let everything come to room temperature before starting (bought the ingredients then left them on the counter) I baked it at 300F for 1.5 hours in a tinfoil wrapped spring form pan set in a bath of boiling water.  Then I let it sit for another 2-3 hours.  I had no problems with cracking/bubbling/browning.  We at it later that night, and WOW.  Between three of us, half of it was gone.  Just about to make another.  So good.

Display Name:
carlton blake

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VERY GOOD AND PRETTY EASY IF YOU DONT MIND WAITING TO LET IT COOL SLOWLY TO PREVENT CRACKS. I PREHEAT OVEN TO 350 PUT CAKE IN WITH PAN OF WATER ON BOTTOM RACK, CAKE ON MIDDLE. TURN OVEN TO 275 AND BAKE FOR 1 HOUR 15 MIN. GIVE OR TAKE. TURN OVEN OFF WHEN DONE (CAKE SHOULD STILL WIGGLE SOME IN MIDDLE)LEAVE CAKE IN WITH OVEN DOOR CLOSED FOR AT LEAST 4 HOURS (BEST TO MAKE AT NIGHT AND LET IT COOL AS YOU SLEEP). PUT IN FRIG. TO CHILL ALL THE WAY THROUGH. THIS PROCESS WILL GIVE YOU A CHEESE CAKE WITH A WHITE TOP WITH OUT A SKIN OR CRACKS LOOKS JUST LIKE IN THE COOKBOOKS!! DONT FORGET TO BUTTER DOWN THE SIDES OF THE SPRIGFORM PAN GOOD TO PREVENT STICKING. HOPE THIS HELPS.

text:
Its a great cheesecake recipe, but not an authentic New York cheesecake. I prefer to use a shortbread crust with all my cheesecakes. Here is the recipe for this crust #  1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour # 1/3 cup white sugar # 1 egg, beaten # 1/2 cup butter, softened Mix all ingredients together and press into a 9" springform pan, bake at 400 degree oven for 15 min, remove and let cool. I also fill a pan with 1-2" of water and place it in the oven when baking the cheesecake, this prevents cracks in the surface

text:
It tasted ok, though certainly wasn't my favorite.  After it sat in the fridge for like 10 hours (and that was after I had left it in the oven as recommended in recipe) it tasted too eggy and spongy, not dense and rich.  After it sat for like 24 hours it became much more rich and more like cheesecake texture.  However, it was pretty bland and not very tangy or rich.  And I thought it was too eggy tasting and not rich enough.  I was surprised about my results, I had researched for a long time before selecting this recipe.  The technique itself was good, but the ingredients weren't quite right.  Needs to be tangier, richer, and less eggy IMO.

text:
Amazing recipe, I made mine with fat free cream cheese and a combo of 7 graham crackers and 4 packages of 100 calorie Sandies smashed, and 1/4 cup almonds toasted and finely chopped for the crust. I also took the advice of other members and baked with a pan of water on the rack below the cheesecake instead of a water bath. We all loved this cheesecake, My husband raved about it so much that my mother-in-law asked for the recipe and made it for her mother-in-law who also asked for the recipe. I made this for our anniversary and microwaved 1/4 cup chocolate chips and 1/2 tsp vegetable oil for 30 seconds, it wont seem melted, just stir. Add to a sandwhich bag, cut the tip and drizzle over the cheesecake.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my husband's birthday and we both loved it.  I changed to recipe to be healthier, and it was still very very good. I used only (3) 8 oz packages of cream cheese as that was all I had, 2 fat free and 1 reduced fat.  I used egg beaters, splenda, skim milk, whole wheat flour, reduced fat graham crackers for the crust, and the butter substitute brummel and brown (as it has much less calories than real butter).  Mine did crack in one spot, but that was my fault.  I was in a hurry...my cream cheese was not at room temperature, I forgot to grease the pan before pouring, and I couldn't let it rest in the oven as I had other cooking to do.  I made a red raspberry cream sauce for the top to cover the crack and it worked perfectly.

text:
This is a full-on 5 star cheesecake in terms of taste. I did have a little trouble, as I have made this twice (I used a wooden spoon for mixing to prevent incorporating too much air). The flour formed large lumps in the batter when I stirred it in so I ommited it on the second try. I still got cracks in my cheesecake both times, so I'm guessing it has something to do with temperature and/or overbaking. Next time I'll try at 325 degrees and probably in a water bath. Despite the fact that mine looked like the Grand Canyon, the taste was SUPERB, and I just know that this will make a beautiful cake once I find a way to steer clear from cracks. :)

text:
Ok, so I followed this recipe to a T...except that I substituted light sour cream for regular.  That's all I had.  I was very excited about this recipe because of the fact it stated that there would be no cracks in the cheesecake. Well, mine did not have any cracks at all....it had the grand canyon on top!!!  I was so disappointed.  There were 2 inch deep cracks in the entire top.  I wasn't sure what I was going to do.  I made a sour cream, vanilla and cool whip topping and it looked perfect.  It also tasted VERY good.  Just a little disappointed about the grand canyon type cracks.  I would try this again, but will use regular sour cream.  Not sure if that was the problem of the cracks. Update...9/21/09.  I tried this yet again and the grand canyon was still on top of my cheesecake. Followed the recipe but substituted an oreo crust.  I have not tried this yet, but the crust smells very burnt.  I am not at all sold on this recipe and think the issue is leaving in the hot oven for so long after it is done baking.  This one just doesn't work for me.  I will try another.

This cheesecake is delicious and really is easy to make!!! I have made it once so far but it was a hit at our family gathering and everyone fought over the last piece! I am about to make 2 more today for a birthday (my niece asked me to make it for her birthday, instead of her mother buying a cake). city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cheesecake for my brother's girlfriend's 30th birthday-- she works at a dessert restaurant and she said it was the best she has ever had!! Word to the wise: Research how to make cheesecakes! I spent an hour reading about the science behind it and it surely paid off!! I baked it in a cookie sheet with hot water, and checked it every 15 minutes to make sure the water hadn't evaporated. Also, I used a 9" springform pan-- that MADE the cheesecake!! When it was done baking, I left it in the oven to cool, and after 5 hours of cooling in the oven, I transferred it to the refrigerator for an hour or so. This is such an easy recipe as long as you follow the directions!! My best friend and I are going to make it again this weekend!

But i will definitely make this over and over again until i become a great grandma.. if i live that long haha.

I've been making this cheesecake for awhile now.  At first I had issues with the cheesecake cracking, but after doing some research, I found that all I had to do was put it in a water bath and...VIOLA, no more cracks!  But now, sometimes a little water leaks through the springform pan, but next time I will probably try lining the pan with foil before putting it in the water bath.  Otherwise, great recipe!  I was never a fan of cheesecake before, but even people who aren't cheesecake lovers would love this.  I love the texture and the taste of it!

text:
Oh my goodness have your taste buds ready for this....AWESOME!!! I cooked mine in a water bath which was the way to go if you do not want any cracks in your cake.  Cover the bottom of your pan with foil and I also used a cooking bag (to make sure no water got in) and then put in a cast iron pan with about 1 1/2 inches of water.  After cooking I left it in oven for about 2 hours then in the frige.  It came out wonderful.  Will be making this again real soon.

text:
I've never been much of a cheesecake person, but this recipe could certainly make me one! Not being big on graham cracker crusts, I made a shortbread crust of 1.5c flour, 1/3c sugar, 1 egg, 1/2c butter, 1 tbsp fresh lemon zest. It was a bit more crust than I wanted for the 9" springform, so I made 6 small cookies for my hubby to munch on while waiting for the cheesecake. :) I made this in the evening, so it only was left in the oven for about 2 hours after it finished and still came out perfect. I agree completely with previous posts to not touch the oven door once it's in the oven.. and definitely use a water bath. Thanks so much for sharing this wonderful recipe.

text:
I just made this cheescake, it was absolutely perfect! I put a roaster pan of hot water on the oven shelf below the cheesecake. This makes more sense than trying to wrap foil around the pan and placing it in a water bath. Why take the chance of the water leaking into the cheescake? I made this exactly to the directions, making sure all ingredients were at room temperature. AND NOT OVER MIXING!! I sprayed my springform pan with non-stick oil.  I baked it late in the evening and let it set overnight in the oven (without opening the door!!) The result was a "PERFECT CHEESECAKE", no cracking in the cake, it was well set and had a very creamy texture! Added a can of cherry pie filling on the top.  I will definitely make this again! This recipe is foolproof if the directions are carefully followed! Everyone that tried it gave it a great review! This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
I've never made cheesecake before so I was very nervous. It seems easy to mess up. OVERALL this turned out great! The taste and texture was delicious. I think the middle didn't get baked as much as the outside because it was much creamier. Since I'm at sea level I wonder if I should have cooked it a bit longer than recommended. I also was terrified of overbeating the cream cheese but mine probably could have been beat a bit longer, there were a few lumps. Per lots of advice and articles I got a glass bottomed springform pan and some heavy duty aluminum foil, and made a water bath with my roasting pan. I used light sour cream and cake flour. My topping was a modified cherry pie filling. Overall this was terrific, thanks for such a nice recipe!

I have tried to make cheesecake for several years & failed many times because I was over beating them. I am master baker but had not reserchased baking cheesecake. I found this recipe to be the best cheesecake I have ever tasted even without any topping. I had everything at room temp. I mixed the cream cheese sugar, flour & vanilla with a hand mixer then added all other indgs. one at a time mixing by hand. I used heavy cream & only 2 Tbsp. flour as suggested by Laurelc43 in  the reviews.  She said to bake it 3 hrs. & 40 min. at 225 degreese F. it was perfect. The 1st time I put foil around it & it leaked so the 2nd time I used a baking bag with great success. I would give this 10 stars.

Oh my god!  I never would have thought that I could make a cheesecake, much less one that came out PERFECT and tasted like HEAVEN.  I followed other reviewers advice and baked it in a bain marie (water bath) with the pan wrapped in a roasting bag.  I have made this three times now. This last time I made it, I forgot to grease the pan and realized it as I was pouring the filling over the crust!  Daaang!  I freaked and ran to Google "I forgot to grease my cheesacake pan".  After reading several accounts, I realized I was not in big trouble after all.  Well, I baked the cheesecake and when it was finished I ran a knife around the inside of the pan as suggested.  The only thing this accomplished was to tear up the crust a bit.  I was nervous as this cheesecake was meant to be dessert that night.  We were entertaining some fairly new friends and I wanted to make a good impression.  They arrived that night bearing sweets, so I knew that if the cheesecake was a disaster at least we would still have dessert.  The time came to bust out the cheesecake and I gave my disclaimer about forgetting to grease.  We cut into the cake and served it around.  It was perfect again.  Save for the bit of roughed up crust we were in business! Thanks chibi chef!  You and this wonderful cheesecake ROCK!

text:
For the holidays I always bake a cheesecake. This is the first time ( probably 20 attempts) I ever made a perfect cheesecake with no cracks or dips in the middle. It was truely a work of art and the taste was fantastic. I used the recipe as written and the techniques discussed in other reviews. I preheated the oven for 1 hour, placed a pan of hot water on the shelf below 30 minutes before I baked the cheesecake. I only used the beater for the cream cheese and sugar and used a wooden spoon to blend in the remaining ingredients by hand. I sprayed the entire pan with Pam. I baked the cake 1 hr and never opened the oven door until 5 1/2 hours after the cake was baked. The result was perfect. I had to take a picture. Thanks to everyone for your tips. It is a good feeling to finally have success.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
When reading this recipe, I saw that you needed a "springform" pan, and that it needed to cook in a "water bath". I wasn't going to try this recipe, simply because I didn't have either. I really wanted to try it, though because of all the great reviews. So, I compromised and used a regular round cake pan, heavily greased it, and put it in a rectangular cake pan about 2'' tall. I put this in the oven, and then filled the rectangular pan with about 3/4'' of HOT water. I baked it at 350 for about an hour, turned off the oven, and left it inside to cool slowly (about 3-4 hours). The top didn't crack, and the sides didn't stick. So, if you don't have a spring form pan or are intimidated about the word "water bath", please use this method because this is THE BEST cheesecake!!! And it was my first time making one!! Thank you !

My family said this cheesecake was the best ever! It all got eaten in just one night. I only changed a few things. I cut the recipe in 1/2 baked it in a 8x8 square glass dish.  I love shortbread crusts, so instead of a graham crust, I used a shortbread crust ("Shortbread Crust" from allrecipes.) I also added a little more sugar to the recipe. When you half this recipe, it calls for 3/4 cup of sugar. I did just slightly under a full cup (pretty much a level full cup). You dont have to do this, but I like my cheesecakes more sweet. And to me it was absolutely perfect this way!!!!!!! Loved every modification I made. Loved the way I did it! But this is definitely the best cheesecake recipe I have ever tried!

text:
Nothing more can be said bout this great cheesecake! But for those thinking of making this 'healthier', I used Low-Fat greek style yogurt instead of sour cream and you won't be able to tell the difference. Also, I baked it at 225degF for 3.5 hrs as the other reviewer suggested, grease the sides of the pan well and a pan of water on the bottom rack of the oven. No cracks. Also, if there are tiny air bubbles in the mixture when pouring into the cakepan, you might wanna poke it or it will create little holes on the final product.

text:
To be honest, with all the modifications I did to this recipe it was hardly the recipe at all, but the measurements of the ingredients were the same, except that I halved the flour.  I was skeptical at first, especially since I've have had bad luck with allrecipes in the past.  I took the advice of LAURELC43 and reduced the flour and changed the cooking time to 3 hours and 40 minutes at 225 degrees.  This worked beautifully, the cheesecake barely had any color on top and had none on the sides.  I still don't know how people get it with no browning at all like the picture shows.  I basically used Alton Brown's method of doing cheesecake.  Sour cream first, then cream cheese and sugar.  I did let the cream cheese warm, but I don't think it was enough since it had a few lumps.  Then I blended all the liquid ingredients and added them in a thin stream.  I had no idea when to add the flour so I added it in the beginning. I'm going to omit it or use cornstarch next time.  I used a springform pan and water bath of course.  I recommend wrapping the pan in aluminum foil and putting parchment paper underneath the crust.  It wasn't perfect, I did end up with some small bubbles on the top of the cake, but it was great nonetheless.  The sides also didn't come away perfectly, perhaps I should have sprayed them a little more than I did(I used the canola/flour spray).  I may try smearing it with a shortening flour mixture which I've had very good success with when using cakes cakes. I'm goin

text:
I trusted the most popular reviewer, the one who said that the recipe is perfect and if it didn't turn out, it's my fault. Well I followed the recipe to a T. Let the ingredients come to room temp. Didn't open the oven door. Even made sure the oven's temp was really 350. I did not over beat anything. The cheesecake came out gritty, over-browned, and with a large crack. If a water bath is necessary, then the recipe should say so. Maybe this recipe is perfect after you make tons of changes, but again, I made it as stated. IF I make this again, I will make it with a water bath. I know it was over cooked, but it's my fault for trusting the review, and the recipe.

text:
So good! Two suggestions (both common sense):  1) Let all your ingredients warm up to room temp before mixing. It makes them blend much easier/require less mixing and thus not as tough.  2) Don't be an idiot like me and dump the vanilla extract on dry ingredients (like flour). I did this (stupidly) and I had brown clumps of flour throughout my cheesecake. Still fantastic

text:
EXCELLENT!!!!  I followed the directions almost to the letter. Rather than using a hand mixer (wasn't sure if I was supposed to!), I mixed everything by hand. It appeared a bit lumpy, so I then  poured the mixture into the cake pan through a sieve. I also used a 10" pan, as I don't have a 9" pan. I did use a water bath, and only left it in the oven for 2-1/2 hrs after it had cooked for an hour.   The end result was a wonderful cheesecake without cracks, that all have enjoyed either just plain, or with various toppings.

Display Name:
Melissa

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, I didn't have a spring form pan, and I didn't really want to go out and buy one for this dish.  Instead I used a round ceramic quiche dish that I had (although I'm sure a round cake pan would do just as well) and I lined it with tin foil.  I sprayed the tin foil with non-stick cooking spray so that the cheesecake wouldn't stick to it.  I was worried about the crust not having enough butter and thought it might not hold together, so I added another Tablespoon of butter.  I realize now that I probably didn't need to, it would have done fine, but it turned out to be just as good with the extra butter.  I ended up doing a water bath as well, and IT DIDN'T CRACK!!!  After baking, I cooled it in the oven, and then overnight in the refrigerator.  When it was completely cool, I was able to pull the tinfoil right out without a problem!  Who needs a spring form pan anyway?  It was THE BEST CHEESECAKE EVER.  Do yourself a favor and don't try it, your hips will never look the same!

I am rating this a 5 because my cheesecake tasted like a baby watson new york cheesecake...my mom is a born and raised NYCer and I think she almost teared up at the memories of this cheesecake! Here is what I did for those that want it: •	2 (8 ounce) packages cream cheese  •	2 eggs  •	1/4 cup sour cream  •	2 tablespoons all-purpose flour  •	1 cup white chocolate chips  •	1/4 cup half-and-half cream  •	1/4 cup white sugar

I found this receipe from this website some time ago, and I have never looked for another recipe since.  It is perfect, and it is DELICIOUS!  Follow the steps EXACTLY.  I have never had a single cheesecake, when following this recipe at least, come out with a single crack.  They are always perfect. My family is constantly requesting that I make it for family gatherings.  I love to mix up my own raspberry topping for it.  No recipe to follow, I just cook raspberries with a little bit of sugar and water in a saucepan, and let the raspberries break down.  I add honey and more sugar to taste.  Let the raspberry mixture cool, then strain to remove the seeds.   YUM!

text:
I usually make the New York Cheesecake III recipe (which I pull off without a problem whatsoever), but was requested to try one with a graham crust. I used all organic ingredients- for whatever reason, organic cream cheese is extremely difficult to cream (yes even at room temp). I had to mix the milk in with it in the sugar to get it workable. After I blended everything, I dropped the bowl as much as I could to get out air bubbles. Despite baking exactly one hour, the cheesecake browned a lot (probably too much) on the edges. It rose up like a mushroom cloud but now that it has settled, it has a San Andrea faultline sized cracked straight down the middle. Ugh! Everything was room temp and I tried not to overmix any of it. Maybe after it settles more the crack will heal itself (doubtful). I hope it tastes better than it looks. And crushing the graham crackers is a huge pain and extremely messy. Just toss it in a blender and save yourself the trouble. (I used cinnamon, and added extra butter/cinnamon/nutmeg as suggested, left out the extra sugar) I'll stick to the other cheesecake recipe from now on.

text:
This cheesecake comes out perfect every time i cook it.  Its almost fail proof, I don't know how anyone could mess this up.  The trick is getting all your ingredients to room temperature BEFORE combining them, and when your finished baking, just turn the oven off and walk away.  DO NOT take the cheesecake out of the oven, just let everything cool down by itself.  I usually make this the night before and leave it in the oven to cool all night.  I'm considered the queen of cheesecake at work now, and they are a tough crowd (frequent Cheesecake Factory diners)

text:
Simply wonderful recipe!!! This was going to be my fist attempt at a cheesecake so I did a trial run as I wanted to make sure I was sucessful for Christmas. First time was amazing no cracks with using a water bath and following other instructions completely. For Christams I used a full sleeve of graham crackers a couple of Tbs of sugar and 4Tbs butter. I made a caramel sauce and poured 2/3 over the crust. Sprinkle about a cup of chopped pecans over the caramel. POured all but  1 1/2 cups of batter into pan.I melted about 1/2 chocolate chips and combined 2/3 in the reserved batter. Swirled into pan. Using heavy duty foil you could tear a sheet that turned sideways so I didn't have an edge in the water to stop any leaks. I did double the foil for a thicker covering. After pulling it out of the oven at the recommended time. I used the reserved (reheated) caramel and chocolate chips to drizzle over the top with a few pecans. Just georgous!!! Thanks a gain for the perfect cheesecake recipe.

text:
This is an excellent recipe! I have a few tips for no-fail results:(1)Butter the sides of a 10-inch pan.(This allows the cake to easily pull away from the pan as it cools, eliminating cracks.)Change the crust ingredients to 2 C. cinnamon graham cracker crumbs, ½ C. melted butter, 2 Tbsp. sugar, and ½ C. chopped pecans; press into the bottom of the pan and bake for 10 minutes in a 350-degree oven. Let cool. Wrap the outside of the pan in 6 sheets of heavy aluminum foil.(This keeps the edges creamy and the bottom from overcooking.)(2)Use 1 ½ times the amount of ingredients listed when making the filling. This fills a 10-inch pan perfectly. Also, change the flour amount to 2 heaping Tbsp., and substitute cream for milk. Allow the ingredients to reach room temperature before mixing. Beat the cream cheese alone first, until it’s smooth and creamy, before adding any other ingredients.(3)Place a broiling pan half full of boiling water onto the lowest rack in the oven.(The moisture produced from the water while baking also helps prevent cracks.) Move the top rack to the middle, and bake the cheesecake on the middle rack.(4)Follow Javaflops’ advice on baking. They produce a PERFECT, BEAUTIFUL cheesecake. Her instructions are: “…bake it at 325 for 15 minutes and then at 250 for 15 minutes and then at 225 for 15 and then 200 for 2 hours and 50 minutes and finally 250 for 10 minutes.” Then turn the oven off, prop the door open with a wooden spoon, and let it set overnight.  Don’t touch i

text:
Ok, this was my first attempt EVER at cheesecake.  It was quite easy, mine did crack, I baked as directed and left it in the oven for 5 hours, it cracked before then, so I didn't think it was necessary to wait any longer, the damage was done.  It was my turn to bring dessert to family holidays, so I topped this cake with cherry pie filling, everyone loved it, and no one saw the crack :).  It was quite tasty, next time I think I'll add the "bain marie" as one reviewer suggested, also I didn't mix anything by hand as another suggested because the recipe said "do it just the way it reads" and I didn't want to risk it. If the "bain marie" doesn't help next time, I'll go with the "by hand" suggestion.  Regardless, the cake was a huge success.  Even my niece, the "cheesecake" specialist enjoyed it.

text:
I made this for a Christmas Church gathering and it was a big hit.  The only changes I made was my crust was 1 cup crushed graham crackers, 2 T. sugar and 1/4 cup melted butter, pressed onto the bottom and up the sides sligtly of the pan.  I did cook it in a water bath like others said.  Once cooled I topped it with a chocolate sauce.  To make do the following; in a microwave safe measuring cup put 1 cup semi sweet chocolate chips and pour heavy cream over chips to almost the top of them.  Microwave for 45 seconds.  Stir mixture until all chips are melted and sauce thickends up.  Pour over top of cheesecake and refrigerate.
Review:
Rating:

userID:
907214
Display Name:
CINDYLOUHOO

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is cheesecake always gets rave reviews. I think it is better the day after. Sometimes I change out the crusts. A favorite is using a whole box of Lorna Doone Shortbread cookies with a sprinkling of Cinnamon mixed in or using oreo cookies. Make into crumbs using my food processor and then combine 3 TBSP of Butter in.  To avoid a cracking cheesecake it has to be moist enough to prevent this in the oven. So, even with turning off the oven and letting it sit for hours mine cracked every time.  Nothing I did wrong. So if this is happening to you like it did me, countless times. Use a water bath. It works and is easier than you think. Buy wider foil to wrap pan in. Pressing the foil slightly over the edge of the pan to seal it.I do a double layer of it. Boil water on stove. Put cheesecake with foil in the pan. I use a roaster pan. Pour the boiling water around the cheesecake about and an inch or more. Bake cheesecake for an hour. Shut the oven off and leave cheesecake in for about 6 hours. Take out an put in fridge. Turns out beautiful every time.

text:
I used all the "tricks"- put my water bath in the oven while it was preheating, greased the bottom and sides of the pan, didn't over-mix the batter (I even whisked all the eggs together in a separate bowl before adding), and baked it exactly one hour, then turned off the oven and left it competely alone, no peeking, for 5 hours.  BUT, I put the bottom of my springform pan in upside down, and the waterbath leaked into my crust.  This recipe STILL turned out WONDERFUL despite user error!  It was unbelievably good- and it looked perfect.  No cracks, no pulling away at the sides, and smooth and silky all the way through.  Except for a soggy crust.  Next time, though, it will be perfect!

text:
I made this cheesecake for a birthday party today and it was a huge hit! I mixed the flour with the sour cream before adding to the cream cheese mixture and that avoided the issue with the flour that some other reviewers had. Because I was short on time I cooked the cheesecake for an hour at 350, turned the oven off and left it in the oven for an hour with the door closed, left it in the oven for 1/2 hour with the door propped slightly open, then put it in the fridge for 3 hours and it was perfect. It didn't crack and it was well set. I've never made a cheesecake before and this was so easy! This is a new family favorite. Thank you.

Ok, I am a total newb cook. This is the second time I have baked anything in my 41 years of life (besides frozen pizza) and it turned out AWESOME, (the cheesecake, not the pizza). To the one who said it did not turn out; try it out again because you screwed it up somehow.  I did the water bath thing with a pan of water on the shelf below the cheesecake and it turned out flawless. I was VERY careful not to over mix the stuff so I did all of the mixing but the milk by hand (sore forearms). If I can do this anyone can. Seriously, if it does not turn out for you, look for what you missed or messed up because all I did was carefully follow the directions. Go figure.

text:
I've never cared for cheesecake until I made this for my boyfriend's birthday.  It's delicious!  I followed other reviewer's suggestions for the crust (1 1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup sugar) and lowered the flower to 2 tbl spoons.  Also put a pan of boiling water on the bottom rack and lowered baking temp to 325.  The cake turned out beautifully, no cracks, rich smooth texture.  I made another cheesecake the next week using 1/3 less fat cream cheese and low fat sour cream (did everything else the same) and still got rave reviews.

text:
I have a small deli-style bistro, and had always bought from my suppliers their pre-made cheesecake, because I was afraid of not being able to make one as good.  I gave this one a try made it just as the recipe read, with the exception of wrapping the pan in foil and adding a small amount of water to cookie sheet, and now I can't keep enough of these made.  This is absolutely the best.  Thanks  
PS  I usually make this late in the evening, so that right before bed I turn the oven off and leave it untouched till early morning and it has never cracked.
Thanks for the recipe!

text:
OK, so I was skeptical about this recipe, but tried it anyway.  I have a degree in culinary arts and I felt the cook time didn't make sense but I thought I’d try it anyway.  Sadly I was right.  This cracked - or should I say - cratered in the middle in three directions after the first 45 minutes in the oven. I left it in with the heat off and it was done in about another 90 minutes.  If I'd left it in the entire time it would have been ruined.

Next time, I'll use the basis of the recipe, but will turn down the oven after 30 mins and bake it with the oven on and water in the oven to create moisture.  The base flavor of the recipe was good that's why I gave it 2 stars....I had to camouflage the top with strawberries to serve it though - very disappointing.

text:
WOW, this was AMAZING! I followed the recipe exactly, but I didn't have a springform pan so I used a 9-inch cake pan. There was a little extra filling so I made a mini cheesecake in a custard can. I did use a water bath and cooked for about 15 extra minutes--at one hour the center was still very jiggly. Then I broke some major rules...I didn't cool it in the oven, but ran a knife around the edge and then threw it in the fridge overnight covered in foil. There was no cracking whatsoever and it had the perfect fluffy, creamy consistency the next day. YUM!

I bake all the time, and I have lots of experience making cheesecakes.  That said, this recipe is just ok.  First of all, the crust needs a lot of work, it is bland and there is way too much of it.  Secondly, the cake itself is creamy, but the texture is a bit firm (maybe too much flour).  I still liked it, as did my boyfriend, but it is not the perfect recipe that so many other reviewers have said it is.

text:
Anyone who said they won't make this again or it didn't turn out or it was bland should probably stay out of the kitchen.  This is an amazing cheesecake.  Perfect every time, never cracks, etc.  I made this for my b/f's birthday.  I read a lot of the reviews and took a little bit off some of them.  It turned out AMAZING.  Smooth, creamy and had a wonderful flavour.  For the filling, I used 2 tbsps of flour instead of 1/4 C.  I baked it at 225 for 3 hours and 40 minutes and let it cool in the oven.  I made a sour cream topping of 1 C sour cream, 2 tbsp sugar and 1 tsp vanilla.  It was just unreal.  I was VERY pleased... as was the rest of my family.  Even a friend who hates... HATES ... cheesecake like this one.

Update to review 6-11-10
I just made this recipe again after a year of more. It is still just as good as I remembered, maybe better.  I made 2 for about 50 people and it got rave reviews for everyone.  Personally I'm not a huge cheesecake fan, too rich for me, but even I like this.  It's a perfect recipe as is or you can add variations like chocolate swirl or lemon zest.   


Excellent recipe.  I followed the crust modifications from KIMAR and added a layer of pecans to my crust. I also used a whole vanilla bean and cut the vanilla extract to 2 teaspoons.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the tastiest cheesecakes .  Creamy and perfect and I usually can't eat a whole piece of cheesecake. This one I could eat seconds.  Son-in-law said best he'd ever eaten. Will be in my collection forever.  11/09 Want to add that some reviews say not enough butter in graham cracker crumbs and they're right, but just add more. I do what other reviewer said to cook 1 hr. 325 and don't open oven and leave in all night. Cook in water bath with alum. foil doubled so water won't leak in.   I do it every time and it's perfect, no cracks.  Then put in fridge.  I add a little cinnamon to crust too.  If you don't like this recipe, you're doing something wrong because it's fool proof.  I use the heavy duty large aluminum foil doubled.  Water bath is a must.  Also, I leave it in oven after turning off overnight sometimes but definitely several hours.  Don't open it or touch it.  I just made crust with gluten free ginger snaps from Trader Joes so hope it's good.  For gluten for I add gluten free flour to mix too.  Works fine!!  I won't make any other cheesecake!!

text:
I made this for my daughter's birthday, and it was a complete sucess!  I used the waterbath for the first time - having cracked every other cheesecake I have tried - and it worked wonderfully.  I also held out 2 cups of batter and mixed in 1/4 cup baking cocoa. Then dropped the chocolated batter in spoonfulls and swirled it with a knife.  About an hour before serving I drizzled melted chocolate over the top (as well as the glass cake plate before putting the cheesecake on) then rimmed the edge with chocolate dipped strawberries. Wow it looked just like a professional one!  It is so cool when something turns out that great on the first try!

text:
I'd never made cheesecake before *IN* MY LIFE, and decided to try this for a family barbeque.  I warned everyone it was my first time making it, and told people not to expect much.  This recipe made it easy. People were AMAZED and asked that I make for all the other family get togethers!  I subsituted nufanchuel (or whatever the lower fat stuff is, next to the cream cheese), for 1/2 the creamcheese (in an effort to make it A LITTLE healthier), and I also made more ghram cracker crust (my preference), and a home-made topping of choice (peach-strawberry in sugar).  I didn't have a water-pan thing, and it DID crack, but the topping I made (peach and strawberries in sugar) covered it up.  Everyone LOVED it and couldn't believe it was my first time making it. And I didn't cook/bake much when I tried to make this...I just know what tastes good.  So the recipie is really easy AND tasty

Also, I used 'hand beating'/mixing because I didn't have a mixer.  I don't know if that makes a difference... but just thought I'd put that out there.

text:
Yummy!  Half the recipe made 48 mini cheesecakes (in mini muffin pan) and 5 regular muffin size.  I used about 4 Tbsps of butter for the crust and it seemed like it still could have used more since it was still a little dry and crumbly after baking.  I baked the minis for 30 minutes at 350 and the regular muffin size for 40 minutes.  Once chilled, we tried  them with blueberry pie filling, caramel drizzle and strawberry jam -all very disappointing.  I made them for a BBQ and thought I'd have to throw them out but the next day I tried one again, this time without any topping, and it was delicious!  I love the bite size for parties!  My only complaint is that mine must have had air bubbles in the batter because the cheesecake had holes in it instead of being thick and dense but they were still really good!  With a full size, I bake it in a water bath & let it cool in the oven like the recipe says & it's perfect -no cracks! Great recipe -thanks!

userID:
2170530
Display Name:
Marlene Wise
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great and simple recipe!!!  It is true that this is not a dense cheesecake.  It is what I would describe as light and fluffy and is easy to eat.  It is not overpoweringly rich.  I used an 8 inch springform and just scaled the recipe back to 75% of the original and it was the perfect amount.  I also used the alternative crust with the sugar and cinnamon and I HIGHLY recommend it.  It is FABULOUS!!!  Many people suggested more crust so I did not scale back the crust.  I did not use the water bath.  I baked it at 350 for an hour and then let it sit in oven until cooled (never opened the oven).  It cooked with no cracks, set up nicely and the crust was perfect; however, the top cooked with a slight rim around it that cooked a little too brown for my taste.  I simply cut it off with a sharp, serrated knife.  This did leave it looking less than perfect so I made a raspberry sauce and poured it over the top and piled some raspberries in the middle.  The sauce added a tangy taste that worked well with the cheesecake and hid the imperfection.  It is as follows:  1 cup raspberries, 1/4 cup sugar, 1/2 lemon, 1/4 cup water
Stir, let sit 30 min., process, then strain.
This is a thin sauce and makes enough for a 9 inch cheesecake with a little left over.  It works great with strawberries and frozen berries work as well as fresh.  One last suggestion:  take care when adding the flour, etc.  My batter was perfectly smooth to that point and then got lumpy.  But, don't fear the lumps

text:
Really good!
I followed the advice, room temp ingredients, water bath and leaving it in the oven till completely cooled.
I did not add the milk of the flour as some people suggested it makes it a bit too cakey and not dense enough.
I tried not to overbeat and banged it in the kitchenn surface a bit to get the air bubbles out.
I placed it in a waterbath and after an hour the top was still nice and pale but I didn't have a circle as some people said, it was a bit wobbly and reminded me of vanilla pudding but yeah, I ran a knife around the edge though I think it didn't need that as I greased the tin very well.
I left it in the oven over night as it was pretty late.
Next morning I put it in the fridge and after like 7 hours I had my first slice and it was really creamy and had a good flavour.
I do believe this is the best cheesecake one ca probably make at home.
I do prefer the really dense ones which is basically totally solid but I really enjoyed this cake.

text:
I give this 5+++ hands down, and I believe everyone I served this cheesecake to would agree with me.  I made the cheesecake for the first time, for a friend's birthday party and it was fabulous!  I've made other cheesecake recipes before that were good, but this is above and beyond good.  If I hadn't made it myself you could have served it to me and said it was from The Cheesecake Factory and I would have believed you, it was that good.  It was creamy and smooth with the right amount of sweetness and no overwhelming cream cheese flavor.  I served the cheesecake with a strawberry sauce, but it would have been great plain.  This recipe will be the based for many many cheesecake variations in the future.

My only issue was with the crust, instead of 15 graham crackers I just went ahead and used 2 packages which was 18 crackers, so I used 3 T. butter and that didn't seem like anywhere near enough, so I ended up using 5-6 T.  Even if I would have used just 15 graham crackers I don't think the 2 T. of butter would have been enough.

text:
I made this recipe twice for a party.  The first time I followed the directions perfect; it cracked and was a brown on the top and edges (not v. pretty).  The second time I made it, I read several reviews first.  I ended up following the directions exactly as I did the first time, but baked it in a water bath!!!  IT TURNED OUT PERFECT!!!!!!  I baked both the same day and the only difference was the water bath.  Chantal's Cheesecake is by FAR the BEST cheesecake I have ever had!  I can't wait to have another party so I can bake it again.  I don't usually say WOW THIS IS AWESOME about food I make when I have company over, but I couldn't help it.  It was beautiful!

text:
Wish I could give this recipe more than 5 stars...it is excellent! Not much can be said that hasn't already been said. I think that the key for this recipe are the baking instructions. I tend to overbake cheesecakes and check on them frequently while baking which leads to cracking. I followed this recipe's baking instructions exactly and even though it didn't appear to be done, the cooling time firmed everything up, leveled the top and resulted in a perfect cheesecake. Wonderful taste, wonderful texture. Don't bother with looking farther than this recipe...this one's the best! Thanks for sharing.

text:
This cheesecake came out very good.  I made it for a friends b-day at work and have gotten rave reviews so far.  I did things a bit differently.  I did use a water bath and unfortunately, although I covered the pan with foil some water seeped into the crust so it was a bit soggy.  I cooked the cheesecake for an hour and then left it in the oven for 2 hours, left it on the counter for 1 hour and then put it in the fridge.  Unfortunately there was a huge crack right down the center of my cake anyway.  I'll have to figure out how to stop that, trial and error is the only option I guess.  This was my very first cheesecake and was really a success especially with the good reviews I got from friends.  Will definitely make this again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Well I have made "Chantals New York Cheesecake" many times now and it's always hit in our house; the first time I made it I was very disappointed at the color which is why this recipe only gets 4 stars as is.  The high temp. causes it to get dark.  Many people suggest putting it in a waterbath or putting a big pan of water beneath the cheesecake while it bakes, I've tried the later and it didn't work, my cheesecake still darkened.  OK so besides the color the cheesecake is wonderful!  The flavor the density and thickness are spot on.  Going back to the waterbath; If you like a softer cheescake that is what you will get from the steam of a waterbath, to get a firm "New York" style cheesecake I wouldn't use one. So yesterday I made the "almost" perfect baked (no waterbath) cheesecake... I followed the recipe and then messed up with the temperature... That's what happens when you read too many reviews! lol... I Covered my cheesecake with aluminum foil and baked at 350 for 30 minutes then I lowered the temp to 325 taking foil off for last 30 mintues and preceeded to let cool in the oven; my cheesecake was "underdone" in the center for our Thanksgiving dinner but looked beautiful and not brown or cracked... Maybe I was the only one who noticed the slightly gooey center but I think I will do the same thing next time only not turn the oven down for the last 30 minutes... Perfect cheesecake is an effort, I know why they charge $30-$40. for them at bakery's.. :) ~ Happy Thanksgiving!

text:
I was a little nervous making this cheesecake since it was my first attempt and heard that they could be tricky to make but after seeing all the positive reviews I knew I had to try it.  I took the advice of other reviewers and baked my cheesecake in a water bath and used room temperature ingredients.  Just make sure you wrap your pan with a double layer of foil and preferbly the extra large foil as opposed to the standard size if using the water bath to prevent water from getting into the pan (I used a double layer of the reg. size and some water seeped in).  My cheesecake came out so well, very creamy and didn't crack!  I'll definitely be making this again, esp because I already have a request to make it for my sister's birthday.

Display Name:
Always Smilin'

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake really is amazing. I read several of the reviews before making it and took some of the advice - the water bath was a good idea. I decided, again because of the reviews, to make the crust using the recipe on the Philly cream cheese package (1/4 cup melted butter mixed with 1 1/4 cups of graham cracker crumbs)and the result was excellent. It did crack while sitting the two hours in the oven, but I think it was probably because we had a cold snap and the air was super dry even with the water bath. I then covered it with plastic wrap, making sure it was placed directly on the surface so that the cake would not form a dry "skin". This came off with no problems the next day. 
I took the cheese cake to my boyfriend's for Easter Dinner and it was a huge hit. (I sliced it in the kitchen and spooned cherry topping over it so no one had any idea it had cracked.) I was also pleasantly surprised at how creamy it was - and pretty proud of myself. 
I am adding this recipe to my collection as a definite keeper!

text:
This is a very good cheesecake...

The best tip I can give people is that instead of adding the vanilla, flour, and sour cream directly to the cheese mixture individually - it is better to whisk them together in a small bowl before adding. This will prevent any unseemly lumps within the batter....

text:
OMG!!  I made this as my birthday cake and it was HEAVEN.  I halved the recipe as I don't own a springform pan and only had a 9 inch pie plate and it was perfect.  I cooked it for 60 min at 325 in a water bath and did not open the door, and after 60 minutes left in the oven for 3 extra hours.  It was perfect and not a crack in sight.  It tasted amazing, although it didn't quite have the texture I prefer in a cheesecake, which is a firm texture.  It was light and creamy.  But it could have been something I did, and it is something that I can completely overlook as the taste is so amazing!  ***update***  I have made this recipe probably 10 times now and never had a problem until today!  I finally got a springfoam pan so I used it for the first time, followed the recipe as always (after the first time, I cut the flour to 2 tbsp to get the texture I like) and today I got 2 HUGE cracks!  I am so disappointed because I have come to depend on this recipe to give me a perfectly baked cheesecake every time

country:
None
text:
My very FIRST attempt at making a cheesecake, and after reading many reviews, I was so apprehensive!  Some said that a bain marie was essential - others said not to use one.  I just didn't want to waste the ingredients on a failed attempt.  I chose Chantal's recipe due to the ratings and positive reviews, and SO glad I did!  I followed ingredients as per the recipe.  Did not have a baking pan large enough to accomodate my springform pan, so followed anothers advice and placed a pan with water in the oven alongside the springform pan.  I did wrap the springform in heavy duty Reynolds wrap foil just in case of leaks.  Baked 1 hr., then turned oven off and left cake in with door closed for 4 hrs. (bedtime!).  Just 1 minor crack in the top...no big deal.  Will be serving tonite with fresh blueberry sauce for hubby & son...I am the only cheesecake "purist" who loves it just as it is.  Excellent recipe - excellent results! Many thanks, Chantal!!

I had promised my teenage son the requested New York cheesecake for his birthday and this one delivered his rave reviews. He is a choosy one about what he eats so this is significant! This is by far the BEST cheesecake recipe ever!  Bain marie (waterbath) is ESSENTIAL, as is turning the oven off and leaving the cake ALONE for 5 hours.  I've made this cake a few times and it is a huge hit with everyone.  I added two teaspoons of sugar to the graham cracker crust mix to sweeten it slightly.  I always top with a can of cherry pie filling as my husband loves cherry cheese cake.  One can makes a PERFECT topping.

text:
Delicious!!!  Used the water bath, and followed directions exactly.  Worked perfectly, no cracks.  After the hour baking time, I turned the oven off, and left the cake inside as directed.  I remember thinking this doesn't look done.  Cake was very, very wet, and had not pulled away from the sides the way others had indicated it would, so I was a little concerned.  However, I looked again 2 hours later, and the cake didn't look wet anymore.  I left in the oven overnight, by morning it had pulled away from the sides.  I let it age in the refridgerator 2 days before serving.  The flavor was awesome, perfect.  Not to sweet, a good cheesecake.  Deserves all the ratings it is receiving.  Thanks Chantal!

I made this for my husband's birthday and he loved it. I ran into a few small problems: it doesn't say how many cups the 15 graham crackers amount to which posed a small problem because I used teddy grahams instead. (all the graham crackers had ingredients that I don't use and the only natural brand at the store  I was at only came in bear shapes) I used the whole box which amounted to 2 1/2 cups. I had to use twice as much butter to bind it leading me to believe that I had too many bears. 
Next, the recipe made a TON of filling. I  have no idea why, I followed the recipe exactly. I don't have a springform pan so I used a Pyrex pie dish and filled it to the top and still had enough for one more, which was fine but confusing. 
I was baking other things so I took it out of the oven immediately, after one hour. It was baked perfectly, golden around the edges and creamy in the center. It looked soft and perfect except for two small-ish cracks that wasn't a big deal for me. 
I know a lot of folks take cheesecake baking very seriously but mine was perfect enough for us, tasted great and had just the right amount of crust-to-filling ratio, despite my minor deviations from the recipe. I spelled out "35" in raspberries and you couldn't even see my small cracks. 
Next time I would add a tiny bit of lemon extract, juice or rind but as is was great too.

This was the most delicious basic cheesecake I have ever tasted in my life. It was gone within minutes for my family. I highly recommend this recipe.

I followed these tips from other viewers and get perfect results every time:

1) Use a waterbath.
2) Don't overbeat the ingredients.
3) You only need to leave it in for 2 hours, not 6. It won't crack.

I followed the recipe closely and it turned out beautifully. No cracks, no sinkholes. The only change I made was baking the cake in a water bath as suggested by other reviewers. The cake pulled away from the sides of the pan (which were NOT greased) and I didn't need to cut around the edges. I used a heavy non-stick springform pan. I doubled the butter to make the crust because I knew from the look of the graham cracker and butter mixture that it would not hold. I give it 4 stars because the texture is not the kind I like for cheesecake. Otherwise, great recipe!

text:
Wonderful! I'm not much of baker and I've never made cheesecake before, so I'm amazed this came out so perfect! I used the water bath and left it to cool in the oven for 5.5 hours and got no cracks (see my photo). :)

A word of advice to anyone using the water bath -make sure you DOUBLE wrap it with tin-foil!! I only used one layer and somehow it got a little hole in it (even though I thought I'd been really careful!). Thankfully it didn't get into the cake, but it would have been a disaster if I'd been using a crappier cake-tin. 

Thank you for a wonderful recipe -I'll definitely make this again!!
