text:
The texture and taste of this cheesecake was perfectly how I like it. I dont like creamy cheesecake, i like it a little more solid. My pan was larger than the recipe called for, its 10.5" so it wouldnt fit in the water bath as reviewers had mentioned. So I just filled a cake pan with hot water and put it on the shelf below it. I put it in the oven for 60 minutes on the dot, and then turned it off and let it cool for five hours WITHOUT OPENING THE DOOR. This is very important so you don't let out the steam and heat! Mine did not crack! Turned out beautifully. Only thing I didn't like was the crust, but that's probably because I bought the graham crackers with added fiber instead of the regular kind. Oops!

I just made this for Thanksgiving, and it turned out perfect! No cracks and very dense. Everyone loved it so much they finished it off even though there were 4 other desserts. In fact, my 16 yr. old son asked me to make it again today! city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 2 of these. One in my pressure cooker and one in the oven.  They both came out perfect.  The only advice I would give is if you are cooking it in a pressure cooker is cook it for 35 minutes, take it off the burner and let the pressure cool down naturally.  I would say about 30 min. It will look a bit pale on top.  Put it in the fridge for 3-4 hours to firm up.  I made the mistake of cooling it on the counter for an hour and then digging in.  It was very loose in the middle and oozed out.  It is very important to refrigerate it first.

text:
I am a beginner baker and I wanted to try this recipe. It was easy to put together. I read most of the reviews on tips. I did the 2 in. of water on the shelf below the pan. No changes to the recipe except for some cinnoman on the crust. Baked 1 hr @ 350 then turned off. Of course I peaked 2 hours later and several times after that. Finally a long 5 hours I took it out to put in the fridge over night and not a single crack. I took it to the In-laws Thanksgiving dinner with Strawberry topping and it was a hit. No peices left over. I will defintately bake again.

userID:
1303293
Display Name:
Meaty0
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3977685.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've cooked this cheesecake more than 20 times now.  First 5 times, it cracked every time.  Then I found the secret!  

DON'T BOTHER WITH ALL THAT WATER BATH NONSENSE!  You don't need to.  Just FOLLOW THE RECIPE.

Here's the secret.  Grease the springform pan - bottom and sides.  Then line the springform pan with baking paper.  It won't stick to the sides and won't crack.  I bake it for about an hour at 150 deg C (fan forced) in my oven.  I turn the oven off and let it cool with the door open a little for about 4 hours.   I know that's not what Chantal says - but it still doesn't crack!

I use two tablespoons of self-raising flour.  If you want a less cakey taste and a lighter creamier texture - use less flour.

The other "secret" is - the cream cheese MUST be at room temperature when you beat it.  And you must beat the hell out of the cream cheese and sugar to get rid of all the lumps!

DON'T beat the eggs any more than you have to.  Add them one at a time and mix slowly until they are just barely combined.  Same for the other ingredients.  Don't over mix them.  

I love this cheesecake and I wouldn't bother cooking it if I had to do that silly waterbath business.  You don't need to bother with it either.

userID:
2266039
Display Name:
Smokering
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Luscious!  I've made this three times now; twice with a splash of lemon juice in the mixture, and served with a raspberry and orange coulis.  The third time I added a block of dark chocolate to half the batter and made a marbled cheesecake--yummy!  I use gingernuts for the base, too, and vanilla paste as well as essence.

Don't bother with foil-wrapped springform tins!  I make mine in a regular piedish and it works beautifully (with a water bath).  There's always enough mix left over to make a cheesecake 'loaf' in a loaf tin as well.  That one sits at the bottom of the oven, without a water bath, and never cracks either!  Seriously, this is a surprisingly forgiving recipe, and definitely delish.  Make the day before; I've found if I taste it while still warm (even barely) it tastes rather bland and boring.  But 24 hours later... mmmm.

5

text:
I have made many "fancy" cheesecakes and was looking for something more basic- just to really enjoy and not mix with snickers or nuts, etc..I followed the recipe but just added some extra sugar to the crust-(few tbls)  I only left it in the oven an hour after and about half hour on the counter and then refrigerated it and ate it about 5 hours later.  It was perfect.  Great texture and flavor- not too fluffy, not too dense- not overly sweet.  I served it in strawberries that had been soaking all day in some sugar.  A huge it.  Will make many times.  Had to give away most of the leftover so I wouldnt attack it all the next day!!

I made this cheesecake for Christmas and it was perfect!  It neither cracked nor sagged and was beautiful and absolutely yummy in texture and flavor.  My cream cheese was out of the frig for hours to ensure room temperature.  Also I baked it in the evening, turned the oven off and went to bed so it cooled in the oven overnight.  I left it in the spring form pan until a few hours before serving.  My family is already wanting me to bake another one...and I definitely will!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2006-12-20T08:49:00.057
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1376819
Display Name:
Maria
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
69
favoritesCount:
227
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4733825.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off, let me just say that I'm a firm believer in the Cheesecake-By-Water-Bath method.  I have switched from recipe to recipe for my cheesecakes, but I have *always* tried the water bath.  However, since my apartment has the teeniest, tiniest oven, and I'm unable to fit a roasting pan big enough to fit my springform pan into it, the waterbath is right out.  So, desperate, I tried this recipe.  The method itself is odd, and I did have to rotate the pan because it was browning unevenly.  Two hours into its cooling down inside the oven, however, I noticed a small crack.  I thought, okay, whatever.  Half an hour later, the crack was much larger, so I pulled it out and let it cool the rest of the way on the stove.  So, one star taken away for my not-so-aesthetically-pleasing cheesecake.  HOWEVER.  Oh, wow, was the recipe itself good.  The cheesecake was moist, deliciously rich, crumbly and not soft (how a good, deli cheesecake should be!) and everyone at the annual holiday party raved about it.  I could barely get a slice for myself!  In conclusion, I could leave the cooling process behind, but I think this will be my cheesecake recipe for many cheesecakes to come.  Yum!

I made this cheesecake for the holidays, followed the recipe exactly as it said and also heeded the advice of many reviewers. I used the water bath on the rack below and let it cool in the oven. Not a single crack, the edges were smooth and it was the most delicious cheesecake I've ever tasted! It was my first attempt at cheesecake and I'll never use another recipe. Kudos to Chantal!!

text:
I make a dessert every Sunday night for my husband to take to a pot-luck barbeque at work.  Yesterday I decided to make this cheesecake.  Usually my husband will leave any leftover dessert at work for the next shift to enjoy, but this morning I found half of the cheesecake in the fridge.  I was concerned that maybe everyone didn't like it and that's why he brought it home, but when I asked him about it, he said that it was the best dessert I had made so far.  One of the people he works with is a lover of cheesecake and she said it was the best cheesecake she has ever had.  He brought it home so our family can enjoy it too!  I made a strawberry topping to go with it and it all worked out deliciously.  I was so happy that they had all liked it that I had to try it for myself and ended up having a piece for breakfast! LOL.  Absolutely delicious!  I didn't have whole graham crackers, so I used the recipe of the graham cracker crumb box to make the crust.  It all worked out perfectly.  I am very pleased with how well it turned out.  I can't wait til I have a reason to make it again!

Nicole

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was divine. My whole family loved it and could not get enough!!

I baked it at 335 degrees with a cake pan of boiling water under it. I used a 10" springform. I tuned the oven off after 70 minutes and left it in a closed oven for over 8 hours. There wasn't one crack.

 The recipe says 15 grahms, and I wasn't sure whether 1 grahm cracker means 4 rectangles or all 8. I used all 8 and it seemed like too much. I had to double the butter in the crust. It still turned out fine.

I also didn't put in the full 1/4 cup flour, but close to it.

I used milk to 1/3 cup and the rest w/ heavy cream.

I topped it with a raspberry sauce that was excellant!!!

Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
The BEST! This was my first cheesecake and it not only turned out perfect (No Cracks), it saved my Christmas dinner. My wifes grandmother, who was a cook her entire life said it was the best cheesecake she ever had! I followed the recipie exactly. The only thing I did different was to put an additional pan in the oven under the cheesecake with approx 1" of water in it. after the cheesecake was done baking I left it in the oven an additional 5 hours before removing it. Thanks for this wonderful recipie.

text:
Wonderful cheesecake!  I followed the suggestions of others and reduced the flour to 2 tablespoons.  I used a water bath and left the cheesecake in the oven for a full 6 hours after baking and it was perfect--no cracks, with a smooth and creamy texture.  I now know why it has received so many 5 star ratings -- this one is a keeper!

text:
The recipe was solid, but it turned out too cakey for my tastes.  Also, to prevent splitting, I greased the sides of the pan and stuck strips of parchment paper along the sides.  They were wrinkled by the time the cake was all done, but they didn't take away from the appearance at all, and they peeled right off -- no splits!

I always use the waterbath, and it turns out just right. After my first time making this cheesecake, I was forced to be the dessert supplier on special occasions. Only, they want this cheesecake! I am now obligated to make it for all family holidays. This is the most delicious, perfect cheesecake that I have ever had. Thanks for such a wonderful recipe!

text:
Delicious!  This was my first cheesecake and I was a little initimidated after reading some of the prior reviews.  I had all ingredienta at room temp, and didn't use a water bath (just a pan of hot water on bottom oven rack) but the cake cracked anyway.  I planned on covering with cherries so it wasnt a big deal.  I used the graham crackers/cinnamon/sugar/nutmeg recipe that I saw posted earlier and will definitely be making again!  The crust was perfect...I did bake it 1st for 15 minutes/350 degrees before I put in the filling.  Great recipe!! Thanks!

text:
Absolutely fabulous!  I am a displaced New Yorker now in North Carolina.  Deli's are non-existent along with any type of good northern cuisine.  Made this recipe and it was a winner.  I did wrap the bottom of the pan in tin foil and use a water bath, however, the water leaked into the pan.  The cake was a little soft on the bottom, but nonetheless was loved by all!  Next time I will omit the water bath since the top cracked anyway.  Thank you for a winner!

I agree with several other reviewers that if your cheesecake does not taste like the best deli cheesecake you've had then you did not make it right. I've made this recipe for the last 8 years and everyone loves it. It is "My" dish to bring to all the holiday dinners every year! I've used it to make my own modified "flavored" versions as well such as with rasberry swirl, chocolate, and fudge pieces - And it comes out perfect and works with everything. I even made it into pumpkin pie by pretty much mixing a batch of homemade pumpkin pie mixed up just before you'd normally bake it and mixed it into the batch of cheesecake then baked it and voila! Had pumpkin cheesecake. It actually came out much better than any actual "pumpkin pie cheesecake" recipe i've found so far! Thanks Chantal!

Great flavor, very rich, and not too horribly sweet. I add cinnamon and chopped walnuts to the crust for a little extra kick. I imagine it would be completely perfect in the proper size pan, if you can perfect the baking times for your own pan and own oven.

text:
Absolutely perfect.  I substituted chopped pecans for about 1/3 of the graham crackers in the crust, and pre-baked the crust for about 10 minutes to ensure a toasted nutty flavor and crispy crust.  I baked the cheesecake with a broiler pan full of hot water on the rack underneath.  Also shortened the baking time.  The center was jiggly after 50 minutes, so I turned off the oven and cracked the door at that point.  The cheesecake cooled in the oven for a couple of hours, and came out perfect:  no cracks, and a delicious creamy texture.

I tried this cheesecake for a Christmas party and everyone said it was the best cheesecake they had ever eaten.  It is very delicious and had a great texture.  I baked two at the same time--one in a regular springform pan and the other in a black coated springform pan. Thanks for a great recipe.  I will use this recipe all the time for making cheesecake.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is the one recipe I come back to this site for, again and again!  I've come back at least 5 times for this recipe, and it has never disappointed me.  Every time I serve this, everyone at the party fights for who gets to take the last couple of slices home!  Chantal, you discovered the secrets of the cheesecake served in all of the best restaurants, bravo!

I must add, that because of a friend of mine that is allergic to gluten, I was able to make changes to this recipe and have it still come out perfect.  I substituted a small pack (about 6oz) of gluten free chocolate chip cookies, crushed in the bag, for the crust, and about 2 and 1/2 tablespoons of rice flour for the all purpose flour.  I couldn't taste a difference in the cheesecake when I made it.

(Added Aug 28, 2008):  Let me give you a hint if the cheesecake cracks: chocolate ganache.  There are recipes on this site, but you can also make a simple one with 8 oz of whipping cream and 8 oz of semi-sweet or dark chocolate chips.  Pour the chips into a good-sized mixing bowl, set aside.  Heat the cream to just boiling and then pour into the chocolate chips.  Stir until the chips are melted and consistency is uniform.  Immediately pour onto the cheesecake, making sure to not spill any over the sides.  Let it cool in the fridge for at least 8 hours.  Et Voila, no one knows it cracked.

Display Name:
SHINYAM

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake was very delicous, and deserves more than 5 stars.  It should at least be in the Hall of Fame.  The texture was perfect: creamy yet firm.  The sweetness was perfect too.  I used digestive biscuits for the crust.

I didn't have a springform pan, so I used a regular rectangular baking pan, and placed it inside a bigger pan filled with water.  The steam produced is supposed to prevent cracking.  Also, right after baking, I took a knife and cut around the edges of cake so that the cake would not stick to the edge of the pan while contracting, prevening cracks.  Finally, I left the cake in for one hour with the oven door closed, then left it in the oven with the door open for one hour, and let it cool until it was room temp., and then put it in the fridge overnight.  All that work paid off, the cake had no cracks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughter asked for Blueberry cheesecake for her birthday so I picked this recipe out for the base filling. I'm glad I did! It was so delicious! Creamy and smooth but it cracked awfully even though I followed the base recipe and left it in the oven nearly all day. It did not hurt the taste and nobody really cared. I used frozen, defrosted, drained berries dusted with flour. The flour keeps the berries from bleeding and turning a beautiful cheesecake into a brown ugly mess. I sprinkled the berries over 1/2 the filling then poured the rest over. I added a T. of fresh lemon juice to the filling because we enjoy a tart cheesecake and it complimented the berries very well. Several people said it was the best cheesecake they had eaten in years! Oh, I used a 10 inch springform pan and it filled it up! Thank you! I will make this again for sure!!

text:
Delicious cheesecake.  The first time I made it without reading reviews -- it was delicious, but it cracked, and the texture wasn't quite right.  The second time, I followed the AllRecipes suggestions and the cake did not crack and has a nice, smooth texture.  I baked for 325 for about 80 minutes, then left for 2 hours in the oven and it is still just a bit soft in the middle (but awesome).  HOWEVER, I will never try the water bath again with a spring form pan.  I wrapped very carefully and the water still got in around the edges.  It doesn't seem to have badly affected the cheesecake, though.  I will try using the pan of water on the rack underneath next time.  Thanks for "my" new recipe!!

One of the best cheesecakes I've ever tasted much less made!!  I followed some of the other reveiwers' advice and cooked it at 325 for one hour.  I also made sure everything was at room temperature before starting and used a water bath.  To top the cake, I bought strawberry pie filling at the supermarket, put it in the blender and pureed it to make a glaze for some color.  I put it over the cake after it had cooled for about an hour (still in the warm oven).  Afterward, I melted some dark chocolate morsels and drizzled chocolate over the top... SUPERB!  I'm making this one again tonight :)

text:
I was very nervous making this cheesecake for the first time for a large family gathering.  It was the easiest recipe to follow and the most delicious cheesecake that I have ever made by far.  I got so many compliments that I am making another one this weekend. I have tried so many recipes over the years...they don't beat this recipe.  The key is to turn the oven off on time.  The cheesecake doesn't look done but it will finish setting up in the oven.  Doing that creates a super creamy cheesecake. Otherwise it overbakes and gets dry and crumbly.

text:
While the flavor was very good, I only rated it three stars because of the huge cracks that developed.  I made this for my husband to take to a potluck at work and I almost didn't send it because it looked so terrible.

I've made hundreds of cheesecakes and had small cracks show up now and then, but NOTHING like the crater in the middle of this cake.  It opened up like the San Andreas fault.

Seeing as how my chocolate chip cookie dough cheesecake and my snickers cheesecake always come out without cracks, I have to think that some adjustment could be made to this recipe to prevent such ugly cracks from forming.

I doubt I'll take the chance of making this one again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake is the best I've ever made! My husband used to visit the Bronx in New York City and buy cheesecake from a bakery there, and he has been raving about that darn cheesecake ever since. I have baked many cheesecakes trying to duplicate the one he had many years ago in N.Y. City. Thank you Chantal, I've finally done just that with your recipe. The only things I changed is the crust. I used the recipe on the box of Honey Maid graham cracker crumbs. I also baked it 30 minutes longer than the recipe called for. I cooled it in the oven for only 3 hours, and on a rack outside the oven for a few more hours. This is the first cheesecake I've baked that didn't crack. I am throwing all my other cheesecake recipes away and making only this one in the future. Thank you so much Chantal!
                           awesomeaura

This recipe was easy to make, and although there was a slight crack on top it didn't detract from the look of the cheesecake.

Everyone seemed to enjoy this cheesecake, but the fact that there is still half of it left after it has been sitting in the fridge all day tells it's own story.

I'm a bit of a cheesecakeaholic and usually people have to keep their extremities well away from my mouth if I'm eating cheesecake. Not so with this offering. 

All in all this cheesecake seems to be rather bland.

I think I will make it again sometime, but next time I will serve it with a chocolate or fruit topping.

text:
I made this for my mom's birthday, and everyone loved it!  I used a different crust though, and since my grandma doesn't eat eggs, i substituted 1 Tbs custard powder for each egg, and it held together well.  Although it had a crack at the top, I topped it off with strawberries and whipped cream and it looked and tasted fabulous!  For those who do not have a springform pan, I don't think it's a problem, because the filling was too much to fit in my springform pan, so i just made some extra crust and used a regular nonstick pan for the excess, and it wasn't a problem to remove the cake from the pan.  Excellent recipe Chantal!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent cheesecake!  I took it to a luncheon and people were assuming it was store-bought!  One lady said she was a cheesecake expert and said it was the best she'd ever had!  I did the water bath and baked at 350 degrees for 40 minutes, then lowered the temp to 300 for 50 minutes, cooling in the oven for 5 hours.  No cracks, no browning at all!  The only flaw I had was that I poured my vanilla on top of the unmixed flour, resulting in brown clumps that wouldn't blend in.  Otherwise it was perfect. I used a different crust:  1 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/3 cup melted marg, 1/4 cup sugar. Thanks Chantal!

userID:
2701038
Display Name:
deb
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
175
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first time making a NY style cheesecake.  I read a number of the reviews and followed most of the recommendations and it came out beautifully.  The only thing I had an issue with was getting all of the cream cheese to incorporate smoothly. It remained a bit lumpy.  I greased the pan well, put a pan of water on the oven rack about an inch below the rack that held the cake pan, baked it for 1 hr at 350 degrees and after the hour I took a plastic knife and separated the cake from the cake pan. I then left it in the oven to cool for about 2 hours. The cake was very loose in the middle after the hour of baking and solidified after the 2 hrs cooling in the oven.  It seems like using the knife to cut around the edge worked because when I took it out of the oven the cake had pulled away from the pan by about 1/2 inch and the cake did not crack at all. I  removed the pan sides and then put in the fridge overnight. In the morning I used a piece of dental floss to remove it from the bottom of the pan.  I added a few tsp of sugar, 1 tsp of cinnamon and 2 tablespoons of cocoa powder to the graham crackers for flavor as suggested by some.
I didn't use the flour and replaced some of the milk with about 1/4 c of Kahlua.  I really appreciate all the suggestions that people make to adjust a recipe or to help with technique, without completely changing it.  All recipes can be a good base and this one came out beautifully. I haven't eaten this yet because it's a gift but I'll update w

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is very good. The people I've had taste test it loved it. There are only a few things I would like to point out during my experience make it. 
Last weekend was my first attempt at ever making cheese cake. I followed this very easy recipe double and triple checking I was following every step. It came out terrible. The edges were burnt, cracked and it was so sunken in. I let it cool of and it when right into the trash. 
I decided to make some adjustments. I had been worried that the instruction say to keep the cake in the oven while it cools for 5-6 hours because I though this would over bake the cake. And in my case I think that's what happened. My oven took long to cool down and it ended up cooking it even further to the point of drying out cause it to pull so much from the sides and crack. 
My second attempt at the cake was much better. I followed the same recipe, cooked for the same amount of time but after the hour cook time I moved the cake from my top oven to my bottom oven. I think this helped drastically over all. My cake still cracked. but on a tiny bit in the middle. And the edged where a little more browned then I wanted but that's just cosmetic. I shared the cake with some friends and they all loved it. 
I'll be making this cake again with a few more changes to the cooking and cooling process.
*This is no way an attack on this recipe. If it worked for others then obviously it works and its good. I wanted to share my experience with this recipe and I just

Excellent results! I’m a total nube at baking. I read probably 25 reviews with tips and variations. I followed the recipe for the cheesecake exactly, including using a mixer for the entire mix as the video shows. (I did use a different recipe for the graham cracker crust with sugar and more butter.) I used the water bath and left the cake in the oven for 5 hours (impatient) and left in the refrigerator for 24 hours before taking out of the pan. No cracks, and excellent texture. I may not have a refined cheesecake palate, but my family and I thought it was fantastic!

text:
Fantastic recipe! I’ve made it as is, or with 50/50 graham cracker and ginger snap cookie crust for a little extra zing. My whole family loves this cheesecake and begs me to make it for special occasions or just because. I always do mine the evening before we want to eat it. I am sure to put a pan of water in the oven with the cheesecake to keep it moist and help prevent cracking on the top. Don’t over mix the batter. As others have suggested, I bake mine for 60 minutes and then just turn the oven off and leave it overnight. Don’t crack the door. Don’t check to see if it’s set! Just leave it alone. I get up in the morning and put it in the fridge to chill.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you want to know how to fix a cracked top and brown top edges then read on! 

This was my first time making a cheesecake and it was a success! However, I did run into some problems making this cheesecake so I thought I would share how I fixed them.  I did not let my cream cheese come to room temperature so the batter didn’t look really smooth, which then led me to over mixing the batter to compensate.  This led to a cracked top in the middle in the end (will share how I fixed it).  The other issue was my oven at 350 was too hot (going to do it at 300-325 next time) so the cheesecake was dark brown on the sides and around the edges on top.  It didn’t look that great.  What to do you asked? Well after I let it rest in the refrigerator for 6 hours I took it out and first carved out the brown edges on top.  This worked for me since the edges of my cheesecake was higher then the middle. I just made it all even. Then I got a metal cake spatula and a cup of hot water the one you use to put icing on a cake.  It has to be metal. Then you dip the spatula in the hot water to warm it up and then you wipe the spatula with a towel to dry and press gently on the cracked area and watch it disappear.  My crack was pretty big so that took sometime. Then I just did the same with the cut edges and the cheesecake looked much better at the end.  I covered with fresh fruit and powder sugar and it looked great! (see picture)  You can search on youtube repairing cracks in cheesecake and the first

I have made this recipe for cheesecake many times over the past few years. It is always a hit. The first time, and only the first time, I made this it cracked. My wife suggested a water bath and haven’t had a crack since. Simply wrap springform with foil and place in a larger cake pan with about an inch of water in it. userID:
26720633
Display Name:
Melanie G
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my incredible goodness!  I bought a spring-form pan 10 years ago with the intention of learning to make cheesecake and never did.  I took a chance on making it for my family's Christmas and really hoped it turned out good since it was the only dessert.  IT.  WAS.  AMAZING!!  Incredibly creamy all the way through.  Never stuck to the sides or cracked.  Cut in nice neat wedges for serving.  I read several of the reviews to make sure I followed all the tips and incorporated what I thought were the best ideas.  1) reduced flour to 2T instead of 1/4 c.  2)  Made sure cream cheese was to room temperature.  3) Made sure I didn't over-beat -- in fact I hand stirred it all and only until the point of ingredients being blended.  4)  I liberally sprayed the sides and bottom of the pan with cooking spray.  5) I wrapped the bottom of the pan in two layers of foil as instructed and set it in a pan with water in the oven.  This was the most challenging as I didn't have a "pan" big enough.  I used the bottom of my broiler pan and it worked great.  6)  Baked on 225 degrees for 3 hours and 40 minutes.  Then turned off the oven and left it in for another 6 hours with the door cracked.  Then refrigerated for 6+ hours.  Result was a cheesecake of perfection that got rave reviews from all that tried it.  I will be making this again very soon!!

text:
We now call this "the legendary cheesecake" in my family. I have been making it for years and I made it this year for Thanksgiving and my aunt, who is a huge health nut and does not like sweets tried very hard to resist but she caved in and had, not only one slice, but two. 

I am an experienced baker and I will say just follow this recipe and it will be perfect. do not change a thing and do NOT overmix this batter no matter what because that's how cheesecakes get cracked or cave in the middle etc etc. Also just leave it in that oven and no opening just leave it in there. This cheesecake is PERFECT.

This is a wonderful recipe ! I’ve made it a few times and I think I finally got it just right. Do not open the oven lol! You’ll want to but don’t do it. text:
Awesome recipe! I am in my 60's and I think I've only made one other cheesecake in my life. Decided to make one for Thanksgiving. My husband is a "cheesecake snob" and said it was truly the best he had ever had! I watched the video and used the baking sheet under the springform pan as shown. I also added a little insurance by placing a 9x13 pan of water under the rack as was suggested in another review. After cooling in the oven and completely cooling in the refrigerator, I had seen a suggestion to dip a butter knife in hot water and go around the inside edge of the springform pan, dipping the knife in water every few inches. It came out perfectly! Very happy to say I would not hesitate to make this again!

text:
This recipe is a now holiday tradition in our family. I have made it numerous times and it comes out great every time. This year, I poured chocolate over the top for a change and it was beautiful.  My family LOVES this cheesecake and I get all the credit, but it's really this recipe. 
A long while back I read somewhere about wrapping the cheesecake pan in tinfoil and placing in a pan of water about 1 inch deep while baking and it will not crack. I began following that information  whenever baking cheesecake and NEVER  have any problems with cracking whatsoever. 
Other than that, I follow the recipe EXACTLY and every time it comes out beautiful and delicious. 
AMAZING RECIPE!!!!

userID:
12605666
Display Name:
missy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing cheesecake. Works out perfectly every time. Very creamy and smooth. Everyone loves it, and I get requests for it. I don't vary from the recipe at all. I do not stick it in a "bath" of water though. I actually just put a large pan on the rack below it and add water to that. It creates the steam you need. I let it cook in the oven for an hour, and then I just leave it in there (without opening the door) for the next 5-6 hours. I immediately place it in the fridge from there. I have gotten away with just 3 hours in the oven and it worked out fine, but I prefer the 5-6 hours. My cheesecake has never cracked, and, honestly, I mix the heck out of it with my mixer. I do butter the bottom and the sides of my spring form pan, and I do press the graham cracker crust 1/2 way up the sides of the pan. Sometimes I make my own graham cracker crust, and other times I use the boxed kind.  Honestly, best cheesecake ever!

text:
I’ve made this recipes several times and it comes out great every time! Just follow the directions. Don’t over analyze the recipe. Do not over beat. Turn your mixer on low speed and only blend enough to incorporate the ingredients. This not only makes for a dense cheesecake, but it prevents cracks and over-rising. You can also make this lower carb by using truvia sweetener in place of the sugar. It still tastes great!

text:
I have been making this recipe (with minor tweaking to the crust and technique) for a LONG time and it ALWAYS gets rave reviews. I personally find the crust is a bit bland as is so I add 1/4 cup melted butter, 1/2 tsp. ground cinnamon, and 1/4 cup sugar to the crushed graham crackers. I leave the filling as is, it's perfect. I don't usually get cracks but I utilize a few tips not mentioned in the recipe (using a water bath, using room temp ingredients) so I'm not sure I can give the recipe all the credit there. Overall this is an excellent cheesecake recipe. I prefer to top mine with fresh strawberries but even plain, it is scrumptious.

text:
I made a few modifications:

For the crust, I used two sleeves of cinnamon graham crackers, added an additional 1/2 t of cinnamon, 2 T sugar and a 1/4 c butter. 

For the cheesecake batter, I followed the recommendations of another review I read on here and decreased flour to 2 T then baked at 225 for 3 hrs 40 min.  Once it finished baking, I turned off the oven and let it sit in there for 6 hours before putting it in the refrigerator to chill.

I also lined the sides of my springform pan with parchment to prevent it from sticking and baked it in a water bath.

I made this recipe exactly as written and it was marvelous. This was my first cheesecake ever! I did lots of research and watched many other how-to videos as I had heard that it could be tricky to get the cheesecake to not crack.  Mine came out perfect! I put in a 9x13 glass pan filled halfway up with hot water on the rack directly underneath my cheesecake. I think that did the trick.

userID:
9693855
Display Name:
olga32
isPro:

12

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing recipe, HOWEVER, if you have a decent oven, DO NOT LEAVE INSIDE FOR 5 HOURS! Not even 2. Experiment first.

The first time I made the recipe I didn't have enough time so I didn't leave the cheesecake in the oven (like the recipe suggests) after it was cooked. It turned out fantastic, no cracks.

The second time I made it I thought I'd leave it in, just to follow the recipe exactly as it is. I looked through the glass 2 hrs later and it had darkened AND had developed a crack down the middle! 
The crack certainly wasn't there when the baking finished and I turned off the oven. So leaving it in caused the crack and created somewhat of a dark, slightly crispy crust around my cheesecake surface which is not good.

Also the crust crumbles way too much. You're left with half the crust of your slice all powdered up on your plate.

From now on I will be
- taking it out immediately after the baking is complete and letting it cool down on the counter before refrigerating
- baking the crust for 5 minutes before I put the mix in

Ingredients are great though. Everybody loved it.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-08-06T17:17:28.133
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
23901144
Display Name:
Joanne St Andre
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5525144.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
KETO COMMENT BELOW.  I have made this multiple times, as is and with modifications (this weekend is lemon cheesecake).  Some recommendations:

1. Beat cheese and sugar (I use fake sugar) on high until well combined - watch not to overmix.

2. Pre beat eggs, slowly beat into batter on LOW. DO NOT OVERMIX!  I actually gently stir in the remaining ingredients with a spatula, not the mixer. Overmixing causes cracks and a different texture.

3. Once you pour the batter into the pan, drop it from about 2" height onto the counter several times.  This removes bubbles.

4. Bake at night, turn off the oven and LET IT SIT IN THE OVEN OVERNIGHT.  Do not open the oven door!  In the morning refrigerate it (no cracks, ever, bain marie or not).

To make this KETO friendly, obviously, replace sugar with Swerve or your fav sugar replacement. I use Swerve confectioner sugar replacement but granular would work.

CRUST: Use toasted coconut mixed with golden flaxseed meal, butter and some Swerve (a couple of TBL).  Toast the coconut to deep brown but not burned!  Crunch it up (I do it with my hands) so it is the same consistency as graham cracker crumbs.  Then follow recipe.

BATTER: Use 5 bricks of cheese, 4 eggs, 1 c sour cream, sugar replacement and desired extract (I use vanilla or almond or coconut or whatever.  I also use more than recommended in this recipe - like 2 TBL.)  Bake roughly 60 minutes (based on your oven) and leave it overnight in the oven to cool S L O W L Y.

I will often top
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2019-08-03T16:43:03.26

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the recipe you want to use every time. I’ve made this cheesecake a handful of times and it never fails. I make it exactly how it is written. Sometimes I make it into a sweet potato cheesecake and it comes out perfect. It has never cracked thankfully. I combine all ingredients before adding the eggs just to make sure it passes the taste test. I add eggs last. I cook in a water bath. Someone here had a tip. Instead of wrapping the bottom in foil just place the cheesecake pan in a larger pie pan and then place both pans in a water bath. This will eliminate water seeping into the bottom of the cheesecake pan. I also bake my graham cracker crust for about 10-15 mins before adding the mixture. Turn oven off at exactly 1hr and let it sit in oven for about 5 hours. Perfection. Everyone loves this cheesecake. Add some homemade whipped cream and strawberries to the top and it’s even better.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
So this was my first cheesecake with a springform pan, I was so nervous but This cake was ssooooo easy and after reading the reviews which I recommend doing, I used some tips and made some adjustments. I made it the day before I served it....its best to make it the day before, because it helps with the process and flavor! I loved the way it sank just enough to make a perfect pocket to hold my topping.  Next time I will double the graham crust bc I would like to have a thicker crust and have it creep up the sides of the cake... I feel like the more I make this the better it will become! I would say don't even bother with the water bath, save your foil bc all u need to do is put a small baking bowl or pan (what ever u have that can be used in oven) of water under the cake, this will be perfectly fine and ur cake should not crack. I read a lot about why the cake cracks and there seems to be several reasons, but a Fact is if the air is dry the cake will crack ..just like dry skin ..u must keep it moist or it will crack, and if it does throw a topping on it, no one will know but u! The family loved it, I will make it again for sure! Thanx to everyone for all the reviews they really help!

text:
My first attempt making a cheesecake, it turned out nearly perfect! I followed this receipt for the most part, I left out the milk and flour. I also put my spring form pan in a water bath while baking the cheesecake, this helps keep the cheesecake moist while baking. As soon as the time went off, 1 hour of baking, I turned the oven off but cracked the oven door to allow my oven to cool off quicker. After an hour cooling in the oven I put it right in the refrigerator, waited approximately an hour before releasing the spring form pan. My cheesecake turned out perfect, the texture was amazing and no cracks. This recipe is dummy proof as long as you follow the directions. One important thing to remember is DO NOT OVER MIX YOUR INGREDIENTS, mix just long enough to incorporate. I will hands down make this cheesecake again and couldn’t recommend it enough! My husband rated the cheesecake as a 9/10, I was impressed myself! (I swirled raspberry filling throughout the cheesecake)

text:
I've used this basic recipe countless times over the years. My main change is to use Animal Crackers for the crust. 
To do a great chocolate variety, add 3 heaping teaspoons of cocoa powder to the sugar and a half tsp of both cocoa and confectioner's sugar to the crust with a dash of vanilla(fake is ok for chocolate chzck)
Pumpkin is a challenge, decreasing the milk is a good way to keep it from being too loose.
Mocha - Mix instant coffee with the milk (don't be shy) and make the base chocolate batter.
Let me know your successes with these slight modifications.

text:
Very good! Instead of using 2 tablespoons of butter and 15 graham cracker pieces, use 3 tablespoons butter and 24 graham cracker pieces (not whole bars). Also, I request cooking cheesecake for an hour and then letting the oven cool with the door open while the cheesecake is sitting after cooking for one hour. We left it in for 5-6 hours and it over cooked but if you let the oven cool and leave the cheesecake in for one hour with the door open, it should taste great!

text:
Excellent recipe.  I did however make a few changes based solely on personal preference.  I changed out the graham cracker crust to a ground almond crust as my son prefers it.  I used heavy whipping cream instead of milk because I happened to have some that needed to be used up, and cut the sugar by 1/4 cup.  Also, after reading about some people having problems with cracking I wrapped the pan with heavy foil and placed in a baking pan half filled with hot water, then checked the cheesecake at 50 minutes bake time.  I ended up having to bake 1 hour 5 minutes.  It just depends on the accuracy of the oven and I would rather check beforehand than have an overcooked anything.  This recipe is very forgiving, letting you change things up depending on preference.  Great recipe.  Family all loved it, better than the cheesecake I made for Easter from Driscolls website.  Got lots of 'wows' from everyone. Thank you.

text:
I made this the first time as is and it tasted great but the crust was crumbly and it cracked even though I had everything at room temperature, hand mixed, and left in oven for 6 hours to cool. When making the second time I increased the butter to 4 tbs and added 2tbs sugar and a pinch of salt to the crust. For the cake I used 2/3 cp of heavy cream instead of the milk. This time I used the mixer for the entire recipe. I left the cake to cool for 6 hours in the oven and NO CRACKS! This cake was sooooooo creamy and smooth and the crust was to die for. Will definitely be my go to recipe (with my changes of course)

I’ve made this cheesecake twice. The first time followed instructions as is. Tasted great but looked like a total disaster and was a little dry. text:
I've taught cooking for over 25 years and I made a few changes:  I sifted the sugar with the flour to help prevent lumping.   The first time I made it I did as per the instructions given and my cake still cracked.  So, the second time (and thereafter) I used the water bath method and the cheesecake didn't crack and browned just slightly around the edges.  Lovely.  The taste and texture are just superb.  Thank you.

None
text:
Very easy to make and delicious! The only thing I would add  is to give your cheese cake a bath. So put tinfoil around the bottom of your spring form pan and then place it on a deep cookie sheet and add some water onto the cookie sheet so it creates a bit of steam. The steam will prevent your cheesecake from cracking by keeping up the moisture. Works every time.

This recipe is AMAZING. I was tempted to fall into the trap of thinking I know better - I'll just tweak this, change that a little - but I trusted the recipe and it came out amazing. text:
SOUS VIDE Cheesecake!  I made this recipe SOUS VIDE METHOD and cooked it in ten 4oz mason jars and one larger glass container. It came out excellent!  The smaller mason jars were much more like a ‘cake texture’ while the larger glass container was creamier texture. The only downside was the graham cracker crust wasn’t crunchy like the oven baked version. Next time I’ll try cooking the crust only in dry heat then add the cheesecake. Wish we took picture but everyone ate it up too quickly.

Grease spring form pan
Two layers of foil over springform pan & do a hot water bath
Do not over beat
Bring ingredients to room temp before mixing
Gingersnap crust
12 ounce ginersnaps
1/2 C chopped pecans
6T Butter melted
2T brown sugar
1 dash of salt

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good flavor. Mine didn’t crack or sink. All of my wet ingredients were room temperature. I beat the cream cheese and sugar with the electric mixer, but I hand-whisked everything thing else until just blended, to avoid over mixing, which causes cracking. I cooked for one hour,  left in the oven for one hour with the door closed and the oven off, then cooled for one hour on top of the still warm oven, then one hour on the table, then I refrigerated it. This was my method of gradual cooling. The only negative comment I received was that it was a little thick. I think next time I will use 2tbs flour instead of 4.

text:
My daughter and I made this cheesecake yesterday and followed the recipe exactly as written. It did not crack but the taste was good but not great. It's a bit bland for us. Also, using the 9" pan made it way too thick to cook evenly, next time I will use a wider pan and adjust the crust size accordingly. Also, the crust had a "sandy" texture, next time more butter. I'm now looking up berry sauce recipes to spruce up the flavor so we don't waste this very large cheesecake.

text:
Delicious!  I followed a few of the reviews and used a water bath.  It cooked closer to 1.5 hours, but turned out perfect.  We only let it sit 5 hours in fridge.  it was good, but the texture is MUCH better if you let it sit overnight.  Per another review, I also added a little cinnamon and white sugar to the graham cracker crust.  yum!!  Making my second cheesecake with this recipe as I'm typing.  This time, we're going to let her cool for a full 24 hours.

text:
I made the recipe exactly as stated. Turned out perfect. This was my second time making this cheesecake. The first time it was not completely done in the middle. I think it was because I opened the oven door to check on the cheesecake. DO NOT OPEN the OVEN DOOR.  It lets out the heat needed to completely cook the cheesecake. It is very tempting, but DO NOT OPEN the oven door.

text:
This was my very first attempt at making cheesecake and it came out perfect...I followed the recipe almost exactly...I did add a splash of lemon juice, I reduced oven temp to 325 and put a pan of water on the bottom rack of the oven...and to be honest, I really did not measure out the crust portion...I just crushed a bunch of grams and mixed in melted butter a little at a time till it was the right consistency.  When I make this again I am going to blind bake the crust...its good, but I prefer a more crisp crust.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I make cheesecake, this the only recipe I use.

I do add about a tablespoon of ground cinnamon and a quarter teaspoon of nutmeg to the batter when I add the vanilla.  It adds just a hint of flavor that people usually can't identify but everyone tells me adds a really nice flavor.  

As others have mentioned, I put the cheesecake pan inside an oven bag and place that in another larger pan.  I then add hot water in the outer pan so it reaches about 2/3's up the side of the spring form pan.  Doing this, I have never had a cheesecake crack.

text:
I downloaded the recipe for the first time 2 years ago & I've made it about 10 times since then.  I  do it just as the recipe was written, but I use a waterbath, the first couple of times that I made it, it did crack, so my husband used a thermometer in the oven and we realized my oven heats up hotter than what it says on the dial, so I set my oven to lower now and it works fine. I put a wooden spoon in the oven door to hold it open.  (When it did crack I just added a chocolate fondant to the top & no one complained that they got the part with the extra chocolate in the crack, but that hasn't happened since I started checking my oven with a thermometer to make sure the heat isn't over 350F.)

text:
For context, this was my first attempt at a BAKED Cheesecake.

Overall, pretty good though not quite what I was hoping for.  I do plan to give it a second shot but with a couple changes to see if it gets a bit closer to what I was aiming for: 1) remove all flour [too "cakey"/fluffy for my taste], 2) perhaps remove much/all milk [there's something just a bit off about the taste/texture combo and I can't tell if it's just the flour or flour/milk], 3) lower the oven temp 5-10 deg [the outside edge and bit on top edge were dark brown - not burnt but heading that direction], and 4) reduce the sugar by about 1/2 cup [just a tad too sweet for my taste].

I didn't have a pan large enough for a water bath, so just had a pan of water in the bottom of the oven for steam.  I left it in the oven for the full 6 hours after baking finished.  The Cheesecake did still crack, however perhaps I over mixed.  We'll see on the 2nd attempt.

Oh my gosh, this is my favorite ever cheesecake recipe EXACTLY as it is! My only problem was on the graham cracker crust. It didn’t clarify 18 whole graham crackers vs 18 quarters. Very easy to make ( I didn’t do a water bath or any of the other suggestions and it was perfect). Everyone raved that it was the best cheesecake they had ever had.

country:
None
text:
I've made this cheesecake 6 times, each time it came out perfectly.  I use a 9" Pyrex casserole dish with the inside greased so it can pull away as it cools and shrinks, & bake it @ 325, no water bath; hasn't cracked once.  I leave it in the oven for 5 hours with the door closed after I turn it off.  Ridiculously easy to make & better-tasting with superior texture compared to any cheesecake I've bought.  I leave the cream cheese, eggs, sour cream, & milk to sit @ room temp for 2 hours before preparing.  Also, I do not use the flour; it turns out amazingly creamy.

rirybakes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this countless times and always get raving comments on it. I almost never have leftovers. I've had the famous New York Junior's Cheesecake twice and this is pretty close to it (but way cheaper). The recipe is pretty foolproof and I would say that the water bath is a must unless you want the top overcooked and dry. I had issues with soggy crusts many times (even with foil) until I discovered using the crock pot liner bags. Seriously works! I've brought it out when the timer beeped for time's sake before and it was just as good as when I left it in the turned-off oven for a few more hrs (with a water bath, it shouldn't affect it much!). I agree with upping the butter to 1/4 c and I usually add a pinch of salt to the crust. I've tried many variations of this including raspberry swirl, chocolate chip, and also a gluten-free version (no flour and use gluten free cookies instead of graham crackers) for my celiac and gluten sensitive friends. All in all, my go-to cheesecake recipe.

Display Name:
Jeannine Gama Hubbard

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3844643.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this using a waterbath as suggested - wrapped the pan in foil then set into a crock pot liner to make sure no water got inside- baked at 325 for 75 minutes, then left in the oven for four hours to cool.  It did not look cooked AT ALL after the 70 minutes, no browning on the edges, but i just left it and trusted it was cooked.  After a day in the fridge i tried it and it was DELICIOUS!  The day after that it was even better! I think for my next one I will back off the sugar in the crust, it was a little weepy and a tad too sweet, so i'll probably halve the amount of sugar.  Made a blueberry topping for this, and OMG was it good!  Several people said it was the best cheesecake they've ever had and I've been asked over and over for the recipe.  It is now my GO TO cheesecake!   

Make sure you allow all your ingredients to come to room temperature, it makes a big difference in the success of your cake.

Yummy, Taste five stars! I give it four because I feel like it needs to add some very needed tips for cheesecake novices like me. I made it and it turned out great except that the sides browned a bit and there is a crack down the middle. It wasn’t until after this happened that I looked up what should have been done to avoid this like putting it on a pan with water, being very careful to not overwhip, and other helpful tips.  It’s definitely missing that something that makes a perfect cheesecake!

text:
Excellent, excellent recipe! I have made this now three times and my last attempt was my best!! The recipe itself is very clear and is impt to follow. There were a couple of reviews which helped me, as well. I had a slight cracking with my previous two attempts and have reduced my mixing and added extra butter to the sides to prevent pulling when cooling. This last time I also tried placing a baking dish with water underneath during baking and cooling. A water bath was recommended, but I was nervous to submerge, so I just kept an extra pan with water below to add moisture. A must try!!

country:
None
text:
The texture of the filling was good, but it wasn't sweet enough. The crust was too crumbly and didn't stay together when cut.  It caused quite a mess.  Cooking time was too long.  I peeked in the oven after 50 minutes and I could tell it was getting too dark.  I shut off the oven at that point, but  I still had to scrape the dark brown (almost black) surface.  The crust tasted a little burnt too.  I covered the scrapes with a mixture of sour cream and powdered sugar and it looked ok.

If I make it again, I will increase the sugar by 1/2 c. for the filling, increase the butter to 1/2 c. for the crust and add about 1/4 c. sugar to the crust as well.  I'll cook for about 40 minutes instead of 1 hour.

text:
absolutely the real deal! PERFECTLY DELICIOUS!! it is my no fail, go to, impress our dinner guests dessert recipe.... i do recall the instructions used to have more details though....
all ingredients room temp, pour batter through a cheese-cloth or sieve to remove air bubbles, cook in a water bath and yes DONT open oven to check it just turn oven off and leave it there for 5-6 hours... DONT forget the perfect cutting  techniques either.... long bladed knife (one cut) ran under hot water so it wont tear up edges, then ran again under hot water to clean & heat blade before each cut. PERFECTLY BEAUTIFUL EVERYTIME! Thanks Chantal!

text:
I'm putting a 3 simply because I need to remake this again, as it is.  I tried to make this recipe with what I have available to me in Germany, and well, made a couple substitutions (accidental) which yielded a yummy cake, but not this cake, and certainly a more "cheesy" cheese cake than I'm used to.  For those in Germany (or of German background), if you like the taste of Schmelzkässe, I used this recipe with Schmelzkässe instead, as well as I left out the sour cream (another purchasing error), and it made a very taste, although cheesy, cake.  My girlfriend and her friend encouraged me to post this as an alternative for those struggling to find the right ingredients in Germany, or for those who really enjoy Schmelzkässe.  Also a note on the crust (for those where grammar crackers are not found), I used Leibniz crackers, which ended up being an excellent substitute.  I'll update this once I've been able to make the real recipe!

PS - As far as cracking is concerned, absolutely no cracking, and it baked perfectly.

text:
I put a water bath above and below the cake (I put a rack in the bottom bath so the pan stays above the water line.)  I mix the flour with the milk with an immersion blender before adding it to prevent lumps.  I have done it with and without parchment.  It comes out amazing every single time.  The top water bath prevents drying and cracking for me and creates a smooth unbrowned surface.

text:
First time making this recipe, based on the number of reviews on the site.  While there were many suggestions and modifications posted, decided to follow the recipe as is my first time around, with the exception of a little less sugar because I ran out, be using Greek Yogurt instead of sour cream because sour cream wasn't available. I also mixed everything by hand because I did not have an electric mixer. I greased the baking pan well to prevent cracking. My cheesecake turned out great with no cracks even without using the water bath that many people suggested.  While creamy, the cheesecake turned out to be a little soft, whereas I would have liked it to be a little more dense, but other than that, it is a great recipe and the cheesecake was a hit! I will try it again with The suggested modifications so that I can compare the results!

text:
I halved the recipe and it still made a 10 inch pie. I used a store bought graham cracker crust and it was good. I followed the recipe except I had to use what I call, fake sugar (hubby's diabetic) and I didn't leave it in the oven for several hours. I started out baking it at 350, then reading some of the reviews saying they baked at 225, etc, I turned the oven down to 300 for 1 hour. It turned out fine and I let it set in the oven for about half hour then cooled it on the stove. I will make it again, for sure. Good, simple recipe.

text:
My first time making cheesecake! Brace yourself for a long review as I also write this as notes to myself for future baking.

First: reason for 4 stars and not 5 is because I didn't follow the recipe exactly. So 4 stars just to be safe and not overhype this recipe.

I made 15 servings worth to fill up my 10.25" pan and it was the perfect amount. I didn't "beat" at all as I didn't want to whip any air into the batter. I had it on stir and stirred the cream cheese by itself until fully smooth. I whisked the flour and sugar together separately to break up the flour and prevent flour lumps in the batter. Then I stirred the ingredients in the order as instructed, except for the milk bc I kind of just forgot. I DID add a tiny splash of almond extract (I do this with many of my different types of bakes) as it can really round out flavors. I lined the bottom of my springform pan with parchment for a hopefully easy removal onto a cake board afterward. I ended up baking this for 45min at 300F, then 30 min at 325F, then 30 min rest in closed oven, then another 30 min in an door-ajar oven. The reason for the 300F is because my oven when down in temp after I put the cake in--it started at 325, then down to 300. When I turned off the oven, the cheesecake was doming around the rims with a dip in the middle (like a donut shape) and a couple of very small cracks along the sides, but as it cooled down, the cake leveled out and pushed the cracks together so you don't see them anymore. This also

text:
This was my first time making a cheesecake. I made this exactly as written except for 2 very minor changes: I added 2 more T of melted butter to the graham cracker crumbs because with the first 2 T they seemed pretty dry and like they would not pack into a crust and  I also didn't have quite a full cup of sour cream on hand. It did crack a little on the top but that did not change the taste of this cheesecake. It was fantastic and got rave reviews from all who tried it. I was making it for a birthday of someone who likes plain, no topping cheesecake so I did not add any type of sauce, etc. to it. Re: the graham cracker crumbs, I used 15 full length graham crackers, not 15 squares..maybe I used too much? I'm not sure if the extra butter was needed or if it would have been fine without it but it was delicious the way I made it. If I need or want to make a cheesecake again, I will return to this recipe.

None
text:
This was my first time making cheesecake, so I read a large number of comments prior to starting the process. I used a different crust. The filling was as directed except I only used 3 T flour, as someone suggested, and I used sucralose sweetener instead of sugar to make it diabetic friendly. Many reviewers said having everything at room temperature is key and numerous comments said to use a water bath. I placed a broiler pan of hot water on the oven rack directly below and placed the spring form pan on a cookie sheet to bake it. It baked for 60 minutes, then I removed the water container, shut the oven door, and let it remain in the oven for 6 hours. It was still slightly warm, so I allowed it to cool before covering and storing in the refrigerator. This cheesecake was a hit when I served it the next day. It was especially good with fruit toppings and whipped cream. Thumbs up!

text:
After making this cheesecake multiple times and it cracking, I've finally found the adjustment this recipe needs. 350 degrees is too high. It needs to be around 315-325. An hour is also too long. 45 minutes is a better time. I also add the eggs last and mix with a silicone spatula instead of an electric mixer.

text:
I haven't tasted this cheesecake yet, but it looks horrendous. I was trying to cut corners for Thanksgiving and avoid the water bath, so when I saw this recipe I thought I'd give it a try. Baked it for exactly one hour and left it in the over for 5-1/2 hours and when I opened the oven (the light is broken in my Thermador so couldn't see it beforehand...it was sunken in the middle, over-brown around the edges and cracked all over. I followed the recipe EXACTLY. Have made many cheesecakes with great success and this was a great disappointment. I guess you need the water bath. Maybe it's me--or my oven , or something because there certainly have been a lot of people who made this with success, but for the life of me I can't figure out what happened!

text:
This is the best and easiest cheesecake recipe I have ever made! My family actually requests I make it for birthdays, holidays... as a form of payment lol. My husband is a cheesecake SNOB and even says this recipe is better than any restaurant he has ever tasted, and what makes it even sweeter it is half the cost! Now I did read alot of the other reviews, and cheesecake 101 is ingredients have to be room temp, no over mixing the eggs, and no peeking in the oven! These all equate to a cracked cheesecake. Still delicious, but flawed (aren't we all really? :p) Also I was reading on a few reviews that the flour was giving a "cakey" taste to the final product, get this... I used RICE flour. Its super loose, it doesnt clump like all-purpose and no "cakey" after taste... I telling you its AWESOME. Ive made the cheesecake 4+ times now (I honestly think my family won't allow me to stop making it) and its always turned out fantastic.

text:
Revising:::::  I scaled the reciepe to serve 100 servings.  OMG 
 it was more like 1000.  Now I have so much cake.  Neighbors will love the holiday's.  . Cheesecake is phenomenal.  I have made cheesecake for years.  I would say this is the best one yet.  I do change it a bit.  I take about 1 -2 cups of sour cream add surgar till it taste good about 4 tablespoons  of sugar.  I bake cheesecake as directed remove about 5 min before it is complete.  I gently pour the sourcream mixture over cake and bake about 5-10 min longer.  It is a nice topping.  I think it was originally designed to cover the cracks for the novice baker but it adds another layer of flavor.  Awsome Reciepe as it is to.  Thanks for sharing.

Display Name:
Grinny23

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a triple birthday and everyone flipped out - it was so good!  This was the first time I made a cheesecake that had ZERO cracks.  I used the same ingredients with the exception of cinnamon sugar graham crackers for the crust and enough of them to coat the bottom and halfway up the sides of the pan.   For the mixing/baking, I followed a combination of others' recommendations: ensure ingredients are at room temperature first; pre-bake crust for 6-10 minutes to dry it out (and yes, you need more butter, big deal..); only use mixer for cream cheese and sugar - all else stir just to incorporate; don't add vanilla and flour at the same time; wrap outside of pan with tinfoil to make water tight and place in large roasting pan with water filled to 1/2 inch up the sides of the pan; turn oven off after 60 minutes and leave door shut for 5-6 hours before moving to refrigerator.  I served this with some strawberry sauce on the side, an easy recipe I also found on this site.  Thanks for the great recipe!

In order to keep cheesecake from cracking, cover the bottom and sides of your springform pan with aluminum foil (outside not inside). Then place pan in a roasting pan with 1" of water. It will never crack.

text:
Sous vide! :)
176°F for 90 minutes in 8oz wide mouth Mason Jars for wonderful self serve cheesecakes!

We first tried the Chef Steps recipe. Unfortunately it was not a hit at our house. To my family the flavor of that recipe was off. So I decided to give this one a try. I halved this recipe and it made 12 individual servings on cheesecake. They were devoured! In the sous vide there's no concern of the cake cracking or not setting up right. They each turned out as good as anything we've ever bought. We will be making these often. I've tried making cheesecake before we bought our precision cooker, and all my attempts were failures. With our Anova Precision Cooker, Mason Jars, and this recipe - easy success.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/292501.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent.I give this recipe 5 stars made  as is. I used the exact ingredients and proportions as listed in the recipe. I made sure all ingredients were room temperature. Followed preparation suggestions found in various reviews. and voila, a perfectly even picture worthy cake without cracks or cravices (picture attached). Here is what I did:
I used a mixer to mix the cream cheese and suger, then used the spatula to mix in rest the rest of the ingredients making sure not to over mix. I used a 10 inch tart pan with removable bottom and made sure to grease the edges as well as the bottom of the pan (once the cake was chilled, it slid out like butter). As nany recommended, I baked my cheesecake at 325 degrees farenheit for an hour. I turned of the oven, and left the cake in to cool for an hour refrigerating overnight afterward. I kept a baking tray with 1/4 hot water right underneath the cake pan like a waterbath while vsking and cooling (it kept my cake from cracking and the top came out looking like a mirror).  I also prepared a Supreme Strawberry Topping found on this site (preserved 1/3 of fresh strawberries to mix in with the other 2/3 in the sauce). It complemented the cake perfectly. Great recipe. Will definitely make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this cheesecake 5 stars because it was so easy to make once I read the reviews and followed the directions ! It is so moist and dense and just the perfect texture. I used pre crushed graham crackers and used 1 1/4 cups and 4 tbsp melted better . I think I might add some cinnamon or nutmeg and finely crushed nuts next time for more flavour . The actual cheesecake is perfect , I followed everything except the vanilla which I never measure . I would use a vanilla bean next time for more flavour and nice look . Some suggestions for toppings would be a ganache of melted chocolate and heavy cream or fresh fruit such as strawberries , mixed berries. I have made so many cheesecakes and I've got to say this is a winning recipe with the proper tricks . You do need to but it in a water bath . What I did was put an 8" inch springform pan into a larger 10" inch pan and then covered that in aluminum foil then proceeded with an inch of boiling hot water . I cooked the cheesecake for one hour exactly which I was a little skeptical of but I did as told and turned off the oven after an hour and left it in overnight , the next morning refrigerated and cling wrapped it . It is perfect . Thanks so much for an amazing recipe .

text:
Full disclosure: I made one change and baked this in a water bath, which is how many other recipes are written. I'm not sure how much of an affect that had.

GREAT recipes. I left all ingredients as-is and it came out perfect! Also this was the first time a cheesecake I've made hasn't cracked, or sunken in after cooling. It was honestly beautiful. This will be
My go-to recipe, and I'll just modify with flavors when I'm in the mood.

I was a bit worried because one reviewer said his came out bland and without that characteristic cream cheese richness (he blamed the milk and flour I think), but this was restaurant quality.

I love this recipe! I made it one other time and it cracked, so I took the advice of other reviews by: making sure all ingredients were at room temperature before mixing, different graham cracker crust recipe & water bath cooking technique. I also tried to make this in a regular pie pan the first time around, so followed the directions and used a spring form pan this time. I had no cracks and the actual cheesecake tasted better than any cheesecake I have ever tasted before. Even my picky father-in-law went back for seconds, complimenting that it was the best cheesecake he had ever had! Great recipe!

None
text:
I've made this cheesecake many times. It is perfect. You have to know that it will crack unless you take precautions. It isn't about overbearing/mixing. You need moisture while baking. Put a small baking pan with an inch or so of water on the rack below while baking. This will give moisture in the baking environment to prevent cracking. Works for me each time. This cheesecake is so so good.

text:
I would have given this five stars but made quite a few substitutions. Crust: 1 1/2 cups graham crackers, 1/2 cup butter, 1/4 cup sugar, 1/4 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg. Made the recipe as is but omitted the milk and flour all together. Baked at 325 for 60 minutes. I followed other advice and let all my ingredients come to room temperature and didn't over mix. I greased sides and bottom of springform pan but did not do the water bath. Came out great! And no cracks! Ran a knife around the edge right when it was done baking then put back in oven to cool for an hour then cooled on counter for an hour then the fridge for 4 hours. Delicious!!!

text:
I read several of the ratings before made this cheesecake. So here is what I did: I beat the ingredients together with a folk!( I am sure this got the lumps out and produced a light texture), had most ingredients at room temperature, used only 1/2 cup of milk, 3/4 cup of sour cream and 2Ts of flour and sent a pan of water in the oven under the cheesecake when baking. The cheesecake was light in texture and tasted great! I think this is a forgiving recipe if you have a basic sense baking. this will be me go to recipe! Thanks to all the suggestions.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really love this recipe! My husband loves whiskey cheesecake so I modify it based on some other reviews I've read. For the curst I use 1 1/2 cups ghram cracker crumbs, 1 tsp of cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, 1/3 cup sugar, and 1/4 cup of melted butter for the crust. I think any more sugar is too sweet. 

When we make the whiskey cheesecake I add 1/2 cup of whiskey instead of milk, and we add 2 TBS of flour instead of the 1/4 cup the recipe calls for. I also decreased the sugar by a smidgen to 1 1/3 cup in the cheesecake it's self, and when I make a regular cheesecake  I used 1/2 cup of half and half.

text:
I watched the video that assists this recipe, and noticed that they poured the batter all the way to the top of the spring form pan. I filled my pan up all the way, just as they did, and my cheese cake rose way too high. As it got taller and taller over the pan, the top of the cheesecake reached a more brown color, much darker than golden brown. I suspect this was because it was reaching closer to the top of the oven, and because I filled the pan up to the rim. I understood that cheesecake rises, but assumed that if I just do exactly as the video says, I can't fail.

None
text:
FAT CONTENT IS KEY!   I have made this recipe several times now and always ended up with HUGE cracks. I have been tweaking this recipe and finally got the Perfect cheesecake!  What I did was lower the temp by 25 deg and used whole sour cream, not the light or fat free stuff, THEN I also ditched the whole milk and instead I used Half and Half. Now I have a perfectly smooth cheesecake and no slightly brownish edges from over cooking. I did leave it to cool in the oven for about 6 hours. Now I can present a perfect cheesecake without using fruit filling on top to hide the cracks!  - sorry, but I really dig cheesecake so this makes my day!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The consistency and texture of this cheesecake was perfect.  This will now be my base cheesecake recipe.  
I used it to make minis and a regular-sized cheesecake.  It is much better in the larger size because it retains the moisture.
Although it tastes good as written, here are the modifications I use:  3 fewer graham crackers, substituted for about a 1/3 cup finely chopped macadamia nut, sub vanilla bean paste for the vanilla extract and add an additional 1/2 teaspoon of Madagascar vanilla extract and 1/2 teaspoon lemon extract.  Tastes amazing as a vanilla bean cheesecake or becomes a lemon cheesecake by adding a layer of lemon curd on top with some white chocolate curls.
I cook mine in a water bath to keep it moist.  Be sure to let the cold ingredients come almost to room temperature so your batter doesn't get lumpy.
Thanks for the great recipe!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I've made this cheesecake and for both times it has came out amazing. It's the perfect balance between sweet and sour. Just make sure that EVERY cold ingredient is room temperature and that includes eggs, sour cream, cream cheese, milk etc. It usually takes about 2 hours maybe, I forgot to slice my cream cheese into cubes but microwaving saved time! I used my electric mixer throughout the entire process, after every addition, make sure that you make sure it is JUST MIXED and smooth. Don't over beat. My cheesecake has always come out with a little bit of air bubbles on the surface but never a crack. Follow the instructions of letting the cake sit for a few hours and bake no further. I recommend to not use a water bath for this recipe since it has a starch component in it. Other than that, this is delicious!!

text:
This turned out wonderfully. The first time I've ever made a cheesecake, even went and bought a springform pan.  I used several tips from the comments section. I let the cream cheese and eggs get room temp, and only used the mixer for beating the cream cheese and sugar. After that I used a rubber spatula to minimally mix in the rest of the ingredients. I used a water bath and left the cheesecake in the oven for several hours after turning it off before letting it chill for about a day, not a single crack and the texture was great! I also incorporated a part from another recipe to make it a coffee cheesecake by replacing 1/4 cup of the milk with espresso, so I had a 1/2 cup milk and 1/4 cup espresso and it tasted amazing. The only problem I had was that the crust was a bit too soft for my liking, even though I baked it on its own for 8 minuted before hand. Maybe baking it a couple minutes longer?

I made this exactly the way it said, only I left out the flour. I did not use a springform pan, instead I used a disposable pie tin and it came out perfect. The only difference is the cake itself won't be as tall and you'll most like have to make two cakes. Also, I didn't use a water bath and my cake didn't crack or cave in whatsoever. I added chocolate chips to the batter to make it more flavorful. I'd let it chill in the fridge for at LEAST 5 hours before eating. Huuuuge difference in taste between the cake being lukewarm and cold!

text:
I have made this twice now, both times to the letter of the recipe. I will keep coming back to it time and time again, it is so simple to make and sheer joy to eat with any sort of topping!

You have got to try it.

Let your eggs and cream cheese come to room temperature. I nuke my butter in a glass bowl, and mix into the graham cracker bits in the food processor. I also spray my pan liberally.

This time, I made 6 cupcake sized cheesecakes (in silicone cups) and still a (thinner) cheesecake, because I am bringing the little ones to share with my coworkers tomorrow.  (The cupcake ones were done in about a half hour. )

Thank you for sharing this awesome recipe!
