I forgot to add the flour! But it still turned out incredible.  I did tweek it a little - add 1 vanilla bean and an extra egg YOLK only and for the milk 1/2 cup milk and 1/4 cup heavy cream.  It is a delicious and simple recipe.   Tomorrow I'm going to top it off with a berry compote and a drizzle of Chocolate.

Part II - 24 hours later.  Know this first.  I have Fibro and yesterday was a particularly bad day.  I was using Lamaze breathing techniques to get me through the electric shooting nerve pain.  I almost went to the hospital.  Infact I grabbed the keys twice.  But I though I would just "breathe and walk" my way through the pain and finish the cake off.  So GUESS WHAT?...I also forgot the SOUR CREAM!!!!  uGH!  I noticed that late lastnight when I put the cake(s) in the fridge.  
So, this morning, I whipped up 2 (8 oz) pkg of cream cheese with one cup sour cream, 1 tablespoon lemon juice (and zest) and 1 tablespoon vanilla and about 3/4 cup  powdered sugar.  Then I spread it on top and put it back in the fridge.  IT  TASTES GREAT!!!  Just a 2 textured thing, but it's still yummy.  I'm going to top 1/2 with a fruit compote and the other half with Torani Dark Chocolate Sauce.  #anythingcanbefixed!

text:
yaaaaaaas cake! made this for the first time with a few tweaks from the other reviews that i read on here. I used a water bath, only used 2 tablespoons of flour (instead of the 1/4 cup ) and for the crust I used 10 graham crackers, and an entire sleeve of DoSiDo's Girl Scout Cookies, oh and 3 tablespoons of butter. all mixed in a food processor to make it super fine.It's a gift and a curse that my daughter is a Daisy scout because i have CASES AND CASES of Girl Scout cookies in my living room, so I think I might make variations of this recipe with different GS cookie crusts. Thin Mint crust...Samoa crust...this is why i'm still fat haha.  after I greased the pan and pressed in the crust, i sprinkled on cinnamon, nutmeg and lemon zest before pouring in the batter. i also added lemon zest to the batter. i took someone else advice and cooked it at 225 degrees for 3 hours and 40 minutes, turned the oven off and opened it to vent a little faster, then closed it and let it sit for 5 more hours.  Its pretty friggin phenomenal .

userID:
5972746
Display Name:
Happyinsca
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really easy to make. I never made a cheesecake before. I made it four times already. First time, I followed the recipe exactly, without any changes. The cheesecake was yummy, exactly how I would think NY Cheesecake taste like at bakeries or restaurants. However, the side was burnt and the top cracked. It still tasted great! After reading others' reviews and recommendation, I made the following "technical" modifications. The subsequent cheesecakes were PERFECT!  The changes made are: Cream cheese, eggs, and other ingredients were allowed to come to room temperature. Made sure creamcheese and sugar were thoroughly mixed prior to adding any other ingredients. I greased the side of the pan as well. I pre-baked the crust before the filling. I used water bath to bake it. While some says to use hot water in the water bath, I used faucet water. I also baked it pre-heat oven at 325 degree. After an hour later, I turned the oven off and left the cake in the oven for another 2-3 hours.  I also made sure the cake was little bit underdone before the oven is turned off. The cake will continue to cook and then begin cooling. Then I refrigerated the cake for another 4-5 hours.  I also used a pie can to bake this cheese cake, cutting the recipe in half. It worked perfect as well. The final product was a half size, not as tall. However it was a perfect size. I was careful in cutting the cheesecake, as I were cutting a pie. This takes some time but was worth it. I will bake this cheese

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Barely changed a thing. Just added a bit more butter to graham cracker crust to help form it a bit more. (I used almost a whole stick and crust was great- maybe will use 3/4 of a stick next time.) Otherwise, made it exactly as recipe states for ingredients. Of note, I don't have time to leave things in my oven that long. I baked until it was done. Let it cool down just a bit on the counter for about 15 minutes and popped it right into fridge. Yes, I sure did. Guess what? It looks fine. No crack (I did grease bottom and sides of springform pan.) And we even had a piece about 5 hrs later. It's even better on day 2 later! Creamy, soupy cheesecake to me is like the instant box kind. This is the real, rich, stick-to-your teeth kind that I had in New York! Forgot to add that after slowly adding the eggs one by one on "stir" on my mixer, I then mixed the rest by hand with a wooden spoon to avoid overmixing per another suggestion. Worked great. I wouldn't change one ingredient on this recipe except adding a bit more butter to the crust until your liking for texture.

text:
Alright, I know, you shouldn't rate something 5 stars if you didn't make the recipe to a T. I am sorry. I rated it 5 stars due to the amazing recipe itself, along with outstanding tips & tricks by other reviewers. 

The adjustments I made to the cheesecake itself was I only used 1/4 cup of milk and 2 TBSP of flour. This only effects the consistency, not the taste (so much). I like a more creamy, dense cheesecake so that is what I adjusted. 

I also followed the guidance of others on here of using 1.5 cups of crushed graham crackers, 1/4 cup (maybe a smidgen more) of melted butter, and 1/4 cup of sugar to make the crust. I didn't pre-bake the crust or anything like that and it turned out crunchy and all together.

I baked at 325 for 1 hour and 10 minutes. I turned the oven off, removed cheesecake from water bath and left the door closed for probably another 45 minutes.  I removed the cheesecake and allowed to stand at room temperature (in microwave) for another two hours, prior to refrigerating.

It turned out amazing. 

Tips, as some others have stated: 

1. Double or triple wrap springform pan in heavy duty aluminum foil.
2. Ensure the water bath has boiling water in it prior to placing cheescake in.
3. Do not overbake, because when you jiggle the cake it looks to wiggly in the middle.  Cheesecakes still look that way, even when they are done, at least while they are hot and haven't set completely. 
4. Just use a stand mixer to mix the cream cheese and sugar. After that, han

text:
I decided on this recipe after reading several positive reviews. The only change I made was to add a flour based crust, not graham cracker. When I placed it in the oven, I took a look at the poor reviews and really started to worry. How could 1 hour in the oven do the trick? I was afraid it would come out a sloppy mess and I was expecting 10 people for Christmas dinner! But I stayed true to the recipe (and the advice of the first commentator) and just left it in the oven for several hours. Actually it was in the oven overnight because I had forgotten about it! Getting to the point, it was delicious! Everyone, even the small kids, loved it. It didn't crack, nor was it dried out at all.  So it seems like an easy, fool proof recipe - and I can't wait for an excuse to make it again!

text:
I have made this about eight times and it comes out perfectly without exception. Yesterday my sons requested that I put smooth peanut butter in half of it and cinnamon in the other half. I dotted about 8 teaspoonfuls of peanut butter all over one side and pushed them down in the batter until completely submerged. For the cinnamon side, I sprinkled the top with cinnamon and then used a fork to lightly mix it into the batter. My sons thought this was my best ever. I also used The suggestions of two other reviewer's and added 1/2 c sugar, 1 teas cinnamon and 1/2 teas nutmeg to the crust. It needed 3/4 of a stick of butter to hold it together. Also, after baking one hour, I only let it cool for two hours in the oven, then ran a knife around the edge before refrigerating. Perfection again!

text:
Wonderful cheesecake! Just one issue with the recipe as written: putting the flour into a liquid batter is difficult as you end up with lumps that you have to overmix, thus ruining the consistency of the cheesecake. Add the flour at the beginning with the sugar and it's much easier.

text:
Tasted too sour the day after but 2 days later it tasted really good.
Don't overheat as it will make it have the wrong texture and it will crack. Only mix till it's smooth. If you overcook, or don't grease the pan, it will crack. 
Bake for exactly 60 mins then turn off oven and leave it alone in the oven.
All ingredients should be at room temperature.

text:
I give this a 4 because I did have to follow other suggestions of increasing the butter for the crust.  The filling itself is definite 5 star!!  I used this for the filling and then did muffin sized "cakes" .  For the muffins I took the additional butter recommendation and used another recipe as a guide on the cooking time.  Had tons of left over batter but not enough for a spring form pan, and didn't have a mini one, so used a square cake pan.  This time used 2 TBL of butter as directed.  The crust is all crumbly and can't serve it.  I cut back the baking time to 45 minutes since it was a smaller pan, and left it in the oven like everyone said, while I ran an errand.  Came back and the top was browned but not cracked.  Done a little too long but the filling itself is definitely 5 stars!!!  Someday I'll try this in a springform pan.

text:
I made this cheesecake the first time as per directions and found that the cake almost overflowed out of my pan. The second time I made it, I used a water bath. I baked the cheesecake at 350F for 1 hour, turned off the oven and let it sit inside for another hour without opening the door. I found I could make a thicker cheesecake this way and could use more of the mixture. There was a lot left over the first time I could have made a second cheesecake with it.

I also use almond milk in this recipe and there's no difference in taste or consistency.

country:
None
text:
This cake is spectacular! Creamy, rich, decadent...I followed the directions precisely. The top of the cake DID crack, however that was easily concealed with cherry pie filling on top.  I also added 1/4 cup of sugar to the crust, just to add a bit more taste to it. Now I am going to try to make a chocolate marbled cheesecake by adding 1/2 a cup of cocoa powder to the filling, and top it with strawberries! Very excited! (I am also going to try using a water bath to see if I can't get rid of the cracking) ANOTHER TIP: Do NOT overbeat or overcook this recipe, and if you think that you have overbeaten it, tap the bowl of filling on the countertop a few times to release those air bubbles. Do NOT open the door while the cheesecake is cooking, simply set the timer for 60 minutes, and turn the oven off when it is done, leaving the cheesecake in the oven 6 more hours. Chill overnight for best results.

I made last Saturday and it turned out great. text:
This was by far the best cheesecake I have ever made or even tasted, ever! My husband gave it a 10/10!  I used the water bath, triple wrapped the pan in heavy duty foil, and let it cook in the oven at 325 for 60 minutes and resisted the urge to open the oven for 3 hours and it was enough.  The only thing I thought I might improve was the crust - it was a bit soggy - so next time I may try putting a pan of water on the rack below and pre baking the crust longer.  I did use pecans, cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg in the crust, and it tasted great.  I was so proud of this cheesecake!  Thanks to all those who posted reviews, I followed all the tips and it came out great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the best cheesecake recipe. I made the cheesecake filling exactly as is-did not change a single thing and it turned out absolutely perfect and creamy. However I did jazz up the crust a bit by adding cinnamon, nutmeg, and sugar. As for the cake cracking- mine did not crack or sink at all. I added a pan of water in the bottom of the oven (so not an actual water bath)- this aloud for it to create enough moisture to prevent cracking without the worry of water leaking in the cake pan. I did as the recipe said and tured oven off after baking and left in oven for 6 hours. If your cake cracked then you either over beat the filling or did not add a pan of water. Took this to thanksgiving and everyone raved that it was the best they ever tasted. Thanks for the amazing recipe.

text:
PROS: The ingredients list is spot on. 

CONS: The cooking method and time are so wrong!

I planned to make this cheesecake for Thanksgiving. I made it the day before, so I had the whole next day to cook other dishes. I opened the oven, after letting it sit in there for 6 hours. It was BROWN, cracked, and completely solid. I was devastated! That meant going back to the grocery store in the madness right before Thanksgiving, and scrambling to get it done the next day. It turned out perfect, though, when I used a water bath and cooked it for only 45 minutes. Also, no need to leave it in the oven for 6 hours!! Just let it sit in the waterbath with the oven door open for maybe 30 minutes, to cool down a bit, and then stick the cheesecake in the fridge.

Alright I cheated and purchased pre-made graham crust and recipe had more than would fit in little container but turned out amazing! 

I stirred everything with a wooden spoon to prevent over beating mixture. I also added eggs one at a time mixing in between. After cooking I let the cheese cake sit in the oven for two hours to let it naturally cool. I than placed in refrigerator over night to let it form and get firm. It did not crack at all and browned just perfectly!

text:
Stupid good. Better than restaurant quality. Ours cracked which was my fault but it was still ridiculously awesome. It's now a favorite. Highly recommend.

Update: I've made this 4-5 times over the past few years. Always comes out great. Really love it. 

I forget, 100% of the time, to take it easy in the mixing as some reviews suggest. I do exactly as the recipe suggests and it's the best cheesecake ever. Oh, and it cracks every time. I guess I can try harder to prevent that but I don't see why it's a big deal...but the last time I made it I left it in the oven for 5 hours and it still had a crack...but was still awesome.

text:
This was an amazing cheesecake!!! My family loved it.....definitely will make it again! I followed the ingredients exactly as written.  All I changed as far as baking goes was to wrap the bottom of the springform pan in foil and placed it in a water bath,  and baked at 300 degrees.  I baked it at a lower temp because 350 seemed too high for the water bath.  For anyone concerned about the use of flour in the batter I assure you this cake was FANTASTIC, rich, creamy, and not "cakey" at all.

text:
This was my very first cheesecake making experience. The recipe was easy to follow, and the cheesecake was delicious. My  coworkers even raved about it. I used a water bath, per a friends recommendation. It was on moister side, which I prefer.  It was a little fluffy(?) for lack of better word. It wasn't super dense like some cheesecakes. This may have been because I over-beat the cream cheese. Regardless, I thought it was perfect. I think density and moisture preferences probably vary person to person. ;)

Okay very good recipe, but when making the crust i found that i had to use a whole stick of butter instead of just 2 tablespoons? So just be prepared to use a whole stick just in case.

text:
I used a graham cracker crust recipe that is really easy. 1 pkg graham crackers, 2/3 cup sugar, 1 stick of butter and 1/2 tsp cinnamon. I followed the rest of the recipe as far as the ingredients go but I took into account all the baking tips in the reviews and came up with this: wrapped the springform pan in foil and then submerged in a water bath, cracked the oven door and let cool for 6 hours before refrigerating, and once in the refrigerator put a plate on top of the cake to prevent drying.

This was my first time ever making homemade cheesecake from scratch. I followed the recipe exactly. Made it for my mother-in-law for her birthday as a last minute request.   Everyone LOVED it. I did not realize how long it takes for a cheesecake to set so I did't have time to cool the cake overnight or even a few hours. I plan to try adding almond extract the next time I make it as I read in one of the reviews, just to try a different flavor.  I did use one of the hints I read from other reviews and put a pan of water on the bottom rack while baking and my cake did not crack.

userID:
8722660
Display Name:
earthygirl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6

37
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/971511.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sorry, but as a former pastry chef, I must agree with the reviewer that said the oven temp is too high.  I was taught to bake a NY cheesecake at 250°F (admittedly, depending on the oven - esp a home oven, compared to a commercial one, you may need to increase the temp to 275°F or even 300°F - but no more!) and either in a bain-marie or putting a bowl of (hot) water in the oven separately.  CRACKING is usually caused by the oven being too hot, but over-mixing* does not help.

 Also, IMHO, NY cheesecake should not have ANY flour!  It certainly doesn't need it.

Lastly, yes, definitely do not (*) over-mix !  Cream cheese and sugar first, as has been mentioned, but further to that: I always add my eggs LAST, after the sour cream (I also add some grated orange and lemon zest and juice) -- ONE AT A TIME -- and I still do this in my stand mixer.  You do not need to use a wooden spoon and mix by hand.  (In a commercial kitchen, that would be impossible!)

Kudos for the mention of leaving the door closed after turning off the oven, but you are only partly right: leave the door closed for 15-30 minutes (if the cake is still fairly jiggly), but then, crack the oven door OPEN for 30 minutes before removing to a rack to cool.

Trust me, I have made more cheesecakes than most people make in a lifetime, and this method has never failed.  Happy baking!

text:
I'll admit, I made this recipe about 4-5 times before getting it just right. And it was my own fault for not following instructions. I kept leaving it in the oven too long, thinking it was jiggly in the middle and not all the way cooked. Finally, after following the directions EXACTLY...wouldn't ya know, it was perfect. I did follow the tip of someone else, doing the water bath in the oven, it made the texture much creamier and for once, my cheesecake didn't crack! When it says don't overmix, they mean it. Stir in the last few ingredients with a spoon or spatula - NOT an electric mixer. Make sure your butter and cream cheese are room temp. After it's done, turn the oven off and leave it there for 6 hours. No peaking! Do all this and it should turn out amazing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night before I went to bed, turned the oven off and let it sit until I got up this morning. I rate it 3 stars because this recipe does have a few flaws, and the author's claims that it is the perfect recipe is far from true. I used each one of her suggestions: only used an electric mixer to mix the cream cheese and the sugar until smooth, did not over beat it, and then used a wooden spoon for the rest of the mixing. I don't think this recipe needs the milk and the flour. I think it would have been more dense and creamier without either. Furthermore, 350 is way too much heat in the oven. Mine came out very dark brown. 300 or even 315 would have given the perfect cooking and color to the cheesecake. Finally, 15 crushed graham crackers needs more than just 2 tbls of butter. I had to use 3 1/2 to get the graham cracker crumbs sticky enough to not break form and crumble. It was creamy, but it wasn't dense. It was rich, but not rich enough. The cream cheese taste did not pop out at me, and it didn't leave me smacking my mouth wanting more. I think with a few improvements this could be great. As is, it is just average. I want to taste New York, not the boonies.

Edit 9/12/2016: I remade this without the milk and the flour and it came out a hot mess. It had too much moisture without the flour, which made the cream cheese custard fall apart. It came out gritty and wet. Overall, this recipe is just bad. With the flour it comes out muted, and without it comes out wet an

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe to make a Raspberry Rainbow cheesecake.  I divided the  batter between 6 bowls.  I added 2 tbls. of  raspberry puree to 2 of  the bow;s  and colored  them red  and  purple.  Then colored  the remaining 4 bowls  green, blue, yellow  and orange.  Poured the  batter into  a Oreo cookie crust  to make a tie dyed  effect. I baked  mine  at 325  for 1 hour and 45 mins in a water bath.  Let  it set in the oven with the  door open  1 inch for 2 hours. Came out  beautiful and  delicious.  I uploaded  a picture of mine.

text:
Very delicious and easy recipe! I followed the instructions to the tee the first time, and the cheesecake cracked while baking, but was still delicious.

The second time around, I decided to the put the cheesecake into the oven as soon as I turned it on. Let the temperature of the pie rise with the oven. No crack afterwards. It browned a little on the edges, but that didn't take away from the flavour.

This is a recipe I will recommend to anyone looking for a good cheesecake recipe.

text:
This was perfect! I did end up cooking mine for an additional 15 minutes because it was still all liquid and wasn't set on the sides like I'd like. Could have been because I cooked it in a hot water bath. After that I turned the oven off and left the door shut for an hour. Then cracked the door and slide a warm knife around the outside edge of the cheesecake to release it from the pan and the left the door cracked for an additional two hours to cool. Removed pan to counter to cool for another three hours then let set in the fridge overnight. This was sooo creamy and velvety. Perfect texture and so tasty. I left all of the ingredients the same and did use whole milk. My in laws and husband and I all loved it.

Display Name:
Larissa Broady

country:

text:
I love to cook and am NOT a baker by any means, nor am I a plain cheesecake lover, but this was a great recipe and it was my first attempt. 

I did make revisions to the crust, as per the reviewer's comments (thanks Sciota, review#4). 1 1/2 cup graham crackers (about 12), 1/4 cup of finely chopped nuts (I used walnuts), 1/4 c salted butter, melted, 1/3 cup white sugar (some reviews said 1/2 c and some said 1/4, so I took the middle ground), 1 tsp of cinnamon, and 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. I also put the crust in a 9" springform pan very greased, in the freezer to set and harden (reviewer suggestion), until I had completed making the cheesecake mixture. After making the crust, I put a 13X9X2 filled with boiling water  water on the lower rack in the oven (paranoid that I would make a mess with the water bath!!) for a warm moist oven (thanks Porusgirl review #118)I then made the cheesecake, as per the ingredients (at room temperature-per many comments), and also tossed in a Tbsp of lemon juice (per a reviewer, and that person was correct, it did not make the cake taste 'lemony' at all, which I did not want, only to enhance the flavors). I baked the cheesecake  on the upper rack at 325 for 75 minutes. I did leave the cheesecake and water in the oven for the additional 6 hours to cool. (No peeking was easy as I put the cheesecake in the oven at 2:45am, and turned the oven off at 4am, then went to bed.) 

The changes that I might make next time are to double the crust recipe, so that the

Display Name:
Jennifer

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was so nervous to make my first cheesecake, but after reading a lot of the reviews I figured I was ready. It came out GREAT. I was actually told this was better then Juniors' (pretty close I would say:) I think the key is the make sure the ingredients are room temp. I left everything out on the counter for  over 5 hours. Also, I was careful not to over mix except for the cream cheese and sugar. I did use a water bath and  when the cheesecake was done (one hour)  I shut off the oven and left it in  to cool overnight. A little radical, but I wanted it to be perfect. I should mention I used the crust recipe from the back of the Kebbler crushed grahm cracker box and used a well greased heart shaped spring form pan (no cracking!) Definitely looking forward to making this again. Thanks so much Chantal!

text:
I'm sure this is a great recipe, according to the comments! I made a big mistake but not so big! I forgot to let my cream cheese soften before mixing it! 

So my cheesecake came out cracked and clumpy, it was not very good :(

But...after it cooled, I scooped all the inside out from the crust and mushed it all together with a fork until it was more smooth but still had a little clump in it. And EVERYONE loved it! They said the texture made it better than the store bought ones because it had small tiny clumps in it! I also topped it with whip cream, strawberries and strawberry puree oh oh! And a sprinkle of cinnamon on top!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making cheesecake and it turned out perfectly! Followed the advice of some of the other reviewers: Baked at 325 degrees for one hour with water bath, then allowed to sit for about 6 hours. Made sure all ingredients (not just cream cheese) were at room temp and hand mixed everything after the cream cheese and sugar.  Only used two tablespoons of flour as my husband likes creamy cheesecake and added sugar and cinnamon to the crust.

Cheesecake came out with no cracks and a great creamy texture. The taste of the cheesecake is phenomenal, and my husband says it is the best he has ever had. I did not like the cinnamon addition to the crust and will be leaving it out next time. 

Per other reviews and tips the main things to do to get the cheesecake to turn out right is:
1. Bake at 325 degrees
2. Use room temp ingredients
3. Do not over mix
4. Bake in waterbath
5. Do not open oven to check on cheesecake

text:
This is, by far, the best cheesecake recipe I've made.  I do it in a water bath and zero cracks. I've also tweaked it a bit.  I make the regular recipe then take out 1 1/2 cups of the batter and add 1/4 cup cocoa, 1/4 cup white sugar, 1/2 teas vanilla and 1 TB oil.  Mix that up and marble it into the regular recipe and bake as normal.  Who needs The Cheesecake Factory.  Serve with a bit of whip cream and a nice Moscato!! I'm in heaven.  Thanks for the recipe!!  Since our nearest Cheesecake Factory is 3 hours away, I make this a lot!!

text:
Very good recipe! I've made a few different ones over time, this is one that is on the top. Couple changes I made
1. Make sure everything is at room temperature before starting, makes the cream cheese lighter.
2. I used evaporated milk for the milk for a richer flavor
3. I incorporated the eggs at the very last and only mix the eggs enough to incorporate them, do not over whip them it busts up the proteins if you do.

Mine still cracked, but honestly who cares? You made a cheesecake that is delicious, no one cares there's a Crack I promise, they're just excited to eat the cake, crack and all!

text:
First time (5/16I made as is; no water bath, ingredients at room temp, did not overmix. It rose up really high and the edges got really brown and there was a crack in the middle. Second time (6/17) I lowered the temp to 325 and baked on lower rack with pan of water under. Baked for 1hr15m, let sit 90 min and put in fridge - middle was runny. Next time I'll bake for 1hr45 and use maybe 12 graham crackers and more butter - I baked the crust for 10 min first but it's still more like a layer of crumbs than a crust.

I scoured various recipes and went with this one.  Used the crust that others recommended.  I did use heavy cream for the milk, one less egg white and added some lemon zest.

I baked in 1in water bath for 70 minutes at 325 degrees., shut oven off, and let sit for an hour.   It set perfectly, no cracks or anything. 

This cheesecake is better than some bakeries I've gotten.  Dense, creamy.  Served with a mango coulis.

userID:

Display Name:
Jo1
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I will make this again. Everyone loved it. After reading many of the reviews I made a couple changes. I made the crust like many reviews suggested (1.5 cups crushed graham crackers, 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup sugar, cinnamon, and baked the crust for about 5 minutes on its own). I used room temperature ingredients, didn't over mix, banged the side of the filled cheesecake pan to release air bubbles, greased the pan well, and baked at 325 for 1 hour. I  used half the amount of flour and milk the recipe called for because many reviews used less or none at all. I did use the water bath method because many of the reviews suggested it. My cheesecake pan would only fit on my cookie sheet pan so I had only about 1 inch of water. It seemed to be fine because my cheesecake had no cracks and the texture was perfect. I used an oven bag to protect my cheesecake from water seeping into the pan. Many reviews said wrapped foil doesn't stop the water so I used an oven bag, worked great. I cut the bag so that it came up to the top edge of my cheesecake pan and used the tie it came with to secure it. After baking (for 1 hour) I let the cheesecake sit in the turned off oven for 1 hour before removing the water bath and running a greased knife around the edge of the cheesecake. Put it back in the oven for 2 more hours. Then let it cool on the counter for 1 hour before covering and putting it in the fridge. I didn't have time to let it sit in the oven for the amount of time the recipe call

text:
Rich, creamy, thick but fluffy cheesecake! 
Best cheese cake without the lime-y flavor.
Maybe I don't know how to describe it but it's not gelatin-y like other recipes or (like others) it doesn't slowly start running off the sides after the first slice is cut out.
This is perfect slices of cream-cheesy sweetness! 
After baking, I like to top it off with a layer of home made cream cheese frosting for added sweetness.
Also, we've made a 1/4 of the recipe and poured into the ready-made graham cracker crusts and it turn out perfect.

cakes

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome... changed a little from reviews.  Crust: 15 graham crackers, 1/4 c. almond slivers, 1/3 c. sugar, 1 tsp. cinnamon.  Mix in food processor and add 6 TBS melted "butter".  Press into foiled and greased 10.5" springform pan.  Bake in preheated 325 oven for 15 minutes.  Made cheesecake in my Kitchen Aid (the one on a stand).  Creamed cream cheese and sugar as stated on high speed until creamy.  Then on lowest setting added eggs, vanilla and sour cream in that order.  Omitted flour and milk.  Made many cheesecakes - doesn't need.  Let sit 25 minutes.  Pour onto crust.  Put 1" hot water in 8 X 8 pan on  bottom of preheated oven, and the cheesecake above it.  Cooked for 1 hour and shut off.  Left for 5 hours and refrigerated.  Bed time!!  Made my own toppings.  If you're going to go this far.... go all the way!

text:
My husband is a New York native and he gets upset if I tell him he has to share the cheesecake. I often make it as payment to friends and family for yard work or mechanical fixes to my car. I make Chef John's Fresh Strawberry Sauce from this site to go with it and they are the perfect pairing. As others have said, make sure your cream cheese is room temp and don't overmix. I make it with my stand mixer but I keep an eye on it the whole time. Also, the quality of the vanilla will change the outcome. I recommend using Madagascar bourbon vanilla extract.

text:
Ladies and Gentleman:  My cheesecake is in the oven - awaiting results.  Gave it high ratings as the recipe was easy to follow.  However, I read the reviews *before* starting the recipe....so I could be prepared.  2 problems - (1) "15 graham crackers" isn't specific enough, as each 'sheet' of graham crackers has a total of 4.  I went by the serving suggestion on the grahams' box which equaled 3 3/4 sheets, and it appears the crust is a bit thin to me; (2) Water bath?  Someone mentioned in their comments it required a water bath, which it does not.  Although I appreciate the info, it made me nuts trying to figure out what I missed.  So, I decided - no water bath, bake 1 hour and leave in there for 6 hours as recommended.

userID:
1118314
Display Name:
IYKIWBAS
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night.

I only had 2 cream cheese blocks, so I halved the recipe and made it in a 9 inch pyrex pie plate.

I used other reviewer's notes for the crust: 1.5 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup sugar, 1/2 tsp cinnamon. I did not pre-bake the crust, and it was fine.

I thought I had enough sour cream, but only had half of what I needed, so I used plain greek yogurt for the other half.

I added the zest of one lemon to provide a little flavor.

I baked at 325 for 1 hour and then let it sit in the oven for about 4 hours, then put it in the fridge.

It came out beautifully (no cracks) and tasted great.

If you are expecting some other taste from the cheesecake, I don't know why. This recipe is unflavored, so it's all about the cream cheese. I chose to add the lemon zest, but I'm sure it would have been fine without. If you want flavor, then add some, but don't judge the recipe because it is a pure one.

I mixed everything by hand with a fork since I believe that is the best way to prevent over-mixing. I also let the ingredients sit out (minus the milk) to come to room temperature before mixing. I did not use a water bath and I don't think it's necessary, but maybe I'll try one next time to see how it changes things, if at all.

region:

country:
None
text:
Delicious! This is my second attempt to make a cheesecake, it's been a while since the last time.. And it went out perfect! Very delicate, creamy, moist enough, just wonderful! I did strawberry compote myself, which completes the dessert.

I followed the tips in reviews about the process. I upgraded the crust a bit adding cinnamon, nutmeg and a bunch of grounded almonds, baked the crust alone for 7 minutes, then I used KitchenAid mixer to mix all the ingredients one by one and just to incorporate them. It did it perfectly! But just in case there's a lot of bubbles left, I threw down the form to the table a couple of times to let bubbles go up, leaving the flat surface of cake ready to bake. I baked for 1 hour using the pan with bubbling water on the lower rack as a water bath, turned out the oven and left the cake there for 6 hours. Honestly, I don't think it requires so much time to cool down, next time I'll wait not more than 4 hours or so. Then cooled it in refrigerator (happens to be overnight, but again, I would say 1 hour and it's ready!). Excellent easy recipe! Everyone's happy. Definitely will be making again!

text:
PERFECT result!!! The only changes I made were to the crumb crust, I pre-baked it (10 min) and used 3x as much butter as they suggest, 6tbsp, to make sure it didn't crumble as so often happens to me (I can't get graham crackers here so I use some biscuity cookie things which work OK but often make a very crumbly crust). Also, when I poured the batter into the pan, I poured it through a small strainer because the flour had left lumps in the batter. I was concerned about the instructions to add it last, thinking it would lump. I should have listened to my instincts and maybe mixed it together with the sugar before even adding the cream cheese in the beginning or something. Still, the straining worked and the cake came out wonderfully, no cracks and the perfect taste and texture, so it still gets 5 stars!

text:
I finally dared make a cheesecake!  My son is not a fan of cake, but loves cheesecake.  I'd never braved it as I was fearful of cracking, but I followed the directions to a 'T', including a couple of the tips from comments for good measure (a pan of water underneath, not over mixing, and making sure all ingredients were at room temperature) and it was fantastic!  No cracking and positively delicious.  It was best after having been refrigerated for a day, so I'd suggest making it in advance if possible.  I will definitely make it again, though I'll be looking for a different crust recipe.

userID:
17187396
Display Name:
Beth Hulett
isPro:

followersCount:
3

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best cheesecake I've ever made! Not just my opinion, everyone who's tried it loves it. My only springform pan is 10 inch, so I was worried about the bake time. I added 30 minutes to the 75 minute bake time at  325 F that another reviewer recommended. So that's 1 hour and 45 minutes total. I didn't  open the oven at all, despite the fact that it still didn't look done. After 6 hours to cool, transferred to the fridge. At this point it had set nicely, no cracks, and pulled away from the sides.I used a shortbread crust with lemon zest, rebuttering the sides after prebaking the crust and letting it cool. and a bain marie with an oven bag rather than foil per reviews. Switching to a wooden spoon after the step of creaming the sugar and cream cheese together also helped avoid over beating. The final product is dense, moist, creamy, rich, and everything I love in a cheesecake. The lemon zest in the crust makes it a treat on it's own, and it stands up to macerated strawberry juice without getting soggy. One thing I'd do differently is not to use a cake circle under the crust. It got soggy from condensation, and the crust is so thick and sturdy that it can take the condensation on it's own. It may be that the cardboard weakened the seal on the pan, causing more moisture to collect than necessary. I puddled the juice on the plate, and set the crust on top, then topped with the berries, and the crust was still nice and firm. The long cool down in the closed oven is really th

text:
Upon realizing I had absolutely no lemon juice or zest in my house, I went on a search for a good cheesecake with no lemon included. I was suspicious of the use of so many wet ingredients, but I was very pleasantly surprised. This recipe was just as good if not better than all the cheesecakes I've made previously! I used pre-prepared crusts which were normal sized for cheesecake, and I ended up with enough batter to make 2 full cheesecakes. The only downside to this recipe is that the cheesecake cracks more easily than other kinds I've made, but the taste is wonderful and if you're careful it comes out really well.

text:
I have made this cheesecake twice, and, I have learned a couple of things: Use a water bath!  Even if you just use a separate pan with water in it - do that and wrap the cheesecake pan with aluminum foil!!! The second time I made this I did not wrap the outside with foil and my cake cracked very bad

region:

None
text:
I made a cheesecake years ago and I guess it didn't turn out so well, because I haven't made another one in as many years!
I made this one after reading all the rave reviews, and suggestions...and it was a breeze!  However, I made changes as follows; Used a 10" spring-form, made the suggested crust of 1 1/2 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/2c. melted butter, 1/2 c.sugar, 1/4 c.pecan bits, 1t. cinnamon & 1/4t. nutmeg.  For the filling I used the ingredients as listed, except I left out the flour and the milk.  In place of the vanilla, I used fiori di sicilia, which gave it an INCREDIBLE flavor!!  I baked @ 325, for an hour 5 minutes, utilizing the 13  x9 pan of HOT water placed under the cake pan.  The top still browned a little...next time maybe I will try 300 degrees, even though the slightly brown top doesn't bother me in the least!  I will post future changes as I make new cakes.  Thanks soooooo much for such an AWESOME recipe!  You took all my fear of making a cheesecake out of my sails.  I think this is a good thing.....I'm certain my waist line or scale WON'T agree!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe!

Here's a few tips I've gathered from other reviews.  

-make sure all ingredients are at room temperature before mixing together.
-mix cream cheese and sugar very well with a whisk.  Mix all other ingredients lightly with a wooden spoon.
-don't forget to sift flower.
-make a water bath for the pie.
 Wrap the spring form pan with two pieces of foil, making sure the bottom is completely covered and no water will seep in.  Next, place pie in a baking pan and fill it with 1" of hot water.
-bake 350 degrees for 60 minutes.  After 60 minutes turn off the oven and let the pie sit in the oven for 5-6 hours. Do not open the oven. Ever. Just turn off the oven and let it sit.
-after baking, leave pie in the spring form pan and refrigerate leaving the top open. If you cover the pie moisture will gather and drip onto the pie.
 Enjoy!


I was out of sour cream so I replaced it with Greek yogurt. It came out great.

This cheesecake tasted great but I followed the instructions to the tee and it had huge crevices on the top when I finally took it out of the oven and the sides were very dark.  I had to shave the top off and take a hot icing spreader to the cake to fill in the deep cracks but nothing could be done about the sides.  The flavor was very good and, in order to cover the top, I added raspberries, a raspberry sauce  and drizzled with dark chocolate.  Every bite was eaten but it was a bit labor intense with fixing the appearance.  I might try it again on a little lower temp.

text:
I made it for Christmas.  Everyone loved it.  It was fairly simple.  Mine did crack but I was not overly concerned about that as long as tasted good.  The cracking I think can be created by many different variables and different people have different takes on how to prevent.  I did minimal mixing after initial mixer but did sparingly use a whisk as well as wooden spoon to get smoother.  The texture was perfect and did not have to use knife around edges to release from pan, came right loose.  No messing with pans of water in oven.  

Totally pleased with this recipe.  Plan to use again.

I'm very disappointed with how my cheesecake came out. I followed the directions to a tee and it still has a huge crack! My ingredients were room temperature, I mixed only the cream cheese and sugar together, then hand incorporated the rest of the ingredients to avoid air bubbles, let the cheesecake rest before baking and kept it cooling in the oven without opening the oven door for several hours! I was so excited to see it when I finally opened the oven door and my heart just sank :(  Haven't eaten it yet, but I'm sure it tastes great - how can a cheesecake not taste good! I wanted this to be the perfect Christmas cheesecake, but unfortunately it didn't work out that way.

country:

text:
Fantastic cheesecake recipe!!! This recipe has wonderful flavor and texture, so smooth and creamy.  I would agree that this isn't a true NY cheesecake in that it's too creamy and not dense enough, but I actually prefer this recipe.  I did follow other suggestions and cooked it in a water bath.  after the hour of baking, run a knife along the edge of the pan to release the edges which prevents cracking.  I also remove from the water bath at that point to dry out any water that may have seeped in. So far I've made the recipe as is and as a pumkin cheesecake; next I'm trying it as a white chocolate peppermint cheesecake with ganache topping. All were huge hits with my guests.

userID:
17040404
Display Name:
PJ Stoneberger
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times and i absolutely love it. I made it exactly as the recipe called for and it came out perfect and even my husband (who hates cheesecake) loved it. The only thing i did different was to add cinnamon to the crust recipe for a little extra flavor and i baked the crust for 10 minutes so it would not come out soggy. After the crust was ready i added the cheesecake to it and cooked it for the recommended time and left it in the oven for 6 hours without even opening the oven. Be sure to start with room temperature ingredients and only use a mixer to mix the cream cheese and the sugar, after that use a wooden spoon and mix by hand. It came out perfect. My daughter in law loves a good cheesecake and she loved this one. I also used the water bath and greased the sides of my springform pan, so i had no cracks. This is literally the best cheesecake i have ever made, and i have made several. If you stick to the recipe as is you will have the best cheesecake and everyone will rave about it! Enjoy.

text:
Made EXACTLY as written with only 1 change - cooking over a water bath. I did make sure all ingredients were room temp, and was very careful not to over mix... also greased the spring form pan. The texture was perfectly smooth and creamy, not dry. It baked perfectly even, and didn't fall what so ever! Changes I'll make next time: make sure it's on the lowest rack in the oven, as the top did crack around the edges slightly, and browned a little more than I like. I may also reduce the sugar slightly next time.

Display Name:
Samantha Hennessy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2913425.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to cheesecake recipe that I've made a handful of times now. I cut the sugar down to one cup and add the zest of an orange to the batter which makes it taste so fresh. I also add a teaspoon of cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg, and a pinch of allspice into the graham cracker crumbs for the crust. I bake the cake using a water bath by wrapping the spring form in heavy duty aluminum foil so no water seeps. Room temperature ingredients and making sure not to over mix (stand mixer on the lowest setting and mix just to incorporate the ingredients) are really key steps to making sure the cheesecake doesn't crack. 

After the cake cools, I reduce a cup of strawberry jam over medium-low heat, fold in 2 containers of fresh raspberries once the jam has cooled, plus a little more orange zest, and then top the cheesecake with the mixture. 

I've gotten rave reviews with this recipe from my husband who doesn't have much of a sweet tooth, from my in-laws and from my family. Great recipe all around.

text:
This is the very first cheesecake I've made. I made it for a family gathering and I got  good comments about it. I made my own flavor additions. I added a teaspoon of lemon to the batter and a cup of crushed walnuts and  a teaspoon of almond essence to the crust. Add and extra tablespoon of butter to make the crumb pack properly. Everyone loved it. Ill make it again. The nuts in the crust were  a bit much. I might leave it out next time.  I also cooked it for 3 hours at 200 degrees. It came out smooth and creamy. It was also really dense, which we all liked.  I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because it is better than store bought but I don't have a homemade cheesecake to compare it to. I couldn't let it sit for so long because of time. I also put it in the freezer for about half an hour after cooling. I liked it, you might too.

Display Name:
jrobin2007

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this about 20 times now so here is my review and notes for myself ...  I buy graham cracker crumbs in the box and add sugar, cinnamon and butter generously without measuring.  I pack the crust evenly in my greased (with butter) spring form. I microwave my cold cream cheese bricks until they are soft enough for the mixer.  For milk, I go with a mix of skim and half and half.  I cut the flour down to about a tablespoon and it makes the cake more creamy.
I let the mix sit in the mixer after its mixed up well so that it settles.  I put 2 pie pans of boiling water on the bottom rack and bake at 350 for one hour.  I let it sit in the oven for 3 hours after I turn it off.  Then, I mix up the topping, 2 cups sour crea,. 2 tablespoons sugar and 2 teaspoons vanilla.  I spread it on the cake and put it back in the oven at 350 for five minutes.  I cover and put in the frig.  
My cake hasn't cracked since I cut down the flour.  My ingredients are usually not room temp.  
Everyone loves this cake, I get requests for it all the time!
Review:

5

text:
This cheesecake is the most amazing cheesecake I have ever had. Great if you like New York style cheesecake. Beautiful flavor and texture. I used with room temperature cream cheese and it was smooth and delicious. However, every time I made it mine cracked, even after greasing the pan, not overmixing, and not opening the oven for several hours. But I didn't use a water bath because I didn't have a bath big enough to fit my pan. Didn't matter to me, though! It was still a beautiful cheesecake! I added three tablespoons of butter to my crust instead of two because it wasn't holding together. It pairs perfectly with a homemade strawberry topping! Love this cake.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7712197.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cheesecake for the first time about a year ago as a birthday cake for my best friend. since then I've made about 7 more...mostly at his request. This recipe is phenomenal! I usually make a strawberry sauce to accompany it, and they go beautifully together. But this cheesecake is great just as it is!

Thank you for this recipe!

The sauce is simply 1 pound of strawberries, hulled and halved, or quartered for bigger ones, juice from 1 medium-large lemon, 1/2 cup of white sugar, cooked down in a small saucepan over medium heat for 15-20 minutes, depending on the thickness you like. you can mush up the strawberry pieces with a wooden spoon in the pan, or throw it in the blender for a smoother mixture. Refrigerate it and serve with your cheesecake! Also great with plain Greek yogurt or over pancakes :)

text:
This is awesome! The only change I make is to do a shortbread crust- 1 C. flour, 4 T. sugar and 3 Tb. butter- mix together and bake at 400 for 8 minutes before adding cheesecake batter and bake as directed- delicious! I also put sour cream topping- sour cream with 3 T. sugar and a splash of vanilla. spread over top. Drizzle dark chocolate over top- baking chocolate melted w/ a bit of butter and sugar until melted- drizzle over top.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2460639.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since I made my cheesecake in a 9x13 pan, I had to increase the amount of crust I made. So I made the crust with 3 cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 cup of sugar and melted butter, and a teaspoon of cinnamon. I also baked the cheesecake at 325 degrees for an hour and left it in the oven for 7 hours and chilled it in the fridge overnight. It did end up browning at the edges but no cracks showed up! To avoid cracks, I avoided over mixing and placed a pan half filled with water on the rack underneath the one the cheesecake was on.

The cheesecake is perfect if you follow the directions exactly,do not over mix or you will crack the cheesecake . make sure all the ingredients are at room temperature if you want that browned New York style cheesecake look do not put in a water bath sit on a cookie sheet, if you want a perfect cheesecake with no Browning light golden color and no cracking put two layers of heavy duty foul and sit in a waterbath do not peek at the cheesecake.  I made this cheesecake at least a dozen times perfect every time

text:
Fabulous, my first attempt to bake a cheesecake and it came out perfect. Only think I changed was the crust, I added 3 tbl spoons of butter and 1/4 cup of sugar, because I bought an original graham cracker. Next time I'll go for the honey graham cracker. I baked it in a water bath but as some reviews mentioned double layer of foil didn't stop the water from getting in. I will try a roasting bag next time. Thank you for the recepie.
Update: I have made this cheesecake many times since and everyone loves it, I used this recepie as a base for flavored cheesecakes and also added a caramel crumble on top. When adding apples or other flavors I baked it for 20 minutes longer.

userID:
924472
Display Name:
ABIGAILG816
isPro:

44

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making cheesecakes for a long time. however, I always made them in a pie plate with a similar recipe using about half of each ingredient. this was my first cheesecake using a spring pan. It came out wonderful. 

I used 18 "full sheets" (2 packages) of graham crackers mixed with 1/3 melted butter for crust. 

I made the filling exactly as the recipe called, except I alternated adding the milk and eggs (I also beat each egg prior to adding it to the batter. ...a trick I learned on Emeril a long time ago. it helps the egg incorporate better) *be sure to use all room temp ingredients. 

When pouring cheesecake into pan, I used all the batter minus about 1/3 cup. The batter was about 1/3" from the brim, so very full.. this initially worried me, but it's fine! 

I baked it at 350 for 1 hour, then left the door closed and turned off the oven. when i checked on it thru the door, I was horrified to see the middle was all sunken in and the outsides were fluffy. but. ......after the cake cooled, the sides flattened out and it looked perfect. 

Mine did Crack...but no bigs. I put some strawberries on top and no one knew. 

Try it! Don't be intimidated! This tastes just like a "Cheesecake Factory" cheesecake. 

xo

country:
None
text:
I have made this many many times and it is always a hit!  I LOVE THIS RECIPE.
Just a few hints:  ALL ingredients should be at room temperature before you start so the batter is smooth without being overbeaten; instead of greasing your pan use a round piece of parchment paper in the bottom (easy to find in baking aisle) and cut two strips of parchment to go around the sides; and place a baking pan of hot water on the lowest shelf in your oven under the cheesecake.  Changes I made after making it EXACTLY like the recipe:  3 tablespoons butter for the crust; add 1/2 tablespoon ground ginger for the crust (I like the flavor and it cuts the sweetness); and sour cream topping (1 cup sour cream mixed with 1/4 cup white sugar spread on top of cheesecake 10 minutes before it's done & then finish as per recipe).

After thoroughly reading reviews I made the recipe with cooking at 325 for an hour as many people mentioned - i followed the recipe exactly except i used 2 tb's of flour instead of 4. I cut a slice out of my cheesecake this morning after I let it cool in the oven - it had not set it didn't bake long enough. Really disappointing. I put in back in the oven for a half hour and then threw it in the fridge. Hopefully that will help salvage it, next time I'm following the instructions exactly as they had them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is, by far, the best cheesecake recipe I've tried! It actually tastes like a store bought cheesecake. I used this recipe to make mini cheesecakes and they turned out great! Because I was baking little portions rather than one huge one, I cooked for about 25- 30 minutes. However, I suggest cooking for 20 minutes, which is a bit before the cheesecakes start to rise too much.  After you are done \ LEAVE THEM IN THE OVEN for at least an hour or two to prevent from cracking. Also, I took Morena's advice and used spatula to incorporate the ingredients after beating cream cheese with sugar then milk. (folding motion). This was the best advice for a novice like me. This recipe makes 24 mini cheesecakes (if you are using cupcake pans). 

I also used ~ ¼ cup less sugar than the amount the recipe calls for. It was still sweet enough for my taste.

text:
So good! I followed the filling recipe exactly, although I did warm up the ingredients on the preheating oven so they weren't cold. For the crust, I used 1 sleeve crushed crackers, 1/2 stick butter, and 1/3 cup brown sugar. SO GOOD - but should have doubled. Wrapped spring pan in two layers of big, heavy duty foil, no issues with water coming in. I poured a full kettle of boiling water in large roasting pan bath. Put in 350 oven for 60 min, then just turned oven off. No cracks and perfectly set.

Well I am here to tell you that the reviews are true.  You cannot ruin this cheesecake if you follow the recipe.  I didn't even have a mixer, I did the mixing by hand and remember DO NOT NOT OVER BEAT. Take your time it is so worth it.  Also Don't over bake.  BAKE 1 HOUR THEN LEAVE IT IN THE OVEN 6 HOURS, DO NOT OPEN THE OVEN DOOR TILL THEN.  It came out perfect and it IS NY CHEESECAKE!!!

text:
Back in the 90's there was a show called 'Martin', on it was a character named "Shenay-nay"! Her trademark saying was, "Oh my Guuudness!". Well, haven't thought about that young lady in years, why did she come to my mind when I ate my first piece?!?! Oh my Guuudness!!!!! I can't believe I made this. I am a scattered cook with not a lot of confidence honestly, but this was awesome! I decreased flour to 2 Tbs, tweaked crust: 1 1 /2 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1/4 c. finely chopped Unsalted nuts ( pecans), 1/4 c. melted butter, 1 tsp. cinn. No water bath was used but would like to try so I can measure difference. I read reviews b4 I started, only changed what was necessary for my taste, because I knew I wouldn't want a cakey cheesecake (flour), and love a good crust on my desserts. I actually took it out after 1 1/2 hrs, no cracks!!! made a simple topping: 8 oz sour cream ,2 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract. If there were any imperfections, it would have been covered by this yummy topping. Used strawberry pie filling to gather berries from and put them in two rows around edges. I never review/rate anything, but I had to let you all know.......FoolProof! Amazing! Thank all who reviewed this recipe before I attempted it!

userID:
9370166
Display Name:
Laura Hamilton
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1199407.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cheesecake is fickle; I'll be the first to say that.  I've made a couple of them, typically with minimal ingredients: crust of butter and graham crackers; filling of eggs, cream cheese, sugar, and a little vanilla.  Sometimes it cracks, and sometimes it doesn't.  I incorporated all of my tricks into this recipe:  soften the cream cheese, don't overmix, don't open the oven door at all during baking and a couple hours after.  After several hours I opened the oven door to a glorious...crack in the shape of an X decorating the top.  After some chilling, I tried a slice.  Still runny in the middle.  Oh well.  This time was definitely a miss.  The filling tastes delicious (needs a little less crust), but I'll have to fiddle with the method a little more to get it just right.  Edited to add:  okay, so I'm coming back the next day (after leaving my cheesecake in the freezer all night) with my tail between my legs.  I should've known better, too:  THOROUGHLY CHILL YOUR CHEESECAKE.  Firmed up nicely and tasted perfect.  2ND EDIT:  I think that the crust ratio is off here.  A good graham cracker crust is usually 2 parts cracker to 1 part butter by weight; I used 12 crackers (about 6 ounces) and 6 tablespoons of butter.

text:
I made this for my sister's birthday.  I have never made a cheesecake before.  My springform pan is 10", not 9", which was a good thing as it wouldn't have fit in the 9".  I used 15 whole graham crackers, which I don't think was intended as there wasn't nearly enough butter...I just added added more and went with it.  Due to a physical disability, I used a mixer for all the mixing, instead of a wooden spoon.  I followed all the directions, but my cheesecake did split.  I'm not sure if this was because I used the mixer or if I didn't grease the pan enough.  No matter, it was delicious!!  I will definitely make again and try greasing the pan more liberally and work on mixing enough but not too much.  A crack would not be a deal breaker...there would be plenty of ways to disguise it.  I would be totally happy if I were served this in a fine dining restaurant.

Worth the wait!! Just be careful not to over mix!!  This is the real deal, famity from new York gave the approval for this recipe...I didn't have time to let the cake set for the full 5 hrs (1 1/2 hr was all) since it was christmas morning and I was travelling.  I allowed the cake to cool for about 15 on the counter top after 90 mins of cooling in the oven and placed in a cooler for 1 hr road trip and it held up just fine..some even said it was the best cake they ever had!

text:
This is really good! I'm no expert baker, but I think this turned out surprisingly well. We ate a few slices the same day I baked it and it tasted okay, but after 24 hours in the fridge it's really good. I followed the recipe carefully, but as it was baking in the oven, I read some reviews saying I should let the cream cheese reach room temperature before mixing. After baking the cake for one hour, I turned the oven off and let it cool in the oven, door closed. After an hour, the cake cracked and deflated, still in the oven, door never opened. Maybe it's because the cream cheese was cold? I don't know. But I don't really care, that's just aesthetics, right?

text:
I made this recipe 3 days ago, it's gone now, and I wish calories were a myth because I want to make it again. I don't understand the bad revies this has. mine turned out to be creamy, rich, sweet, cheese flavoured, light, and all over delicious and decadent. I followed the recipe exactly, while putting to good use my own experience baking cheesecakes; always grease the mold so it won't stick to the sides and break, always let it set inside the oven with the door cracked a bit so the cake won't crack, for a moister cake always bake in a ban marie, (I didn't use the ban marie and it turned out great though). Thank you for the recipe.

My first time making a cheesecake and I chose this recipe based on all the good reviews.  It has good texture, but mine did crack.  I tried not beating it too much as other reviewers have mentioned and I did put it in the oven and left it alone for 5+ hours, but it still cracked. Outstanding taste.  I like a cheesecake that is not TOO sweet and slightly dry.  It did crack but that is my fault.  I was in a hurry and could not wait to get everything to room temp AND I forgot to spray my sides really well. text:
This was my first attempt at making a cheesecake.  The recipe was so easy and it turned out perfectly!!  Instead of crushing up graham crackers, I used 2 cups of graham cracker crumbs.  The next time I make this, I will add 1/4 to 1/3 cup of sugar to my crust to make it just a little sweeter.  I also used whipped cream cheese instead of the block.  This made for a very smooth cheesecake.  My friend's daughter from Ohio was visiting with us and she and I couldn't get enough!!  I will definitely use this recipe again.

text:
Several problems with this recipe even thouhh I followed iy exactly. First off through entire process, I hamd beat the batter so not to over beat it.
1. This should be done in a water bath found that the edge of the cheesecake was over done. Was dark and dry.
2. Also, I find that the oven was entirely to hot at 350. Lower it to 325. Found that the cheescake overcoagulated and yes it did crack.
4. Since the cracking was caused by the trapping of air. It would help that if the eggs should be the last thing that is  .  Placed in the batter. I have cooked a lot of cheescakes I found this to be average.

Perfecto! Lo he hecho en varias ocasiones y siempre queda riquísimo. Mi recomendacion es que en vez de engrasar el molde (como otras personas sugieren), utilizes "parchment paper". Siempre lo hago en baño de María y protejo el molde con papel de aluminio.  (= Perfect! I've done it several times and is always delicious. My recommendation is that you instead of greasing pan (as others suggest), use "parchment paper". I always do water bath and protect the mold with aluminum foil.)

text:
This is a good cheesecake..I was given compliments on it,it had a good texture and flavor. However the majority of my friends requested I go back to my old recipe from the back of the graham cracker crumb box. This one is very very similar but to time consuming with the coolong in the oven and then the fridge. I dont use a water bath, i let mine cool on the counter for an hour then in the fridhe for four and no cracks...however I choose to cool mine overnight always as it brings more flavor and better texture..

text:
This was great cheesecake and everyone loved it for Thanksgiving.  I would try to cook this at a lower temp next time,  as the edges were too brown for me.  The taste also didn't jump out at you.  I would try less milk and less flour next time.  I also did not like the crust.  While it was easy to make the crust, I just think it would be worth taking a little extra time to make a homemade crust. As other reviewers suggested DO NOT OVER MIX THIS! So this all being said, if you don't change a thing, it turns out good, but for the people that want much better than good, you will need to change things a bit.

It was a hit!
I made this for Thanksgiving and it was great. I substituted 2 of the 4 packs of 8 oz regular Philly cheese with two 1/3 less fat Philly cheese. And I used 2% milk. It was really easy to make. Although I let it sit for 6 hours in the oven, it slightly cracked. It wasn't a deep crack though. I layered the cake with a can of cherry topping and ta-da. It looked AND tasted awesome!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a good cheesecake recipe to make for my husband's birthday.  I am not a great baker or cook by any means, so I was worried about how this would turn out.  First try, I went the whole hour at 350 and the cheesecake was overcooked.  Also, I overmixed and it cracked, not to mention I had never heard of a 'water bath' before, therefore I had not used it, so there was a grand canyon crack.  Overall, my first try was good, just not great.  It took me a couple trys to figure out the right temperature & cook time (mine ended up being about 330 at about 48 min, just kept checking on it to make sure the top didn't overcook), don't over mix and get the waterbath concept.  At about the 3 try, I had it figured out and needless to say they have been DELICIOUS!  I have also used half vanilla/half almond extract to give a different flavor.

Display Name:
KellyA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only problem I had with this cheesecake is that after I put it in the oven it cracked! I dont know what I did! But I did make a few changes... Instead of cream cheese I used neufelatchel cheese (taste the same but just healthier) and for the top I made my own blueberry glaze. For the blueberry glaze I did 2 cups fresh or frozen blueberries
1/2 cup water
1/2 cup sugar
2 tablespoons fresh orange juice
2 tablespoons cornstarch, mixed with 2 tablespoons cold water
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
Zest of 1 Orange
1. In a saucepan over medium heat, combine the blueberries, 1/2 cup of water, sugar and orange juice. Stir frequently, and bring to a low boil.
2. In a small bowl, mix the cornstarch with 2 tablespoons of cold water.
3. Slowly stir the corn starch into the blueberries, taking care not to crush the blueberries. Simmer until the homemade blueberry sauce is thick enough to coat the back of a metal spoon, about 5 minutes.
4. Remove from heat and gently stir in vanilla and orange zest.

userID:
2231359
Display Name:
Big "M"
isPro:

2

244
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My daughters favorite dessert is cheesecake - I don't make it cause mine is usually dry/cracked. BUT for her 40th surprise B.Day Party I just had to. I read so much about making one and this was the recipe I chose. I did cut the flour to 1/2 the amount - I've done it with the full amount and it was not near as creamy - so if you like a "dense" cake use the full amount. I put boiling water in a pan on the bottom shelf - room temp. ingreds - hand beat everything after the cr. ch./sugar -  greased/floured entire pan - baked for 3 1/2 hours at 225 degrees - knifed around the edge when it came out - let it set 3 hrs. in the oven with door closed - set on counter to cool a bit more - SHOULD HAVE: set in the refrigerator for a hour or so before removing pan only because it bulged on the side a tiny bit...but still didn't crack. THE ONLY THING I DIDN'T DO WAS TO PUT PARCHMENT PAPER IN THE BOTTOM OF THE PAN - so i just set the cake with bottom connected on serving plates. There was a problem of serving and not getting the entire bottom crust with the cake. NO ONE CARED!!! THIS CAKE WAS SO CREAMY AND YUMMY. TWO PEOPLE WHO MAKE CHEESECAKES ALL THE TIME SAID IT WAS DA BOMB!!! I used crushed Heath bar in the middle and on top since thats her favorite candy bar. 
I THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF MY HEART!!! I used to work in a wonderful bakery (though we never made cheesecake) and I love to bake - but my kids never cared for my cheesecake - so I just gave up - they now think "I'm Da Bomb"!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first cheesecake ever. OK. I've read all the reviews; good and bad. Here's my take. I followed the directions exactly except I PUT A PAN WITH WATER IN THE OVEN with the cheesecake. I didn't over mix but I needed to mix it to the "satiny" stage. 
Pros: texture is creamy and soft. No cracks. Cheesecake is picture perfect. First bite is amazing. 
Cons: crust was soggy even though I baked it prior to filling. After the first few bites I could taste the egg. Almost reminded me of a sweet deviled egg. Took forever. 
Next time: I'll use 2 eggs only. I'll add more vanilla and lemon zest. I'll add more butter to crust and cinnamon. 
Good recipe just tweak to your specific taste.

None
text:
This is a good recipe. The taste was perfect and so was the texture. If you like a more tangy cheesecake, I would suggest adding some lemon zest to the recipe. Anyway, I followed the recipe to the T and it still cracked. Yes, I did grease the pan (with a baking spray that contains flour), so the cake pulling away from the sides as it cooled was not the issue. And, yes, I did turn off the oven and left it in there with the door closed as it cooled for 6 hours. I would suggest using this recipe, but water bathing the cake as it bakes. I will try that next time and write about the results. PS I iced it with a sour cream frosting and topped it with strawberries which not only hid the cracks, but tasted amazing!

text:
TIP FOR CRACKS: I have found out that the best way for dealing with cracks in this cake is to use a hand whisk. Add ingredients one at a time and gently mix everything together(don't use machines for this cake). Do not mix fast because this creates bubbles in the batter. This is a delicate cake to make so be gentle.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
i was so excited to make this recipe for my husband who LOVES cheesecake, the creamier version. i'm 23, pretty much a beggining baker lol. i didnt realize how technical cheesecake was! my husband said i chose a very difficult recipe. but it turned out SO AMAZING!!! i will never buy another fake cheesecake :) i did look through the comments and used a few changes they mentioned. i let my cream chz reach room temp. before i started. i cut down the flour to 2 tbsp so it would be creamier. I did use a water bath but putting it in an oven bag didnt work the bottom still got lil wet. i added a sprinkle of nutmeg, cinniamon, and sugar to the crust mix. one thing i didn't know and no one mentioned it was to sift the flour into the batter mix. i ended up wit little clumps i had to break up. then before i put it in the oven i dropped it on the counter (a trick my granny taught me to get air bubbles out of cake batter) im not sure if that really made a difference or not. but i let it cook for 60 min without opening oven then i turned off oven and left it for 3 1/2 hours then put it in fridge. it turned out sooooo beautiful. i got my husband some strawberry filling in the can and he went to town on the cheesecake lol. he even told his uncle about it (husband gm of jerry js, uncle is the owner of the franchise) :D i will def. be making this for family reunion or christmas to share wit the family!

text:
This cake was edible, but I rated it one star because it doesn't deserve the five stars it gets by a long shot. There wasn't enough room in a nine inch springform pan for this recipe--it was so overfilled that it ended up breaking. I've never broken a cheesecake before! I recommend other testers use a ten inch springform pan. Secondly, one hour wasn't NEARLY enough time to cook this cheesecake. Since the recipe called for the cake to sit in the oven six hours after, I figured it would set better---WRONG. This cake was beautifully browned but TOTALLY raw in the middle. Really? I ended up cooking it another half an hour and since it was already broken, I just topped it and refrigerated it. My tips would ultimately be to use a ten inch springform (which I had at home anyway...ugh!)and to cook for an hour to an hour and a half. Overall, I would just choose a different cheesecake recipe. Disappointing!

text:
I followed the recipe as written, using the video as a guide.  It was very easy to make.  I agree whole-heartedly with another reviewer who said this was "like cheesecake" but it was not the kind of cheesecake I expected.  The richness and density just were not there.  I topped it with freshly picked strawberries and strawberry glaze and those additions made it look beautiful.  I was expecting a dense and creamy texture with a sweeter, more buttery crust.  To me, cheesecake should be so rich that you couldn't possibly eat more than a small sliver, and this missed that benchmark.  That's just me.  I feel that if I'm going to spend the calories they should be worth it.  On to the next one!

text:
Super tasty cheesecake. I used this as the middle layer of a cake (sandwiched between to layers of chocolate cake) and everyone loved it. I would caution people to not add the flour at the same time as vanilla, as some others have done. I'm sure it's fine without the flour as well. 

I did bake it in a water bath because... well, it's a cheesecake. I didn't let it cool for quite as long as the recipe suggested (time constraints) but it was still excellent. No cracking, delicious and rich.

text:
Made this without the crust. Burned a little on top and when it came out of the oven it felt like a custard. But cut off the top layer, put it on top of a red velvet cake (after the crumb coating), and covered it with cream cheese frosting. Froze overnight and by the time I got to my Fathers house for Father's Day, it was thawed and delicious! My family loved it! One thing though, instead of leaving the oven closed for 6 hours for it to set, I cracked the oven and let it sit for 2 hours.

I made this recipe without any modifications except that I did not let it cool in the oven, as I was in a rush -- and I took it out of the fridge a little early before serving. It did not crack.

Highly recommend even for cheesecake novices, like myself!

text:
My wife and I have been making this recipe for a number of years now and love it to death. We did make a little change in the recipe though. We cut the sugar almost in half. The way it's laid out now is just too much sugar and it leaves a nasty, sugary after taste. We do ours measurements in metrics. I think the original recipe called for 200g of sugar and we dropped it down to about 130g. This is the reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. Other than that, it's fantastic!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only cheesecake recipe I've used, and I've made it twice as of last night. It's very good, but there is one issue: the middle of the filling doesn't cook properly. It cooks enough to hold its structure, but it has a very buttery/creamy texture rather than the classic tacky texture the outer filling correctly achieves. I tried cooking it 15 minutes longer or so this time, but it didn't help. Aside from that, I did follow the recipe exactly both times. I'm not pro enough to know why this happens, but I've read that a cheesecake shouldn't crack unless the internal temperature gets too high. However, this pie cracked both times for me AND the middle is undercooked. So maybe there is a fundamental problem with the ingredients here, such as too much liquid? Even so, it's a very delicious cake. I don't think anyone would dislike the creamy texture if it comes out this way for you!

If your cake does crack, I suggest topping it with a 1 c. sour cream + 1/3 c. powdered sugar topping. Tastes good and hides the crack!

userID:

Display Name:
zehbookie

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For the first cheesecake I ever made it ended up awesome! I made it mango flavor, with real mangoes, on my dad's birthday. A bit of a mistake. It cooked well in the water bath and really was all cooked after a little more than an hour, but because of the rush I left it in the oven for only three hours afterwards and in the fridge for thirty minutes. We just wanted to eat it on his birthday. Putting it in the fridge that quickly didn't cause it to crack or anything, but the middle was soft and my mom thought it was undercooked. It was fine, but for it to get that cheesecake consistency we put the leftovers in the fridge and overnight it became perfect. Great recipe, you don't need to follow the ingredients to a T, but the water bath and the time is important to get right.

Amazing cake! Only problem is that whenever I make it - I can't stop eating it.
2 tips for baking a cheesecake:
1. place a bowl of water at the bottom of the oven.
2. wrap baking pan in very wet newspaper or paper towels.
It's absolutely worth the extra 2 minutes work.
