I used this crust recipe from another reviewer...it was delicious:  1 1 /2 c. graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1/4 c. finely chopped Unsalted nuts (walnuts, pecans), 1/4 c. melted butter, 1 tsp. cinnamon and a 1/4 tsp. nutmeg
I think I kept everything the same & added cherry pie filling.  It was perfect!!  I followed the baking temp & directions, left in the oven for 5-6 hours, and wrapped in Saran Wrap & let sit in fridge about 18 hours.  Sooo worth the wait!

text:
Right. I really dislike cheesecakes due to an experience I had back in primary school, that one tasted sour and nasty but I actually enjoyed this one that I made. I have no idea what graham crackers look like (seriously I don't) so I subbed with Oreos. This cheesecake recipe makes a very moist, my father called it wet, cheesecake. Tasted amazing no lie but very very moist. So if your looking for a creamy close to cakey cheesecake you will need to add more flour than just a 1/4 cup. Perhaps a 1/2 or 3/4 cup. I also added some zest from a lime to give it a kick and loaded it with essence lol. But if you do like very moist cheesecakes this is your keeper! Oh and yea all those hours you see there, that they give. You don't need em. I left mines in the oven after it baked for 3 hrs and chilled it for however long I wanted. Overall I was very happy with this recipe seeing as how it was my first time and all making one!

This was my first ever "baked" Cheesecake.  Before making this I read a lot of the reviews.  I told my husband that I wasn't sure what to do.  Water bath, no water bath; plain crust, add nuts, etc... etc..

userID:
10131122
Display Name:
JWells
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Don't ever really leave reviews but this one deserves it. Best cheesecake I have ever had, hands down. Made a few changes. Lowered the graham crackers to 8, doubled the melted butter to 4 tbs. Added 1 tsp of sugar and 1 tsp of cinnamon to the crust. Changed the milk to heavy cream. Lowered the flour to 1/8 cup. Let all the cold ingredients get to room temperature before making. Filled a cake 9x13 pan with boiling water and put it on the rack below the cheesecake. Baked the cheesecake for an hour & 15 mins at 325. Let cool in oven for 2 hours after baking. Then put the cheesecake in the fridge for another 4 hours. I did have cracking but I didn't really care because I covered it with a turtle style topping which hid the imperfections and I let it cool in the fridge for another 2 hours. It is extremely dense but that is what makes a good cheesecake. I've had cheesecake from many many many places and I would rate this the very best one with the modifications made.  Though it was extremely time consuming, I will be making it again.

text:
I thoroughly enjoyed making this recipe and eating the product it produced after. I set out to make this cake for a co-workers birthday and was nervous to do so because this was my first cheesecake. Between the recipe and all the helpful comments, I felt confident in making this cheesecake and I'm pleased that I did. I decided to make up some salted caramel to top the cake which was a great fit. The little salt really helped cut through some the richness of the cake.

NOTES:
• My cake split but that's my fault for being to curious. You know what they say "Curiosity kills the cake!"
• Use a heavy oil or grease for the pan
• Increase the butter for the crust to 3 tbs. to help give a more moist crust.

text:
This is the most outstanding, lifetime best cheesecake recipe, and it can be done by a first timer!  It was just on the verge of liquid in the middle.  That's perfect for me, but you can increase baking time 5 - 10 mins if you like it a little more done.  I used about 80% of the graham crackers and double the butter.  (I like wetter crust better than dry).  Combined this with a Jelled Rasberry Topping with frozen berries and rasberry jello, lifetime best topping.  Of course, fresh whipped cream topped it.

text:
Everyone who ate this cheesecake enjoyed it. I did a few things ddifferently though. I didn't use a springform pan because i don't have one. So I used a regular nine inch cake pan andused a spatula to help me gt out the cake with the crust intact. I poured a little water onto the ovens baking tray as I didn't have a separate tray. I used an oreo crust and added about 2 tbls of the oreocrem in the batter itself.I also forgot that I hadn't measured out the greek yougurt, whih I used instead of sourcream, so I added mybe about. 1 1/2 cups of that. Still, I didn't have any cracks. I baked it for anextra fifteen minutes, left it in the oven for about 20 minutes, them left it to cool on a rack for about 3 hours. Then i put it in the  fridge overnight. The middle was a bit soft so I put it inthe freezer and served it frozen. It was still great. Served with whipping cream and. cherries

text:
5 stars all the way!!! I made just the way the recipe said except I used the store bought, already made graham cracker pie crusts(2 big ones plus a pack of 6 miniature graham cracker crusts). I was able to fill all of them. I didn't leave sitting in the oven after baking, I let them cool for awhile on the table and then did a quick chill for the bigger pies in the freezer for about a half an hour. They had cracked some before they were done baking anyway and didn't crack more from taking them out. I'm thinking about making these again this weekend!

This was the second new york cheesecake I have ever made. My first one, years ago was a disaster. I followed this recipe and all of the helpful device from the other reviewers.I put it in a water bath, baked it for an hour and let it sit in the oven for six hours before putting it in the fridge. Thank you for the recipe!Now I have to experiment with this and different variations like pumpkin and sweet potato.

text:
This recipe is very well written and easy to follow. I should have done as others suggested and used a water bath - mine cracked after the first hour...so I took it out of the oven and refrigerated it. It doesn't matter much that it cracked, but the next time I make this, I will use a water bath. I guess I was just in a hurry :) Thank you for the great recipe.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as the cutting cake for my friend's wedding. One recipe makes two 6" springforms, so you could half it for one. To make it gluten free I omitted the flour, and also the milk (upon another's suggestion), and instead doubled the amount of sour cream and made with 5 packs cream cheese. I made the gluten free tart crust from elanaspantry.com but forgot to pre-bake it (will do next time). The crust came out soggy but I could ignore that because the cheesecake was amazing, and the most classically tasty and rich cheesecake I have ever made.

None
text:
I have made this cheesecake more times that I want to! No lie this is the best cheesecake I have ever made, problem is all my friends want me to make them for them they even get all the ingredients when they want me to make this for them lol. The only thing I changed is I make sure i grease the side of the pan before i put the crust in, then i wrap the bottom of my springform pan with foil and then put it in a oven bag with a twist tie I don't water bath anymore. Then I put the mixture in put it in the oven. Not opening the oven is the best secret to a no crack cake...see the other reviews it's soooo true. I make these early in the morning or the day before. You won't be disappointed.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a great recipe, but I did a few things differently. 

First, this makes a massive amount of cheesecake filling and it make my cheesecake too thick. So I scaled the directions down to 3/4 of the amount. (You can do this by typing in 9 where the 12 is under servings, and hitting calculate) 
Next I found the crust to be a bit soggy so i added a tablespoon of eggwhite to the crust ingredients and mixed it thoroughly with my hands. I pressed this mixture into my springform pan and baked it for about 10 minutes. Then I let it cool completely before putting the cheesecake filling it.

Turns out perfect every time.

text:
Yikes! I am not sure what went wrong here... My mother recommended this recipe to me. I have tasted the cheesecake she has made, and it is beautiful and yummy... Mine somehow didn't turn out. I made certain to follow the recipe just as it says to. I was very careful not to over beat the batter. When I poured the batter into my 9 in. spring form pan, I noticed that it looked a bit full. I didn't think much of it though since cheesecake is very dense. I didn't expect it to rise much. The batter was about once inch from the top of the pan. I put it in the oven at 350 as specified. About half an hour in, I looked through my oven window to see that it had risen about an inch above the top of my pan... I was concerned, but I know that they shrink when they cool, so again, I let it ride. When 20 minutes remained on the clock, I peeked in the window again. Now the cake was about two inches above the top of the pan and the edges looked quite burned. No cracks at all, but it wasn't very attractive at all. It is now cooling in the oven. It has been in there for about 30 minutes since turning the oven off. The situation hasn't improved much. The only thing I can think of is that my spring form pan is a dark coated pan. Perhaps the oven temp should be reduced some for this? The recipe didn't specify, so I'm not sure. Hopefully it tastes better than it looks. I know the recipe can turn out well since my mom has made it. I will check with her to see what variables may have been different.
Review:

3

text:
Although I had recently gotten into baking and this was the first cheesecake I have ever made I LOVED IT and probably wont be making any other :D My family loves it as well; every get together they request it.The first time I made it I left it in the oven over night but it cracked; the following times I did as the recipe states and left it in the oven overnight again and I also baked it with a pan full of water  on the rack under to keep it moist (suggestion from a friend). It hasnt cracked since so decorating is way easier :D I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS CAKE TO EVERYONE!

text:
Tips:
Check the size of your eggs, google egg conversions.
Use heavy duty aluminum foil, 1 or 2 layers around your pan.
Buy an oven thermometer!
To remove cheesecake without parchment or wax paper on bottom, simple take off the sides, heat the bottom on a burner for a few seconds, slide a big spatula underneath and move . . . helps to have to receiving dish right there or you may have a multi-part cheesecake.

text:
Ah, to find the correct word is almost impossible. The magnificence of this recipe is practically inscrutable in mere words! I changed nothing! I agree with others to let the cheesecake cool down in the oven. In fact, one NEEDS to let it cool down. Perfect food requires time to spread and absorb. In the meantime, wallow in the atmosphere this cake exudes. I let it refrigerate over night with a chocolate ganache coating, and it is the greatest thing I have ever made! The taste is delicate, yet also invigorating! It's not an invasive taste; rather, I'd say, it's that sort of taste that can just stay with you for the night, as every single bite makes your heart jolt with delight! Magnifico!

This cheesecake was a HUGE hit last Christmas!! I went to make it again, and when I bought the ingredients, I forgot to carry the recipe with me. DOH! Of course, I bought the wrong amount of cream cheese (I got 2 pkgs, instead of the 4) - but sometimes good things come from bad goofs, right? I did have some goat cheese in the fridge, so I used 16 oz. of cream cheese, and made up the rest of the 16 oz. with goat cheese. Not that this recipe needs any substitutes to make it any more incredible than it already is, but the final result turned out fabulous, too!

Worth every penny/effort. Update: Some say to avoid getting a crack in the cheesecake by leaving the cheesecake in the oven after turning off the oven. BE CAREFUL. This has cheese in it and should be refrigerated. Cheese should stay out no longer than 2 hours.

text:
Really good recipe. I crushed the graham crackers by putting them into a ziplock bag and using a rolling pin. I think maybe doubling the butter in the crust would help, as the crust doesn't stick together too well, but it does already taste good so who knows. I skipped the sour cream, because I think that's gross :) Also, I put a pan of water on the bottom of the oven, to help stop cracking. The full hour was too much for mine, I got a browned top, but otherwise excellent result.

I'm an international student and I never wrote any reviews due to my limited English ability. But I just have to say this time...This recipe is awesome!!! It was my first time to make a cheesecake. text:
This was amazing! the first time I made it, it was for my friend's birthday. Then i made it for another friend's wedding. I used Hy-Top brand cream cheese the first time and it was delicious but hard to smooth because it was very hard, until I put in the eggs. Then it was fine. It cracked when i baked it, but was fine, and tasted fantastic! The second time I used Philadelphia brand cream cheese and it was much easier to mix. But it bubbled on the 9 inch one that I made, and the mini 4 inch ones that I made cracked, and sunk badly after baking. Also it tasted watery and off. I will go with the Hy-Top from now on.

text:
This recipe is very good. My whole family loved it!  My only issue was that the cake got too dark about 2 inches in from the edge. When I make this again I will reduce oven temp and possibly bake longer. Also I did exactly as instructed by just turning oven off and letting it cool in oven but I also got pretty good cracking. Next time will use a water bath. Graham cracker crust was too much...I will reduce amound of Graham crackers and possibly add a touch of sugar and more melted butter.  Overall it was excellent! So hard to wait until the next day so we had some that night and the next day...it was so much better the next day. Texture was creamier.

text:
Have made this a couple times, with success.  Followed the recipe exactly the first time, but no water bath -- I left it in the oven for hours, but it still had a crack.  No big deal, it tasted fantastic.   Second time around: I ran out of sour cream (only put in about 1/2 c), again no water bath (but I put a big casserole dish of boiling water on the lower rack, for steam), only left it in the oven to cool about 3 hours, and it turned out perfect, no cracks, great consistency!

text:
I had never made a cheesecake before and my daughter wanted one for her 16th birthday. I was skeptical that I could do it but this recipe looked easy enough, even for me. Well, let me tell you...it was so good I would rate it among a real NY cheesecake...and having lived in NY for over 30 years, I was shocked at how good it was. I didn't leave it in the oven after it cooked (I had to make dinner) and I did notice some cracks form but I didn't care...I knew it was going to be covered with strawberries. I didn't use a bath either because I thought the water would leak into the springform pan and make it soggy. All in all a truly wonderful and easy recipe.   My family loved it and wants me to make it again for Christmas...and I will....with pleasure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this cheesecake many times now.  It is great just as it is!  I am normally one to add strawberries or chocolate to the top of my cheesecakes but the one time I decided to add strawberries to my piece, I found myself pushing the strawberries to the side and eating it plain.  I have had to adjust cooking temp and time to suit my pan and oven.  I am cooking it at 325 for 50 mins to 1 hour.  Next time I think I will try 300 and see what happens.  NOTE:  Try as i might, I am an OVERBEATER. I just can't help myself. Just before the pan goes in the oven I firmly drop the pan on the counter several times to bring the air bubbles up to the surface. I pop them with a toothpick or fork and continue with this process until I see little or no bubbles.  It takes me 10-15 mins to do this. But ever since I started doing this to my cheesecakes, I have not had a single crack!

Hooper

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making a cheesecake and, it cracked and turned out overcooked. Fortunately and remarkably, it was still good. I would suggest cooking it at 300°F so it doesn't crack. For the time, test it every twenty minutes until it is still fairly wobbly in the centre but still partially cooked. Then, turn off the oven and let it slowly cool until the centre is just slightly wobbly. At this point the cake is cooked properly. Next, let it cool at room temperature for a while (until is is touchable). Finally stick it into the refrigerator with a covering to retain the moisture. This should work.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
3237178
Display Name:
nicole
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
BEAUTIFUL recipe! I have never made cheesecake before (I have always been kind of intimidated to try before now) This recipe really turned out fabulous. My cheesecake DID crack- despite following all the directions exactly, but it tasted so great that it did not matter. PERFECT texture. It did brown on the top but I like it like that.  I made some strawberry topping: Slice strawberries and put them in a saucepan with sugar-around a cup of sugar for a small container of strawberries. Put more in if you like them sweeter. Also add about a teaspoon of lemon juice. Cook just till it comes to a rolling boil and drain the liquid, separate strawberries, and put liquid back into the pan. Continue to cook JUST the liquid until it is thick. Once thickened, place the strawberries back into the pan and continue to cook them until they are the desired softness. YUMMY and very pretty!

No cracks!! Pre-heated oven to 350*. Put cake in and immediately turned oven down to 300*. Had pan of water on separate rack under cake because didn't have a pan big enough to fit my springform pan. Very not-sweet, which we like, though next time I think I'll add another 1/4 cup of sugar since we aren't having a sweet fruit topping on it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made many cheesecakes and this one has been the most successful one yet - especially the presentation.  Folks are always awed by the flawless result - looks like any you would get from a professional bakery and taste is great.  I tried a crust from food processed Stelladoro chocolate/almond biscotti (1 cup), 1 tbsp sugar and 5 TBS melted butter, pre-baked in 350º oven for 10 min to set and it was great.  The tips here also helped, room temp ingreds, and water bath (though risky for water leaking - really have to use 2 sheets of heavy duty foil and also used a oven cooking bag).  My 3rd time using this recipe with great success.  I don't see any reason to look for any other recipe if you like NY style cheesecake..

text:
wow! this recipe is spectacular! i've been looking for the perfect recipe and this IS IT. the filling i followed exactly which turned out wonderful but i didn't use but 10 crackers (b/c my boyfriend doesn't like a thick crust), used a 10" pan, and still had leftovers of crust. i also added about 1 t of cinnamon and 3 T of sugar to the crust for preference. my waterbath leaked :'( so i cranked up the oven to 450 and put it back in on the bottom rack for about 5 mins and that helped a little. i also did a little "taste test" at room temp and was a little weary as i tend to like warm cheesecake and didn't much care for it but after overnight refrigeration i was hooked. very creamy and decadent. if yours doesn't come out perfect, it's gotta be a mistake on your end. i may add a little lemon zest next time, though. topped w/ fresh strawberries only makes it better (if that's even possible).

text:
I have made this at least 6 times and it always turns out...NOTE if you are getting cracks you need to make sure you grease the sides of the pan so it will not stick.  The only time I had a crack was when I forgot to grease the sides.

Also works great as a Marble Cheesecake....take out one cup of filling and mix with 1 block of melted unsweetened chocolate.  Makes for a great switch up and still turns out amazing!

text:
It cracked!! 60 min at 350 was too long in my oven. The crust got a little too dark and I think that's why it cracked. I followed all recommendations to avoid cracking. Ingredients were at room temp, I avoided over -mixing and I greased the pan. I didn't do a water bath but I placed a pan of water in the oven. It was delicious though and I used frozen strawberries in syrup on top with Redi-Whip. Husband raved about it and he didn't care about the cracking. Next time I will try it for 50 min at 325. Once I get the bake time and temp worked out, it will be a perfect cheesecake. When my daughter comes to visit with her family, I will be the Gramma with the best cheesecake!

text:
WOW! I just made this and it is the best! I did as others did - hand mixed, made a foil crust, put a water bath on the second shelf and then set it and forget it! I made it thru the hour cooking and then let it set (no peeking) for 2.5 hours, then chilled it over night. No cracks, smooth as could be, not too heavy, not too light - pure perfection! Will never buy or make another one!  Oh and this was my first time making a cheesecake..and I had no problems! LOVE LOVE LOVE!

Have now made this recipe twice & it has turned out PERFECT both times! I used the exact ingredients listed. Only change was that I used a 10 inch springform pan and I place a pan of water on the rack below the cake... other than that I baked it just like it said and it was absolutely wonderful! I took it to work & it was devoured. My mom asked me to make her one for a get-together she is having. I do suggest letting the ingredients sit out of the refrigerator for a while, but I didn't have time for them to get to exact room temperature. I mixed the sugar & cream cheese with my mixer, but mixed the rest of the ingredients in with a wooden spoon. Anyway, give this recipe a try... it is awesome!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for years and it's never once not come out tasting absolutely delicious.  I use my kitchen aid to mix it, but am careful not to overmix (it's not really that hard).  I try to make sure everything is at room temp before mixing, but even when i don't it's all good.  I tap the pan on the counter before putting it in the oven to get the air bubbles to the top, and I put a large pyrex bowl of water on the rack under the cheesecake.  And honestly - if it cracks, who cares...it still tastes AMAZING!!

text:
This recipe is amazing.  Pretty much fool proof, and I would know being a fool.  It always comes out moist, creamy and never cracks.  The trick of keeping it in the oven after baking is great and always leaves my cheesecake looking picture perfect. Hey, this recipe even comes out perfect with Italian ingredients, meaning no graham crackers (so I use crumbly butter cookies) and no sour cream (so I use something similar but not quite right).  I always have to add more butter to the crust for it to stay in the pan well, but I think that has to do with my cookie substitute. Great recipe.  Italians and Americans alike love it!

text:
I made this cheesecake for Christmas and everyone loved it. I did make a few alterations to the crust recipe and used the crust recipe from one of the reviewers that posted on here. I also wrapped my pan with a Reynolds Oven bag and aluminum foil (as another reviewer had recommended) and used a waterbath. Other than that... I followed the instructions to the letter. I made sure that everyone in my family knew that the over was off limits until the next morning....so the cake was not disturbed. IT was PERFECT. No cracks, creamy and delicious. This is now my "keeper" recipe for cheesecake and the only one I will ever make again.....Thank you!

userID:
1889548
Display Name:
tonya
isPro:

10

83
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think I've hit on a magical combination here:   The crust:  1 1/2 sleeves graham crackers, 1/4 c. melted unsalted butter and 1 tsp. sugar.  The cheesecake batter:  Instead of 3/4 c. milk I used 1/2 c. heavy cream and 1/2 c. whole milk. I added 3 TBSP lemon juice and an extra tsp of vanilla.  I used only 2 1/2 TBSP flour and that was plenty.  I kept the other ingredients the same.  I think the lemon juice is key in preventing the cheesecake from tasting bland.   As far as mixing it: I mixed the cream cheese and sugar together first, then added the milk/cream, sour cream, vanilla, lemon juice and the pinch of salt together, mixed that until smooth and then added the sour cream and mixed it again.  Then I beat the eggs lightly in a separate bowl and added them last, beating just until mixed and completely combined and I think that method really helped keep the cheesecake from cracking.  I used a roasting pan full of water on the rack below instead of a water bath. Also, I tented it with foil halfway through baking to keep it from browning too much.  Great recipe! Will make again and again!
Review:
Rating:
2

Display Name:
lchoward

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/279096.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cheesecake is ridiculous! I used the "Graham Cracker Crust I" recipe from this site, which I use for any recipe that calls for a graham cracker crust. I used the Neufchatel cheese for this that is "1/3 less fat than cream cheese" and no one could tell this slighteset difference. I did cook this as directed in a water bath, but this center did not get cooked all the way. Next time I will allow it to sit in the oven with the door closed for a longer times. I opened the door and left it in the oven for about an hour this time, and it didn't seem to work. The taste was still amazing, though, and the longer it kept in the refrigerator, the more it hardened up. This has a very creamy texture that is just wonderful! It really does need to be refrigerated overnight before serving. It was delicious with a canned strawberry glaze, but it really does not need a single thing at all! Just amazing!

text:
This cheesecake turned out really good!  People who said they normally didn't like cheesecake loved it.  I served it with frozen raspberries that I thawed.  The only problem I had was that it wasn't done after 1 hour.  I made two and had to put one back in the over for 20 mins because the first one was still too soft.  It may just be my oven.  I used gluten free ginger snaps for the crust and it turned out really well.  I will definitely be making this again.  Oh....one thing I changed was that I used lemon extract instead of vanilla because I ran out.  People really liked the mild lemon flavor.  Thanks for the great recipe!!!!

text:
This cheesecake was so easy, that I thought I did something wrong.  We made it twice in one month, and my husband did not want to share it.  It turned out great both times.  We used the foil water bath, and let it cool for 2 hours in the oven. I pureed raspberry pie filling for the first, and blueberry pie filling for the second.  We marbled the cake with this.  I do have to say that the cake was so thick that the first marbling only did the top half.  For the second, we filled half way, marbled, then repeated on top.  I was told that it was the most beautiful cheesecake someone ever saw!  Thanks, Chantal!!!

userID:
3153241
Display Name:
Marcella
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/679892.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice now with Splenda to see if it would turn out nicely low-carb for my diabetic son, for special occasions. The first time was not too successful. The top browned and it seemed overly dry and flat. I tried again, with some changes, and it turned out ABSOLUTELY GREAT!  There wasn't even any taste of the Splenda at all. Here is what I did: Mixed everything by hand as patiently & gently as I could until it was just incorporated (the first time I made this I beat in everything with my mixer and that was a mistake). Then I lowered the oven temp to 240 degs., I also lowered the oven rack to just below middle. I used a plastic roasting bag to cover the spring form pan bottom and used a water bath. I set the timer for 45 mins. and left it in oven at 240, but began to watch for doneness by jiggling. When there was just a slight jiggle in the middle, I turned the heat off. That was at about 55 mins. I then let it sit in the closed oven for 5 hrs. It did have very slight browing around the top edge.  I think I could have turned heat off at 50 mins. Everyone thought it tasted great. I finished it off with a bit of raspberry sauce lightly dribbled over the top, and whipped cream piped around the edge.  I was so pleased with the outcome.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We thought this recipe was very good; the cheesecake was nice and dense and had a good flavor. The crumbs for the crust needed extra butter. I ended up nearly doubling the butter to get it to stay together. I added a few chopped pecans and a little cinnamon for extra flavor. Next time I'll use cinnamon graham crackers. We will definitely make this one again. An easier way to do the water bath is to put it on the shelf below the one the cheesecake is on; you still get the moisture without having to worry about the water seeping into your crust. We used that method and had zero cracks. It looked beautiful!

text:
This was one of the best recipes I have ever tasted. My husband said it was better than the local cheesecake factory that we have in our area. I did follow a few bits of advise that other people blogged. One was that I used the oven bag instead of the foil on the bottom of the spring form pan. I was worried that the crust would get wet. I omitted the flour(I admit that was an accident but it came out fine). I only left it in the oven for 1 hour after the hour bake time only because I just didn't have the time. There were no cracks in my cake and it was sooo delicious! I have come to the conclusion that it is over beating. After the cream cheese and sugar were blended I only used a spoon to stir in the ingredients.A++++++++

text:
I made this using gluten free grahamn crackers and Bob's Red Mill Gluten free flour (1/8 cup instead of 1/4 because GF flour tends to be a bit heavy).  I then baked it in a 325 degree oven for one hour, switched off the oven and left it in there for about 4 hours to cool.  It cracked, but I think that was my fault because I couldn't help peeking AND I forgot to run a knife around the edges before cooling.  Instead of sticking it in the fridge, I used the freezer since I needed it sooner. Everyone loved it and there wasn't a crumb left!  I thought is was just "okay", but I'm told I'm my worst critic.

userID:
4049718
Display Name:
sdb30
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made my first cheesecake last night using this fabulous recipe!  I took the advice of other reviewers and did the following:  -Greased the sides of the springform pan with a baking spray (prevents cracking).  -Covered the bottom of the springform pan with foil to prevent water from the water bath from seeping in.  -Creamed the sugar and cream cheese using a KitchenAid standing mixer.  Using a wooden spoon, I then mixed in the milk, eggs (one at a time), sour cream, vanilla, and flour.  -After pouring the mixture in the springform pan, I placed the pan in a water bath.    I baked the cheesecake at 350 degrees for an hour.  Once the hour was up, I left the cheesecake in the oven (as directed) to do its thing for the next 5-6 hours.  DO NOT OPEN THE OVEN DOOR AT ANYTIME DURING THIS PROCESS.   This morning, I removed the cheesecake from the oven and there weren't any cracks in sight (yay!).  Aside from greasing my springform pan, the pan I used is by Analon and has a non-stick coating which my have prevented the cracking.  My experience was great with this recipe and highly recommend that first-timers give this recipe a try!

text:
Made this Thanksgiving 2009. Followed the recipe exactly. This was BY FAR the best "homemade" cheesecake my wife and I have ever had. I used a jelly roll pan with about 3/4" water in it. Buttered the sides and bottom of the springform pan. Wrapped the outside in foil. Baked @ 350 for 1 hour, turned off oven, went to bed. Did not even peek!! I must say that the top was significantly more brown than I anticipated. No worries, the taste was unreal. Cannot wait to make this again for the next gathering. Congrats to Chantal!!!

text:
This cheesecake came out AMAZING! I followed the recipe exactly. There were no cracks, and it was cooked perfectly. I made sure to mix all the ingredients on the lowest setting of my mixer. If you have a mixer that doesn't have a LOW LOW speed just use a spoon after you mix the cheese and sugar like some other reviewers have sugested. One tip, if you are worried about air bubbles after mixing, run a knife slowly through the cheese mix before putting it into the springform pan, it helps to bring the bubbles to the surface so they pop! I will be making this recipe again for Christmas!

This is the first cheesecake I have ever made.  I couldn't find a springform pan in any of the stores, and decided to scale down the recipe and just make mini cheesecakes. They turned out perfect! I turned off the oven and let them cool for an hour and then put them in the fridge.  I served them with a dollop of heated strawberry preserves (unseeded).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I’ll give this recipe 5 stars for mixing and baking methods, it worked well for me, no cracks and a decent texture (didn’t use a water bath). Only 3 stars on flavor though. To me this cheesecake fell flat on flavor and it didn’t seem sweet enough. The crust ingredients didn’t look right, so I followed the ingredient list on the box of Graham cracker crumbs. After I formed the crumb crust, I greased the sides of the pan. I then blended the cream cheese and sugar with an electric mixer. In a small dish, I beat the eggs together and added them all at once, using a rubber spatula to blend in the eggs and all the remaining ingredients, didn’t want to over mix. All said, I will make this recipe again but tweak it some; maybe a bit more sugar, and some lemon juice and grated lemon rind, so the flavor is more to my liking.

text:
Overall, I thought this turned out really well. My only complaint is the crust; I thought it was a little too crumbly and moist. I like my crust to have a little bit more of a crunch, so I will have to play around with that part, but the cheese cake was great. It was pretty easy to make, and if you follow the directions and people suggestions for not over mixing and not opening the oven after baking, then you will have an amazing cheesecake afterwards.

text:
My 89 and 90 year old grandparents found it delightful. My grandpa said.....you can tell this is a real homemade cheesecake none of that store bought . The crust doesnt crumble and its delicious......and my grandma (who is blind and cant walk and has alzheimers at 90, bless her heart) couldnt have been happier. She said "its very "smooth" and she wanted more. Of course my brother wanted another one, so i added mini chocolate chips into the second one and he loved it. So, all in all my family is very satisfied. The only thing I didnt like is the chocolate chip one cracked and im not sure why. I think next time instead of buttering the edges and bottom I might use parchment paper along the sides and bottom and hope this prevents it from cracking. Might have been the extra ingredient though because the first one turned out beautifully!! Just to add when I made this the first time and cut into it it was really runny. I always refrigerate it now overnight after it sits in the oven for 6 hours. I think that may have been the problem because I havent had a problem since.

text:
This recipe, combined with the tips that are spread throughout the reviews makes for a great, easy cheesecake.  Like many people have suggested, bake it in a water bath, add some finely chopped nuts to the crust and cinammon, let the ingredients warm to room temperature... don't overbeat... put away that electric mixer after you've mixed together then cream cheese and sugar and only hand-mix from then on.  All in all, I've made around 6-8 of these and have gotten nothing but requests for more.

text:
interesting that my review is right after "L"s, as i was making the batter, i sensed that it was lacking something - lemon juice. so i put some in. the cake is baking in the oven right now. so i cant rate it yet. but here's what i did - for the crust i used plain biscuits and crushed them in the food processor with a half a bar of semisweet chocolate. added to the butter (added a little more like someone suggested), added cinnamon, sugar and ground nuts.  double wrapped the pan but made the water bath on a lower shelf in the oven. didnt have enough cream cheese so used more sour cream. also i changed the amounts to 10 servings and it was good i did cuz more batter would not fit into my pan. i cut back a little on the flour and now all i have to do is pray...  also i wonder if anyone tried using vanilla pudding instead of the flour. i didnt do it but a lot of my cheesecake recipes call for that.  anyways i'll be back when the cake is ready (that'll probably be tomorrow since i plan on leaving it in the oven all night) gave a 5 cuz i cant review w/o rating. i hope it'll get a 5!!

I also had problems with the lumps after adding flour and vanilla -- I will sift the flour next time. Managed to worked most of them in. text:
I came across this recipe in the Top 20 and decided to give it a shot; I've never made a cheesecake before, and in fact am not really in love with cheesecake, but my boyfriend does love it so I decided to make him one.  I was SUPER worried, because a few years ago my dad spent countless days "figuring out" how to make the perfect cheesecake, that he was baking for a wedding rehearsal dinner, so I figured I had a challenge on my hands.  I'm very happy to say that it came out great!  I followed the recipe exactly, using the tips of others, and it came out very well.  I had no cracking, although my top did brown... which I'm a little sad about, and I'm having a hard time finding the answer as to why it browns?  Is it the water bath that prevents it from browning?  I did not use the water bath as suggested because I did not have a big enough pan to put the cheesecake in; next time I'll try that and see if it makes a difference.  My batter was a little lumpy, but I believe it was the way that I added the flour & vanilla that caused it to lump.  It wasn't bad and is not noticeable in the final product.  I'm giving 5 stars for taste and simplicity!  I had great fun and am looking forward to making more cheesecakes (and perfecting them!).

text:
I am new to baking and this was my first attempt at a cheesecake ever. I followed the recipe and took some pointers from the reviews (baking at 325 in boiling water bath). Also, I baked it in a square 8x8 glass dish because that's what I had available and I put cookie crumbs on top. I let it cool in the oven for about 4 hours, then put it in the fridge overnight. I was so pleasantly surprised, it came out just as good as any cheesecake I've ever tried - hah probably better! OMG, so delicious. MY SO is a big cheesecake buff and I know he will devour this this in 1 sitting lol.

text:
I have been baking for over 30 years, but had never baked a cheesecake. I had great success using this recipe and the instructions given in this article http://allrecipes.com/HowTo/Baking-Cheesecake-Step-by-Step/Detail.aspx. My only disappointment was that the top of my cake was browned. Next time I will try baking on the lowest rack in my oven, reducing the heat slightly (345 degrees) and turning the oven off after 1 hour (I baked for 1 1/2, going by the article rather than the recipe). Ultimately I think the most important things I did were to a) use a water bath, and b) let the cake cool in the oven for 4 hours.

I do think the cake itself is very good, and will be making it again, this time I am going to try it with some fruit on top :)

country:

text:
so so so so good!  and pretty easy to make.  next time I'll use a cup of sour cream instead of 3/4 cup (just for personal taste). And my crust came out a tad soft... not sure if that's because water seeped in from the water bath or because of the filling.  **update** I think I used too much butter with the crust last time because this time I used the amount called for in the recipe and the crust came out great. I also only put half an inch of water in the water bath. It is definitely better cold! So after it is finished baking for an hour, turn off oven and leave it in there. After an hour, run a knife around the edges and then put back in oven. Let it sit in oven for a few hours and then in the fridge for at least a couple hours before serving. Making it in the morning would be perfect.

text:
Made this the other day and followed the recipe exactly with poor results, came out overcooked. Next time I'll use a water bath and instead of leaving the oven door closed for the 5-6 hours, I'll open it and let it cool that way. Flavor was good and texture was smooth but there is nothing spectacular about this recipe. Crust was crumbly too, needs to be prebaked a few minutes before adding the mixture. I'll try it again but next time adding something to bump up the flavor and adjust the cooking method to something more traditional to prevent overcooking and cracking.  One more thing, I always have an oven thermometer in my oven to be sure of an accurate temp.

I made this for my family, and everyone loved it--both with blueberry topping and without.  I started and then realized I didn't have any granulated sugar, so I substituted confectioner's sugar instead.  I was also in a bit of a hurry, and may have cut some corners, which I think was the reason my cheesecake cracked.  The recipe itself is great, and I will definitely make it again!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly as written and it turned out perfect. I baked it in a water bath and there were no cracks and it was not too brown on top.  The water bath will help with the top not getting too brown.  I used another reviewers suggestion of a sour cream topping placed on top after it has cooled approximately 10 mins.  (If you do use the sour cream topping I would suggest clear vanilla as the brown vanilla will turn the mixture an off-white color)  I spread the mixture on top and allowed it to cool in my oven for 5 1/2 hours.  I let it chill in the fridge overnight to allow it to firm and set.  I served with fresh strawberries and raspberries (toss the berries in separate bowls with a little sugar to make a syrup).  I was expecting a much sweeter cheesecake but this was still simply delicious.  Next time I may increase the sugar amount by just a tad bit but otherwise this recipe deserves a high rating.  It is definitely five star restaurant quality.  I will definitely make again.  Thanks....

userID:
3043820
Display Name:
Selene
isPro:

followersCount:

46

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/14.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When you follow the instructions exactly, you will get a cakey cheesecake because of the flour content. So, if you are a fan of silkily creamy cheesecake like me, then by all means omit the flour (and maybe the milk too, if you like a denser cake). Also, double the amount of butter in the crust, and be sure to add a pinch of cinnamon or some other seasoning, else it'll be quite bland. In addition, if you want a nice-looking cake, bake it in a water bath - it is not as hard as you think and REALLY prevents cracking and over-browning. Just wrap the bottom of the cake pan with aluminum foil (if you are using a springform pan) and put it into another pan of hot water (around 80-90 degrees C), with the water reaching half way up the side of the cake pan. Then put them into the oven, and this is how difficult a water bath can be! I baked my cheesecake at 300 degrees F for 1 hr 15 min and let it sit in the oven for 2 hrs afterward. The cake turned out with a PICTURE PERFECT top (for the 1st time in my life)! One last tip: you can warm up cream cheese by cutting it into small chunks in a bowl, and then placing the bowl into another bowl of hot water (like around 50 degrees C). Stir occasionally until the cream cheese is fully softened.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-07-25T06:47:25.667

2880675
Display Name:
Wendy Durham

city:

text:
This is what I'd been looking for! I did consider some reviewer's tips and made some changes (see below).  I also found the waterbath interesting & very helpful - no cracks and perfect results.  Leaving it in the oven to cool for those 5+ hours is the trick.   My changes only came because I didn't have enough of some ingredients and it was so late when I began, I didn't want to go shopping.  For the crust I used 1.5 cups of graham crackers crumbs (from the food processor) while the crumbs were in the fp, I added 5 T. melted butter, 1 T. sugar, and a quarter teaspoon vanilla or almond.  The balance of the recipe was follow except that I only had 1 1/4 cup sugar, so I added a 1/4 cup powdered sugar (and prayed it wouldn't mess it up).  Also, I only had 1 teaspoon vanilla, so I added that.  Then, since I had almond extract I measured out a full tablespoon -less one teaspoon and added that. I suggest a longer refrigeration time - maybe 5-8 hours.  It gets good and solid. The results... award winning! I've made it twice (the second time I had all the ingredients listed!)  My coworkers are still raving!  Thanks so much for my now favorite cheesecake.

This was my first cheesecake and it turned out creamy and delicious but looked absolutely terrible.  The looking terrible part was my fault though.  I was so concerned about overmixing that I missed a swoop of sour cream - there's a bright white swirl on the top of my cake. Now I know for next time, just a little more mixing and possibly sifting that flour so it doesn't get chunky.  Anyway, awesome recipe.  Very easy, very delicious.

text:
I had to look up what a spring pan was, turns out it is the wierd pan thing that opens.  Follow the recipe and it works out to taste better than the stuff you get while out.  I had some lumps of cream cheese I was worried about, but I was more worried about over handling (warning from another reviewer), so I left them alone, they must have melted or something, as I didn't notice any lumps in the finished product.  Also I only let it cool for about 3 1/2 hours in the oven before I even opened the door, and gave it the boot 30 minutes later.  I made sure it had seperated from the sides and then put it in the fridge, I'm not saying it is a good idea, but in this case it didn't hurt anything and it was ready for dinner.

text:
First and probably only cheesecake recipe I will ever use. After reading about many failed attempts on the internet I was worried about trying a cheesecake at all. Then I read some really helpful tips about making the cake and mine turned out fabulous. Biggest helpful hints were let ingredients sit until they get to room temp. Do not over mix your ingredients and last but not least cook as directed for 1 hour and turn oven off and leave it alone for 5 to 6 (don’t even open the oven door). It was PERFECTION! Another great tip was to foil wrap the bottom of your spring form pan before putting in the water bath. This recipe is totally worth the effort and honestly not as hard as it sounds.

text:
I have made this recipe for years.  To prevent the cheesecake from cracking a friend shared a tip with me a long time ago.  Put a baking pan of water on the lower rake below the cheesecake when baking.  Also as previous posters mentioned..NEVER open the oven.  Leave in oven for at least a couple of hours after baking. You will have a beautiful cheesecake that takes wonderful too.

text:
although my cheesecake didnt turn out, i give this a 5 on taste alone.  excellent!  after an hour in the oven (ina water bath) i turned it off and left it in there for approx. 3.5 hours.  it wasnt done.  so this recipe is not fool proof.  you still have to check the cheesecake and make sure that it is done before you shut the oven off and let it sit.  and i believe when this recipe calls for 15 graham crackers, it probably means half of a graham cracker.  i used whole graham crackers and had to add more butter.  if i did this recipe again i would just put it in a prepared graham cracker crust (2 actually cos it wouldnt fit in 1) cos it's much easier and there is nothing special about the crust in this recipe.  i will definitely try this one again...hopefully with better results! thanks!

text:
I will never use another cheesecake recipe again after finding this one.  I have made this so many times now and always get so many compliments on it.  After making it several times, I realized that I wanted a lemon flavor to it, so I typically add some lemon zest as well as the juice.  After a day in the fridge, the lemon flavor is very noticable.  I always use a water bath and have never had my cheesecake crack.  I also use my food processor to mix this as it gives it a much creamier texture with no lumps at all.

Our family loves this recipe and I've turned it low carb to satisfy my husband who is on Atkins.  He saves his carbs all day so he can spend it on this fabulous cheesecake! I make the recipe as is, but omit the crust and substitute sugar for Splenda (either 1 1/2 cups of the granulated Splenda or 36 individual packets) and I use whole milk.  I followed other's advice, making sure all my ingredients were room temperature and I make it at night so that I can leave it in the oven to cool over night and put it in the frig in the morning. The cake is rich, so one slice definitely satisfies us for a dessert!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simply Decadent! It was my first attempt of making a cheesecake and it was a TOTAL hit. Everybody loved it! I followed the recipe to an extent (and given the fact it was my first time baking this, I took a really big chance here). I didn't use the flour nor the milk and I baked it in "bain-marie" for 1:45 minutes. Not a single crack! Also, I covered the sides of my springform with baking paper, so once I unclipped the clasp at the side of the pan it came off instantly and the cheesecake had that perfect round-shaped format. Also, as you can imagine, that made the clean up part a total piece of cake!   To see if the cheesecake is done, simply pinch a fork in the middle of the cake. If it comes out SLIGHTLY wobbly, that means it's done. Turn off the oven and let it sit there until it cools down.  The cooking process will continue, so the middle will be perfect by the time the oven cools down. In my case, when it was almost completely cool I took it out of the oven to speed up the process :).  Anyway, from there it went to the refrigerator for about 3 hours and voilà, the perfect desert! I covered it with framboise (raspberry) jam and fresh strawberries. Heavenly!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My family is in the initial stages of opening a restaurant so we decided to offer cheesecake as part of desserts.   I have many recipes that I gathered from cookbooks but this-Chantel’s New York cheese cake, is by far the easiest most delicious cheesecake I tasted better than cheesecake factory.  I made small changes though, as was advised by one of the reviewers, I used 2 tablespoon flour instead of 1/4, substituted the milk with heavy whipping and baked it for 3 hours with a bubble bath.  It came out perfect, no cracks.   I concur cracking occurs due over whipping, so I used my hands, yep that’s right! I used gloves, loll. I learned this technique up from a well known chef who was featured in cooking show.  In addition, best way to get fabulous cheesecake filling is by making sure all the ingredients to be in room temperature, it really does make difference.   As I mentioned previously, I have loads of recipes that tastes really good, however, some my cheesecakes cracked or the water from the bubble bath seeped in. This time it was perfect!  Thanks Chantal for this scrumptious and creamy cheesecake recipe……

text:
I make a walnut graham cracker crust for this that goes with it so much better. I also don't cook it at such a high heat. I took another users advice and go for the 225 for 3 hours and 40 minutes. I don't add as much flour as suggested, I use 1/8 of a cup and that seams to go perfectly. I use chocolate to decorate while it is still warm so I remove the sides of the spring form before it is totally cool so the chocolate will melt the correct way. A water bath is highly suggested, I use a roaster pan and it works very well. I guess overall I love the basis that this recipe gives me and it keeps people asking for more and more. remember don't mix it too much and make sure your cheese is at room temp.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for Easter (Made cheesecake for 1st time). There is no need to fear this recipe if you follow all the tips from so many reviews, which, by the way, thank you all, very helpful.  Here it goes:  1. Don't go non-fat    a. Leave the flour out, not needed. 2. Do use a bain marie (water bath) 3. Wrap pan in foil, heavy duty, or twice wrap in normal foil. 4. Do heat the oven at least half hr before and put the water to boil first. 5. Do use electric mixer for cream cheese, do not overbeat, you'll see when to stop cause you won't see any lumps. I used it for the sugar and milk, too.    a. Always beat the cream cheese alone first.    b. ingredients must be room temp. 6. Use a wooden spatula and fold, do not mix, just fold the rest of the ingredients. 7. 1 hr to bake, 2 hrs to rest, do not open oven door. 8. You will not have lumps, cracks or anything wrong with the cake.   Hope this helps.

Wow.  Wow wow wow.  Best ever, and I made it exactly per the recipe.  Well, except the crust - I added a pinch of cinnamon and sugar to the crust.  But it's the cheesecake itself that's the winner here.  It's soo creamy and good, deli style but not the really dry kind.  I love Ely's cheesecake and Cheesecake Factory, but this tops both.  I honestly don't think I've ever had a better cheesecake.   I did cook it in a water bath, greased the springform pan, and cooled it a couple hours in the oven (2-ish).  No cracking, just awesome cheesecake that all my guests raved about.  Frankly, I didn't know I could make something this good myself.

Great, easy cheesecake!  I normally make a cheesecake with heavy cream and was looking for a lighter cheesecake and this is it!  It still has that wonderful "true" cheesecake texture. It's cheaper to make too!  I took the suggestions of other and cooked this in a bath of water and it turned out perfect. No cracks!  I cut up strawberries added a little sugar and heated on very low heat and let the strawberries make their own juice, cooled and served on top of the cheesecake. Everyone LOVED it! Great recipe!

text:
The BEST New York Cheesecake I've ever had.  Honestly, you have to follow the directions precisely and not worry about "what if it's not done."  Bake the cheesecake, turn the oven off after an hour and don't touch that oven door for six hours.  If you don't have the time, try a different recipe.  We loved it so much we made a second one a few days later.  It really is that good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great tasting cheesecake!!  I did put a pan of water on the lower rack. I baked it at 325 for 60 min.  I put three strips of wax paper about 3in tall around the edge of the spring form pan, this makes it so simple. The cheesecake does not stick to the sides of the pan therefore cracking does not happen.  Also the first time I made this I added the vanilla then the flour and it caused it to clump.. Do not let the two come into contact. The next time I made this I added my flour to my sugar. I also only use two tablespoons of flour.

text:
Very good cheesecake!  The only changes I made were that I used cinnoman graham crackers & also halved the recipe & made in a smaller pan.  By following the directions exactly & making sure not to overmix my cheesecake came out without a single crack (and I didn't even use a water bath).  Next time the only thing I will do differently is to add more butter to the graham cracker crust so that it sets up a little sturdier.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making a cheesecake, and it was AWESOME.  Here are my tips/suggestions:  I followed previous suggestions about not over whipping cheesecake mixture, also I placed the cheesecake pan in a baking sheet filled with about 1/4in of water in the oven to heat evenly. I only let mine cook for 45 min because it was getting brown on top, but it was perfect. I then let it sit in the oven for a few hours to cool before sticking it in the fridge.  For those of you who are health conscious: I made it with 1/3 less fat cream-cheese, light sour cream, and a half-half mixture of Splenda and sugar, and it was just as good as the real deal.  Served it with a simple strawberry syrup and whipped topping- will make again soon!

I originally gave this 2 stars but the taste was good so I've updated it to 3.  Original review:  I'm giving it a 2 for the GIANT craters that developed while cooking.  I took it out of the oven after 4 hours of "cooling" time, which was way too late.  I can't imagine what it would have looked like if I'd left it another 1 to 2 hours, as the recipe had called for.  I mixed it by hand and have a hard time believing that I over mixed, which other reviewers said could be the only reason for it to crack.  Maybe it wouldn't have cracked if I'd used a water bath.  Unless the taste turns out to be really good, I doubt I'll try this recipe again.

text:
Ok I just attempted my first ever cheesecake and I must say that is turned out great.  Was worried about the cracking or sinking in the middle but it looks wonderful.  I did use the water bath and wrapped my pan on the sides and bottom about 4 times and water still seeped in so I am thinking of another way I can do the water bath without water getting to the crust.  My oven acts crazy at times and the temp wants to just shoot up for no reason so I did have to keep peeking at the oven temp that I have in my oven to make sure it did not act crazy.  Still with me peeking at it several times throughout the baking process it turned out just fine.  I plan to add the three layers that I make my black tie mousse cake on top of this cheesecake.  Check out my profile for those pics and layers.  It is going to be rich I am sure but it is for some really big sweet lovers.  Hope that the cake turns out for the next person that attempts to make it for the first time like it turned out for me.   Oh and thanks for all the tips from the other reviews posted, they came in pretty handy.  Thanks Chantal.

text:
I used this recipe to make my first cheesecake ever and it came out perfect! I followed the recipe exactly and used tips given by other reviewers. I used room temperature ingredients and only mixed the batter to blended, careful not to overbeat. I also used a waterbath in the oven and left the cheesecake in the oven for about 3 hours. The result was a smooth, creamy cheesecake that was not cracked, dry or mealy. I was very careful, took my time and read through the recipe completely. Everyone raved about the cheesecake and I will be making this over and over again. I must warn that this made a HUGE cheesecake! This recipe could be cut in half and use a smaller springform pan to make a more reasonable cheesecake size.

text:
This is a very good recipe for a basic NY cheesecake.  I served this with Ruby Red Strawberry Sauce, which I found on this site -- made it darn near irresistible.  I placed the water bath on the rack below the cheesecake and ended up with a 3-inch crack in the middle of the cake, which was totally fine because the strawberry sauce went right on top of it.  Next time I'll put the cheesecake directly in the water bath.  And because the side of the cake was a bit burnt and dry, I'll try baking it about 8-10 minutes less.

text:
I have to agree with the other people who have rated this cheesecake recipe.  It is the best cheesecake I have ever tasted.  It came out perfect with no cracks or bubbles.  I did have a problem with the crust.  I had to double the butter to keep it from being too crumbly.  Also, the water from the water bath seeped around the foil so it was just a tad bit soggy.  I'm making it again tomorrow so I'll try the suggestion posted here about using an oven bag instead of foil.  All in all, it is an outstanding, easy recipe.  Fantastic.  Thanks!

text:
I made this cheesecake for a dinner party.  I hadn't made a cheesecake for years and I was nervous that it would crack, or wouldn't be really good.  

I followed some of the tips left in other reivews and found them to be very helpful.  I greased the bottom and sides of the springform pan, placed a pie plate with water on the shelf below the cheesecake, and turned off the oven after 1 hour and left it in the oven overnight.

The only thing I did wrong was I added too much butter to the crust, and it was a bit soggy, didn't taste bad.

The cheesecake was a huge hit, even my 9 year old liked it!  I will definetly make this again

text:
I've made this recipe several times now, all to rave reviews.  I changed it a little bit, 4 tbsp of butter in the crust, along with a dash or two of cinnamon, only 1/2 cup of sour cream and 3 packages cream cheese, but that's just my own personal preference.  This cheesecake is seriously better than I've had in some restaurants, and much better than any store-bought cheesecake I've ever had.  It cracked on me at first, but I started both greasing and flouring the springform pan really well before use and it seems that helped a lot.  As everyone else is saying, it's also really important not to overmix.

text:
This is by far the best-tasting cheesecake I've ever made or even tasted.  It has such a wonderful texture.  It looks, feels & tastes very professional.  Even my husband loved it & he's very picky when it comes to cheesecakes.  The only trouble I had was that it cracked-- pretty badly too.  Not sure what I did wrong.  As other reviewers suggested, I think next time, I'll try lowering the temperature.  I did have a dish of water in the oven for moisture, but that didn't seem to help.  I didn't have a compote available, so I made a mixture of cream cheese, sour cream & sugar (to taste similar to the cheesecake) and I spread that over the top like a frosting, filling in the cracks.  I then spread it evenly with a frosting knife.  No one ever knew that it had been cracked!

text:
Forgot to grease the pan but don't think it was a problem.  Doubled the recipe and made a 10 inch, a 9 inch and a small one.  I was worried about it all fitting in the 9 in because I'm not used to doing a deep cheesecake.  My 10 in was on the top seemed a little dry, a little bit brown on top and had a huge crater (probably due to overbeating) but the smaller ones on the bottom came out nice and creamy (almost undercooked).  I didn't use a water bath for any of them.  With the help of an online video, I was able to patch up the crater to look like new with no topping!  We ate the 9 in and everyone loved it (gave away the 10 in).  Had added toffee bits but they were hard to find when all was said and done.  Thanks for the recipe!

This is the best cheesecake we have ever had. It is the perfect flavor with a melt-in-your mouth consistancy that makes the simple act of eating it into a sensory experience. As a side note, we found out that it is very important to make sure that you get aluminum foil that is wide enough to wrap the outside of the cheesecake in a single pass. Our's did get some water in and caused the crust to get a touch soggy at a few points, luckily it didn't do much damage. Still, there is no doubt that in our house, this recipe will be used over and over for years to come.

This is a delicious cheesecake! It's very creamy without being dense or overly sweet. I was skeptical about leaving the cheesecake in the oven after 60 minutes for 6+ plus hours, but sure enough, when I removed the cheesecake, it had the smoothest top without a single crack! I made a fruit topping using a cup of red currant jelly that I heated up in a saucepan. I added a pint each of raspberries, strawberries, and blueberries and stirred to cover the fruit. I spread the topping over the cheesecake after refrigerating for 1 hour. Delicious!

My first cheesecake attempt and like almost everyone else I have to give it 5 stars. I rushed through the cooling process because it smelled so good, so I got a little crack on top. But I learned my lesson as that was the only flaw in an otherwise perfect cheesecake. The texture is just right and the flavor is right up there with the best I've ever tasted. And it's surprisingly easy to do. I substituted half and half for the milk, otherwise I followed the recipe to the letter and next time I won't change a thing other than my patience in allowing it to cool properly. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first cheesecake I've ever made so I was really nervous about messing something up but it was surprisingly easy. I made sure to read other reveiwers thoughts and adjusted a few things. I think the water bath was probably my saving grace because my cheesecake didn't crack at all and it didn't cave in. I doubled the butter for the crust, mixed it in and then added a bit of water just to help pack it down. I'll probably add a bit of egg whites next time instead of water. I also added just a few drops of peppermint extract with the vanilla to give it a slight hint of peppermint taste. It was the perfect taste without being overpowering. 

When serving, the very center was just a little too soft and didn't hold form so next time I'll cook it for about and hour and a half instead of 1hr 15min. I also should have given it a little more time to chill in the refrigerator (will do overnight next time). 

My husband is in the army and his soldiers will try ANYTHING you bring in so they were my guinea pigs for the cheesecake. Naturally it didn't last long at all and they're already asking me to bring it in again!

None
text:
Based on cooking this about 15 times:

Grease pan well (use cooking spray).
Ingredients need to be at room temperature.
Mix everything slow, and by hand.
Use "Philly" cream cheese (just a favorite).
Bake at 325 degrees (not 350).
Bake for only 60 minutes.
Do not open oven for three or four hours!

I've found that this makes a perfect, delicious, un-cracked, cheesecake!  Really the best!

userID:
2897463
Display Name:
Goodfood
isPro:
False

20

45

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe with some minor changes!!!!  Just made this (have several really good cheesecake recipes but can always use one more).  Set oven to 300 (lower temps help prevent cracking.)  Bake crust for 10 min before adding the filling.  Add eggs LAST and only mix GENTLY to incorporate.  Incorporating too much air into batter is one of the things that can cause cracking.  Make sure cream cheese is at room temperature to avoid lumps.  I cut the recipe in 1/2 and it was still plenty for a 9 inch pan.  Picture appears to show a sour cream layer on the top which is not part of the recipe (some recipes do that, shortly before end of bake time, you add sour cream mixed with some sugar on the top).  6 hours to cool in a modern oven is totally unnecessary and really has nothing to do with preventing cracks.  I used a glass dish with hot water on the lower rack.  Even when you put foil around a springform pan, it only takes a pin hole leak to ruin the filling.  I never place springform pans in water when baking.  Certainly after 2 hours the oven will already be at room temperature.  Think about how long after an oven cleaning cycle is is back to room temperature.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-10-25T21:08:14.707

This is the first time I've ever made a real cheesecake and it came out PERFECT! I had cheesecake for breakfast this morning and it was the BEST I've ever had!  Very decadent, creamy and smooth. Awesome recipe and DELICIOUS!!!

text:
This was the first time I ever made a cheesecake and it turned out great.  I followed the recipe exactly except that I used low fat cream cheese and low fat sour cream.  I also added some sugar and cinnamon to the crust.  I sprayed pam on the pan before I put the crust in and I only beat the cream cheese, sugar, and milk then mixed the rest by hand.  I did set out the cream cheese for a little bit before I got started but it was still pretty cold.  I didn't have time to wait for it to come to room temperature.  I also put a pan with water in it on the rack below the cheesecake.  I was too afraid to put the cheescake in a water bath for fear of water leaking into it.  My cake didn't crack, the flavor was great, and it was nice and creamy and not too dense, just how I like it.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice, elegant cheesecake.  Added about 1/4 cup chopped pecans and 2 t cinnamon to crust.  Wrapped bottom of buttered springform pan with 2 sheets of aluminum foil and then placed in 10x15 glass pan filled 1/2 way up with hot water.  Cooked @ 350 degrees for 1 hour, turned oven off and left in for 6 hours.  (Mustered up my will power and didn't open the oven door to check.)  Came out absolutely perfect - not a single crack and released from pan perfectly without the need to run a knife around edge first. Served with 3 small glass bowls on the side filled with cherry, blueberry and apple pie filling for the guests' topping choice - very elegant! Creamy, light, not too sweet.  It was a hit - thank you!

text:
Great cheesecake recipe. First time I’ve made a regular cheesecake. I made a peanut butter cheesecake once before and that came out great, but the peanut butter and cream cheese was easier to mix together. When mixing the ingredients use and electric mixture or a blender if not your mixture will clump. Please follow the cheesecake rules! Google them, if you don’t your cheesecake will crack.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I recently made this recipe for a dinner party of 10.  I got raving reviews from almost everyone.  A few even said it was the best cheesecake they had ever had.  I took the other reviewer's suggestions into account.  For the crust I used: 1 1/2 cups of graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 cup of butter, 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1/8 cup of sugar. I baked it at 325 for 60 minutes but still found it a bit too undercooked for my taste, next time I will keep the temp at 350.  Also...make sure you use good quality cream cheese!  I only had no name available and it was super lumpy.  I had to use the mixer throughout to try and get it nice and smooth.  I did use a water bath, but can never seem to keep the water out and I end up with a soggy crust! Even after two layers of foil. Anyway, no cracks which was nice!

text:
Very good recipe that tastes like authentic new york cheese cake.  The changes that I made were:
- added cinnamon and sugar to crust as recommended.
- baked crust for 10 minutes to set before adding filling.
- combined eggs, milk, vanilla before adding as one mixture.
- used water bath method and greased entire pan.

I think that I blended the filling too much as the cake is very light and airy on the tongue instead of that stick-to-your-mouth density.

Oh well, it was so tasty that I am sure there will be a round 2 to fix what may have gone wrong!!

After reviewing I realized that I did not add the flour!  DOAH!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
omg this cheesecake was absolutely delicious. i had never made cheesecake before and was afraid to try it because it seemed like alot could go wrong. I only had a tiny crack on the top and i covered that up with the supreme strawberry topping from this website. You definently need to grease the sides very well in order for it to not crack. i would also improove the crust a little by adding 1 tbs of white sugar and a little bit more butter. Also, i would recommend using cinnamon graham crackers instead of honey graham crackers. Or if you're using honey graham crackers, then add a little bit of cinnamon. Overall this is a great cheesecake recipe and i will definently make again even though it does require alot of time.

text:
Just ok for me...not a real New York cheesecake, but a reasonable substitute, especially because it's so easy to throw together. The taste is a bit bland, and the texture a little to "eggy" and spongy. I would definitely try it again, maybe with egg yolks instead of whole eggs...no flour...maybe adding some lemon zest to punch it up a notch. Needs at least 24 hours in the fridge to settle and firm up. Oh, and mine cracked.

text:
This is THE cheesecake recipe.  I made sure not to over beat.  In fact I only used a mixer to cream the creamcheese and sugar together.  I did the rest by hand.  I banged it on the counter a few times and made sure to leave it alone in the over for the whole 5 hours (I had to leave just to resist).  The result was a stunning cheesecake!  Make sure you give these at least over night to sit in the fridge.  I left it for 2 days and it was absolutly fab!  My husband said it liked it better than the cheesecake factory's!

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for my 2nd daughter's high school graduation.  I found the recipe easy to follow and bake.  The cake was gone in 15 minutes and I have had my children begging to make it again.  I made sure to wrap the bottom in foil to prevent water seepage, put it in a pan of hot water for baking and then afterwards left in the oven for 6 hours (without peeking).  I refrigerated it and served it with fresh strawberries.  It was by far the best cheesecake I have ever made and this is the recipe I will use from now on.

This was my first attempt at a "real" cheesecake and it turned out absolutely beautiful! I had graham cracker crumbs on hand already, so used 1 1/2 C. of those and 3 Tbsp of butter for the crust.  Other than that, followed the recipe to the "T", including leaving it in the oven with the door shut for 5-6 hrs, and it's beautifully smooth and uncracked.  Great recipe!!

text:
My first cheesecake and it was easy to bake, Only thing I think that needs to be changed or upgraded was 1 or 2 more gram crackers and 1 more tbsp of butter, also a topping is a must unless you like it plain, I choped up strawberries and sprinkled sugar on them though them in the fridge to let it sit for 3 hours so it can release some of its juices, then I topped the cheesecake when it was ready with the strawberries and I sprinkled some powder sugar on top to finish it. Cooking time was spot on, mine turned out a lightly goldne brown and the middle was perfect.

5 stars! One of my top 5 favorite cheesecakes ive tasted all time!

We put it in the fridge and the next morning it was so much better.  Next time I will be sure to run the knife around the edge after baking close the oven, turn it off leave it for the full 6 hrs then refridgerate ovenight.  Then it will be sure to be great.  After it sat in the fridge my bf said it was as good as one of the upscale restaurants he frequents.  High praise!  I look forward to making this again and again.

text:
This is truly the easiest and best tasting cheesecake out there.  I have only tried to make a cheesecake one other time and it was a complete disaster.  Thanks to the earlier reviewers that said not to overbeat, to put it in the oven and forget it, and the water bath.  If you use these tips this is no fail.  I used 1 1/2 cups of melted semi-sweet chocolate chips added to the batter and made it a chocolate cheesecake and it was marvelous.  I have so far made this recipe four times in the last two weeks and used it as end of the year gifts for my childrens' teachers.  Thank you for great recipe.

This was so delicious and easy to make!  Cooking it in a water bath definatly makes a huge difference.  The first time I made this it was good but there were big cracks in the middle and the edges were brown while the center was still white.  This time I used the water bath and left it in the oven the full five hours.  The top is an amazing golden brown and there are no cracks or imperfections at all.

text:
PERFECT PERFECT PERFECT!!! Took the advice of others and used 1 1/2 cups crumbs and 1/4 cup butter for crust. Mixed cream cheese and sugar only until smooth, baked at 350 degrees F for 60 minutes with a pyrex dish of water on bottom rack. Let it cool in the oven for 2 hours, used a knife to seperate the edges from the pan, then transferred to the fridge. No cracks, perfect texture! I used a smaller spring form pan so there was leftover batter. Next time I'll use a larger pan.

text:
Great recipe. Made sure that the cream cheese was at room temperature and was careful to not over beat. Cooked it bain marie style at 350* for one hour and left it until morning to cool. It looked a bit custard-y so I baked it at 325* for another half hour and proceeded to let it cool to firm it up. No cracks. Covered it in a chocolate ganache from this site like another user, and it turned out looking professional!

region:

country:
None
text:
This cheesecake is fantastic! The first time I made it, it turned out kind of grainy, but I found out it might have had to do with the eggs not being at room temperature. This time I made sure the creamcheese was smooth before I started mixing other ingredients, while I put the eggs in last (I found the other ingredients have similar texture). I also started using a whisk at that point to avoid over-stirring. I then baked the cake at 325 degrees because my oven seems to heat up a little more. The only thing I didn't do too well was greasing the borders of the pan, so the cake slightly stuck to the sides and cracked a little. (lesson learned :-)). My husband says this is the best cheesecake he's ever had and loves to eat it even without topping :-) . Thank you for sharing this recipe!
